PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Minchin) agreed to:
That government business order of the day No. 1 (Telecommunications Bill 1996 and 12 related bills) be considered till not later than 12.45 pm this day.

DEBATE.TITLE:
TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1996 TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (TELECOMMUNICATIONS) BILL 1996
AUSTRALIAN COMMUNICATIONS AUTHORITY BILL 1996
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (UNIVERSAL SERVICE LEVY) BILL 1996
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (CARRIER LICENCE CHARGES) BILL 1996
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (NUMBERING CHARGES) BILL 1996
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (CARRIER LICENCE FEES) TERMINATION BILL 1996
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSMITTER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1996
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1996
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1996
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (NUMBERING FEES) AMENDMENT BILL 1996
TELECOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 March.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1996
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the Telecommunications Bill 1996 as a whole and Democrat amendments 1 and 7 to 12 moved by Senator Allison. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the comments made by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) in his contribution to the debate on the amendments moved by Senator Allison, it is reasonable to address the fact that the minister quite specifically mentioned that his motivation for opposition to the amendments is one of allowing the carriers to be commercially driven in their developments and the extension of their infrastructure. Senator Margetts made the point quite specifically: whose interests does the minister have at heart?

SPEECH.PARA: I contend that this is precisely the role that the government should be taking with respect to providing guidance to carriers on indicating that cables should go underground. An amendment such as this, particularly with respect to the section relating to the objects and inserting an additional objects provision into the Telecommunications Act, fulfils quite clearly the role of government in this regard. Stating that the minister's concerns are primarily commercially driven flies in the face of this whole package of bills, which are to deregulate and to allow the carriers and, by virtue of the fact of their involvement, the market to determine what is a commercially viable and efficient outcome.
A quite suitable role for government to take is to set in place an aim such as that defined in the Democrats' amendment to clause 3, page 3:
(g) to promote the relocation of existing overhead cables, and the location of future cables, underground, wherever possible.

Minister, I ask you quite specifically: do you believe that making an assertion of this kind is an appropriate role for government? In the context of that objective, do you believe that you are not placing any commercial imposition or otherwise on the telecommunications carriers? Indeed, even if you were, surely the role of government is to provide guidance to industry on the way we want the infrastructure to be developed, not because we are trying to be technology specific but because you have a social obligation to ensure that the concerns of all members of the community are addressed in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a private discussion with the Democrats about their amendments. Minister, I cannot see why the Democrat amendment 1 in document 404, which is down as (g) but I think actually should be (h), cannot go in the objects of the act, which are on pages 2 and 3 of the Telecommunications Bill 1996. As I said last night in the debate, all of those are to promote. They are objectives; they are not prescriptive in detail, in defining that certain things must be done by a certain date. However, I accept the comments made in the debate yesterday—and I have expressed this to the Democrats—about the package of amendments on this issue. Democrat amendment 7 seeks to insert the following provision:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the object referred to in paragraph 3(2)(g) is attained.

I understand from discussions with your own officers this morning that none of the other objectives has such a subsequent clause to say the minister must take all reasonable steps to attain any one of those objectives. Certainly, under Democrat amendment 8, if there is a contravention in this area the carrier could lose its licence. I understand from advice this morning that there is no penalty of losing your carrier licence in any of those other objectives to promote a range of things.

From the opposition's viewpoint, we are sympathetic to the idea that what I think should be (h) rather than (g) should be included in the objectives on this issue. But we do not support Democrat amendments (7) to (12) because we think it would be out of kilter to tie those penalties to one section of the objectives in the bill. We think that clearly there would be an imbalance.

Therefore, from the opposition's point of view, we put to you, Minister, and to the Democrats that we are willing to vote for Democrat amendment (1), even if you want to make suggestions about upgrading the wording. For example, I think it should say `telecommunications overhead cables'. I do not think we have the power, fortunately or unfortunately, when it comes to electricity cables. But we should make it clear that it is telecommunications cables we are talking about because that is what this bill is about. If you can get some other wording that you think satisfies some of your concerns about how it should be there to promote the objectives, then I think we in the Senate could get a good outcome here.

If the Democrats accept the issue in regard to making this a penalty if you do not achieve the objectives—and it is unspecified as to how you achieve the objectives—and you can then actually lose your licence, I do not think that penalty should be tied to an object of the bill when I understand that no other object in the bill is tied specifically to the possible loss of carrier licence. There are other processes for that.So I put that forward for both the government and the Democrats to see whether that is a compromise they can live with. I think it is a reasonable outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats would be happy to have amendment No. (1) considered separately from the other clauses, clauses (7) to (12).
—That suits me.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that Senator Allison is not conceding, nor indeed even responding to anything that Senator Schacht has just said. I welcome Senator Schacht's acknowledgment that serious consequences would flow from amendments (7) to (12). Certainly Senator Schacht is perfectly correct in saying that removal of a licence is the ultimate catastrophe—
—For the carrier.

—For the community. You have millions and millions of people relying on the carrier to provide services. It is inconceivable that anyone could seriously come into this chamber and put forward that proposition. Can I put it to you rather in these terms? To endorse an objects clause in legislation has to have some consequences, otherwise there is no point putting it there—it is not just Pollyanna. If you were able to wave a magic wand and say, `Look, we want these things underground so, bang, they are underground', and if it could be done cost free and overnight, of course in a perfect world that is what would happen. But that is not what this is about. This is about saying that you want everything put underground—telecommunications cables in your case—
—But to promote—
—Listen to me. You are stating a direction in which you think governments, carriers and the industry ought to move.
—And the community wants to move.

—I am not sure that that is right. Really, that is where the fundamental sticking point arises. You assume that that is inherently desirable in social terms. You simply cannot have a social objective divorced from the economic and financial consequences. If you want to propose something that is relatively cost free and is inherently desirable, I do not have a problem with it. But if you propose something that could potentially cost—and you cannot dispute that it could potentially cost billions and billions of dollars to put cables underground throughout Australia, even in rural and remote areas where the local communities may be perfectly happy to have them above ground—it seems to me that you are simply abdicating your responsibility to make hard choices.

BREAK.PARA: Objectives are all about delivery, otherwise you are a hypocrite. If you say, `Well, my intention is to live a good life, but in fact I break every rule in the book', I say, `Well, why did you get out there and proclaim you are going to live the good life?' You might as well shut up, do what you are going to do, and we will make our judgment.

To put an objects clause in legislation is to say that we think it is inherently desirable that all cables go underground as soon as possible. I do not know that that is inherently desirable when you have to make hard choices. If you are talking about billions and billions of dollars, is that necessarily the best way of spending that money when there are all sorts of other social obligations?

Senator Harradine would no doubt say to you that there is a hell of a lot more you can do in Tasmania to assist that state to permanent economic viability than force people to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on undergrounding cables whether or not they want that to occur. And you can multiply that argument around Australia. So you cannot have an objects clause without consequences, otherwise you are being irresponsible.

And, once you proclaim that as your objective, it seems to me you are pre‐empting a whole range of very difficult issues—not just that you are expecting an open cheque and that you do not care what it costs. As I said to you yesterday, it may well be that this becomes an obsolete approach in a few years. If you have satellite delivered services, what the carriers might do is simply remove overhead cables and throw them away, yet you are saying it is an inherently desirable objective to put these things underground. So it does not follow. The proper way to go about it is not to rule out any of these possibilities but to have—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not ruling out any of those. It doesn't rule it out.

—You pre‐empt the debate by saying it is inherently desirable to put everything underground. It is not inherently desirable; it is a matter of choices being made. That is why you have your inquiry; that is why you find out what it is likely to cost; that is why you work out who ought to contribute to that, and then you make the ultimate judgment. Are we prepared to see hundreds of billions of dollars on undergrounding cables rather than on hospitals, schools or whatever else has a greater claim on the public purse, or do we think this is overwhelmingly important to the exclusion of those other priorities? I think that is a very difficult choice.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —But you cannot ignore the purpose of an objects clause. It just seems to me that, if you put that in, you are at least binding yourself in a moral sense to going further.

BREAK.PARA: I take your point at one level—the ultimately draconian penalty of removing a licence is far too extreme. But any penalty or any obligation to go further simply assumes that this is unarguably the right thing to do, and I simply do not accept that proposition at this stage. It may well emerge from the inquiry that it is going to cost only a few billion dollars, but I cannot believe it is going to cost any less than that. We have had estimates, as you know, of it costing up to $10 billion in Adelaide alone from ETSA.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, if you believe ETSA—

—I know what you are going to say, but there is nothing else on the table that you can believe. I have had one of my colleagues come to me and say, `I think that is probably a bit exaggerated, because I have got an independent assessment from engineers who said that the cost in Sydney for undergrounding telecommunications would be only $5 billion.'

BREAK.PARA: Sydney has a third of the population—particularly when you get beyond the metropolitan areas—and, on that basis, you would be talking about $15 billion or $20 billion. I am not prepared to proceed on the basis that it is inherently desirable to go underground wherever possible when you have those sorts of cost implications hanging over the issue.

That is why I say by all means let us not sweep the thing under the carpet. We are very much committed to exploring all of these possibilities, and there are a lot of people who think it would make sense. They would rather we had been able to have them underground from the beginning, and I do not quarrel with that. There are many parts of Australia where they have been underground from the begin ning—in new subdivisions and elsewhere. But that is not the fact of life.

The fact of life is that, under the 1991 regime and since that time, we have had quite a bit of overhead cabling. The issue now is this: do we put it underground, what will it cost and is that the best use of funds? I simply say that even an objects clause is a clear indication that it is inherently desirable. I think the jury must still be out on that issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to respond to a couple of points the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) made. The point is that we are in this situation because the choice has not been able to be made locally. The minister says that we cannot just assume this is the right way to go. Well, the government has assumed that overhead cabling is the right way to go. By its every action, it has facilitated and ensured that that is what has come to pass.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that local communities—by virtue of the powers and immunities within the current act—have not been able to make that choice, it is incumbent on the government to take steps towards responding to the enormous amount of concern out there in local government and in the communities. We cannot measure that concern. There has not been a referendum produced on this issue. All we can go by is the response we have had, and I think that has been fairly conclusive. That response has come through local government in no uncertain terms.

It has been quite arbitrary of the government to make the decision that we should not go ahead with undergrounding on the basis of cost, yet we have seen, as the minister acknowledges, no reliable figures about what that actual cost would be. We also know, as I said yesterday, that the cost would have been quite low had Telstra chosen to go underground instead of overhead.

I have seen figures elsewhere which indicate that undergrounding, whilst it might take a little longer, would not in fact be much more costly than overhead. It depends on where you are in Australia and it depends on what the long-term objectives of the relevant state government are. In Western Australia, for instance, the state and local governments are committed to undergrounding all cabling—TV cabling and electrical cabling.

So it is quite arrogant of the government to assume that it knows what is desirable, what is to be paid for and how it is to be done. We have seen this roll‐out of aerial cabling proceed apace without any debate about the desirability or otherwise of it being aerial. The amendments that have been put forward by the Democrats would at least go some way to taking that responsibility back at the federal level. Since it took the powers away from local communities in the first place, the federal government should take that responsibility and do something about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to make a couple of brief comments. I really hope this whole debate in the committee stages of the bill is not taken up by arguments about projected costs of projected changes to infrastructure. Already the phrase `billions and billions of dollars' has been uttered by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) on far too many occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: I would ask the government and the minister to remember the context in which this debate is occurring. We are talking about a deregulatory package of bills for the telecommunications industry. We are not currently discussing a prescriptive regulation. We are discussing a broad objective that seeks to offer guidance to the industry about the priorities that carriers should perhaps assess in making their decisions.

I do not accept that arguments about projected costs of billions and billions of dollars and estimates by carriers, who have an obvious interest in such things not being put in the objectives, are reasons for us as a parliament to ignore the need for the insertion of those clauses. I do not believe the government can have it both ways in this bill. On the one hand, its deregulating allows for the market to prevail and competition to be implemented in an effective way and, on the other hand, it refuses to put in place broad objectives that do not prescribe, but do not seek either, to state the government's position, intent or objective, which is what we are discussing.

BREAK.PARA: Minister, I put it to you that you cannot have it both ways. We are talking about a deregulatory regime and we are currently debating an objective not a prescriptive regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I put forward that suggestion because I thought that it would be a not unreasonable compromise as to your concerns, particularly on what some call the black letter of the law about penalties, et cetera. The opposition would not support that, but we would support something else, even if you wanted to suggest a different form of wording to the Democrat amendment on what (g) or (h) should be in the objectives to promote in this area. I think the wording does need to be changed, but I left that, if you were willing to look at that and deal with it.

SPEECH.PARA: I did that on the basis that through this bill overall the opposition's view is cooperation, being constructive and trying to reach agreement as far as possible. Yesterday on the issue of digital data capability it would have been much simpler for the opposition to stick to our black and white position against the government and then campaign strongly that you had dudded 400,000 potential rural subscribers from getting digital data capability when we were holding the purist position. In the discussions overnight and again this morning, an amendment will come forward which we as an opposition can support. It may not be 100 per cent the best political outcome in cynical terms for the opposition, but I think it is the best outcome for Australian telecommunications consumers.

Again I am putting to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) that as a compromise they put a form of words in the objectives to promote the vision. I know visions may not be a great thing to talk about anymore in politics and it may not even be politically correct to talk about visions, but I do think there should be an indication in our own telecommunications bill that this is a reasonable objective, without putting time scales, dates or levies on it in the objective at all. It is a message to the broader community that we are not just technical engineers, software developers and so on in telecom munications, but that we do understand the broader urban and rural environment in which we operate and we do have environmental concerns.

The minister is concerned about the overall cost. I am not ignoring those comments. If you said, `We are going to start today undergrounding every cable in Australia', it would run into billions and, even starting today with every effort provided, it would take years to achieve. I accept that this has to be a program that may take a generation or more. If you say to the Australian community that we believe that is a useful objective, I think their response will be positive. For example, 25 or 30 years ago if you drove around the rural areas of Australia you saw along the sides of country roads endless wooden telephone poles in some states and iron telephone poles in other states. There were Telstra telephone lines and copper pairs running down the sides of the roads. In Gippsland, where I grew up on a dairy farm, Telstra's—or PMG as it then was—telephone lines were on one side of the road and there was electricity on the other. Everyone could trace their own pair all the way back to the telephonist‐operated local telephone exchange.

Over the last 30 years off its own bat Telstra has overwhelmingly undergrounded all of those rural cables for local distribution. They made that choice because they got a better return and the maintenance costs were lower and all those sorts of things. One social advantage of the cables being underground was shown in South Australia in 1983 during the tragic days of Ash Wednesday. When all the electricity wires were going down and being burnt out, you could actually make phone calls from the middle of a bush fire because all of Telstra's wires were underground. That is a social advantage. Telstra had already done it. Across the bush Telstra's telecommunications cables are already overwhelmingly underground.

In my own street in Adelaide the cables are underground down the street, but they go up an electricity pole and my copper pair comes in through the air onto the side of the house. That was done in the 1950s. In some areas of Adelaide you can still see the copper pairs entwined together, coming in off poles and going into houses. I imagine over the years ahead Telstra will gradually replace those copper pairs with other cabling as they become redundant.

We already have a major change in telecommunications cabling by Telstra off its own bat. I do not know whether it was way back in the 1950s or the 1960s that the minister responsible for the PMG made an actual decision to tell Telstra or the PMG to put all the country telephone lines underground. I suspect it was done by the management of PMG for economic reasons. I have to say we all would agree that Telstra and these utilities have never been overwhelmingly sensitive to architectural aesthetics in what they have done, but they made that decision. I believe that putting that in there to promote is not out of kilter with what they have already been doing for 30 or 40 years as a telecommunications company. They put the cables underground because it was to their advantage.

Mention was made of public opinion. Everyone will quote different public opinion polls all over the place and whether this is really an issue that people are upset about. There is a view around that the Liberal Party gets more flak in the leafy treed suburbs of Australia than I might because people in our Labor voting areas are less concerned about it. All I can say as a senator from South Australia is that the outrage is pretty even, although in working class areas the councils have reluctantly had to accept that they cannot stop it happening. I notice in Adelaide that Optus has rolled the cable out first in the working class suburbs and is leaving your leafy Liberal voting electorates until last, because the meetings in those areas have been particularly vigorous. The Mitcham council which is a strong Liberal voting area—

TALK.START.PARA: —Pretty leafy.

—And pretty leafy, as Senator Harradine, a former South Australian, would know. It is very leafy indeed. They have conducted independent public opinion surveys in their area and they have published them. They show 80 per cent of people do not want the cable and, even if it comes, they are now saying, `No matter what it is, we do not want to connect to it even if it means a slightly cheaper telephone call.' That survey may not have been done by a firm as reputable as Newspoll or AGB McNair, but it was done by a firm that is reputable. It has been operating in South Australia for many years doing those sorts of polls for all sorts of community organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a strong opinion about this and I believe you cannot ignore that public opinion. Minister, you are also the minister for the arts with some commitment to aesthetics, design and so on. I believe you would also have a view that in the long term for Australia it is not just a simple dollar and cents issue about what sort of urban and rural environment we live in. I think it is about setting ourselves examples of how we can have a better urban design and better streetscapes. Even in the working class areas of South Australia they like having bigger trees in the street and better streetscapes. That is not an argument that is only an issue for the silvertails in the leafy suburbs of the North Shore of Sydney; that is an issue everywhere. In new suburbs where all the cables have gone underground—my state has about 10 per cent of urban areas that have all underground cables—if you say to them, `We are going to put overhead cables up now,' there would be an absolute riot about it because people understand the advantages.

I believe it is not unreasonable, therefore, to put a form of words in. If the present Democrat amendment No. 1 is unacceptable in the form of words—and I think, technically, it should at least say telecommunications—Minister, I am willing to say to you that if you want to redraft that, as an objective, I am willing to look at it in a spirit of compromise on this because that is what I want to work my way through this bill on. So if you want to take another adjournment for a period of time during which we can go on to another area, I am willing to support that happening but I will not support Democrat amendments Nos 7 to 12 because they are unnecessary. I again ask you, taking note of all you have said, to have a look at putting something in the objectives that you can live with as well as we can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Schacht has adopted a generally positive and constructive approach to what is a very complex package of legislation and one to which none of us can really do justice in the time available. We did have the Senate inquiry for the very specific purpose of enabling a lot of these matters to be canvassed exhaustively. I did attend that committee on I think three occasions and I hope a lot of these issues were already canvassed there.

SPEECH.PARA: The way that objects clause is worded it continues to have a number of vices, not just in terms of being too wide in terms of cables. It requires retrospectivity. In other words, it is not just talking about cables in the future—and I can perhaps understand it being said that after 1 July that is an inherently desirable approach to take. That is really why we have banned all overhead cabling unless it is done with the consent of local authorities.

You could say that in principle after 1 July that is clearly an object in relation to future building of pay TV, telephony and broadband services. But this does not talk about that at all; this is going backwards on undergrounding and imposing retrospective burdens. What I could live with is an amendment which had it as an object of the bill to examine the affordability, feasibility and desirability of the relocation of existing overhead cables and the location of future cables underground—

TALK.START.PARA: —Telecommunications cables.

—Telecommunications cables, and doing that wherever possible because that would then signal that it was something worthy of serious examination. In other words, it is desirable in principle but subject to what I think is an absolutely essential examination of the implications. Otherwise, you are simply whistling in the wind. You are saying, `Wouldn't it be nice to have everything underground but we are not prepared to do anything about it?' We say, `It would be nice to do that; let's have a good look at it.' At the end of the day, as you say, Telstra may have been doing these things in the past but they have not been doing it irrespective of cost. They have done it pres umably because it was affordable even though they were a monopolist and did not have to worry about competition.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in a very different world these days. They simply cannot ignore the cost implications and that is why, in some instances, they have sought to compete overhead with Optus because otherwise the practical consequence is that people still have close to the highest local call charges in the world. Government is all about hard choices; it is not about saying, `We have decided in your interests that your cables ought to be underground whether you like it or not and therefore you are going to have 25c local call charges whether you like it or not. The community is entitled to say, `Hang on, why shouldn't we make the hard choice on that?'

Some councils and suburbs have said they would be perfectly happy to have overhead cables. I told you that Ballarat only last week consummated a deal with Northgate Communications whereby Northgate did not pay anything. The council was very keen to have an overhead service because it provides free local calls to their customers, the prospect of untimed local calls to Melbourne and a whole range of cheaper services such as a 25 per cent discount on pay television and, presumably, broadband services will again be at a significant discount.

These are choices that people make. If people living in one area of Ballarat are perfectly happy to say, `We've got high quality, affordable, high technology services and the price we have had to pay for that is to go overhead; and we accept that outcome,' who are we to say, `No, you are wrong. Sorry; we are not interested. You are going to have it underground. You are going to have to pay more because we think it is in your best interests.' I do not think that is a responsible approach to take. That is why I say I have no problem in principle with that being examined as a desirable objective but it does not follow to me that that will be the inevitable outcome. That will depend upon a whole series of choices and examinations. Therefore, I could accept an amendment that was in the form I have indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you circulate that? Would you get your officers to draft that so we could have a look at that?
—Yes.

—The Democrats will not support the rewording of the amendment along the lines the minister has suggested. He is in fact suggesting his own amendments Nos 250 and 251, which we will come to in due course. I think the arguments have been well and truly canvassed on this issue, and I would suggest that we proceed to vote on the matter.

—The amendments before the chair are Democrat amendments No. 1 and Nos 7 to 12. Is it the wish of the committee that amendment No. 1 be put separately? I can put amendment No. 1 separately from Nos 7 to 12.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Allison is determined to proceed with this, then the government will proceed to vote against it on the understanding that we will bring back another form of words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to think that the government realises that, in looking into it, the mirror‐mirror approach on this issue is not actually good enough. It does not actually enable the carrier to make that decision if it finds it will cost more. That is why the decisions have been made at the moment for Telstra and other carriers not to continue undergrounding. It is more competitive to do things the cheaper and shoddier way. That is why it is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: If all you do is change the words to say `if it is cost feasible,' then those in the competitive environment say that they will not do it. If the government comes back with an amendment or a change to the wording, I do not think it is acceptable. It is basically saying, `No, it's not going to happen.' Government knows that. The community, I believe, is making a very strong statement.

Telstra's money, generally, will not go into providing hospitals and schools, and the private contractors, the private carriers, will not put their money into hospitals and schools. Their profits will go largely into their pockets. There will be some stuff coming back into government through whatever we have left of Telstra, but the reality is that, largely, this will be taken out of the hands of the community. This is one of the few opportunities the community has to have its say through the Senate process.

In my opinion, it is not acceptable for the government to throw the amendment back. If they throw it back, I hope the response from the community groups that you say do not care or think it is not a big issue will be made very clear to you in the meantime. Such an action of throwing it back with mealy‐mouthed words that say `We'll do a mirror‐mirror approach' means that commercially it will not happen. I really do not think that will be good enough.

If that is the basis upon which this is happening, I would like to think there will be a very strong community reaction which will let you know that it is not just the people in the leafy suburbs; it is actually a lot of people who are interested in this issue. What is said about community values and community interests should actually be listened to by government. Without government listening and without government taking that kind of firm line, corporations cannot take action on their own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Margetts may have been out of the chamber when we first canvassed the proposed inquiry that the government would conduct. It is not a matter of simply leaving it to the carriers to decide whether it is affordable. It is a matter of deciding from an independent examination, supplemented by high‐powered, independent research, whether or not that is a path down which the community as a whole ought to go and, if you do decide to do that, who should pay for it.

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand, if you say that the carriers ought to pay billions and billions of dollars, it is fairly clear what the consequences of that will be. You will not get any of the price reductions you would otherwise get and you will probably get a lot less investment in the latest technology. If, on the other hand, you decide that governments ought to bear a substantial portion of that—be they local, state or even federal government—again, those are decisions that you would take to impose those obligations on the carriers. So it would not have anything to do with the commercial decision making and discretions of the carriers. It would be a regime imposed by government or by the parliament.

I think you ought to at least appreciate that our inquiry is not designed to simply enable the carriers to make their choices. It is designed to examine whether or not the community wants that to occur and, if so, in what proportions the cost should be borne and by whom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —With all due respect, I think the minister has missed the point. The people who are calling for this are saying that it is the carriers' responsibility to act in a responsible way and, yes, if that affects the pricing, that obviously will be reflected in the price of the services. However, that is the reality. But if it is not in the legislation, looking into it in the future means that you will say that people have to pay separately for community interest, public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, that is not good enough, considering all the assurances that were given prior to this push for privatisation: `Oh, yes, we will have those built into legislation'; `Oh, yes, those assurances will be there. The carriers will know what their responsibilities are.' No, the message you are sending is that carriers will have the responsibility for maximising their profit and anything extra in terms of public interest and public amenity will be at the separate expense of taxpayers.

I know the chambers of commerce would like that to be the case. I know the chambers of commerce in Western Australia have asked that the universal service obligations should be paid separately. I do not believe that. I believe that those people who are making a profit out of providing that service should contribute to that. I think a lot of other people believe that as well. You are actually going along and providing the means by which the chambers of commerce, in the long run, will get their way. I do not think that is good enough.

I can see what is going on. I am not as green as you might think; I am cabbage looking. Basically, we have seen through you, Minister. I would like to support this amendment and I would like to think that the Senate will continue to support the spirit of this amendment if you throw it back to us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just very briefly, it is very unfortunate that Senator Margetts refuses to understand the concept of the inquiry. It is not about simply saying that governments ought to bear all of the cost; it is an examination into who should bear the cost. That may be carriers, utility companies, power companies who are responsible for overhead electricity cables, ratepayers or a mix of the lot. That is precisely why we want to look at all of those issues.
—Minister, who has the numbers on the inquiry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not got to that stage yet, Senator Harradine. The principle of this is not simply loaded from the outset in one direction or another.
—How many people do ACCI have on it?

—Just a minute. I do not have a predetermined view. If it was cost free, it would all be underground tomorrow. That is quite clear, I would have thought. The question is whether it is affordable. The only stage we have reached at this point is that government amendments 250 and 251 would require the minister to undertake a review of the options for placing communications and other facilities underground, for example, electricity cabling, with a report to be provided to the parliament by 1 July 1998.

SPEECH.PARA: The group that we are in the process of putting together has 20 persons, I think, on it. They represent each of the state and territory governments. They represent the Australian Local Government Association, the Electricity Supply Association of Australia, the Austral ian Chamber of Commerce, the National Trust, the carriers and ATO. I think that is the full proposed working group.

It is meant to provide an independent assessment of the options and the costs. As I indicated yesterday, the carriers have already volunteered $1.5 million, which is a very substantial sum of money in the scheme of things. It will enable completely independent research to be undertaken.

As Senator Schacht has quite rightly said, if you just took the word of ETSA you would not get anywhere—which is the last thing we want—any more than if you took the word of the carriers because they would be speaking through their back pockets. The whole idea is to take that money to commission independent research, to have a proper examination by all of the interested parties and then have the matter reported back to parliament where we can have a full debate on what it all means.

It seems to me that that is the logical progression. It can be against the background that you all would like to see, in principle, cabling underground as quickly as possible. But to simply ignore all of those things and to say up front, `We have decided, irrespective of cost, irrespective of new technology, that everything has to go underground as quickly as possible, but do not tell anyone we are not going to do anything about it, we will just put it in as an objects clause,' is not a sensible and responsible way to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to be moving on to the matter of government amendments 250 and 251. However, I think we need to point out at this stage that that review is not due to report back before July 1998, by which time, as I understand it, most of Adelaide will have had its aerial cabling completed, and certainly the same for Perth. It is like shutting the door after the horse has bolted. We will in effect not have had any opportunity to promote at least the cabling which is yet to be erected. That is the problem with making that argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, you know full well that there will not be overhead cabling after 1 July, subject to the transitional arrangements, unless local councils—local ratepayers—want it. So putting in an objects clause makes no difference at all to any of that. The government implementing that strategy would make no difference at all to that very short timetable. We are talking about another few months for overhead cabling, unless local authorities want it. Again, if they want it, then that is the decision they make.

SPEECH.PARA: This inquiry cannot be done in five minutes. You cannot examine multi-billion dollar questions in that time just because you are so obsessed with the urgency of it that you would like it all to happen tomorrow. The fact is that enormous financial and social consequences arise from a decision to go underground wherever possible. You need to do it in a sensible and measured way. If you give yourself time to do that, it seems to me that you are much more likely to come up with the right answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to point out to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) that it is not true that after 1 July or 1 September all cabling will be underground, as he well knows. Anything which is 13 millimetres or less will continue to be erected as aerial cabling if so desired by the carriers. Of course, there are other exceptions which will apply, so it is not reasonable to say that in just a couple of months all cabling will be underground.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That amendment No. 1 (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Sherry did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Faulkner did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Democrat amendments Nos 7 to 12 be agreed to. I think the noes have it.
—The ayes have it.
—Is a division required?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I understand the right of any senator to call for a division, but we have something like 300 amendments before this chamber. We did have a Senate inquiry which went on for a number of days and gave everyone endless opportunities to explore all of these issues. In a situation like this, where it is already clear that the Labor Party has indicated that it will not support these amendments, if you are simply doing it as a matter of principle you will take up another 10 minutes on every amendment or every opportunity to express a view. I do not know what you get out of that. The community will understand where you stood on it because you voted for it—it is your amendment. But if you simply call a division mindlessly when you know you cannot win—if this is an indication of how long this package will take—I am simply saying you are going down a path of totally unnecessarily adding another period of hours to the debate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask again: is a division required?

INTERJECT.PARA: That amendments Nos. 7 to 12 (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Alston)—by leave—proposed:
(250) Schedule 3, page 499, after clause 46, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 46A Review of options for placing facilities underground

PARA.TAB: (1) Before 1 July 1998, the Minister must cause to be conducted a review of the options for placing facilities underground.

(2) Those options are to include options for placing facilities underground as part of a co-ordinated program of placing other infrastructure underground (for example, electricity transmission and distribution infrastructure).
(3) The Minister must cause to be prepared a report of the review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 46B Monitoring of progress in relation to placing facilities underground

PARA.TAB: The ACA is to monitor, and report to the Minister on, progress in relation to the implementation of efforts to place facilities underground.

SPEECH.PARA: (252) Schedule 3, page 499, after new clause 46B, insert:

TAB.TAB: (a) an overhead line (the eligible overhead line ) is attached to a pole (the first pole ); and

(c) the installation of the eligible overhead line was or is authorised by:

SPEECH.PARA: the local government body may, by writing:

TAB.TAB: (c) exempt the owner of the eligible overhead line from compliance with subclause (1) in relation to the first pole; or

PARA.TAB: (3) If there is a prescribed administrative authority for the State or Territory in which the first pole is situated, the prescribed administrative authority may, by writing:

TAB.TAB: (a) exempt the owner of the eligible overhead line from compliance with subclause (1) in relation to the first pole; or
(b) extend the period of 6 months mentioned in subclause (1) for the purposes of the application of subclause (1) to the owner of the eligible overhead line and to the first pole.
(a) there is no local government body for the area in which the first pole is situated; and
(b) there is no prescribed administrative authority for the State or Territory in which the first pole is situated;

SPEECH.PARA: the regulations may make provision for and in relation to:

TAB.TAB: (c) the exemption of the owner of the eligible overhead line from compliance with subclause (1) in relation to the first pole; and
(d) the extension of the period of 6 months mentioned in subclause (1) for the purposes of the application of subclause (1) to the owner of the eligible overhead line and to the first pole.

PARA.TAB: (5) Regulations made for the purposes of subclause (4) may make provision with respect to a matter by conferring a power on the ACA.
(6) This clause does not prevent 2 or more instruments under subclause (2) or (3) from being combined in the same document.
(7) In this clause:

SPEECH.PARA: administrative authority means:

TAB.TAB: (a) the holder of an office; or
(b) an authority of a State or a Territory;

SPEECH.PARA: that performs administrative functions under a law of a State or a Territory.
line includes a disused line.
non‐communications cable means an overhead cable (other than a line).
overhead cable means a wire or cable that is suspended above the surface of:

TAB.TAB: (a) land (other than submerged land); or
(b) a river, lake, tidal inlet, bay, estuary, harbour or other body of water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, we have amendments as well in the same area—on our sheet No. 417—which deal with levies to fund placing lines underground, and is in two significant sections. To speed the debate, it may be useful that the discussion on government amendments Nos 250 to 252 and the opposi tion amendments on document 417 be dealt with at the same time. I ask for guidance as to whether we can deal with them that way.
—Yes, that is all right.

—Your amendments relate to conducting a review. Senator Harradine raised a good question, almost by way of interjection, about who has the numbers on the review panel for a start. You gave a quick description of the membership which is not written in the legislation. I do not have any concern about that and I am certainly not asking that you write the membership into legislation or even have it as a disallowable instrument, but I do think it ought to be tabled. As I recollect, you said that each state and territory government gets one representative, the electricity supply association gets one representative, the National Trust gets one representative, the carriers get—
—I'll put out a release on it if you like.
—Have you put it out?
—We have announced that we are setting up a working group.
—Yes, that has been announced. You said that there will be 20 members. Do each of the designated carriers get a representative?
—Telstra, Optus and ATUG.
—I presume DOCA has a representative. Is DOCA chairing it?
—Yes.
—Is that the only federal government department that has a representative? Does the environment department have a representative?
—Three other departments are represented on it. I can't remember which ones.
—Could we get some detailed indication of the arrangements. I would have to say that any working group of 20 by definition is going to have some problems in terms of size.
—Do you mean that it might be too representative?

—No, getting 20 people together at some stage will be difficult. I do not think you can avoid having most of those people involved. I do not necessarily want to increase the membership. You have the National Trust represented. If you have the environment department, which I think ought to be on there, as one of the other departments, I also do not think it is unreasonable to suggest that the Australian Conservation Foundation, as the major—as far as I am aware and I stand to be corrected—environmental organisation in Australia which has a brief to look at all environmental issues, would be a useful addition. That would not change the numbers overwhelmingly. It would not surprise me with this working party if there was a split decision or a number of minority reports. I think that is probably quite reasonable rather than forcing a low level consensus decision that is absolutely meaningless. If people on the working party disagree that ought to be published.
—You can get independent research in any event.
—Trying to force what you have already put together to reach a consensus decision I would find unreasonable because of some of the issues. I am not sure that the carriers—
—You might get a majority report.
—I think that is all important. I would also like to suggest—
—Come on, Senator Schacht, get a move on!
—Senator Patterson, the minister and Senator Schacht were cooperating very nicely.

—All I can say to Senator Patterson is that if you want me to be difficult I will hang this out for months. It is not my intention to do that. We are dealing with, in my view, one of the most significant pieces of long-term legislation to come before this parliament. I do not think it is unreasonable for this to take two or three days in the committee stage because if we can get agree ment with the government, the opposition and even the minor parties I think that will be of benefit.
—It's been a long while.

—Senator Patterson, you really are starting to provoke me not to be cooperative. I do not think the minister wants that. I am trying to get information about the amendment that the minister is putting about the review and so on. Most of it is probably acceptable to the opposition. I want to get clear what it is doing. The details of this review committee were not announced in the Senate inquiry or in the response to it. We are asking for the details now, and I think that is not unreasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, I would also like to suggest to you—I know the government might take some ideological objection to this one—that I do not think it is unreasonable that there be a trade union representative or representatives of the workers who will actually be doing the work in a committee of 20 or 22. I raise that suggestion with you because a lot of the practical work of how you put stuff underground is going to be done by tradespeople, whether they are employed by Telstra, a carrier or some other trade organisation. So, with that query, Minister, you will file us with that information, and I think that is reasonable.

I am not unhappy with the rest of the proposal in amendment No. 250. Minister, I raise with you that in my amendment No. 2 on sheet 417 I have added two terms of reference. In private conversation, there has been some indication from the government that they would be willing to look at incorporating that as part of the terms of reference. If that is the case, can you respond and we can make arrangements to write that into your amendment No. 250, I would presume? Can we get a response to that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take on board what Senator Schacht had to say about the membership of that working group. We did look at it being a smaller size. The states all insisted on being separately represented rather than collectively. I think the intention is that over the next few days we would be writing to each of those organisations inviting them to nominate a representative. I will look at the final composition against the background of what you have said. As far as what you have in sheet 427, if that is the proper description of the amendment, those are all issues that can be—

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I would like to seek a point of clarification, if I may, at this stage. The Democrats are opposed to considering the opposition's amendment on sheet 417 alongside the government's amendments Nos 250 to 252. Can I just clarify whether that is what we are presently doing, or not?
—I understand that 417 has not been moved yet, we are just debating where we are going.
—There was agreement that it would be discussed cognately.

—It is simply being discussed in the same context. As Senator Schacht would say, if you are going to debate the merits of the working group, you should also look at some other issues that it might examine. I am indicating that I would be happy to give a formal undertaking that the matters he has raised in his amendment could be matters that the working group would consider. Doing that is probably tidier than trying to put something into the legislation because there are a lot of other things that it would be required to examine as well. There is no reason why I cannot give that undertaking to have those matters specifically included in the terms of reference.
—That is including clauses 1 and 2 of my amendment?
—Yes.

—Nos 3, 4 and 5 are procedural matters. In my amendment on sheet 417, Nos 1 and 2 are standard issues about the underground levy; No. 3 is you have to prepare a report for the review when you are doing that; No. 4, again, is similar to yours, about 15 sitting days; and, No. 5 in this clause is a definition of an overhead line.
—Nos 1 and 2 can be considered and, as I understand it, the others are simply procedural, which we will be following anyway.
—Can I take the opportunity—
—Geez!
—Senator Patterson, you really are starting to provoke me.
—I just feel for the chairman, that is all, but it is not my problem at the moment.

—I just wanted to make some comment about our amendments Nos 1 and 2. The minister has given an undertaking that his review will deal with the two which are specifically asking for a term of reference in that review, and we accept the minister's undertaking on that. He has also indicated that the issues we raise in our amendment No. 1 will be taken into account.

BREAK.PARA: I wanted to explain here that our amendment No. 1 was drafted to acknowledge the fact that this bill itself cannot impose any levy on carriers to provide funds for undergrounding. It was quite rightly pointed out that, under the constitution, any bill that deals with imposing a levy can only be introduced into the House of Representatives. The opposition, of course, has no chance in the House of Representatives of such a bill being introduced because of the numbers down there, so nothing will happen. We accept that.

However, it was pointed out to me by my advisers that we could allow a situation to occur whereby, if local government and carriers reached agreement themselves on some levy to start the undergrounding process in a council area under the existing state planning legislation, this would be allowable. This is what my amendment No. 1 does, but it also makes it clear that any such levy agreed to between a council and a carrier cannot be imposed without the approval of the Australian Communications Authority.

The reason we put that there is that, firstly, it is our constitutional power under telecommunications to have that with the ACA and, secondly, although the ACA will not be determining the levy, by having to have its approval means that certain criteria can be looked at. One of the issues a number of people have raised, including the minister, is that, if a carrier reaches agreement to accept a levy on its operation to pay for undergrounding in a particular council area, it cannot cross‐subsidise.

For example, you might find that in one council area it is agreed that the carrier will put up charges to all consumers of telephony across the whole of the network of Sydney to help pay for the undergrounding in North Sydney. Therefore, consumers in an area where there is no program to underground in effect would be paying a higher price to subsidise a specific area. In my view, that would be very clearly an area the ACA should rule out—that levies cannot be cross‐subsidised by the area where there is no undergrounding.

From my discussions with the Local Government Association of Australia in the last few days it is clear that they accept and understand this issue. They would like to get a general levy applied—and I think the minister's review will find this—across whole regions of the metropolitan area so there is no missing out and there is no possibility of a cross‐subsidy. That is an issue that the minister's review is going to have to deal with. Certainly, the opposition does not support an accidental cross‐subsidy or a designed cross‐subsidy that all consumers would pay for but with only some areas to go underground. It should be directly relevant.

I wanted to put on the record that the opposition does not support cross‐subsidy. That is why in the long run we hope the minister's review deals with an issue of having a broad based levy over a long period of time—accepting the minister's view expressed today that there is no way that you can underground overhead cables in a short term. It is a going to be a 10‐ or 15‐year period. And that is when you determine a levy to raise the money over a lengthy period of time for a dedicated fund.

The next issue that we are concerned about is that we want to make sure that any levy that is raised goes to that specific purpose of undergrounding. We are strongly opposed to any levy being placed on overhead cables to raise revenue for councils to do something else. I think the consumers would be outraged if they found that the money went to building a new town hall or to some other non‐undergrounding process.

We have had issues raised that New South Wales and South Australia local government law, once this immunity is adjusted, would allow councils, unless this act stops it, to raise levies of their own volition in those two states. I have been lobbied very hard by local government associations, particularly from my own state and from New South Wales, to allow that to continue. I have indicated that the opposition's view is that if there is going to be a levy it should be for a dedicated purpose, properly administered under the control of the independent authority, the ACA, to ensure that it all goes in the right direction.

So, Minister, with the undertaking that you have given that my amendments 1 and 2 or all of them on 417—four of them are procedural—will be included in the terms of reference for your working party and so on, I will accept that as a compromise with the government. I point out to Senator Patterson that, again, this is cooperation from the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats would support the opposition's amendment. We think that local government should be allowed to impose levies on carriers in respect of their infrastructure. It is the case that in places such as New South Wales this is already happening.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be our preference for enabling this to occur, as can be seen from item 91 of the Australian Democrats' amendments, to delete clause 42 of schedule 3 all together. This is the position of the New South Wales Local Government Association and of many other community organisations such as the Cables Downunder group.

The purpose of this clause is to annul state or territory laws which discriminate or which would have the effect, even if it is indirect, of discriminating against a particular carrier, against a particular class of carriers or against carriers generally. In our view, that clause is not necessary, and we would even go so far as to say it is devious.

Passage of this clause as it currently stands would severely limit if not entirely eradicate the ability of councils to protect their long‐term investments in expensive infrastructure. This is a particularly serious problem in New South Wales and South Australia where such schemes currently exist. In these states, for example, local government authorities are not permitted under state law to impose rates on electricity utilities and, given that situation, they would not be able to impose rates on telecommunications carriers because doing so would discriminate between carriers and the power utilities.

So the New South Wales Local Government Association has argued that passage of this clause would at best act as a trigger to enormous litigation about the proper application of state and territory laws and, at worst, cause local communities to subsidise the profits of telecommunications carriers—and we think these are important points. Local authorities may well be driven to challenge the validity of a Commonwealth law which overrides their rights, in addition.

The more important point however is that where private interests gain from the use of public assets or where they devalue those public assets such as the urban environment then they should pay a reasonable charge for such use or devaluation. If charges are not levied on private interests who profit from or devalue public assets, then the broader community is in effect subsidising the activities of the corporations.

We think that rather than preventing such charging from occurring government ought to be encouraging it. No doubt the carriers do not want to face extra costs and charges, but they should be forced to compensate the community for the urban blight that they have caused in so many places. There is nothing inappropriate about such charging. It is perfectly in line with the whole notion of user pays—or should we say polluter pays—and the government should, for once, side with the community interests rather than those of the big end of town.

BREAK.PARA: The ALP amendments are an alternative approach to those proposed by the Democrats. It is important to note however that the ALP amendments only make an exception to this anti‐discrimination clause for the sole purpose of enabling a levy to be raised from overhead cabling. It does not permit a levy to be charged for other forms of telecommunications infrastructure which are despoiling public assets in some way. Conventional economic analysis would suggest that such charging is warranted.

In the interests of achieving a positive outcome the Democrats are considering supporting the opposition amendments, but before doing so there are a few points that I would like to raise, and questions I would like to put to Senator Schacht. Could you confirm, Senator, whether your amendment enables those states, such as New South Wales, where a levy is currently applicable to continue to apply the levy? My reading of subclause 1 of your amendment suggests that this is possible. Perhaps the minister might also like to comment on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little confused. I thought that the opposition were not proceeding with the amendment on sheet 417 on the basis that the government would give due consideration to including in the terms of reference of its inquiry the points made in 1 and 2 of the opposition's amendment. I thought that was the situation. Under those circumstances I would be supporting the motion before us, which as I understand it is government amendments 250 to 252.
—That is my understanding as well, Senator Harradine. Perhaps we will get a confirmation from Senator Schacht and then from the minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not proceeding with those amendments on sheet 417 for the reasons I have given. The government has now given an undertaking which I accept as a strong undertaking. I also do so knowing that the minister will have to present a report back here. I have to tell the minister that that will be a report that the opposition does not expect will drop into a pigeon hole and disappear out of sight. If you expect that to be the view, whatever the opposition's argument about that is, you are going to find in the local community that this issue is not going to go away. It just will not go away despite any attempt by a Labor or coalition government in the future to ignore the overhead cables issue and say, `We are not going to deal with it; we have had reports, it's all very nice.' The opposition accepts that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not expect it to be a unanimous report because of the interests, as I said before, on the committee. There may be a majority report. I would hope that the government will then make some recommendations. I would certainly expect that during 1998‐99 we would come back into this place to debate appropriate legislative amendments to deal with the issue of overhead cabling. If the government did not proceed with that or if the opposition backed away from it then I would think that we would have to take our punishment in the general community because the community does expect action on it. I am as impatient as the Democrats or the Greens about getting an outcome on this. I do not think you can walk away from it.

The minister has mentioned ETSA in my own state. For 10 years I have led almost a one‐person campaign in South Australia to get ETSA to go underground with its overhead electricity cables, and along comes telecommunications. So I have been on the record in my own state as being a consistent advocate of undergrounding of all cables. The immunity issue about planning and management being amended, which we will be debating generally, is an issue that I hope the planning review will also have to look at.

There is another issue that I would expect is going to have to be dealt with. In my own state an independent accident research unit at Adelaide University has informally suggested to me that up to 20 people a year may be killed unnecessarily because they hit a stobie pole, as we call them in Adelaide. The poles are non‐frangible—they do not bend. They are designed to do the maximum damage not only to the car but also to the people in it, who may, through no fault of their own, hit the pole.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pole jumps out into the middle of the road, does it?

—It is on the edge of the road. You could be driving along and someone could hit you into the pole. This is what they have found. For 40 or 50 years this has been going on. ETSA has never had to worry about it because they have had the shield of the crown as a statutory state authority. Sooner or later the community is going to ask about even statutory authorities; and if they are privatised and are no longer owned by the public, should they still get the same immunity?

SPEECH.PARA: Now that we have telecommunications cables hanging on those poles in Adelaide does that mean that a telecommunications carrier, if the shield of the crown is removed or adjusted or if they are privatised, is in any way responsible for a class or individual action being taken for damages if someone is killed or injured by hitting a stobie pole? It is not like hitting a ramp or even a tree; they have sharp edges and they just cut a car to pieces. If you said, in any other area of public health, that up to 20 people a year were dying there would be considerable outrage and action demanded to change it. Those are issues that, in the end, the review panel is going to have to deal with.

Senator Allison asked me about whether my amendment allows the continuation of the situation in New South Wales and South Australia. As I understand it, and I stand to be corrected by the minister, the ability of local governments in those two states to continue to put their own levy on is prohibited elsewhere in the bill. I have been lobbied very hard, as I said before, to support the continuation of the situation in those two states if the local governments have been given the power by the state government to put a levy on.

But I think that is a patchwork approach. I think all local governments should be able to be involved in establishing a national levy. I have to accept that I cannot do that through this bill. I have had to compromise and go through the minister's review arrangement because there is no way I can do it. I do not think it is fair that two states can do it automatically through a state planning arrangement when other states cannot.

I have always argued on telecommunications that, in the end, this parliament takes responsibility for the provision of a national telecommunications system to all Australian citizens, and that includes the planning arrangements. Therefore, I say to Senator Allison that, as I understand it, this bill will prohibit local government councils in New South Wales and South Australia from putting their own levy on—for whatever purpose. I think that in another 12 months we will have to debate a different form of the levy on a national basis that all councils can participate in.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2 (line 23), after "payphones", insert ", directory assistance services".
(2) Clause 5, page 7 (after line 6), after paragraph (b), insert:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 134, page 124 (after line 12), after subparagraph (ii), insert:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 144, page 128 (after line 11), after paragraph (b), insert:

(2A) The obligation referred to in paragraph (2)(ba) requires that directory assistance services be made available free of charge to end-users except where the call seeking directory assistance is made using a public mobile telecommunications service, or a satellite service, that is not supplied to the party making the call in fulfilment of the obligation referred to in paragraph (2)(a).
