TALK.START.PARA: —These opposition amendments are designed to ensure that directory assistance is reasonably accessible to all people in Australia on an equitable basis. In recent times Telstra has floated, though not formally put to the government, a change that would see directory assistance being charged at the rate of 50c per call. Telstra puts an argument that it costs about $200 million per annum to provide directory assistance across Australia—that is, when anyone rings on a normal telephone to find out what a telephone number is, the millions of calls to that service each year cost Telstra about $200 million.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that this service should remain free. I find it a bit hard that Telstra argues that this is a crippling or a substantial cost when it has revenues of $15 billion and when its Yellow Pages—which is not directly related, of course, to directory assistance but it does provide directory assistance for business—is a very profitable business indeed. I think it earns some hundreds of millions of dollars.

If Telstra is going to try to cost recover on every community service where the community has accepted and welcomed the provision of that service, I think it will do itself a lot of damage—and it will do considerable damage in the community. When Telstra officials came to lobby me to support this change to charge a 50c fee for directory assistance, they said that this was economically most efficient for them. I said that it might be, in a very narrow accountancy arrangement, that this is very efficient for them but, in the broader context of their relations with the community, I believed it to be a very short‐sighted view. I said, `If you want to end up looking like the banks in Australia where every service that is provided is charged for—where pensioners get charged a fee for a deposit—you will end up as unpopular as the banks, and your name will be muddied and dirtied because people will believe you are only operating on a narrow accountancy provision, with every service being cost recovered.' I said that I would have thought that $200 million worth of goodwill would be a major marketing advantage for Telstra. They would be able to say, `Yes, we run as a commercial operation but there are certain services we provide free, or below cost, because they are services to the community', and the community would respond to that.

BREAK.PARA: One of the great marketing advantages Telstra has is that a majority of Australians still see Telstra as their telecommunications company. Even though in the past there have been complaints about some levels of Telstra services—and there will always be complaints when you are dealing with services to 10 million consumers—in the last few years Australians have seen a marked improvement in customer services and have responded accordingly. That is why, in public opinion polls, Australians have not been in favour of the partial privatisation of Telstra: they see it as a company that has delivered to all Australians.

I think that if Telstra takes to the nth degree the cost recovery process, it may recover the $200 million it costs it for directory assistance but, in marketing terms, in a competitive environment, it may lose hundreds of millions of dollars elsewhere. I think it has to get the balance right. If it wants to maintain its pre‐eminent position of dominant telecommunications carrier in Australia, it ought to make sure it does not end up with the same reputation in this country as the banks, which, in the last 10 years, have gone berserk and reduced services and charged ordinary Australians so as to make it uneconomic for ordinary Australians to have small bank accounts. If Telstra wants to go the same way, it will do itself a lot of damage.

Therefore, the opposition has moved this group of amendments to ensure that directory assistance is maintained for all Australians as a free service. We believe, unfortunately, that, if Telstra is going to take the other line, then we as an opposition are forced to move these amendments. We do so, and commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could intervene here immediately. There is no such thing, I suppose, as a free service—somebody has to pay for it and it will be other consumers. In effect, one needs to look at those customers at the present moment who are using the service and perhaps overusing it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, under the current act, a telco is required to notify the government if it wants to charge for directory assistance, and the government can refuse it that request. What I would like to hear from the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) is some indication of the guidelines to be used by the government in respect of any request by any telco for a charge for directory assistance. For example, how are people with disabilities going to be dealt with? And what is going to happen to people who are getting a bit long in the tooth and cannot use the phone books because of the fine print? Will they have to pay? What guidelines will the government have in respect of these particular matters?

Surely the government would not agree to any charge for directory assistance calls for customers who do not have that particular telephone book—for example, if the number is out of their region. That would be inexcusable. And surely every customer would need to have access to some number of directory assistance calls in a particular period before any charge is made. I would certainly like the minister—if he can now or, if not, at some stage during this discussion—to provide the committee with the guidelines that might be used by the government when assessing such a request by a telco.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition's amendments are similar to the Democrats' amendments—except for opposition amendment No. 6, which is in conflict with our amendment No. 13. Mr Chairman, what is the process in this respect? Can we debate these amendments cognately in order to explore the difference here?
—There is no problem with doing that.

—The Democrats' amendment No. 13 seeks to have operator assisted directory services and other services as prescribed incorporated into the universal service obligation. In doing so, we would ensure that such services are reasonably accessible and provided free of charge to all persons irrespective of where they reside or where they carry on their business.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, if Telstra wishes to impose a fee for directory assistance before 31 December 1998, it is required to notify the minister of that proposal and obtain his or her approval. Under section 24 of the Telstra act, a carrier that proposes to alter a charge which is subject to notification and disqualification must inform the minister at least 30 days before it is to take effect. The minister must then request Austel to provide a report as to whether the alteration should be disallowed in the public interest and to direct the carrier not to make the alteration until the minister has received and considered the report. On receiving the report, the minister has 30 days to decide whether to disallow the alteration on the basis that it is not in the public interest.

Given it is government policy that directory services be provided free of charge, Telstra would appear to have very little hope of introducing charges. However, as has been noted, these arrangements will come to a close on 31 December 1998.

I would like to suggest that, if the government wants to give lasting effect to its policy of ensuring customers are provided operated assisted directory services and if it wants to ensure that the cost of providing the services is shared equitably amongst the carriers, it should legislate to incorporate this into the USO. Consumers should not be deluded into thinking that operator assisted directory services and other services will continue free of charge once the current arrangements come to an end.

We have all heard Telstra state repeatedly that it does want to introduce charges for such services. Their most recent proposal in February this year suggested a charge of 50c per call. That would have reaped Telstra an estimated $150 million in additional profit each year, whilst customers making just one directory assistance call per month under that arrangement would have been worse off.

We have a number of concerns with the opposition's proposal. Perhaps we could discuss those and reach some sort of compromise—ideally, a compromise that would also be acceptable to the government. Given they are also committed to the ongoing provision of free of charge directory services, this should be possible.

One of my concerns with the opposition amendments is that they do not actually require operator assisted directory services be free of charge—rather they simply say `directory services'. I wondered whether this was an oversight or whether ensuring the provision of phone books would satisfy that requirement. Perhaps I can ask Senator Schacht to respond, if he is able to, and tell me whether it is operator or phone book assistance we are talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can be of some assistance. Let us look at the wording of our amendment. The term `directory assistance services' I think clearly identifies that we are talking about operator assistance, not just specifically directory services. I think by using the term `directory assistance services' we are making the distinction between just the Yellow Pages and the services provided by an operator based on a call.
—Then would the opposition have any objection to our inserting the word `operator' so it makes it clear that we are not just talking about telephone books?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Putting in a definition of operator or trying to define the word `operator' is a problem because there is a whole range of services that may be beyond directory assistance where you have an operator service, such as accounts or providing information about other services within Telstra. I think they are commercial services that should not automatically be put into the universal service obligation on the common understanding of what ordinary Australians think directory assistance is, which is to ring up and say, `Can you tell me the telephone number for Mrs Smith of Black Street, Blacktown?' That is a simple query on what the number is in the White Pages . That is basically the common understanding of the community about directory assistance that has been provided free of charge ever since the first telephone was provided, I understand.

SPEECH.PARA: We are saying that that service should be the one guaranteed to be in the USO. I am a bit concerned that if you put it the way you describe operator, there are a range of other operators that people will say ought to be in when it is a commercial service. That is why I have tried to guarantee that the service as people commonly understand it is provided whereas the proliferation of other services do not accidentally get caught up in the definition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand corrected if that is the case. But we have been discussing directory assistance services for some time now and that word `operator' has usually been part of that phrase. It is not something we want to die in a ditch over but it did seem to me to be consistent with the approach in the past and is not meant to suggest that that is more than the directory services that you are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another concern that we have; that users of mobile phones are excluded from access to free of charge directory assistance. Currently mobile phones can ring the basic 013 service. They just get the number, they do not get the automatic transfer onto a line. If they want that kind of value adding service they could ring 0130, as I understand it, and they pay a fee for that. But I do not see any reason why mobile phone users should be excluded from that basic service provision. In many ways they contribute an enormous amount to the revenue coming in on telephone services and they are more likely than anybody else not to be carrying a directory in their back pockets as they move around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a point well raised by Senator Allison. The reason we have excluded mobile phones is that this is to go into the universal service obligation to be determined on the cross‐subsidy arrangement. Again, it is a balance between what it is reasonable to put into the universal service obligation and what people have commonly expected to be available to them as normal directory assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a decision taken in 1987 that has probably had one of the most profound implications for telecommunications but no‐one at the time argued about it because no‐one believed that we would end up with millions of subscribers for mobile telephones. In 1987 Telstra, in introducing the mobile phone service, said it would be a timed call. There was no discussion or debate, as I am aware—I was not in the parliament at the time. It was just accepted that mobile telephones would be on a timed rate, even if it was on a local call. I suspect that at the time all of us thought that mobile phones were a bit esoteric and were for those people at the Stock Exchange, or a very limited number of professional and business people who would be the only ones able to afford it. The cost in 1987 ran into a couple of thousand dollars to get access and buy a mobile telephone.

It is interesting that after all the many arguments we have had in this place about charging rates, one of the most significant decisions ever taken was that mobile telephone calls in a local call area would be at a timed rate. I also think that, as a result, people have accepted that. They might not like it but it is now operating and no‐one is proposing to change that. I also think that, in the common purpose of directory assistance, if you were going to put mobile phones in the universal service obligation a lot of people would say that the universal service obligation is about ensuring that people in the community who could be disadvantaged get access to a telecommunications system.

Our amendment means providing traditional directory assistance to homes for domestic consumers, and in many cases it is pensioners or people with some disability who are using it. The mobile telephone system is used by people who by and large, by definition, are not overwhelmingly discriminated against or denied access to a decent telecommunications system. The system is working well for them. We believe, as far as the universal service obligation is concerned, it should not be in the calculation.

I also want to point out that that still does not stop Telstra from providing directory assistance to the mobile phone system free of charge. If they were smart in the marketplace, and considering the competition they have, I think they should continue to provide the service accordingly. But we do not believe it ought to be in the universal service obligation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that Senator Schacht's amend ment actually does allow for 013 calls via mobile phones to be charged, whereas they are not at the moment.
—We are not asking that they be charged, but we are saying—

—No, but you are recognising that even the original concept of timed local calls applying to mobile phones has in no shape or form inhibited the growth rate. Australia now probably has the highest level of penetration per capita in the world.
—If you want me to make a further amendment to 013—
—If you do, you will be in danger of overplaying your hand even more in terms of shameless populism. I have to say, with the greatest respect, your approach is—
—Your Better Communications was full of shameless populism, Minister.
—We are presently implementing it with great success.
—He's a popular guy.

—I think there is a distinction. There is an important point to be made about what sort of telecommunications system you want in this country and whether it should be cost based or not. There might be some who think that the whole service ought to be free, but we do not take that view. We think the proper incentive structures will only arise if you do have sensible charging structures.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of what Senator Harradine asked, I think there are some very important issues to be addressed here, because the position we have at the present time is that there are something like 400 million calls to 013 each year. That is over a million calls a day, and it is growing at the rate of about 20 per cent to 25 per cent a year. It cost Telstra last year, I think, under $200 million. They estimate that in the next financial year it will cost in excess of $300 million.

Some 70 per cent of those callers are people who do have access to the White Pages. Those who have mobile phones, whilst they might not have the White Pages sitting alongside them in the front seat of the car, I would have thought would expect to be charged and can afford to be charged. Therefore, you would have to say that the great bulk of people using 013 services do not need to or, if they do, they would be prepared to be charged for the privilege.

There are some very important concerns, therefore, that can strike the right balance that Senator Schacht talked about. I do not think that the carriers should be encouraged or permitted to put themselves in a position where they are regarded as social pariahs. I would have thought that, in a highly competitive environment, that is the last reputation you would want. Indeed, if your competitor was building up that sort of reputation, you would be going very fast in the opposite direction and portraying yourself as very user friendly.

It is the case in many countries that calls to directory assistance are charged. It has never been the case in Australia, essentially for political reasons. The way the regime operates at the moment under the Telstra Corporation Act is that Telstra is entitled to apply to the minister and the minister is then entitled to approve or reject or refer it off to Austel for consideration. So there are stages in the process that would allow the matters to be debated.

There is not any formal proposition on the table, but I think we are all aware that Telstra were seriously interested in advancing a proposition several months back. From my point of view, it was not one that I thought was acceptable, but it had the makings of an acceptable outcome. In other words, I think you have to ensure that you absolutely and positively protect those who need access to the service and who essentially cannot afford to pay it or those who do not have access to White Pages. If you are print handicapped, quite clearly, you cannot use the White Pages and you should not be penalised as a result of making an 013 call. Similarly, the national relay service, which provides the teletype facility, is designed to assist the hearing impaired and, again, that is a free service funded on budget.

BREAK.PARA: I think you can go beyond that. It seemed to me that 50c a call was pretty much on the high side. I did not really understand why you needed to go beyond 25c, for example, if that is the standard local call charge. Similarly, as I understood it, Telstra was proceeding down the path of recognising that this should not be simply an opportunity to make money on the deal—even though it is costing them $200 million or $300 million—and that they should be prepared to look at that money going back into the system either by way of a discount on access charges, handset rentals and the like or by other means. So I think it is possible to devise a system in which you can protect the people who need to be protected and, at the same time, impose a charge that will get the growth rate under control. It does need to be carefully monitored to ensure that it is within reasonable bounds.

It simply does not make sense in this day and age to require a carrier to go on incurring a cost burden quite needlessly. The majority of the population, I would have thought, would not have sensible quarrels with that proposition. If you did a survey, everyone might say they would like to have free local calls, but I do not think that that is proper guide.

I did see a survey recently that suggested that something like a third of the community already thought that the directory assistance calls were charged. So in that sense I would be surprised if the proportion was not a lot higher for mobile phone users. I would have thought the majority of them would take it for granted that they were paying timed rates both for ordinary calls and for directory assistance calls.

So I think it is possible to devise a regime. I think we would need to tread very carefully before we went down that track, but I certainly think that it is a very retrograde step to effectively insert a provision because somehow it might pick up a few popular votes in the short term. It will have fundamentally uncompetitive consequences.

It will simply mean, as Senator Harradine says, that the money has to come from somewhere and that will then be built in, or added to, all of the other charges. If you ask why we have the highest local call charges in the world, or close to it, there is a combination of reasons. The more you impose those sorts of burdens, the more likely it is that you will reduce their capacity to offer world best practice on local call charges and, indeed, a range of other services.

I have to say that the position the government takes on this is that it would not be in the best interests of consumers to simply turn a blind eye to an ever-escalating bill which is borne by carriers when the reality is that something like 70 per cent of the population simply choose the service out of convenience. I saw a statistic which said that about 22 per cent of users are aged 18 to 24. I own a couple of those, and they would be classic examples. They would not be bothered looking up the White Pages. They would be more than happy to borrow my mobile phone and I am quite sure they would not have any compunction about dialling 013 whenever they wanted a number.

Eighteen to 24-year-olds use the service 22 times per month compared with the average of six times per month. Fourteen per cent of the population account for 52 per cent of 013 calls. Some businesses repeatedly use the service 500 times per day to gain commercial information cheaply. As you know, that is why Telstra have made it progressively harder to access it. They have limited it to two numbers per call. I suppose that if you are ringing from a business you would not mind—you just keep ringing again, put it on redial and keep going. Telstra have also applied queuing theory, so they do not put on the number of operators to accommodate all of those calls within a 10-second time frame for answer, which I understand is the standard practice in the US, although it might vary a bit state by state.

It is a very inefficient system. All you are going to do is force the carriers to be more and more dilatory in responding because they do not want to encourage people to use services which users could afford to pay for and for which the carriers are not able to recoup any of those costs. We already have a variety of operator assisted calls that are charged, whether they are wake-up and reminder calls, Australia direct or reverse charge calls. It is simply a question of striking the right balance to ensure that on the one hand you have cost based pricing which puts the right incentives in place and on the other hand you have all the necessary social protections in place.

We could devise a statement of principles against which we would measure any formal application. I would be prepared to do some work on that. I share Senator Harradine's concerns very much. I do not think in any shape or form it would make sense for people who are handicapped or disadvantaged in various ways to be forced to pay a charge which they currently do not pay. But that is not the great bulk of the population. They certainly are not a significant proportion of the people who racked up $305 million in 1988-89.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, if they are charging for using 013 more than three times, will your children make fewer calls?

—No, they will not, but I will have to pay for the privilege. I might then have an incentive to tell them not to do it or I will dock their pocket money, or I will have an encryption code that will limit them to a certain number of calls per day, or I will have an alarm device attached to the system so that after they have made more than three 013 calls their bedroom explodes, or whatever.

BREAK.PARA: There are various sanctions that I could personally impose, and I would then be aware of what is going on. At the moment they use it with impunity, and the only people who are paying for it are the pensioners who are paying 25c a call and are therefore cross‐subsidising my yuppies. That is not a fair system. I think there are better ways of doing it. We are not about to approve any proposal that comes before us, but all I can say is that we should reserve that right so that we can strike the right balance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that we have targeted young people so much for criticism in respect of directory services. I cannot visualise teenagers sitting down ringing up directory services for fun. But there you go—I guess it is possible. The Australian Democrats will support the opposition and not proceed with our move to have this service put into the USO, because clearly there is not the support for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that I am not reassured by the remarks of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston). Free directory services are always going to be a target, and we will have this debate over and over again as the industry and Telstra at this stage wish to charge for the calls. Remarks such as, `We are just going for the popular votes,' `It is all short term,' and `The cost burden is being imposed quite needlessly,' are interesting in the light of the very recent remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that this service is intended to be a free one in the foreseeable future. With those remarks, I would indicate that we support the opposition's amendments and that we will not proceed with ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, as I understand it, if this amendment is defeated and Telstra comes before you with a formal proposal—one that has been floated around—to change the directory assistance, you can accede to the changes. I understand that there is no requirement that whatever you accede to comes before the parliament. There is even a disallowable instrument. Is that correct?
—I think that is correct. There is the ability to refer it to Austel.
—By the minister?
—Yes.

—Minister, the reason we are in the position of moving these amendments is that parliament will not have a say on this issue. You may say it is crude populism, but when that Telstra document went out, or was leaked, I did a number of radio talkback programs—I do not say that they are an average survey of these sorts of things—and it was pretty remarkable that the comments from the phone calls were overwhelmingly adverse. Again, that is not a scientific measure for this. The problem that we have is that if our amendment is defeated or we withdraw it, then the parliament, on this issue of where you go on directory assistance, would no longer be in the loop, to use a telecommunications word. I am concerned that parliament would have no more say.

SPEECH.PARA: They are the rules at the moment. This was our legislation as well. What is being put forward is a significant change to Telstra. That means I am forced to proceed, with the support of the Democrats, to support that this be in the USO and that we guarantee it because I cannot see any other way parliament will have a further say on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite right in pointing out that this has always been the regime. You lived with it quite comfortably for 13 years.
—We kept knocking it on the head.

—In the early years they came forward with a proposal which, as I recall, was very ill thought out, was simply across the board, and you quite rightly knocked it back. We are all aware that this is a very sensitive issue. It is not quite at the `timed local calls' level of debate. I heard some of those radio talkback programs and I have to say, as often happens in these things—I am sure you were not whipping it up—that people respond to the general proposition. They use whatever arguments they can, irrespective of the facts. So they will say, `That's outrageous. I've got a 99‐year‐old grandmother at home. Why should she have to pay for it? She has been deaf and blind for 20 years.' They are outraged. Then the next person rings up and says, `I couldn't agree more with the last speaker,' and away it all goes.

SPEECH.PARA: In part, that is why governments are very sensitive in acceding to those sorts of requests because the politics can very much overtake reality. That is why I think you have to bend over backwards to get it right. Just as we made it plain to Telstra that they had a lot more work to do, they have been reluctant to come forward in recent years because they understand the level of community concern. It would be upon our heads, or any government's head, to simply give the green light to a proposal that had not been very carefully worked through. The option to refer it to Austel is a very useful safeguard in that respect.

Inevitably, the matter would be out in the public arena, there would be all sorts of opportunities for the parliament to be expressing its view in spades. As I say, it may well make sense to pick up on Senator Harradine's suggestion and look at a statement of principles against which that could be measured before it comes forward, rather than saying, `Give us your idea and we will kick it around.' Having said that, I would still take the view that you should leave the option on the table where it lies and not simply succumb to the temptation to basically play the populist card, irrespective of cost, because inevitably it is going to be passed on to other consumers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, some of that was quite reasonable comment. The opposition, though, will proceed with our amendments with the support of the Democrats. I point out about populism that even the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made a reasonable remark in the House of Representatives, which Senator Allison referred to, that directory assistance would remain free. That is a political debate which will go on. Without taking any further time of the committee, we will proceed with our amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Schacht's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Evans did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Sherry did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, am I correct in assuming that you do not want to proceed with amendment No. 13?
—That is correct.
—Would you move your amendments to clauses 7 and 144.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 7, volume 1, page 18 (after line 18), after the definition of member , insert:

PARA.TAB: National Relay Service means the service operated by the Australian Communication Exchange from 30 May 1995 for the purpose of facilitating the transfer of messages between text telephone users and voice telephone users.

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Clause 144, volume 1, page 128 (after line 21), after subclause (2), insert:

PARA.TAB: (2C) The regulations may prescribe, for the purpose of paragraph 1(a), the establishment of a service, similar in scope and purpose to the National Relay Service, to facilitate personal communication by persons with hearing and/or speech impairments, for use in connection with the standard telephone service.
(2D) Regulations under subsection (2C) must be made on or before 30 June 1998.

SPEECH.PARA: In April 1994 the government approved $26 million over four years to establish and operate the National Relay Service. Before then similar services were run by volunteers from deaf societies, Lifeline and similar organisations. The National Relay Service commenced operation on 30 May 1995 and is operated by the Australian Communication Exchange. They have a four‐year contract with the Commonwealth which is due to expire on 30 June 1998.

The purpose of these amendments is to ensure that the National Relay Service or an equivalent service is included in the definition of the universal service obligation by 30 June 1998. This is the date upon which the existing funding arrangement for the National Relay Service will expire. The inclusion of the National Relay Service as part of the USO was made by the standard telephone service review group. It was recommendation No. 8 of their report. Given that both the coalition and ALP in addition to the Democrats have previously expressed support for this report in their respective reports to the Senate telecommunications bills inquiry, I cannot see any reason for objecting to this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that we are now talking about the Democrat amendments, but in light of the vote which has just taken place and in light of the fact that there will be charges for directory assistance, I wanted to ask the minister—
—What? No-one decided that.

—I would just like to clarify with the minister, if there is the ability to charge for directory assistance will people get the service that they used to get, and which has now been taken away? Will they be able to find out the things that they used to be able to get from a telephone book? Will they be able to ring up directory assistance and find out an address. I believe that service has now been taken away.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is the ability to charge for directory assistance does that mean that we will not have to go to a post office to find out the information that we were able to get from a telephone book if we had one—and most people do not? Those services have now been pulled out. Most people would know that if they have tried to find out an address from directory assistance these days. Now that those services can be charged for, would the minister clarify whether we will get a service different from the ones that have been pulled out in recent times?

TALK.START.PARA: —We want a precise answer on this, Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just sort of reeling from the shock of Senator Margetts labouring under the illusion that the committee has just decided to impose charges for directory assistance. What we did was to maintain the status quo, which allows Telstra to bring forward a proposal—and we have had a detailed discussion about the basis on which we might conceivably consider that at some time in the future—but there is no proposal at the moment, certainly no requirement, for charging.

SPEECH.PARA: What you do refer to, however, is simply another example of the sort of rearguard action that the carrier is forced to undertake to discourage people from using the service. As I recall, something like four per cent of calls to 013 are not actually seeking telephone numbers. I think some of them even ring up asking for the latest state of the weather and, because Telstra is not allowed to charge, it is saying, `This isn't just a general help line. This is to provide telephone numbers. If you want addresses, you look them up in the phone book.'

None of what we have done today has anything to do with that except that it is an example of the sorts of responses you get from a carrier that will be incurring losses in the order of $200 million and up to $300 million in the next couple of years. That is why it cut back I think several years ago to saying, `You can only have two numbers,' because some businesses were making 500 calls a day getting numbers for direct mail databases and the like. All I can say is that we are not proposing anything of that sort today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, whose decision was it to remove that service that has been available for many years—that is, people were able to find out those things if they did not have a telephone book?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision would have been Telstra's. I am not sure that is right. I think I can recall some years ago ringing up asking for an address and being told that that was not the purpose of the service. I think they then did start to provide it and only recently they decided, again, that it was not the core purpose and, because they are free calls, they are taking what opportunities are available to them to restrict that growth, which is in the order of 20 per cent to 25 per cent a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Our position in relation to the National Relay Service for the hearing impaired is that we are very supportive of the whole concept. This is simply an argument about how it can best be funded. Let there be no misunderstanding, I do not think anyone in the chamber is proposing to wind back current arrangements. At the moment it is funded from the budget. It is possible to do it on a stand‐alone industry basis, or you could fold it into the USO. That is not, I have to say, what the USO is designed to do. The USO is designed to cross-subsidise people in uneconomic regional areas, so it was a geographic concept rather than a social assistance concept. However, there is no reason why these things cannot evolve over time and why you cannot have a broad scheme that incorporates a range of different objectives.

Our position is that we are proposing to review the method of funding for the National Relay Service. That examination will proceed over the next six months or so and that will then tell us which is the most effective vehicle for funding. So the service itself is not at any risk. It will simply continue as it does now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who funds it now—Social Security?
—No, it is from the budget.
—Which budget line?

—Family services and health. So it is already funded, it is just a question of whether there is a more efficacious method of funding. We simply say, `Have that examination, look at the options and, whichever is the best way of doing it, put that in place,' rather than jumping in and assuming that it should go from being on budget to the USO.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Democrat amendment. I have to say, if you do not support it, it is a bit like opposing motherhood.
—No, that is when you succumb to populism.

—No, this is succumbing to motherhood. At the Senate legislative committee hearings when the people representing the various deaf organisations and people who are handicapped came and gave their evidence, they used their interpreters with sign language and so on and explained the impact that telecommunications can have in the operation. It was a pretty convincing piece of evidence to me, and it seems impossible to vote against it in the sense that we are providing the service.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, as Senator Allison has pointed out, we are supporting this amendment. In the review of the standard telephone service, recommendation 8 on page 140—it is called prescribed goods and service, National Relay Service—says:

A service to facilitate interpersonal communications by people with hearing and/or speech impairments similar in purpose and overall cost to the National Relay Service should be incorporated into the universal service arrangements through the making of a regulation establishing it as a service for use in connection with a standard telephone service. These arrangements should commence on the expiry of the existing Commonwealth funding arrangements at the end of 1997 and 1998. The precise details of the service to be prescribed as part of the universal service obligation should be settled before the expiry of these arrangements with industry, consumers and users.
Minister, the review of the standard telephone service has done the work that you suggested in your previous remarks ought to be done before you make a commitment. This review has done the work.

On top of the evidence we were given at the Senate hearing earlier this year, I would think it would be to the government's real advantage to put this into the USO. There is one thing: the Treasurer (Mr Costello) would be very pleased because it would get it off the budget. You are actually going back to tell Mr Costello that you have saved him whatever the amount of money is because this is going to be in the USO and the carriers are going to pay for it. I would have thought that would have been extremely attractive to the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) in any budget lead‐up. With this review, it really should not be a problem for the government to vote for this amendment, and we will certainly be supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Chair, the Greens (WA) will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I agree with Senator Schacht that we should be pleasing the Treasurer. That should not necessarily be our aim in this.
—It's for Senator Alston to please the Treasurer.

—Yes. But I do feel strongly about the question of universal service obligations and these obligations in relation to people with disabilities. I compare it, for example, to our commitment to the universal service obligations to people who are disadvantaged through living in a particular geographical situation in Australia. A similar approach should be taken for persons who are disabled for other reasons, including deafness, blindness or other physical disabilities, or mental impairments.

SPEECH.PARA: I have noted, of course, what was said in the report of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee and might I say that I am very grateful to the people that have done the work in that committee—not only the members of the committee, but also the staff of the committee. It is very useful for me, in my position, not having a party communications committee, to get the wealth of information that is disseminated through these committee reports and so on. In short, I believe this should be part of the universal service obligation and I hope to be dealing with that matter later in the committee as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Chair, I accept the will of the Senate and, indeed, I do not think we have very strong views on the issue. There are, however, a couple of technical limitations that may well flow from what the Senate is proposing to do and I am just flagging that it may require some consequential amendments down the track when we have a better look at it. I can understand the concept. I have a considerable degree of sympathy for wanting to protect it in legislation rather than simply having it on budget. I think what we had in mind was that we would be looking at the best way of doing it and perhaps even upgrading it. This will simply lock it in at the current level, but that is a matter for the Senate. Having said that, I do not propose to take the matter any further.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (82) Clause 255, page 199 (lines 20 to 23), omit paragraph (a), substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: (83) Clause 255, page 200 (after line 33), after subclause (4), insert:

TAB.TAB: (a) the answering of calls to emergency service numbers; and

PARA.TAB: (4B) Subsections (4) and (4A) do not, by implication, limit subsection (1).

SPEECH.PARA: (85) Clause 255, page 201 (after line 15), after subclause (7), insert:

TAB.TAB: (e) a service for despatching a force or service referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d).

SPEECH.PARA: (88) Clause 256, page 201 (line 26), omit "section 257", substitute "sections 256A and 257".
(89) Page 202 (after line 9), after clause 256, insert:

(5) Subsection (4) does not, by implication, limit subsection (3).
(6) A determination made in an arbitration under this section must not be inconsistent with a Ministerial pricing determination in force under section 256B.

SPEECH.PARA: (90) Page 202, after new clause 256A, insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister may make a written determination setting out principles dealing with price-related terms and conditions relating to requirements of a kind referred to in subsection 256A(1). The determination is to be known as a Ministerial pricing determination .
