(3) In this section:

TAB.TAB: price‐related terms and conditions means terms and conditions relating to price or a method of ascertaining price.

SPEECH.PARA: (114) Clause 271, page 216 (line 23), at the end of subparagraph (v), add "or".
(115) Clause 271, page 216 (after line 23), after subparagraph (v), insert:

TAB.TAB: (vi) a service for despatching a force or service referred to in subparagraph (i), (ii), (iii) or (v);

SPEECH.PARA: (147) Clause 361, page 277 (lines 19 and 20), omit "direct access to an emergency service number", substitute "access to an emergency call service".
(148) Clause 361, page 277 (lines 22 and 23), omit "in fulfilment of the universal service obligation".
(176) Clause 450, page 342 (line 23), omit "use", substitute "the purpose of calling an emergency call service".
(177) Clause 450, page 343 (after line 9), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (6) In making the numbering plan, the ACA must have regard to the objective that, as far as practicable, there should be no more than one emergency service number for use throughout Australia.
(7) Subsection (6) does not, by implication, limit section 439.

SPEECH.PARA: These proposed amendments will restructure provisions of the bill relating to emergency call services to clarify and reinforce the arrangements for handling emergency call services, including clarifying definitions, specifying additional objectives relating to calls being transferred to emergency services organisations with a minimum of delay, and clarifying funding arrangements for emergency call services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I note that the Democrats have moved amendment No. 46, which the running sheet says is in conflict with government amendments Nos. 82 and 177. I checked Democrat amendment 46—and Senator Allison may wish to speak to it—and it says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . omit "an emergency service number", substitute "a single national emergency service number".

In the hearings we had evidence from a number of organisations, such as police associations and organisations, and almost a unanimous view on behalf of the ministerial committee meeting of police ministers and justice ministers, et cetera, arguing for a national emergency number. I know there have been some strong statements made on this issue. In commonsense terms, we could have one national emergency telephone number across Australia, so that when you ring 999 or whatever it is, you get through to that emergency number. Such a number could be easily remembered, publicised and promoted in schools, et cetera, so that people know about it and can remember it. It could become even better known than the 013 number just because it is so frequently publicised, as those state organisations, such as the police and emergency services, said.

I just wonder whether the Democrat amendment on this is acceptable to you and whether you have gone that far. I know there are some practical issues but there was some compelling evidence that if it is technically possible we ought to have one national emergency telephone number in Australia. I think the carriers ought to deal with whatever problems they may have. That seemed to me a compelling case at the hearings. Senator Allison may wish to say something as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you , Senator Schacht, for speaking to our amendment. We do think it is desirable that there be a single national emergency number where it is technically feasible. As Senator Schacht has indicated, we heard very loud and strong arguments for that need to have the single national emergency number from the consumer groups as well as emergency service providers. This is unfortunately in contrast with the proposed legislation, which allows for the possibility of multiple emergency numbers.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it is necessary to repeat all the concerns that we have heard. I think we all understand those. But we do want to make the observation that the very fact that the government came up with this proposal reveals, I guess, the ludicrous extent to which they are prepared to drive competition policy. It is supposed to ultimately benefit consumers but I think that commitment to that principle has shown that it is not in the interests of Australians in this respect. So, yes, like Senator Schacht I would be grateful for an indication from the government as to whether this is the direction in which the government will be prepared to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the principle underlying the recommendation but it seems to us that it is impractical to achieve it at this time. There are currently three numbers in use: 000, which is provided nationally; the 1800 number for TTY users; and 112, which is required for us to comply with international agreements for the GSM digital mobile telephone service. The Democrats understand this because the proposed amendments on sheet 407 and on sheet 427 allow other emergency service numbers to exist.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no point in requiring the ACA to have regard to an objective for the making of emergency call services that cannot be achieved. Even where a single number is achieved, it may not be desirable to mandate that this remains the case. Technologies and services may change, necessitating a change of numbers or other numbers for some uses. International technology agreements may require other emergency numbers to be available—for example, for the use of mobile telephone customers who make use of international roaming agreements.

In addition, government amendment 82 requires the ACA in making a determination in relation to emergency services to have regard to the objective that there should be the appearance of a single national emergency call system and that community expectations in relation to the provision of emergency call services are met. This is intended to ensure a minimum confusion on the part of end users of the standard telephone service in relation to emergency call services.

So the government considers that it is going as far and as fast down this path as is sensible and that we should not lock ourselves into inflexible arrangements which may indeed conflict not only with technological progress but international agreements. For those reasons, we would reject the proposed Democrat amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I perhaps make the offer that this amendment be reworded to indicate `where technically feasible', which should overcome the minister's concerns. I think it is important that we introduce at least an indication that the government believes that it is desirable to have a single national emergency number. If that wording `where technically feasible' was included, I wonder whether that would overcome the concerns of the government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might indicate that our amendment 177 requires the ACA in making the numbering plan to have regard to the objective that as far as practicable there should be no more than one emergency service number for use throughout Australia. So that really does cover the point. If we go down that path, we have established the in principle position. We want to make sure it works and we do not want to lock ourselves into those inflexible arrangements.

—I understand the technical difficulties which were explained at the hearings but, despite those technical difficulties, everybody agrees that a national consistent number has many advantages. I accept that your amendment 177 requires the ACA to have regard to that. I wonder whether you could give us an undertaking, without needing an amendment, that in the annual report of the ACA they report on the progress made towards developing a national emergency numbering system so that we can see the progress and, above all else, you may be able to keep some state ministers off your back as well. I am always being helpful.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you are on this occasion. I think that is a sensible suggestion. Clearly, there is a general view in the chamber that we should be going down this path as far and as fast as we can. What I do not want to see is a situation where we simply lock ourselves in and find that that is not a feasible way of achieving the objective. I have no objection—indeed, I think it is a good idea—to asking the ACA to give us progress reports—
—In their annual reports.

—In the annual report in particular, so that we give them riding instruc tions in the first instance and we ask them to report back—and we can kick them along a bit harder if we need to. That way we are going down the path and making sure that we take account of all of the problems that might otherwise be there. The fact is that you do have three numbers at the moment—you cannot just wish them away. I would be more than happy to give that undertaking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wonder if the minister could indicate how this undertaking might be given, other than the sort of reassurance that he has just given. Is there not some way in which the government's amendments might strengthen that commitment? I guess that is really what we are looking for. The commitment is a bit hidden in the amendments that we have.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from once again supporting the amendments that we have put with the inclusion of technical feasibility, I cannot think of any other better way. I just ask the minister whether, rather than just relying on an assurance to us, there is some way that his own words can be strengthened a bit more substantially on this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is possible, and I would be prepared to give a direction to the ACA to ensure that that happens. So, in conjunction with amendment No. 177, the ACA will be left in no doubt about what is expected, and we can respond to that in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, your next amendments were 46 to 49. Did you wish to move all of those or just 47 to 49—or none of them?
—I think they are redundant in view of the minister's undertaking and the carriage of the previous amendments. You are not proceeding?
—No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 22, Volume 1, page 30 (line 26), after "regulations", insert ", except in relation to a standard telephone service".
(2) Clause 22, Volume 1, page 31 (lines 15 to 17), omit:

PARA.TAB: (4) If no regulations are in force for the purpose of subsection (1), then, for the purposes of sections 20 and 21, the boundary of a telecommunications network is:

SPEECH.PARA: substitute:

PARA.TAB: (4) For the purposes of sections 20 and 21, except as provided by subsection (4A), the boundary of a telecommunications network is:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 22, Volume 1, page 31 (after line 34), after subclause (4), insert:

PARA.TAB: (4A) In the case where a telecommunications network is used to supply a standard telephone service to an end‐user in a building by means of a line that enters the building, the wall socket, or wall sockets in the case of multiple residences in the building, are the network boundary.

SPEECH.PARA: Greens' amendments Nos 1 to 3 on sheet 403 relate to what I spoke about in my second reading contribution, and that is that currently the boundary of a telecommunications network is the switch inside the house. There will be changes as a result of this legislation which will mean that the boundary will be the place where the line meets the outside of the house. The issue of network boundaries is one in which this new proposed act is inferior to the existing act. The existing act specifies that the network boundary for most consumers is their wall socket. Under this bill, that would be changed and the network boundary would now be set by regulation.

If no regulations are introduced, the legislation states that, in the case of a telecommunications network that is used to supply carriage service to an end user in a building by means of a line that enters the building, the building entry point is the network boundary. This change is one that impacts on the most vulnerable users of telecommunications services. For example, older persons living in a unit on the top floor of a building would then have the network boundary—that is, the point at which the carrier is responsible—far away from the point at which they access the network.

In the event of a difficulty that arose within the building, it is not clear how they would go about having it repaired. For example, how would they actually know if the problem with their phone was a problem that existed outside the building or within the building? If the network boundary extended to the wall socket then there would be no such confusion. Who do the people contact if the problem is within the building—the building owner? None of this is clear.

There are certainly safety issues involved here. I imagine there are access and equity issues too, because if you do not happen to have a good landperson, then you are going to be disadvantaged under the system and there will be a lot of confusion in the interim. Our amendments simply give consumers the certainty that they have under the existing act, while not interfering with other non-residential consumers' ability to negotiate their own arrangements. I commend the amendments to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens' and the Democrats' amendments, although they are structured differently, are identical in intent. Since the Greens' amendments are more streamlined than our own, I will be happy to support those in place of ours. I will just make some remarks about these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of these amendments is to see that the network boundary continues until the first telephone socket rather than at the building entry point, as is proposed by the legislation. The Democrats do not believe that the potential benefits of having the network boundary terminate at the building entry point outweigh the negative impacts. While it will reduce the costs to the carriers who will no longer have to install wiring to that first socket, it will mean added expense and inconvenience for the great majority of residential customers.

The outcome of the government's proposed change of definition would transfer greater responsibility for the costs of connection for fault detection and service restoration to the customer. While the Democrats can understand the desire of carriers to avoid the costs of providing cabling to the socket, we are also conscious of the needs of consumers. We think it is highly inappropriate to dress up what is very clearly a cost cutting measure for carriers as a benefit to consumers.

Furthermore, there is no indication that consumers are to receive any compensatory reduction in their installation cost or their line rental charges, which would have reflected the cost that carriers are no longer liable for wiring between the entry point and the first socket.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order, I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days a degree of publicity has been given to the travel expenditure run up by ATSIC commissioners in the last couple of years. Given the expenditure of public moneys on ATSIC, it is appropriate that these expenditures be submitted to public scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: Approximately 12 months ago, I was alerted to the apparent excessive expenditure by some ATSIC commissioners. Rather than make the simple allegations, I sought to obtain the relevant data. Through the appropriate forum of the Senate, I sought the details. It would be fair to say that the details were somewhat slow in coming. After literally months of waiting, I did receive a 22‐page response and it appears as though some of the figures may be wrong. I look forward to receiving an update as soon as possible.

The information that I received apparently justifies the concerns that were expressed to me about the travel allowances being paid. However, as I said in releasing the figures, it is too early to draw any conclusions or make any adverse inferences.

Let me say that I welcome the referral of this matter to the director of the Office of Evaluation and Audit. The question of the travel allowance paid to ATSIC commissioners has been referred to the director of the Office of Evaluation and Audit to ensure that there has been full accountability. It was referred by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) after consultation with the new chair of ATSIC. I understand that referral was made on 4 March 1997, the very day before I received the official information. So, as soon as ATSIC and the minister's office were alerted to these figures, they took what could only be described as the proper course of action. Both the minister and the chairman of ATSIC are concerned to ensure that the claims are consistent with the three roles of commissioners—namely, their duties and responsibilities to attend board meetings, portfolio responsibilities, and zone responsibilities.

It is no wonder that they were concerned given that, in one case, travel allowance was claimed by one commissioner to the sum of $68,000 for one year. It is important to note at this stage that the new board of ATSIC passed a resolution at its first meeting in December that says, in part:
Commissioners be responsible for managing their own administrative allocations and that extra funds will not be available if Commissioners over‐expend.

I welcome the initiative by the minister and the new chair of ATSIC and the new board of ATSIC. Undoubtedly, those measures have been taken because of the concern that was expressed to me and the concerns that I have followed up.

The total travel bill for ATSIC commissioners was $1 million for 1994‐95 and $1.5 million for 1995‐96. I just quickly say that the 1994‐95 figures did not tell the whole story. As a result, it is not appropriate to make the claim that travel and travel allowance payments jumped by half a million dollars between those two years. Might I also add that I do not begrudge the amount or the extent of the travel. The in globo figures that I have just mentioned do not really tell us very much.

Individual figures, however, do leave room for speculation and it is important to the commissioners involved and for public transparency that explanations be provided. For example, in 1994‐95, the then ATSIC chair claimed $28,695 for travel allowance whilst the Tasmanian commissioner claimed $42,243, which was the highest amount. When you have those sorts of discrepancies, I believe it is appropriate to ask for explanations. The travel allowances claimed for attending board meetings in 1994‐95 disclose a huge disparity between some not claiming anything up to a claim of $21,938.

Zone travel allowances for 1994‐95 also showed huge variations. Clearly, the size of the zones being represented is an important consideration and those living in larger zones will have greater claims. Yet, one of the smallest zones—namely, Tasmania—had a zone travel allowance claim to the sum of $20,615. In the 1995‐96 financial year, the highest claim for travel allowance was $68,495. This is an interesting figure, given the media speculation about senators' travel allowances.

The media apparently believes that the travel allowance claimed by some senators is excessive. I do not wish to comment on that aspect but the figures reported in today's media are in the vicinity of $100,000‐plus for a number of our colleagues. But that figure is compiled for the period from 1 July 1991 through to 3 March 1997—that is, some 5¾years.

Therefore, if we undertake a simple multiplication—and when I say `simple', I used the calculator for this one—when we multiply $68,495 by 5.75 years, we get a total travel claim of $393,848 for that comparable period of time. In anyone's language, that is big money. So if it is justifiable to have inquiries into travel claims of over $100,000 accrued over five years for senators, it stands to reason that it is three times more justifiable for an inquiry into ATSIC commissioners' travel allowances.

Having said that, I do not draw any adverse inferences or conclusions in relation to those senators who have accrued large travel allowance claims; nor do I do so in relation to the ATSIC commissioners. But what I do say is that there is clearly room for the sort of investigation that is now going to be undertaken by the Director of the Office of Evaluation and Audit, and I look forward to its determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the Senate a plea on behalf of the Snowy River and its friends in the Snowy River Alliance, a representative group of concerned citizens and local organisations, and members of the Australian Labor Party in the electorate of Eden‐Monaro. I wish to give voice to their concerns about the fate of the Snowy River, which is facing severe degradation.

SPEECH.PARA: The federal, New South Wales and Victorian governments are set to corporatise the Snowy Mountains hydro‐electric scheme by 1 July this year. The Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Power Act 1949, to divert the waters of the Snowy River and its tributaries for additional irrigation security on the Murray and Murrumbidgee Rivers, has added value to the water by running it through electric turbines.

This country is certainly now a different place from what it was back then. In that period there seemed to be inexhaustible amounts of natural resources to exploit. While it is still true that `our land abounds in nature's gifts', we are now witnessing the long‐term harmful effects of decisions made about half a century ago. The Snowy River hydro‐electric scheme was undoubtedly one of the greatest engineering feats of modern times. It has a special place in the hearts of many Australians, particularly post‐war migrants who gained a sense of participating in the building of a new nation by working on the scheme.

But mistakes were made during the planning and building of the Snowy Mountains hydro‐electric scheme. One of the most significant was the decision to dam and divert virtually all of the Snowy River's water to the west of the Great Dividing Range without leaving enough water to keep the Snowy River flowing. A near‐empty riverbed has seen the river system stressed in places to the point of complete ecological collapse.

The less than one per cent release of water from the Jindabyne Dam has placed the Snowy River in a state worse than any recorded through drought, and that is permanent. Environmental integrity has suffered so badly that some visitors to the region will not believe that what they are seeing is the Snowy River. The Snowy River was a mighty river—powerful, and abundant in life. It has stirred emotions and invited literary tributes. It is time to rectify the mistake that was made half a century ago.

Support for returning environmental flows on the Snowy is almost unanimous from all levels of government and the local community. Indeed, I acknowledge that evidently on radio this morning Premier Kennett of Victoria said something sympathetic. Premier Kennett is not a person I would normally use as an authority in support.

Although the existing act was set up to divert most of the Snowy's flow, it was not the intention of planners to destroy the river. Unfortunately, the Snowy River communities have noted a lack of will to make the Snowy Mountains scheme meet the environmental standards of today. That is the challenge we must now face—to make the Snowy River something that we can be environmentally proud of.

The communities have told me that they believe the issue has been hijacked by energy ministries given that they are preparing to corporatise the scheme. The energy departments have told local residents that the financial viability of the proposed corporation could be threatened if it were forced to meet scientists' demands and recommendations to return a flow to the river of about 28 per cent of its original volume. It is important that all industries operate with high environmental standards. The Snowy Mountains hydro scheme has a high public profile and a special place in the Australian psyche. But this electricity generator should not be allowed to devastate 450 kilometres of river.

To date, the issue of environmental flows has been represented as a cost or revenue reduction by the energy bureaucrats. But the benefits of environmental flows are not just environmental; they are economic. In fact, if land and water conservation, environment and Treasury are looked at together rather than as separate portfolios, environmental flows represent a high return investment. For example, I am informed that one of the world's largest rafting companies has already shown keen interest in a revitalised Snowy River, and it estimates that it alone could generate revenue equivalent to the value of the released water. I know that Canberra representatives will note that because of the spin‐off advantages for this city.

The Snowy River was also a world‐class recreational fishing resource and was the backbone of a huge catchment supporting a network of highly prized streams which has the potential to become a multimillion export earner for the fishing‐tourist industry.

The original purpose of the Snowy Mountains hydro scheme was to provide additional irrigation security for the Murray‐Darling Basin and the Murrumbidgee irrigation areas. The impact on these regions if a quarter of the Snowy River's water is returned to the Snowy must be considered.

The sustainability of irrigation dependent agriculture in the Murray‐Darling Basin is more complex than the planners of half a century ago could have known. Rising water tables and resulting salinity have led to changes in vegetation and extensive land degradation. Deforestation, increased salinity and high water delivery losses pose real threats to the future of the Murray‐Darling Basin.

A paper prepared for the Prime Minister's Science and Engineering Council dated 13 September 1996 stated that already half a million hectares of the basin's irrigated land, the most productive in the country, is thought to be affected by this land degradation. The worst affected land is already out of production and much more is expected to be retired as water tables continue to rise. Water use must accommodate the very significant constraints imposed by the nature of land and the hydrogeological processes. This is highlighted by the staggering losses of water during water delivery to the irrigation regions. According to the Murray‐Darling Basin Commission, 1,000 gigalitres of water per year are lost in the southern Murray basin. A thousand gigalitres is almost the full Snowy River diversion. These losses contribute significantly to rising water tables and the salinity problems which farmers in the basin face.

With governments already investing through the Murray‐Darling Basin Commission into key areas of water losses, the opportunity exists to invest these water savings into environmental flows for rivers which currently do not have enough water. The fact that this waste has been identified makes the need to return water to the Snowy even more pressing. It is a contention of the Snowy River Alliance that we are sacrificing one of the great rivers of this country not for sound economic or environmental reasons but purely through inefficiency.

The Snowy River is in a state of ecological collapse. The Snowy River Alliance argue that the hydro‐electric scheme was never constructed to be a stand‐alone profit making entity and the proven environmental benefits of returning water to the river far outweigh the possible cost involved. The solution is simple, they say: just add water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The work for the dole scheme is a matter of great public interest. This afternoon the government will introduce in the other place the bills which are necessary to establish this scheme. They have said they want to move very quickly on this legislation so they can begin to get the ball rolling on setting up the programs which will be available under this scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me, however, is that the legislation seems to be being rushed through the parliament long before the government has finalised how it will work in practice. We have been told that the initial work for the dole programs will involve 10,000 young unemployed Australians. We have also been told that these programs will be sponsored by organisations including community group and service clubs. What we have not been told, however, is exactly how many organisations are willing to offer such work for the dole programs or what kinds of activities they would be able to provide to unemployed people in their care.

BREAK.PARA: The government are putting the cart before the horse on this issue. They are introducing into the parliament the legislation necessary to establish the program long before they have thought through the nitty‐gritty detail and the mechanics of how this scheme will work. They seem almost to be making it up as they go along. It is like the people's convention: first of all they said, `We will tell you how the elected half of this convention will work, but we will tell you how the appointed half will be put in place only after you pass the legislation.' This is big picture first, details later, blank cheque legislation. That is how this government are operating at the moment. The government want to have the framework for this scheme in place by next week, but they then want to wait—to receive submissions from sponsors by July, in order to settle the fine details by August. This is the same thing. We are being asked to give a big tick for the big picture first; we are supposed to take the important details on trust for later.

I do not think that is good enough. We do not know enough about how the work for the dole scheme will work. The government has not been able to tell us. When the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was pressed on the first day he announced this, all he could think of as an example was, `We will get them to meet and greet tourists.' Yesterday, I did some research of my own. I wanted to get a better idea of which organisations—vaguely described as service and community organisations—would be willing to sponsor work for the dole programs. I asked my staff to ring and speak to a range of such organisations throughout Australia. We targeted urban and regional areas which had high levels of unemployment. The responses we received were both enlightening and interesting. A number of the organisations we spoke to said that they had not given much thought at all to providing jobs under this scheme. Others said that they would be willing to support the work for the dole program but they could not take on more than a few participants.

Out of the 10 organisations we spoke to in Maryborough, Queensland, several—including the RSL—could offer three positions, while one organisation could offer only two. Out of the 10 organisations, only three said that they could offer any training at all to work for the dole participants. A number of small and regional organisations we spoke to said they could not take on any participants at all, because they did not have the staff available to organise and supervise such a program. This was particularly the case in rural and regional areas.

Several community organisations said they would not be willing to participate in such a scheme, because they did not support the principles which underlie it, while several others said they could only employ people who already had formal qualifications. Interestingly, in one rural area in Victoria with a high unemployment rate—and, therefore, one of the target areas for this program—almost half the organisations we spoke to said they were sorry but they could not see the point of work for the dole programs in their area, because there simply were no real work opportunities in their region.

Another important issue was raised by the organisations we spoke to in the area of Logan in Queensland. Logan is an area on the outskirts of Brisbane which has little access to public transport. Several organisations said that making programs in the Logan area work would be very difficult because of these transport problems. The problem was not the cost of the transport but the simple unavailability of regular public transport. I wonder whether the government has even considered how this lack of public transport in many areas will impact on the success of their proposed work for the dole programs in those areas.

My research suggests that there are still a lot of aspects of this scheme which need to be considered and addressed. What sounds in theory easy and, indeed, appealing to many Australians—such as, `We will get 10,000 unemployed young Australians to work for the dole'—may in practice be a lot harder to set up. I am not saying that setting up a voluntary work for the dole scheme is a bad thing. In many ways, the Democrats are supportive of opportunities to give structure and purpose to the days of young unemployed Australians. But, as we all know, in the long term they need training and real jobs as well.

Unless the government can demonstrate how the mechanics of the scheme will work, I think its positive aspects and its positive reception will be severely undermined. The matter of asking the parliament to give this piece of legislation a big tick almost immediately is very improper. It is unacceptable to say, `This is the big picture first. This is the framework. Everybody supports us. Trust us. We'll fill in the details later.'

I want to have the details now. I believe the parliament has a right to see all the details now. We need to have confidence in all major aspects of the system we are being asked to pass as law before it becomes law and before we say, to however many Australians, `This is the way it is. Bad luck if the details are found out afterwards.' The government has a responsibility to provide those details now and not to seek a blank cheque for the rest. That is why I think this lack of detail is a great matter of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I had the particularly exciting experience of being present when the Treasurer, the Hon. Peter Costello, launched the AAP Mawson's Huts Foundation. The foundation has been established under the auspices of the AAP News Group to raise funds privately to help save Mawson's Huts in Antarctica.

SPEECH.PARA: This happens in a year that will be a particularly exciting and important one for Australia's Antarctic interests. In addition to the project launched last night to save Australia's most significant Antarctic heritage site, this year will also see the 50th anniversary of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition. In February of 1947 the government, with the help of Sir Douglas Mawson, established ANARE, the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition. In December of that same year, the first expedition landed on our sub‐Antarctic territory of Heard Island.

BREAK.PARA: In this year of celebration all those who have undertaken ANARE voyages over the last 50 years have been invited to participate in literally dozens of functions and reunions across Australia. As part of those celebrations, Australia's perhaps best known ANARE expeditioner in recent times, Tim Bowden, will release the ANARE jubilee history entitled The Silence Calling: Australians in the Antarctica 1947‐97. Any senator who enjoyed the ABC series will no doubt find this history fascinating.

This year will also see a significant re-evaluation of Australia's Antarctic direction. Australia's current Antarctic policy was effectively set during the Cold War at a time when territorial issues were of far greater significance than they are today. Much has changed since then. It is now time for the Australian government to review all aspects of its Antarctic program and to provide a strategy for the first part of the next millennium. Australia's territorial obligations are being examined. Air transport, along with other forms of Antarctic travel, is under review. Tourism and the role the private sector might play in the future need to be examined now.

In 1911 Sir Douglas Mawson recognised the importance to Australia and the rest of the world of Antarctic research. I suspect though that not even Mawson could have envisaged the level of importance that the world's scientific community would place upon Antarctic research into global climate change some 80 years on. The priorities of Australia's scientific research program are under review. We intend to build upon the reputation we have earned in the field of subzero research since Mawson's day.

This year, 1997, will as well be significant in that there is every expectation that the Madrid protocol—an agreement adopted by Australia and signed in 1993 and which will ensure greater levels of environmental protection for the Antarctic—will be ratified by the remaining non-signatory nations so far.

All of this makes for an exciting year and should see an increased awareness of Australia's leading and pioneering role in the Antarctic. The Australian government has long recognised the importance of Mawson's Huts to our nation's heritage. It is not only commendable but also appropriate that the private sector has taken the lead in conserving this significant part of our nation's history.

Sir Douglas Mawson was well aware of the role the private sector could play in the Antarctic. Indeed, his first and subsequent expeditions were partially funded by the private sector through donations in both cash and kind. I understand that much of the timber used to build Mawson's Huts was donated by the long‐established and well‐known Sydney timber supplier, Hudsons. The same tradition of private sector involvement was resurrected by the AAP group last night with the formation of the foundation.

Incidentally, the Commonwealth's contribution to the 1911 expedition was £2,000. It was indeed pleasing to hear from the Treasurer last night that the Treasury has become more generous in the last 80 years. Mr Costello was able to announce last night that legislation would shortly be introduced into the parliament to allow tax deduction for donations to this very worthwhile cause. We will be hoping that the Senate will support that legislation when it is brought to this chamber. As an aside, I mention that in 1911 the New South Wales government gave more than three times the Commonwealth's contribution. The foundation would be hoping that the current New South Wales government will be equally as generous.

This project to save Mawson's Huts will be our last opportunity. The Antarctic adventurers Don and Margie McIntyre spent a full year only metres away from Mawson's Huts. They readily testify to the fact that these huts are situated in what is recognised as the world's windiest region. It is nothing short of a miracle that the huts are still standing. Perhaps the resilience of the huts is rivalled only by that of Mawson himself. Recent assessments have indicated that only ice and snow hold the huts together. For obvious reasons, the huts cannot now be moved to Australia.

AAP has set itself a challenging task in organising, through this foundation, the restoration of Mawson's Huts. Needless to say, the government, by the good offices of the Australian Heritage Commission and the Australian Antarctic Division, fully supports the project.

To assist with the promotion of the AAP Mawson's Huts Foundation, a number of Mawson's Huts Foundation ambassadors have been appointed. These great Australasians have each demonstrated a particular affinity with either Mawson's Huts or with Australia's Antarctic territory.

It was my very great pleasure last night to announce that the following people had been appointed as Mawson's Huts Foundation ambassadors. They are the conqueror of Mount Everest, Sir Edmund Hillary, a charming and entertaining gentleman with whom I had the pleasure of dining last night; well‐known corporate identity and longstanding Mawson's Huts champion, Sir Peter Derham; the former director of the Australian Antarctic Division, Dr Phillip Law, under whose direction the first permanent Australian station in Antarctica was established; the well-known TV presenter and presenter of Breaking the Ice series and the author of The Silence Calling: Australians in Antarctica 1947‐1997, Mr Tim Bowden; and the Antarctic adventurers whom I mentioned previously, Don and Margie McIntyre.

On behalf of the Senate, and certainly on behalf of the government, I congratulate those ambassadors and thank them for their help and commitment in taking on this role of publicising the foundation and the fundraising of the foundation.

It is also important to publicly recognise the AAP group for the establishment of the foundation and the work they have done in that regard, and in particular to mention two senior executives of the AAP group, Mr David Jensen and Mr Greg Holland, who have been the driving forces in this significant initiative.

It would also be remiss of me if I did not mention Sir Peter Derham's contribution to the foundation. Sir Peter has long championed the saving of the huts. Without his energy and persistence, the foundation would not have become the reality it did last night.

Finally, I wish to place on record and recognise the contribution to the foundation by the Governor-General, His Excellency Sir William Deane, who made his contribution by his acceptance of the role of patron of that foundation. This foundation is one which I am sure all Australians will support because it is so important that the foundation's fundraising succeeds so that Australia can save that very significant part of our heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity in this debate on matters of public interest to make some comments about regional Australia. At mining sites in Western Australia about 8,000 people fly in and out each week. I believe that we should encourage, where possible, people to move their families and settle in regional Australia. The long‐term viability of their work and the benefit to the community justifies this commitment to decentralisation. By settling permanently, more work is created and a much needed boost is delivered to these transit towns and surrounding regions. There is more business for service industries, and bigger populations warrant more public spending and justify more infrastructure investment.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a substantial social benefit. These isolated communities have few full‐time members. A transitory population justifiably makes little investment in townships. The anthropologist Margaret Mead had it absolutely correct when she said that mobility is not helpful to building civilisation. If we want to engender community spirit and community benefit, we certainly do not do that by having a non-permanent population.

Residents of Sydney and Melbourne now account for 38.9 per cent of Australia's total population. In my own state of New South Wales, 61.9 per cent of the population lives in Sydney. The city is literally bursting at the seams and suffering the social and environmental consequences of its urban sprawl.

The depopulation of most rural and regional areas is one of the biggest tests we face in government. We need to do two things. We need to make changes which encourage people to move to regional areas and to implement policies which stop the flow of people out of them.

In our first year of government the coalition has made many changes which are already benefiting regional Australia.In the extremely difficult economic situation we inherited from the previous government, the diesel fuel rebate was retained. In late January the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced that it is not on the agenda for this year's pre‐budget deliberations. This rebate is crucial to the ongoing viability of the mining and agricultural sectors.

Just prior to Christmas, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson, secured $81.5 million to extend the drought relief payment scheme. This is on top of the $170 million delivered in drought assistance payments allocated in our first year of government—money which has made a great deal of difference to rural Australia and to the families who received that assistance.

Regional Australians will also benefit from a significant slice of the $803 million allocated in the Commonwealth roads program. More than 90 per cent of this money will be spent in regional areas; spending which is critical to continued regional development and exports. Safer regional roads are also a coalition priority. More than $140 million will be spent on the black spot road safety program over the next four years. At least half of that money will be spent in rural areas.

Regional tourism has also been a winner in our first year: $10 million has been allocated to the industry. That money has been used to help attract tourists, to encourage the balance between tourism and environmental protection, to build successful partnerships with indigenous people and to encourage developments with national relevance. There are also the changes to the export market development grants scheme which allows for tourist operators to access the help that the EMDG scheme provides.

To sustain the long‐term future of the environment and agriculture, we are about to embark on the most exciting environmental program in this country's history—that is, the $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust. It will see real investment for the benefit of all of us but especially for those in rural and regional areas, where thousands of committed volunteers in communities large and small are using local knowledge to identify and solve local problems such as soil erosion and salinity. The applications for the first round of grants under the Natural Heritage Trust close in early April and I encourage any community group that wishes to make an application to get it in before then.

Telecommunications is another area where much progress has already been made. Increased competition will lead to better services and lower costs. Upgraded telephone exchanges will provide benefits such as faster faxes, better mobile phone reception, faster EFTPOS services for business and faster access to the Internet. Price caps will be put in place and those in rural areas will benefit from cross‐subsidisation and a new $250 million fund to help bring communications in rural areas up to capital city standards. These examples represent part of what we have done, but we propose to do more.

The reason that more people are not moving to rural and remote areas is that we are not providing the incentive for them to move. Some of these incentives are not expensive and, anyway, on any cost‐benefit analysis they are attractive. Let us take fringe benefits tax on remote housing as an example. In the lead‐up to the 1996 election, we committed ourselves to removing the fringe benefits tax from the housing supplied by primary producers for their workers. This was implemented in our first budget and the new ruling takes effect on 1 April. Although it will cost $10 million in the first year, this 100 per cent concession is exactly the kind of support this sector needs.

The fringe benefits tax still applies to remote area housing in mining and other isolated communities. In towns such as Kalgoorlie and Nhulunbuy in the Northern Territory this fringe benefits tax still applies. In the Burke shire in the north‐west of Queensland, and similar remote regions, it has been estimated that building costs are 90 per cent above Brisbane building prices. Dwell ings have to be built to withstand natural disasters, using materials attracting expensive freight costs.

The problem is compounded in the following scenario: an employer wants to attract skilled, well‐trained staff such as a chef or specialist tour guide but to house this employee and their family would cost thousands of dollars. A three‐bedroom house built especially for them has a negligible market value on completion. When calculating the fringe benefits tax payable on a dwelling, the owner must also take into consideration any free or subsidised domestic electricity, gas or oil which is provided for or paid on behalf of the employee occupying that dwelling. It is asking a lot of an employer to provide housing and then pay FBT on top of the cost. It is practically prohibitive. I believe the application of fringe benefits tax in this instance is a potential area for review.

The zonal tax rebate is another measure which needs review. For these purposes, Australia is divided into two zones, A and B, and the rebate is paid on varying scales according to where you live. In the Australian master tax guide, zone A comprises those areas where the factors of isolation, uncongenial climate and the high cost of living are more pronounced. Zone B comprises less badly affected areas. In addition, certain particularly isolated areas are classified as special areas of zones A and B.

The Commissioner of Taxation draws up a list of eligible towns falling in the special areas and they are generally more than 250 kilometres, by the shortest practical surface route, from the nearest urban centre with a 1981 census figure of 2,500 or more people. A taxpayer who is a resident of these special areas of zones A and B is eligible for $1,173, plus 50 per cent of the relevant rebate amount. A resident of zone A is eligible for $338 per year, plus 50 per cent of the relevant rebate amount. A resident of zone B is entitled to $57 per year, plus 20 per cent of the relevant rebate amount. If we want a zonal tax rebate system to be effective, we have to be a bit more generous than those figures.

We need policies that will make it possible for people to feel that we have a commitment to decentralisation. We need to promote investment in remote areas, with a subsequent increase in employment for both whites and indigenous Australians. We must also use the existing infrastructure we have and provide more. We must have policies that compensate in some way for the isolation experienced by many people who live in these out‐of‐the‐way places in regional Australia which are, by contemporary standards, very inhospitable. We must have policies which provide an incentive for people to populate the remote and regional areas of Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said that a `great goal of the government is a sustainable future for rural and regional Australia'. There is much more to be done if this aim is to be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about a matter of public interest—the future of Radio Australia. On 13 February this year, the Senate determined that the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee should conduct an inquiry into the role and future of Radio Australia and Australia Television. In particular, the terms of reference of that inquiry were directed to considering the contribution made by Radio Australia and Australia Television to Australia's foreign policy and trade interests, particularly in the Asia‐Pacific region.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference were also directed to looking at the activities of similar foreign broadcast services in the region and most importantly, I would suggest, looking at the consequences if Radio Australia and/or Australia Television were to be closed. That Senate reference was carried by the Senate without objection from any senator or any party or group represented herein.

The committee has expeditiously commenced its inquiry. I am advised that it has already received around 800 submissions from people and groups both in Australia and overseas. The committee had the opportunity last week to visit the headquarters of Radio Australia in Melbourne and Australia Television in Sydney, and to commence taking evidence at public hearing. As I have indicat ed previously in the Senate, the committee anticipates, and is certainly working towards, completing its inquiry and tabling a report and any recommendations by early May.

The inquiry arose out of the Mansfield report. That report, as is well known, was commissioned by the government into the broad range of ABC services. The government commissioned it last year, after it had announced that funding for the ABC would be cut by some $55 million per year, and the report was conducted by Bob Mansfield.

As is well known and has been discussed and debated quite widely throughout the community and in the media—and, I might say, extensively within our region—Bob Mansfield recommended that the ABC should be released from its requirement to operate international broadcasting services and be permitted to direct the resulting savings to its core business of domestic broadcast. I am here quoting from page 6 of Mr Mansfield's report. At page 41 of his report, where he dealt with the subject of international broadcasters, Mr Mansfield made it very clear that his recommendations with respect to Radio Australia and Australia Television resulted from the bottom line financial position that the ABC had been placed in. He went on to particularly acknowledge that he had not looked at the foreign policy dimension. In the report, he said:

I accept that the question of future overseas broadcasting activities has a foreign policy dimension. In its submission, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) considered the review should take account of `the significant role the ABC's International services play in advancing Australia's trade and diplomatic objectives'.
Mr Mansfield then went on to say:
I have some difficulty in identifying the extent to which the ABC plays such a role and, if it does, the extent to which it is effective in doing so.

Further down page 41 of his report, after referring to the particular arrangements that exist in the BBC World Service, where they have an agreement with the corresponding department of the government over there, he went on to say:
In the absence of such agreement—
that is, such an agreement applying with respect to the ABC and DFAT—
concerning objectives and priorities, it is difficult to evaluate the effectiveness of funding or to revise priorities for overseas broadcasting services, particularly for RA.
On page 42 of his report he went on to discuss very briefly what the estimated audience of Radio Australia was. Very importantly, he then said:
For an investment of more than $20 million a year, I consider the Government should be in a position to determine whether:
. the service is reaching its target audience;
. the type and mix of programming remains valid; and
. shortwave remains the most cost‐effective means of delivery.
On the basis of the limited evidence put before the review, I consider that there is insufficient evidence for the Government to draw firm conclusions in any of these areas.

Mr Mansfield, in making his recommendation that Radio Australia and ATV could be dispensed with, closed down, sold off or whatever, was clearly acknowledging that he was not considering any of the foreign policy or trade implications and that he certainly was not considering what was happening with international broadcasting around the world and particularly in our region. The fact of the matter is that Mr Mansfield simply did not have the time to consider in any detail those issues. Moreover, and more importantly, Mr Mansfield acknowledged that it was not part of his brief, and I will come to that shortly.

As I said, arising out of the public outcry, debate and discussion that occurred following Mr Mansfield's recommendations, I moved in the Senate, and the Senate agreed, that it would be appropriate for the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee to undertake an investigation of these issues, to seek out information as to, for instance, the audience reach, the importance of short‐wave technology, and the importance of continuing with international broadcasting in the region and the impact of that upon our foreign policy and trade objectives. As I said, the Senate committee is undertaking that process and it will, I am sure, be able to provide to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) and to the government the information upon which it and the ABC can make a properly considered decision about whether Radio Australia continues to exist and how it should be funded.

I make these comments because it is of great concern to me—and it should be of concern to the Senate and the parliament—that the minister is treating the committee and the parliament with contempt, in my view, and is pushing on headlong with his own view that Radio Australia should be gutted and ATV should be sold off.

I point firstly to an interview that the minister gave on 28 February when he was interviewed on the Radio National breakfast program. I quote from a transcript of that interview. In response to a question from Julie Posetti who asked him about the Senate inquiry, Senator Alston said:

I think it's fair to say that Cabinet will consider the issue on its merits and, to the extent that it believes that Australia should retain a presence in some form, then it would obviously have to look at how that ought to be funded. Now, to date, I think Mansfield's made a pretty powerful case. There's been a lot of emotive reaction to it but I haven't seen any sort of in‐depth analysis that demonstrates either the effectiveness of the service or a significant demand for it. There may well be that evidence, but you would have expected it to have been put before Mansfield, and it wasn't, and Radio Australia has obviously had every opportunity to mount their case.
That is a gross distortion of the truth. It is nothing more than misinformation being peddled out in the public arena to try and discredit the inquiry and to discredit Radio Australia.

The minister, in that interview, was stating that Radio Australia had been given every opportunity to put its position on these very important issues. That is simply untrue. Mr Mansfield himself was questioned about this issue in an interview, also on Radio National, on Wednesday, 26 February. I quote from the transcript of that interview, where Mr Mansfield said:
If you look at my terms of reference, I only had to look at the ABC. I didn't have the task and wasn't asked to look at Australia's foreign policy.
Further on in the interview, the reporter David Spicer said:
Two weeks ago, a Senate inquiry was announced into the future of Radio Australia and Australia Television. Bob Mansfield says it's a good move.
Then they cut to a comment by Bob Mansfield who said:
I just didn't have the instruction to take into account the foreign affairs implications. And I think the Government in appointing the Senate committee—
note the slip: the `government' in appointing the Senate committee—
to look into it, wants that looked into, and I have no problem with that.
He was then asked by David Spicer:
If you did have that foreign affairs input, would you perhaps have couched it differently?
Bob Mansfield replied:
Without looking at it, I can't give you that answer.
David Spicer then said:
But do you have a view, though, on the foreign affairs implications of axing Radio Australia?
Bob Mansfield said:
Without looking at the fact, I don't have. I mean, I'm just not informed of it.
David Spicer asked:
If Radio Australia stays, if the foreign affairs argument wins, where should the ABC make their cuts then?
Bob Mansfield replied:
Well, that's for management and the board to look at. That wasn't part of my task.

That is completely contrary to the misinformation being peddled by the minister when he was endeavouring to suggest that Bob Mansfield was looking at this issue and that Radio Australia had an opportunity to put its views.

Then what do we come to? We come to an interview on Meet the Press last Sunday. The issue was raised on the program by Piers Akerman when he asked Richard Alston, the minister, if the government believed that Radio Australia and Australia Television should survive? The transcript shows the minister said:

Well, again, Mansfield's view was that ATV ought to be sold off, and that's been our view, subject to retention of news and current affairs arrangements, and he says that if we can't do that by 30 June, then we ought to close the service down.

I might interpose here and point out that that was not Senator Alston's view when he chaired the Senate select committee looking at the operations of the ABC only two years ago. At that time, he said that ATV should continue to exist and should, if it could not turn a profit, be funded by separate budgetary allocation. But we now know that either he did not really subscribe to that view or he has radically changed his mind. The minister further said:

Now, it is out to tender at the moment. We've had something like 30 expressions of interest and, as I understand it, the ABC is progressing those arrangements. As far as Radio Australia is concerned, Mansfield identified that it was a declining technology—short wave is of dramatically less significance in this day and age—and even Foreign Affairs has very serious question marks about the effectiveness of the service.

That is another total distortion of the facts. As was clearly identified in today's Sydney Morning Herald , and in evidence given to the Senate committee last week by Mr Michael Bird, there is in fact an increase of investment being undertaken into short‐wave transmission. The article in today's Sydney Morning Herald quotes Mr Nigel Holmes, Radio Australia's transmission manager, and identifies the fact that various international broadcasters—the Voice of America, the BBC World Service, Deutsche Welle, the German overseas broadcast service, Radio Japan and Radio Free Asia—are all putting increased investment into short‐wave transmission. Mr Holmes said:
Shortwave is still the number‐one medium for international broadcasting in the region.
I do not know who these nameless, faceless people are who are advising Senator Alston that short wave is dead but they are quite wrong.

It should be of great concern to the Senate that here we have a minister peddling misinformation and distorting the facts out there in the public arena at the same time as we have a Senate committee in the process of gathering that information. That committee will be in a position to report to the parliament and to the government by early May—that is, before the budget is handed down. It is also the fact that this minister is determined to gut Radio Australia and ATV. That is clearly what he has in store when the government Expenditure Review Committee looks at the issue next week. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, I refer to your criticism on radio of the DSS teleservice on 28 February when you gave the figure of 400,000 calls received in one day in January. You said: `People are being driven mad trying to get through.' Could these calls have something to do with the fiasco which resulted in 36,700 duplicate and triplicate concession cards and 98,000 other cards being sent late? Could the inordinate number of phone calls in January, leading to 40‐minute delays, have had something to do with the changes to superannuation for over‐55s and the scrapping of the minimum payment for the youth training allowance on 1 January? Minister, isn't it true that the problems with the teleservice were directly related to decisions taken by your government and the bungles over which you presided? Why weren't you honest with the listeners to 5AA in Adelaide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very nice of Senator Mackay to ask me that question. One of the reasons that there has always been a problem ever since the Labor government introduced the teleservice system is that there is a massive increase in review activity over the summer period with families' incomes and payments et cetera having to be reviewed. That is one of the major drivers of business on the teleservice lines. Even more importantly than that perhaps is the fact that when the teleservice system was set up it was set up with inadequate research and funding, and insufficient people. That is the reason why a few weeks ago I announced a major exercise of investment in people and equipment that will improve the teleservice system so that we can offer better service to our customers.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not at any time suggested that it is going to make it so that you can immediately get through, because the service has proved to be enormously popular. That is the reason for so many callers trying to get through and keeping on trying to get through. The 400,000 unsuccessful calls in a day are, very largely, people picking the phone up and putting it down, and picking it up and putting it down and keeping on trying. Nevertheless, it is an unsatisfactory service that we are currently providing; nobody is pretending differently. We are determined to improve it. I cannot give guarantees to people that they are going to get through on the first call but by the end of this year I would expect our customers to be seeing a considerable improvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I take it from your response that you have asked the department for a report in relation to this matter of the overload on the teleservice. If that is the case, could you table that report, please?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting regular briefs from my department when they do things that might concern the customers—as I would have expected my predecessors in this job to have done; it is only responsible. One of the continuing banes of my life in the last 12 months is the mess that we inherited from the previous government in terms of teleservice centres and the service, or lack thereof. So the department has—
—So that's the biggest problem you have, is it?

—Perhaps you would not understand the problems of regional Australia, Senator Collins. I would have thought that because you represent the Northern Territory you would have a real concern that people who cannot get to a Social Security office do need to use the telephone. People with small children need access by the telephone; people with disabilities and the aged need to use the telephone. If we can provide an efficient service then that is what we are going to try to do. Your government did not seem to bother; you did not put any priority—

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It concerns the Howard government's proposed work for the dole scheme, which is attracting a high level of support within the community. Is he aware of a recent survey which showed that two‐thirds of senior school students backed the concept of work for the dole? How does this level of support contrast with the views of other sections of the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President. We are facing now so many indications of an improving economy and a strengthening opportunity for employment.
—Increased youth unemployment.
—I will remind you of a few if you doubt it.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to say that it is absolutely important that young people get a fair go in that improvement, Senator Collins. The Australian Institute of Company Directors shows 70 per cent of directors believe that growth will pick up over the course of this year; the Westpac‐Melbourne Institute consumer survey said that consumer confidence has risen 4.9 per cent in March. These are good news. Company profits are up 17 per cent in December—greater capacity to employ; retail trade is up 2.7 per cent in January; and business investment rose 0.6 per cent in December.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Housing figures, which have just come out—you may have missed them, Senator Faulkner—show a jump of 5.9 per cent in housing starts. Did you read the Australian Financial Review this morning? It said that Australia's housing industry turned the corner and is now well on the road to recovery. ANZ job vacancies rose by 1.8 per cent in February, and so I could go on.

BREAK.PARA: These are all signs of a strengthening economy, Senator Coonan, but what is important is that young Australians, those who suffered so much under the previous Labor government, are given a fair opportunity. That is why this coalition government has introduced a range of initiatives particularly to try to get young Australians out of the spiral of depression into which so many have fallen. One of the schemes is the work for the dole scheme. It is heartening that it has been embraced so enthusiastically by young people. It really does tell you something when we find in one survey that 65 per cent of young people said that they were in favour; in other words, they said it would be a good idea if young people who were unemployed were contributing to the cost of their dole by taking some form of employment—65 per cent for; 29 per cent against. Young people believe that the Howard government is heading in the right direction in this.

Where is Labor on this issue? It is all over the shop as it is on so many issues. What did Senator Faulkner say when he was first asked about it? He said that work for the dole is nothing more than `poll‐driven tokenism'. That is not what the young people say. The young people are looking to the future a bit more positively. What did Mr Crean then say? Contrary to Senator Faulkner, he said:
Labor supported and initiated a work for the dole scheme, but we didn't call it that. It was a concept that we called reciprocal obligation.

Mr Ferguson, the shadow minister for employment, had a different point of view again. He said that work for the dole belted dole bludgers. Former Senator McMullan, now Mr McMullan, is trying to get a bit each way. He said:
We'll improve it as much as we can but we will not stand in the way of it.

Mr Beazley, the leader, read the poll in the Bulletin today which shows Labor has fallen four points below its poll in the last election and 65 per cent of young people have said they want this proposal to work for the dole. So what does Mr Beazley say? He says it should be extended. So finally it seems that Labor are not only on board but they are urging us to go further. It has taken them a while but at last they are catching up with the sentiment of young Australians and that sentiment clearly is that the Howard government is heading in the right direction.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and relates to the place of enterprise bargaining in the Australian industrial relations system.
