But, of course, they are fundamentally wrong, because they will discover that once again the voters will say that the opposition do not believe in anything but themselves. The voters will agree with what Gary Grey had to say a few months ago when he talked about those opposite being a mob of liars.

BREAK.PARA: They know all about having a credibility problem. This will be a very painful exercise for them, a compound fracture of the credibility zone. They will find that it will all come back to haunt them. The voters thought those opposite were liars and that they had a poor record. What has changed? Brereton is still there; McMullan is still there. Look at that front bench. Most of them are still there because there is no-one else of any credibility to replace them.

The problem is that these were the blokes who sat there when all their spokesmen on IR went out and told us how enterprise bargaining was the best thing since sliced bread. Not a whimper. They did not rush back to caucus to try to have a factional revolt on the subject. No, they were all locked in; they thought it was great stuff. What do we find now? They see the polls and they say to themselves, `We are in enormous trouble. We've got to do something. We've got to anything.' They then rip up the last remaining shred of credibility.

The workers know that this will consign them to high unemployment, a very uncompetitive workplace. They know that the international marketplace requires this sort of reform. Those opposite were committed to it—or so we thought. Now they say they are not, and we still do not know whether they believe that or not. The fact is it will come back to haunt them. They will discover that these sorts of backflips are very painful indeed. This is much more worse than Greg Luganis. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, I think you referred to two members of the other place incorrectly and I would urge you to refer to them correctly in future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the confusion in this area demonstrate quite clearly the accuracy of George Campbell's statement about the Labor Party? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: I don't think the party knows or has a clear perception of what it stands for or, more importantly, what it wants to achieve in terms of the development of our society.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane is absolutely right. They do not know whether they are Arthur, Martha or General MacAr thur. The real joke was contained in the accord mark 8 less than two years ago when it said that the accord parties were `strongly committed to the extension of enterprise bargaining'. If you lot opposite are going to get your instructions, you ought to go somewhere other then having a few beers at John Curtin and thinking that that is the way you devise policy. That will not get you anywhere. The public understand it. The workers know it. That is why they deserted you in droves at the last election. They expect you to come up with something that is in their interests.

ANSWER.PARA: They know that enterprise bargaining provides them with the opportunity to get flexibility in the system and to get productivity improvements. But, no, all you want to do is give it back to your mates so that you can play the same old power games that are getting you nowhere. You are going backwards. You ought to realise that, come the next election, you will be in the spotlight and you will be found absolutely wanting. If you think that is a good way to spend the rest of your lives, if you want to spend all your time mixing with your trade union mates, that is fine. But the public will not have a bar of it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. I refer to the statement in the House yesterday of the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel that her disclosure of compensation and superannuation payments made to Mrs Berrigan, the widow of one of the Black Hawk disaster victims, did not constitute a breach of the Privacy Act. Can the minister please inform the Senate under which provision of privacy principle 11, as contained in section 15 of the Privacy Act 1988, Mrs Bishop acted in disclosing the information. In doing so, can the minister confirm that, one, information of this type is not ordinarily disclosed; two, Mrs Berrigan did not consent to the disclosure; three, there was no serious and imminent threat to the life or health of Mrs Berrigan; four, the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority annual report states that such information can only be disclosed pursuant to the Privacy Act 1988; and, five, no criminal, pecuniary penalty or public revenue protection proceedings were being contemplated in this case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that the senator did not expect to get an answer to a detailed question which is outside my portfolio area. Anybody who is serious about asking such a detailed question would either put it on notice or advise me ahead of time if they really wanted an answer. I am very happy to take that question to the minister responsible, Mrs Bishop, and get the detailed information for you. Unfortunately, it means that you will not get it today, Senator, and I am sorry for that. If you had shown more courtesy or good sense, we would have got it.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thought this was questions without notice. I thought this was current and relevant—
—We're not terribly interested in your thoughts.
—You do not have any, so what is the worry?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: VANSTONE

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on a point of order:

INTERJECT.PARA: I think you should ask Senator West whether she is being honest. I bet she does not want to answer the question, `Did you ever ask a dixer in your life?' You know this is not always questions without notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order.

—Madam President, on a further point of order: yesterday you lectured senators about behaviour in question time. When a cabinet minister, such as the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, stands to take a deliberately spurious point of order in an attempt to protect another cabinet minister, Senator Newman, who is unable to answer a question without notice, as is the pattern and her pattern in this chamber, I believe you should rule that Senator Vanstone is engaging in a deliberate abuse of your ruling and of question time. She is clearly out of order. She should not be recognised and should be disciplined by the chair for abusing your ruling.

—Order! There is no point of order. I had ruled Senator Vanstone not to have had a point of order, neither do you. My comments yesterday I would put into the category of observations about question time. If I give a lecture on question time, it will be quite different.

—Minister, this is an issue that is current. Is it true that under the government's proposed superannuation tax persons such as Mrs Berrigan could be liable to pay that tax on the superannuation component of their payment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, that is a fresh question altogether. It is not supplementary to the question that was asked and therefore is not justified as a question. I am not representing the minister for superannuation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to a report in today's Herald‐Sun which says that the work for the dole legislation, to be introduced into the House shortly, will in effect implement a permanent scheme for all unemployed Australians, not just a trial scheme for 10,000 young unemployed as we were first told. Is this exclusive report accurate and, if so, is there not something wrong with having the verdict first and the evidence afterwards? Is the government not becoming a bit prone to asking us to tick the big picture first and simply take the details on trust for later, the latest example being some really important details of the people's convention legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for her question. Senator, I have not seen the report you refer to. You can wave it around, but I do not have bionic vision—I cannot possibly read it from here. Nonetheless, the question you ask is answerable in this way: that is, what the government has decided to do is to have about 70 projects providing about 10,000 places divided into two groups of 5,000.

BREAK.PARA: As we understand it, in order to implement that range of pilot projects, Senator, it is necessary to have legislative approval. Therefore, it is appropriate to seek that approval, and, if those pilots work out to be effective, to continue on the basis of the approval already given. I think you are misstating the case when you say that you are being asked to tick the big picture.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are.

—You obviously believe that, but I have a different view. You are being asked to approve the mechanisms which would allow the government to proceed with its announced plans to have about 70 pilot projects of about 10,000 places, giving young Australians the opportunity to contribute to their community and to demonstrate that it is a fair thing to ask someone to give something back in return for the safety net that is provided.

BREAK.PARA: That is what you are being asked to do. If you do not want to do it, that is up to the Democrats party room when it meets in a slightly large phone box. As I understand the comments you have made thus far, you are interested in looking at the scheme and working with us on the development of it. We would be happy to listen to the concerns that you want to raise.

We have made it abundantly clear that we want to proceed with this. We want those 70 pilot projects. We want about 10,000 places. We will need legislative approval for that and we will be coming to parliament to get that approval. If it follows that those projects are as successful as many people believe and hope they will be, naturally we will look to extend the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, my concern is: why is there no sunset clause, if all you want to do is have some trial projects and then evaluate them? Is it not true that, without a sunset clause, you have no evaluation at all and so all the rhetoric about this being a trial becomes irrelevant? On a matter of process and principle, don't you think parliament does have a right to evaluate and monitor the trial of 10,000 young unemployed Australians in your scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, if there is a sunset clause in any section of legislation, then those portions come to an end when the sunset expires, and it follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you have asked the question. I am giving you the answer. It follows—anyone would be able to tell you this—that, if it had a sunset clause, a government would have to come back and seek parliament's approval again. That may be a mechanism that you would seek to have the government include and you are welcome to raise that.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, have you been made aware of Senator Alston's comments on the Meet the Press program on Sunday when he was asked whether he had discussed Norfolk Island with Senator Colston in the context of his negotiations about the deputy presidency? Is it a fact that Senator Alston replied, `Well, as I say, only—I can't recall. But it would only have been in the context of that sort of ancient history.' Senator Hill, can you recall? Was the matter broached, and if so, in what context?

—I did not see the program. I have not seen the transcript. I have not discussed it with Senator Alston. If you are asking me whether I have had any discussions with Senator Colston on Norfolk Island, the answer is no.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Hill, will you now given an undertaking to put on the public record the details of the discussions which you had with Senator Colston before agreeing to coalition support for his bid for the deputy presidency?
—As we have said before, there were no conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Minister, in answer to my question yesterday on manufacturing job losses you said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the whole thrust of our economic program, from all economic ministers in this government, is the creation of jobs—the creation of real jobs.

I emphasise `real' jobs, Minister. Can the minister indicate what immediate steps the government is taking to produce real, full‐time, value‐adding jobs in the manufacturing sector? The Prime Minister said that his performance should be judged after a year. It is time, then, to start judgment. So far the score of jobs in the manufacturing sector is one of 55,200 jobs lost. Minister Moore had a pre‐election target of the creation of 200,000 jobs in manufacturing. Apart from cutting $5 billion in assistance and hammering away at tariffs, what are you going to do about creating real, full‐time manufacturing jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murray for that question. I would also like to congratulate him—as I did previously—on his interest in the business sector, which is very rare on the Democrats side. The point I made previously is that the only Democrat I can recall raising issues such as this was the former Senator Siddons. The disappointing thing about Senator Murray is that he reminds me of the old story of the pessimist and the optimist. The pessimist looks at a bottle of beer and says that it is half empty; the optimist looks at it and says that it is half full. There is a difference. Senator, you are always looking for the bad points.

ANSWER.PARA: You asked what we are doing to create real jobs. The only way you can create real jobs is through the private sector. I think any sensible person would agree with that. Only real jobs can be created either through, or financed by, the private sector.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned, the real jobs are created basically in the private sector.
—Basically! That keeps you on the payroll.

—And if they are not created there, the funding for other jobs certainly comes from investments in that area. The way we have to improve the employment position is to create an investment climate which is conducive to people investing in wealth creating industries. This is what we have gone about from day one. We have worked at creating that investment climate. It is no good throwing money at things, as the previous government did, running up big consultancy bills, doing a range of things like that, but with no jobs at the end.

ANSWER.PARA: We have concentrated on those things which will attract investment into real jobs. One of the things we have addressed—as I mentioned yesterday in response to you, Senator—is lowering interest rates. That is a major factor in all sectors of the business community, whether they be small, medium or large.

We have also created an environment which is conducive to investment. Another factor that actually destroyed jobs under the previous government was Mr Brereton's stupid industrial relations laws. We have amended those industrial relations laws so that we now have a private sector which can go out and employ people and not face the wrongful dismissal clauses which do not help to create jobs.

The other point I would like to make is that indicators—and you will be pleased to hear this Senator Murray because of your interest in this—for the manufacturing industry are pointing towards a pick up in 1997. Recent housing finance and building approvals data suggests that dwelling investments will strengthen in 1997 and strong growth in retail sales in January 1997 combined with improved consumer confidence point to increased consumer demand. Restructuring in the manufacturing industry is also helping the industry become more internationally competitive with continuing strong export growth of 10.5 per cent in the last 12 months. The government's policies of responsible macro-economic management and continued micro-economic reform will further improve the outlook for manufacturing industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am aware of some positive indicators, but there are now fewer full‐time jobs in the economy than there were a year ago. Virtually all new jobs are part time or casual. After losing 55,200 jobs in manufacturing in the first year of coalition government will you now be raising your target from 200,000 manufacturing jobs to 255,200 manufacturing jobs?
—I mentioned yesterday in response to a question from Senator Murray that the whole thrust of the coalition government's economic policy was the creation of jobs. I also alerted you to the fact—
—It's no good talking about it; what are you going to do?

—Senator Woodley says that it is no good talking about it. Go and have a look at the Democrat policies. I think you have a policy, Senator, to get rid of the diesel fuel rebate for mining. If you want to destroy an industry that contributes $38 billion to our export income then go down that track. It is not just the mining factor per se that will be affected, it is the spin-off and multiplier effects that come from those industries as well. I mentioned to Senator Murray yesterday—and I know he is very much aware of this because of his interest in this particular industry in Western Australia—that it is those industries that provide the subsidiary jobs, the peripheral jobs, that are so important to the community.

—My question is directed to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, do you recall now what you were unable to recall on the Meet the Press program on Sunday which was whether or not Senator Colston's interest in the position of administrator of Norfolk Island was raised or discussed in the course of your negotiations with him about the deputy presidency? Were these matters raised in those negotiations or in any subsequent negotiations? If you were unable to recall on Sunday, why did you go on to say that `if it was discussed, it would only have been in the context of ancient history'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts of the matter are that there were no so-called negotiations in the lead‐up to Senator Colston's election to the position of Deputy President. I have no doubt that Senator Colston had discussions with a number of people on this side of the chamber and I was one of them. I can certainly recall at some stage discussing with him what I had previously read in the newspapers about how Labor had ratted on him in relation to the prospective appointment to Norfolk Island. I think Senator Faulkner was actually the one who was in a position to make that appointment.
—Did you offer to make good?
—Certainly not.
—And I would not appoint him because he was unappointable.

—I see. I am not in a position to pass judgment on the facts of the matter but, as I read that newspaper article, he was led to believe by people with such enormously glowing reputations as Ros Kelly and Graham Richardson that he had every reason to expect that he might be appointed to Norfolk Island. Whether it was you who ratted on him or someone else is a matter for your side of the chamber to explain. Certainly it was not in any shape or form part of any discussions that we had that might have led up to his election to Deputy President, it was more a reminiscence about how he had been treated by his erstwhile colleagues.

ANSWER.PARA: I had a great deal of sympathy for him because it seemed to me that if indeed those sorts of promises had been made, consistent with the way the Labor Party likes to put in the fix wherever possible, you would have thought they would deliver the goods. It is one thing to say, as Senator Faulkner now likes to do in a particularly sanctimonious manner, `I would never have done it,' but the facts seem to be that, if others were prepared to do it and Senator Colston was led to believe that he might be appointed to that position, I can understand his chagrin at being disappointed in the manner in which he reportedly was. That is as far as the discussions went. I regret that I am unable to assist you any further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Was Senator Hill present at the meetings with Senator Colston where these reminiscences took place? In an earlier answer to a supplementary question I asked, Senator Hill commented that there were no conditions. That was in answer to my request for an undertaking to put on the public record the details—not the conditions—of discussions that he had with Senator Colston. I now ask you, Senator Alston, to place on the public record the details of discussions that you had with Senator Colston before agreeing to coalition support for Senator Colston as Deputy President of the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —This really is desperate stuff. This is not going to get you very far back on the road to government. You have a long way to go. You certainly will not strike any gold if you take this line. There is a bit of a logical difficulty in the first place because you addressed me to remarks I made in the context of not even being able to remember whether I had a discussion about Senator Colston's treatment at the hands of the Labor Party in relation to Norfolk Island but, because I say I do not recall whether those discussions about Norfolk Island even occurred before the vote, you then say, `Was Senator Hill there?' It is a preposterous gap in logic, the biggest non sequitur in history.

ANSWER.PARA: How could Senator Hill have been at something which I cannot even be sure took place prior to that time? Senator Hill speaks for himself. I will speak for myself. There were no deals done. I did not take notes of any discussions that I had with Senator Colston. I would be very surprised if anyone else did either. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister inform the Senate of the progress of the government's Green Corps initiative and the diversity of projects and the benefits that will accrue to the environment and young Australians from Green Corps?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. I am very pleased to be able to inform the Senate that the first 24 Green Corps projects are now up and running. The breadth of the programs is a highlight of the initiative.

ANSWER.PARA: Individual projects range from, for example, the transformation of Penguin Island in Western Australia into a unique native conservation reserve by removing buildings and putting in place a revegetation program which will provide nesting areas for the local penguin colonies and other sea birds to the construction of a walking track along the Roper River at Mataranka in the Elsey National Park in the Northern Territory. In that project, there is also a component of soil conservation work. In my own state, the Naracoorte Caves will benefit from rehabilitation and protection of natural vegetation and the restoration of the limestone caves themselves, all associated with the world heritage listing of that site.

These projects that I have mentioned represent only a few of the worthwhile environmental measures that Green Corps will foster. Just as importantly, the projects will provide young Australians with quality accredited training with strong links to our great natural heritage. I also suggest that the projects themselves will be a great personal experience for the participants. Some of the projects, such as the Roper River project I spoke of, will involve participants residing on the site for up to two weeks at a time.

This government is about providing opportunities for young people, unlike the previous government, to participate in our affirmation of the importance of the environment. Our commitment to the environment is well manifested in projects such as the Green Corps and the establishment of the Natural Heritage Trust.

Our approach could not be more different from the very bitter and divisive approach to the portfolio that was shown by the current Leader of the Opposition in this place, Senator Faulkner. When he was not getting touched up by David Beddall, he was either getting it wrong or being rolled in his environmental matters. I think former Senator Richardson used to call him the `Minister For Getting Rolled'. Senator Alston is very kindly looking for the headline. He thinks he has still got it, the `Minister For Getting Rolled'.

BREAK.PARA: It is amazing that, despite such a record, it is people like Senator Faulkner and his factional ally, Senator Carr, who scream the loudest whenever this government announces a program and policies that are going to provide benefits for the community. When you look across and see Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr, you have to conclude that, if ever there were a Beavis sitting over there and a Butt‐head sitting over there, it would be those two—absolutely for sure. They are the Beavis and Butt‐head of the Senate.

Do not forget, this is the same Senator Faulkner who used to get bullied by Senator Richardson when he was here, even after Senator Richardson retired. I understand that on the night of the 1995 New South Wales state election, in the middle of his then disastrous performance on woodchips, he was pleading with Graham Richardson, according to Bob Ellis, as if for his job, exclaiming out of the office, `But I'm a good environment minister.' How could he claim that in the middle of his woodchip debacle when he was being rolled by Beddall? What a joke! This is the same minister who is well known for commencing his cabinet remarks with, `I know I'm going to get rolled. I know I'm going to get rolled.'

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Second Sydney Airport Relocation of Lucas Heights Reactor

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Can the minister confirm that Mr Lachlan McComish, adviser to Mr Sharp, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, met with a staff member of the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr McGauran, and that at that meeting Mr McComish indicated that the Badgerys Creek site was dead as a viable option for the second Sydney airport and that Holsworthy would be selected as the preferred site? Can the minister also confirm that the proposal to relocate the Lucas Heights reactor was also discussed at such meeting and that the government believes there would be political advantages in making the relocation of the Lucas Heights facility part of the Holsworthy airport package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really speaking on behalf of Mr Sharp in saying that he has been advised by the Minister for Science and Technology that the document referred to in media reports is an internal memorandum dated 15 June 1996, a document with no official government status and can at best be described as rejected advice from his then Chief of Staff, Dr Michael Selley. It is in no sense a current document.

ANSWER.PARA: Any document that proposes the location of a nuclear reactor at Jervis Bay is based on a ridiculous premise from the outset. Mr McGauran rejected the proposal outright and so did Mr Sharp. Dr Selley informally discussed the government's position regarding the second Sydney airport with an adviser from Mr Sharp's office. He was informed of cabinet's decision to broaden the environmental impact statement to include the Holsworthy site as an insurance since the conditions at Badgerys Creek had changed in the 10 years since the site selection had been made.

In a media release of 20 May 1996, Mr Sharp had announced that the EIS process would now be broadened to include an alternative site—the Holsworthy military reserve in Sydney's south-west. This would ensure a fall‐back option would be immediately available if the Badgerys Creek EIS proved unfavourable. Furthermore, the government was determined to avoid a repeat of the noise problems associated with Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek where significant urban encroachment has occurred over the past 10 years.

Mr Sharp's adviser was clearly misunderstood by Dr Selley, who has distorted and misrepresented the position as a result. Other views canvassed in Dr Selley's memorandum reflect his own views, views that Mr Sharp has advised are not shared by his minister. They are not views that Mr Sharp would share either. Mr McGauran did not take up Dr Selley's recommendation to discuss his ideas with Mr Sharp. There have been no exchanges on them, and none are intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I note the minister's answer and I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, could the minister advise the Senate what the fate of Mr Selley, the adviser to Mr McGauran, has been? Further, in view of the revelations that have now come to light that the government has seriously considered and continues to seriously consider the option of relocating the Lucas Heights facility and prefers the Holsworthy site as the site for the second Sydney airport, why does the minister for transport continue to mislead the people of Sydney—particularly the Sutherland shire—that the government still favours the Badgerys Creek option? Minister, can you finally tell the truth as to what the government's position is on this?

—I will ignore that last part; I am sure it was not intended to be expressed in such a manner. Dr Selley resigned from Mr McGauran's staff in September 1996. I am advised that the relationship had not been altogether satisfactory. Since that time, he appears to have had some active exchanges with members of the press gallery, and the Sunday Telegraph article would appear to have resulted from them.
—More to come!

—You might know that, of course, but it is not within our knowledge. I suppose it is the old story: embittered, goes to the press, thinks he can fire a few shots; has, maybe, five minutes of fame, and that is it. In any event, Mr McGauran has stated that he rejected Dr Selley's advice as fanciful. As far as the last part of Senator Forshaw's question is concerned, the Holsworthy military reserve has simply been included as an alternative site to ensure a fall‐back option is immediately available, if the Badgerys Creek EIS does not prove up—(Time expired)

—Madam President, my question is to Senator Parer, the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Following the granting of the Australian monopoly patent for the Hepatitis C virus and cell lines containing HCV to Chiron Corporation, I asked the Attorney‐General to institute proceedings—in the public interest—to revoke the Chiron Corporation Australia patent. Is it a fact that the Attorney‐General has asked the minister for science for his view on the matter of the granting of the patent by the Patents Office, which is under his control? Is that the way to operate? Has the Patents Office, without legal advice, granted patents for human genetic material, including specific human genes, gene fragments and human DNA? Will the minister ask the minister for science to raise this matter at the highest level of government, in the public interest—not only the public interest in respect of the future genetic composition of the human race but also in respect of disease control? (Time expired)

—I thank Senator Harradine for the question. Senator, I understand your concern—shared by a lot of people—in regard to things related to genetic manipulation. I have discussed this—only very briefly—with Mr McGauran, and I am advised that he is prepared to give your request serious consideration.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, are you aware that some universities help arrange repayment deferred bank loans for students undertaking HECS liable courses which include a substantial fee component—for example, aviation courses? Can you, Minister, confirm that these loans are deemed as `actual means' under the revised Austudy means test and may make some students with self‐employed parents ineligible for Austudy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator Crowley, I cannot answer that question for you at the moment. I will make some inquiries with the universities to see what they do—but I realise that is not the thrust of your questions—and I will check for you the nature of inclusion as expenditure of any loans that fall under that category.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to recognise that some people would not like any loans at all considered as expenditure in an actual means test. For example, there would be some people who would say that, if a family on a rural property with significant assets has sufficient funds to borrow money to send three kids down to private schools, that loan—which is expended in that year—ought not to be counted as their actual means. There would be plenty of others who would say, yes, it should be, because if that family has the assets and income to borrow such an amount of money and send three kids to private schools and board them, it is an indication that their actual means are quite significant. That is the purpose of the actual means test. That is why your party introduced it.

Loans are treated differently, depending on what they are for. For example, if you expended all the money from a loan on a house which you were going to keep forever and a day, that would not be included. Let me check for you on the nature of the loans you are referring to—I will come back as quickly as I can and give you an answer with respect to those. But let me give you the general answer that if you had a loan for a house, that money would all be expended in one year but it would not be sensible to include that as your actual means. But a loan, for example, to send three kids to a private school in a capital city should, in my view, be included as actual means. I will get an answer on where the loans you are referring to fit in and come back to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not the case that the actual means test, in interpreting debt as expenditure, severely disadvantages rural families whose income fluctuates from year to year and who need to make up that difference through debt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, if your party wants to claim that all those people who have the asset and income backing combination to satisfy banks that they can they make very substantial loans and that those loans ought not be considered as their actual means, I look forward to you running that case. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Second Sydney Airport Relocation of Lucas Heights Reactor

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Forshaw today, relating to the site for a second airport for Sydney and the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights.

The first thing to note is the surprising amount of detail that Senator Alston had in his brief on this issue. Much of it of course was information that we already know, that has been on the public record for some time. But what it demonstrates is that the government has become very aware of the concern of the people of Sydney, and particularly of the Sutherland Shire in the electorate of Hughes, regarding the deceit and misinformation that is being peddled around by this government over the issue of the location of Sydney's second airport.

What I believe is happening is a cover up here. Last Sunday the Sunday Telegraph exposed the secret agenda of this government—the agenda whereby Holsworthy would become the site for Sydney's second airport. Many thousands of people already believe that that decision has been made by this government and was made some time ago. And as each day goes by, they become increasingly convinced of that because of the leaks that are coming out of the government and because of the off‐the‐record statements being made by people associated with the government and the department about what this government's real agenda is. Because this has been exposed to the public in the press last week there is clearly now a cover up going on, an attempt by ministers to still maintain a fiction that they are committed to an airport at Badgerys Creek.

Let us just look at some of the things that have occurred very recently. For instance, a couple of weeks ago we had the leak that the government had been considering the establishment of a nuclear waste reprocessing unit at Lucas Heights. This was exposed in the press—and what did we see? We saw the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) try to weasel his way out by saying that it was only a proposal they were looking at. The fact of the matter is that that has been very seriously considered by this government. Of course, there has never been any indication to the people of the area prior to the election that this was on the agenda—notwithstanding the fact that the government knows the views of the council and people of the Sutherland Shire about any further extension of the Lucas Heights facility. So that was exposed.

Then it comes out, by virtue of a leaked memo, that the government has also been looking at the proposal to locate the airport at Holsworthy in conjunction with a relocation of the Lucas Height facility—again tying the two sites, the two issues, together. If one reads the leaked memo that is now quite publicly available—and the minister himself acknowledged in his answer that it exists—we note that it states that the adviser to Mr McGauran indicated that he met with Lachlan McComish the adviser to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), that they discussed the location of the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights and—and I quote:

Lachlan made it clear that Badgerys Creek was dead as a viable option for the airport, mainly due to the build‐up of residential housing in the area since the site was first proposed. He believes that Holsworthy will be selected as the preferred site, subject to a satisfactory outcome of the EIS.

Isn't it interesting to note that one of the reasons given by the minister some time ago as to why Holsworthy was put on the agenda was the residential build‐up around Badgerys Creek? But then the memo goes on to talk about how the option should be seriously considered of relocating the reactor and putting the airport at Holsworthy. And this is the real nub. Finally, the memo states:

There may be political advantages in making the relocation of the Lucas Heights facility an integral part of the Holsworthy airport package. The removal of the dangerous Lucas Heights reactor to a more suitable location would be welcomed by the Sutherland Shire and may partly negate the negative impact of the new airport. There would be problems with finding a new site for the reactor but the possible use of Commonwealth land at Jervis Bay may be an option.

And he goes on to recommend that serious consideration should be given to this and discussions take place with the minister. The people of the Sutherland Shire are not going to be bribed by these sorts of disgraceful actions by this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that the Labor Party is starting to move into the mode of trying to win back some of the seats that they lost. Senator Forshaw seems to be acknowledging that by the wry smile on his face. This clearly is a Labor Party beat‐up designed to win back some of the seats such as Hughes that they lost in such a devastating fashion at the last election. You have mentioned the name of Danna Vale—and what a fantastic member for Hughes she is. She will outdo your former failed minister, Robert Tickner, who was the holder of that seat, each and every day. She has been a great campaigner for the people of Hughes and, what is more, will continue to be after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: It does the Australian Labor Party no good to come into this place trying to beat up issues in their desperate bid to win back seats. The only way that the Labor Party are going to win back their seats is by coming up with some decent policy proposals and, above all, by saying sorry for the mistakes of the past. But they cannot come at that, so what do they do? They engage in these campaigns of misinformation.

The media reports about what occurred between an office member of Mr McGauran, et cetera, are really all a beat-up. What has occurred is that this so-called information is not of any official government status. The best it could be labelled as is `rejected advice' which dates back to 15 June 1996. One wonders if the department may have developed that document as part of the process for the former Labor government, keeping in mind that that document only arose some three months after the election. One wonders if the wheels of the bureaucracy were still spitting out the views of the previous Labor government at that time. Senator Forshaw, let me warn you: be very careful when you embark upon these campaigns of trying to undermine the very successful work of the member for Hughes.

In relation to the nuclear reactor, there has been discussion about the various sites. It is only proper that the government do consider those. But it should also be kept in mind that the minister has made quite clear public statements about this matter. Why Senator Forshaw—undoubtedly with the support and connivance of the Labor Party—would want to come in here trying to revive that issue is beyond me, other than once again it is part of the campaign they believe will assist them in winning the marginal seat of Hughes. Statistically Hughes might be marginal but, because of Danna Vale's hard work, I am sure it is no longer marginal and that she will win it again at the next election with a bigger margin.

There was a media release in May 1996 which announced that the environmental impact statement would be broadened to include alternative sites. It is appropriate that the government considers all possibilities when weighing up the options.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The senator is clearly misleading the chamber. There is no consideration of alternative sites; there is consideration of one alternative site, and all other sites have been specifically excluded. Senator Abetz should know that and should tell the truth.
—That is not a point of order; it is a point of view.

—Senator Forshaw, very interestingly, in his point of order said there was no alternative but then said there was only one alternative. If there is one alterna tive, then what I was saying is absolutely right. You are wrong, Senator Forshaw.

—On a point of order again, Mr Deputy President: once again, Senator Abetz is endeavouring to mislead the Senate and misquote me. I said that Senator Abetz referred to alternative sites—plural—and I made the point that that was totally misleading because there is only one alternative site.
—Senator Forshaw, that is a point of explanation, not a point of order.

—It is interesting that, as soon as you start scoring the points against this shabby little exercise of the Labor Party trying to undermine the member for Hughes, they have to get up on points of order to try to erode the time that is available to discuss this.
—He wants Tickner back.
—Undoubtedly he wants Robert Tickner back, as Senator Campbell has interjected—Robert Tickner of Hindmarsh Island fame and the great cost to the Australian community that that occasioned.
—Shining light of the Labor Party.
—The great shining light of the Labor Party. Senator Forshaw, the Labor Party has to do a lot better than this very tawdry exercise that you have pedalled out today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up the challenge given by the coalition through Senator Abetz. I notice that the 180,000 people of Sutherland shire in the city of Sydney can make up their minds. I appreciate that the coalition have dragged out their Tasmanian senator with his legal skills to try to cover up, but they did not give him a brief; so my colleague Senator Forshaw has exposed his lack of knowledge of the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We are happy to take on the coalition parties because they have a long history of being devious and sneaky on this issue of the second airport at Sydney. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that on 28 May 1996 I asked a question of Senator Parer, the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, in which I drew attention to the fact that Senator Parer signed off the report as chairman of the aircraft noise select committee which included a statement that `embarking on another lengthy process of site evaluation will only postpone a new quite urgent decision' in referring to Badgerys Creek. But we were not told before the election that, at the very time he was signing the document, the leadership of the Liberal Party was dealing with the Lawrence Hargrave project consortium in doing a sleazy deal on the people of Sutherland to try to foist an airport on them.

We have a leaked document, and it is a very revealing document. I just want to deal with a particular aspect of it, because it shows the consistency in the Liberal and National parties position. The document refers to the fact that there has been housing in the area around Badgerys Creek.

I refer to another speech that I made on 30 November 1995. So we do not come to this issue as some sort of stunt; we have been campaigning on this issue—a vital issue to the people of Sydney. I refute Senator Abetz's suggestion that this is some sort of a Labor Party beat-up. I will quote myself—I do not know of a better authority—when I said:

We also propose in relation to the Sydney West airport that we ask the state Labor government in New South Wales to repair the damage that Liberal coalition governments in New South Wales caused at a state level by allowing estates to be built in the flight path in the west of Sydney. Over the last few years the Fahey and Greiner governments have allowed estates to be built under where those flight paths will be, and people in the west of Sydney might be affected by that.

The point that we drew attention to during that inquiry, and that citizens raised with us, is that the Liberal‐National party coalition governments in New South Wales allowed at least five major estates to develop in the west of Sydney. Is it any wonder that people in the west of Sydney and people in the Sutherland Shire know that you can expect two faces of the coalition: one is the soft sell, personified by Mr Howard, telling them things will be easy, and the other is the reality of what is foisted on them.

In Sutherland, you have a proposal now, which this document highlights. The government is going forward with the idea that there is a real selection process when this leaked document shows there is not. The hidden agenda is exposed yet again and the people of Sutherland can prepare the most massive campaign that they will ever have to be involved in to fight this development. They can expect the Liberal member for Hughes to be in an impossible position because it is her government that it is making the decision and she genuinely attempts to space herself away from her own government. The sleight of hand as far as the reactor is concerned will not allow her to be able to disown her government and her Prime Minister, the people who negotiated the deal in the first place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator Kernot today, relating to a proposed `work‐for‐the‐dole' scheme for the unemployed.

I asked Senator Vanstone, in my question, to confirm the accuracy of something which purports to be an exclusive report in today's Herald‐Sun . Senator Vanstone did not confirm the accuracy of that report, but it did seem to me that in her answer she did seem to be saying to us, `Yes, the work for the dole legislation which is going to be introduced has to have legislative approval. That legislative approval is going to be reasonably open and, therefore, even though we are starting with pilot projects for 10,000 unemployed young Australians, it is true that the legislation will have the capacity to be implemented in the future for all unemployed Australians without further parliamentary debate. I do not think that is right.

I think it is appropriate to have a trial—for us, preferably, on a voluntary basis—and to say to 10,000 young Australians: this is the way it is going to work and at the end of six months we are going to evaluate how the scheme went. We could ask, for example: what did you get out of it; what kind of tasks were you asked to do; and what kind of training did you receive as part of this six months `work'? I think people would say that a trial has merit. I think they would say it has real merit if the evidence that comes in shows that there was real training and there were real jobs, as a by‐product, at the end it.

But it really concerns me that, in order to put a trial in place, we are being asked to give a big tick to legislation that has the capacity to make it compulsory for all unemployed Australians to meet the requirements that they work for the dole. I hope, when we learn more of the detail, that that is wrong. I certainly would be wanting to put a sunset clause in place, not because I disapprove of the government's proposal to have a trial but because I think it is wrong not to come back to this parliament having evaluated the results of that trial.

I want to make a couple of other comments about the issue generally. Firstly, the government relies very heavily on polls, which show a high level of community support, particularly for young Australians. Those polls are genuine polls. But it would be good for the polls to then go back and say, `Do you think the government should have to provide you with a few basic details before it puts in place a law compelling all unemployed Australians to roll up for work for the dole schemes?' I would be interested in that answer. Or to ask Australians: if the trial unfortunately did not produce the kind of results we were hoping for, would it be a good thing to have legislation already in place which would have an impact on all future unemployed Australians? We need to go on and ask them a few more specific questions, having asked them whether they approve of the work for the dole program in concept. I hope we will do that.

I would like to ask them too what they think about a scheme on which the government makes an announcement on the big picture details without having ready the fine detail of who the sponsors will be and what kind of tasks young people will be asked to do. I think it is the wrong way round. We are asking parliament to pass this before Easter, but we are not asking sponsors to nominate until July and we are not intending to finalise the approval process until August, putting people in place by September.

I have done a ring around of various organisations that I thought would qualify under the government's loose terminology of `community and service organisations' and I think there are so many details that are still unknown that we should be asking the government to come to us and say, `We have firm offers from these organisations for this many young people and we are going to ask them to do these specific tasks. And, yes, in X number of cases we will be able to provide training.' I would really think it is fairer for the parliament, before being asked to vote on this important thing, to have those details first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the answers given by Senator Vanstone and Senator Hill in respect of the work for the dole scheme. It is truly amazing, is it not, that the minute the government comes up with a plan that is likely to do something for the long‐term unemployed in this country, there is criticism. We have a situation where everything supposedly has to be in place—every `i' dotted, every `t' crossed—before we can even offer some solutions to the young unemployed of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing to note about this is, first of all, that there is absolutely overwhelming support for this scheme from the very people who should expect to benefit from it—that is, the long‐term unemployed in Australia. It is interesting to note what is being said by a large proportion of young people who look as if they are not going to be able to get a job after 13 years of neglect and an inability to put into place any structural positions for young kids coming out of school. You find that two‐thirds of 400 senior school students say they support this scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they do.

—They support the scheme and they are not worried, Senator Kernot, about the fact that they do not know who the sponsors are. They are not worried about what tasks they are going to be asked to do. They are concerned and worried that, under Labor, nothing was being offered.

SPEECH.PARA: What this scheme will do is allow these kids to get at least a foot in the door. The important thing to do is allow this scheme to get off the ground—not to criticise it, not to drive it into the ground before it even gets a chance to start. If it did not have any community support, there might be some more substance to the sorts of criticisms that are being made of this scheme. But there is no support in the community for the sorts of criticisms that are being laid at the foot of this scheme.

It is important for young people to know that they can have some self‐esteem, that they can have an opportunity to at least have some skills, and that they can feel some pride in what they do. It is important that they can know they are making a contribution and are not getting something for nothing—that they are getting something because they have earned it.

Pride and self‐esteem are very important for young people. Self‐esteem and some regard for oneself as a human being enables young people to withstand some of the other problems they face—problems such as the appalling temptations that are in their path with drugs and other miseries that relate to not having a job, having no self‐esteem in the community.

At the beginning of 1996, 234,000 young unemployed 15‐ to 24‐year‐olds in this country were looking for work and were unable to find it. These are shameful statistics. Young people actually represented 38 per cent of all unemployed Australians. They were the people who had absolutely no hope.

What this scheme will do is provide for at least 10,000 unemployed in pilot schemes. It will help the young kids aged between 18 to 24 who have been unemployed for longer than six months. You would think that, in those circumstances, this sort of scheme would be greeted with great enthusiasm by the opposition. It is important not only that this scheme is being offered but that there is a bit of bipartisan support for something that is as critical in providing some assistance to kids who otherwise have had very little to hope for and look forward to in life.

It is time not only for the Labor Party but also for the Democrats to accept that work for the dole offers some positive benefits. They should support the scheme and not be so critical before the scheme even gets an opportunity to be properly tested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up on the last part of Senator Coonan's contribution to the motion to take note of the answers by Senator Vanstone and Senator Hill. I am not in the business of knocking work for the dole. But I am in the business of trying to find out from the government exactly what you plan to do.

SPEECH.PARA: When we were in government we implemented a whole raft of plans that actually created several hundred thousand jobs, not just 10,000 potential opportunities. We have no idea at all what you intend for these people. You called those schemes `the road to nowhere' schemes, dead‐end schemes, that provided people with no real opportunity at a real job.

I think I remember Senator Parer talking about `real jobs' created by the private sector. I also heard Senator Hill saying that economic growth is going to be generated through the private sector. I would like to remind Senator Hill of a statement in the Financial Review that the manufacturing sector plans to reduce by another 7,000. That is the sort of approach that the manufacturing sector of this country's industry is taking to how well this government is going.

I want to come back to this question of bipartisan support. Well, we will support the scheme. We do not have a problem. But we—and I think Senator Kernot has also pointed this out—want to know what real benefits and opportunities will be created by your proposal because you do not have a plan, you do not have any—

TALK.START.PARA: —Give it a chance and you will find out!
—We will give it a chance when we see on paper the real outline of what you are proposing to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coonan might be interested to know that the numbers of long‐term unemployed actually increased again just recently.You are saying that you are going to provide some 10,000 opportunities nationwide. Under the Working Nation program we committed something in the order of $4 billion over four years. I have to say that in many respects that program was no different to work for the dole; it was another form of work for the dole.

But we committed additional funds to provide appropriate training and opportunities so that people would actually stand a chance of becoming skilled to the point where they would be of some value, where they could in fact make a contribution to industry and so that job opportunities might be created along with economic growth in this country. But you have said nothing!

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said, `Well, work for the dole; the people want it'. Of course the people want it. There is nothing wrong with the concept of people making a contribution because the taxpayers of this country will benefit. There is nothing wrong with it as a concept. But do not come around here trying to paint it as some grand plan or as some panacea for the problems of unemployment in this country, because it is not.

Moreover, as has been said repeatedly, you have not come up with one line that explains to people what you intend to do. You have been trying to milk this for the populist tokenism that it really is. You will get support if and when you put your plan on the table so that it can be assessed for what it is, but do not expect us to come along and put our hands up in support of something which, quite frankly, is nothing but a facade. It will have no benefit whatsoever unless you put the plan on the table. If you do not, then you cannot expect any support at all from us.

At this point in time I do not think you have a plan. This looks to me very much like another Austudy cock‐up. That is exactly where it is headed. The Prime Minister thinks that it is fine to send young people out to work on the reconstruction of old buildings or to pick up papers or to make a bit of a contribution. On the one hand that is fine, it is a community contribution, but it is not a solution that will get young people or any other people who are unemployed a proper job so they can make a long‐term contribution to this country.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES

(v) the use of the corporations power,
(vi) the Endangered Species Protection Act,
(vii) the Inter‐Governmental Agreement on the Environment, and
(viii) the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development; and

BREAK.PARA: (c) the most appropriate balance of powers and responsibilities between Commonwealth, State and local levels of government and mechanisms for implementation of treaties, conventions and national strategies to ensure consistency between all levels of government in environmental protection.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SERVICES DELIVERY AGENCY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell at the request of Senator Brownhill) agreed to:

Senator CAMPBELL (Western Australia—Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer) (3.50 p.m.)—I table the explanatory memorandum and move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

This bill contains amendments that are consequential on the creation of the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency, which is to be established by the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill 1996 (which was introduced in the Senate on 4 March 1997).

As I said in my second reading speech on the Agency bill, the establishment of the Agency will implement a major change in service delivery arrangements for the Commonwealth. It will provide an administrative framework for integration of access to Commonwealth services so that, where possible, people can get the help they need in one place.

This bill makes minor, technical amendments to give effect to that administrative framework. In particular, it proposes amendments that reflect the fact that, once the Agency bill has been passed by the parliament, various functions currently undertaken by the Secretary to the Department of Social Security and by the Department itself will be able to be delegated to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency and to officers of that Agency. This means that various Commonwealth acts need to be amended to reflect the fact that certain functions of the Secretary and the Department may be carried out by the CEO or the Agency.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

On 9 September 1996, the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Having regard to the correspondence addressed to the President, whether any false or misleading evidence was given to the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed.

The matter was referred following the President's acceptance of a recommendation from the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee that it should be so referred.

It was first raised on 9 November 1995 with the then President of the Senate, the Hon. Michael Beahan, by Mr Geoffrey Marr, who claimed that false statements had been made by a Telstra officer to the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee in the course of its estimates hearings of 27 June 1995. On 13 November 1995, a similar complaint was made by Mr Paul Miles, a friend and supporter of Mr Marr. The former President referred both letters to the ERCA committee on 13 November 1995.
The basis of the complaints may be summarised as follows:
That, at the ERCA committee hearings:
(a) Mr Krasnostein falsely alleged that Mr Marr had threatened violence against Telstra employees and their families; and
(b) Mr Krasnostein falsely alleged that Mr Marr and Mr Miles had unlawfully obtained an internal Telstra e-mail message.

The committee has examined the extensive documentation associated with the reference, including submissions from the persons just mentioned and from Senator Paul Calvert, who has demonstrated a continuing interest in Mr Marr's relationship with Telstra.

For the reasons detailed in the report, the committee has concluded that no contempt of the Senate has been committed in respect of the matter referred to it. It has, however, made some observations about the difficulties experienced with evidence given by Telstra over a considerable period. In this regard, the committee has drawn attention to a resolution of the Senate of 21 October 1993 concerning the duty of all officers at senior levels of the public service and other agencies to understand the principles governing the operation of parliament.
It has also taken the opportunity to seek from the Senate a re-endorsement of the following long established principle in respect of statutory authorities:

That whilst it may be argued that Statutory Authorities are not accountable through the responsible Minister of State to Parliament for day‐to‐day operations, they may be called to account by Parliament itself at any time and that there are no areas of expenditure of public funds where these corporations have a discretion to withhold details or explanations from Parliament or its Committees unless the Parliament has expressly provided otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
Madam President, this bill proposes amendments to overcome an anomaly in the Corporations Law which came to light in a court decision last year.

Part 5.3A of the Corporations Law, which commenced in June 1993, provides a regime for companies to enter a scheme known as voluntary administration. The scheme allows a company in financial difficulty to enter into a deed of company arrangement with its creditors, which enables the company to continue trading for a period with a view to producing a better return for creditors than would be available if the company was wound up immediately. Using this method can, ideally, result in saving the business of the company and the jobs of employees. The mechanism may also serve to avoid costs and delays often associated with formal liquidations.

The voluntary administration scheme is increasingly being used in substitution to other means of dealing with corporate insolvencies because of its stream lined procedures and minimal court involvement. In a significant proportion of cases, companies enter into deeds of company arrangement with their creditors in an effort to save the company or, at least, its business.

However, there are cases where, after a period of trading under a deed of company arrangement, it becomes clear that the company cannot trade out of its difficulties. In such a case, the Corporations Law provides for an automatic transition to a liquidation.

In June last year, His Honour Mr Justice Cohen of the New South Wales Supreme Court held in Re Crawford House Press Pty Ltd (1995) 13 ACLC 874; (1995) 17 ACSR 295 that where persons deal with a company under a deed of company arrangement (as opposed to dealing with the deed administrator), and that company moves into liquidation, those persons may not make a claim in the winding up for any outstanding liabilities of the company in relation to those dealings. His Honour stated that this was not a result that could have been intended by the legislature and therefore called for legislative amendment. Industry bodies, the legal and insolvency profession, and commentators have supported the call for amendment as a matter of priority.

In October last year, the Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1995 was introduced by the previous government. The 1995 bill was designed to overcome the anomaly uncovered in the Crawford House decision. However, the 1995 bill failed to be passed before parliament rose prior to the March election and, accordingly, it has lapsed.

At the time the 1995 bill was introduced, the coalition (then in Opposition) had some reservations about the form of the bill. In particular, the coalition had concerns about whether debts incurred while a company is under a deed of company arrangement should not only be provable but should also receive priority over other unsecured debts.

This year the government consulted with key industry participants about the best means of overcoming the anomaly uncovered by the Crawford House decision. During the consultation process, the government was advised that a large number of insolvency practitioners have been acting on the assumption that the 1995 bill would become law.

In those circumstances, the government considers that, in the interests of certainty and stability, the most desirable course is to retain the bill in the form it was originally introduced last year. To modify the bill in order to give certain debts priority could potentially give rise to some very difficult situations if liquidators have conducted administrations relying on the form of the 1995 bill. The most important thing at this stage is to ensure the debts are provable so creditors are not left high and dry and to prevent the voluntary administration scheme being compromised.

However, as the question of the priority which should be accorded to debts incurred by a company under a deed of company arrangement remains an important issue, the government will refer the question of priority for consideration by the Legal Committee of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee which is currently undertaking a wide‐ranging review of the voluntary administration scheme.

Both the Law Council of Australia and the Insolvency Practitioners' Association of Australia have expressed their support for this course of action in light of the time that has passed since the lapsed 1995 bill.

This bill seeks to effect two substantive changes to the Corporations Law. The first change is intended to ensure that debts and claims arising while a company is under a deed of company arrangement are admissible to proof in a subsequent winding up. The second is intended to ensure the validity of acts of liquidators who admitted such debts and claims on the basis that they were provable, prior to commencement of the amendments in the bill.
The bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on government or business. The Explanatory Memorandum describes the potential impact on creditors.

In accordance with the Heads of Agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, I confirm that the Ministerial Council for Corporations was consulted and gave approval to the provisions of the bill.
Madam President, I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the winter sittings 1997, in accordance with standing order 111.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

The Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 amends two acts. The main provisions of this bill amend the Airports Act 1996. Technical amendments are also proposed to the Air Navigation Act 1920 to establish a register of encumbered aircraft as well as to strengthen consumer protection provisions and streamline approval processes for international charter flights.

Amendments to the Airports Act 1996 will empower required regulations in relation to a number of key environment matters, as well as clarify some technical issues which are unclear. These provisions include:
. Variable penalties for breaches of environmental standards;
. Providing new offences for deliberate harm to the environment;
. Powers to allow pre-existing contamination to be addressed;
Prohibiting sub-leasing to trusts;
. Requiring airport-lessees to seek public comment prior to submitting minor variations of master plans and major development plans to the minister for approval; and
. A statutory requirement for an airport operator to use an airport site as an airport.

My department has been developing Airports (Environmental Protection) Regulations (the EP regulations) in consultation with Environment Australia. This process has highlighted a number of areas where improvements can be made to the regime originally envisaged in the act.

Under these recently tabled regulations, the environment strategy is the centrepiece of a performance-based regulatory regime under which each and every person carrying out an activity on an airport is responsible for the environmental impacts associated with their activity

While the current section 130 requires that an airport-lessee company take all reasonable steps to comply with any final airport environment strategy, it does not require that other persons carrying out activities on an airport site do so. An amendment is proposed to allow for regulations to achieve this.

The EP regulations will establish a regime to identify and `manage' any pollution or sources of pollution at the leased airport sites. Soil pollution is a serious hazard, and there will be provision for remediation of pre-existing pollution, as well as for soil pollution that occurs after the regulations come into force.

This process is enshrined in the EP regulations but cannot be applied to pre‐existing contamination due to the acts Interpretation Act 1901 restriction on regulations with retrospective effect. To overcome this limitation, a proposed amendment will enable the Airport Environment Officer to require remediation of sites identified as polluted.

In drafting the EP regulations, we have been constrained in the penalties that can be used for breaches of certain regulations. The amendment proposed to section 132 will enable appropriate variable penalties to be set in these regulations.

While the EP regulations avoid a strict liability approach, we want to include offences for deliberately causing environmental harm. Given the seriousness of these offences, they should be addressed in the act rather than regulations. Having surveyed state environmental legislation, drawing particularly on the South Australian and Queensland regimes, we believe a tiered approach to environmental harm is the best approach. The proposed amendments set out offences in the act to deal with persons intentionally or recklessly causing:
. serious environmental pollution;
. material environmental pollution (lesser but nevertheless serious harm); and
. environmental nuisance.
