The amendments on environmental matters are consistent with the tougher stance being taken by states to strengthen their environment protection laws.

I am concerned that trusts may be used to evade the ownership provisions of Part 3 of the Act. The amendment will prohibit a trust being declared in a sublease or a licence, and also prohibit the separation of the legal and beneficial interests of a sublessee or licensee. The regulation making powers in sections 34 and 35 have also been amended to impose or prohibit certain terms being put in the sublease or licence agreements to ensure that any future developments in this area can be dealt with by making regulations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Air Navigation Act

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will amend the Air Navigation Act 1920 to allow a national register of encumbered aircraft to be established pursuant to regulations to be made under the act. The register was originally proposed by the aviation industry who will benefit by providing buyers and sellers of aircraft with information on registered security interests held by lenders and creditors over aircraft, including airframes, engines and avionics.
However, the register will provide no legal protection on transactions and will not deem a person who has not searched the register to have notice of its contents.

It is envisaged that Airservices Australia will be responsible for the development and ongoing administration of the register of security interests over encumbered aircraft. The register is to be established on a national basis and will operate on a fully cost recovered system.

All the states and territories have given their in-principle approval for the establishment of the register. The states, with the exception of Victoria, have complementary legislation in the form of their Air Navigation Acts which currently pick up the regulations made under the Commonwealth's Air Navigation Act 1920. Victoria has agreed to adopt similar legislation so that the register can be established as a comprehensive national register.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments in relation to charter flights

SPEECH.PARA: In June 1996, the government took a major step towards a more liberalised and flexible international air charter market in Australia with the release of updated charter guidelines. The government believes that charter operators provide competition for scheduled airlines and their growth will promote efficiency in the air transport industry, with subsequent benefits to users of air transport services and the wider economy. Charter operators also have the potential to further develop new markets and bring tourists directly to major regional centres throughout Australia.
The amendments in the bill will streamline approval processes for charter applications and strengthen consumer protection mechanisms.

The bill provides that applications to conduct charter flights will only be accepted from the owner of the aircraft or the operator of the aircraft. The government's intention is that persons such as tour package operators should not be allowed to apply for permission to operate charter flights. This ensures that only persons reasonably capable of completing the program of charters will be given permission to operate international non-scheduled flights.

A statutory requirement is also being introduced requiring applicants to provide evidence that fare paying passengers will be indemnified for financial loss caused by the failure of the charter operator to fulfil its obligations or complete a program of charters. The charter guidelines released by the government in June 1996 will also be revised to reflect the above amendments.
The sale of long-term leases on Federal airports, starting with Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth, will improve airport investment and operations.

With the selection of the successful bidders and finalisation of the sale of leases expected soon, successful bidders should commence operation of these airports in the first half of this year. To provide certainty to new airport operators and existing airport tenants, and to ensure that the Commonwealth can exercise adequate regulatory control over leased airports, it is essential that this legislation be passed in the current sittings to meet that timetable.
Debate (on motion by Senator Carr) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in statutory rules 1996 No. 338 and made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

In a nutshell, what the government is trying to do here is to remove the requirement that the export of whole logs, unprocessed wood, out of Australia be no longer licensed. The government is washing its hands of any responsibility for what happens to our forest resource in this country, beginning with this move on plantations, both softwood and hardwood.

The first states which will be affected are Tasmania and Victoria because they have a form of forest practice code which the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) will judge is environmentally satisfactory. Other states will follow, and a little further down the line all native forests that are not protected are going to be open to export by the major players in this industry, which is targeting the Australian public's great forests, and no licensing will be required any more.

We had more forests and the industry was cutting less when it did not have the technological fire power which it has now to smash down our forests, put them on to log trucks, take them to the nearest port and send the logs away unprocessed. Jobs were exported and profits were exported with sending the logs to the Northern Hemisphere to be processed downstream. Jobs were created there. Of course, after they go through the pulp and paper industry, they end up on the rubbish dumps of Japan, Korea, Taiwan, China and Malaysia, or wherever it may be.

So we are seeing a suite of these regulations come through as the Howard government, the most environmentally irresponsible government certainly at this end of the century, divests itself of its responsibilities as far as the Australian forest environment is concerned. We know that 80 per cent of Australians want the machinery out of our native forests. We also know that we are in a period where hundreds of millions of dollars spent on the creation of plantations in this country in the 1960s and 1970s—taxpayers' money—are now bearing fruit. We now have a tidal wave of plantations available for processing. There is no need to be cutting our native forests because we have this enormous repository of plantations which are there because the public paid for them back in the 1960s and 1970s.

Here is the ideal opportunity to save our native forests by moving across to plantation investment and to create jobs by having an industry management plan in this country which sees that those plantations are processed here. What have we got instead? In this set of regulations, another component of the move to have those trees simply put on ships and sent overseas. What we have is a process for turning Australia's forest into a giant wood mine. It is `quarry Australia'; it is `transport our forests out of this country'. Never mind the jobs, the downstream processing, the profits, the rural centres which are dependent upon and which could get some benefit—jobs and money—from the downstream processing; and even never mind those good minded people in the industry who have up to $1 billion worth of investment in downstream processing, given the right conditions, in this plantation resource that we have in this country.

BREAK.PARA: Who is going to win out of this? First of all, the big plantation companies who have a mining mentality: the quickest dollar possible. I cannot avoid the opportunity of saying that every time there is an environmental question to do with our forests in our country these big operators bring out their front organisations—like the Forest Protection Society which gets hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, as a front organisation, paid for out of the cutting down of forests in Australia by these big corporations—to cry crocodile tears about the loss of jobs.

Here we have this government—and I understand it is going to be supported by the Labor Party—endorsing this process of having the trees cut down and shipped out of the district to the nearest port and sent to Japan and Taiwan, and with them the jobs. It is a sham: this whole industry pretence that it is concerned about jobs when, in fact, it is concerned about making a dollar as fast as possible—never mind the jobs—and is hell bent on so‐called streamlining and downsizing and re‐equipping at the expense of workers in this country.

There are already export licences for 830,000 square metres of plantation logs out of this country—50 per cent from Tasmania. That 440,000 square metres of logs to be exported out of Tasmania could be made into building materials within this country. Taking them from the plantations to the ports is going to create 40 jobs. If this government and this opposition were really concerned about jobs they would have an industry management plan which ensured that those same trees were processed in this country. Just that Tasmanian allocation could create 1,880 jobs.

Here we have over 1700 jobs being exported out of the country because the industry is able to tweak the ear of the big parties and say, `We don't want licensing; we don't want any controls; we'll work under the forest practices code of Tasmania or Victoria or Western Australia or wherever it may be because we've been able to see that that suits our convenience. We want to make a quick dollar; we want to exploit the hundreds of millions of dollars invested by the Australian public in plantations; and we want to make that dollar as fast as possible—never mind the jobs.' That is the reality. And never mind the environment because the native forests are next in line.

Let me say two things about this. This industry is hell bent on logging national estate forests. We are currently seeing that in East Gippsland where it has been given the imprimatur of Mr Howard and Premier Kennett. We are shortly about to see it in Tasmania and Western Australia. In Tasmania the areas include world heritage value forests in the Picton, Huon and Weld valleys, in the area of Wild Crag, in the Great Western Tiers and in the Tarkine where, amongst other things, rainforests are targeted. Part of the proposal inherent in these regulations is the flattening of ancient rainforests—sure they call them degraded forest—to make way for eucalypt plantations for a quick dollar further down the line. With the destruction of those forests, including those rainforests, is the destruction of the wildlife and the ecosystems, the intactness of which go back to time immemorial.

I have camped out in them. At night you hear the calls of a number of different owls. You see the bats, which in Tasmania live only in the forests. You see the other bird species—like the white goshawk, which is down to 200 breeding pairs. The great wedge‐tailed eagles of Tasmania, which are bigger than their mainland cousins, are also down to 200 breeding pairs.

Those birds nest in the north-east facing corner of these giant trees because they know that, in the early spring and late winter, that is the best place for them to be to get the early morning sunlight on their chicks so they can be raised to be the next generation. They are a generation which faces no trees at all in many of these areas. Plantations will be devoid of the original wildlife and will have no ability to provide the necessary security and vastness for the great nesting operations those eagles require for their future.

We have plantations available in this country so that the whole of our forest products industry can not only continue as required but expand. Because of those plantations, which we as taxpayers invested in 20 years ago, we have at this critical period the ability to achieve a win‐win situation—to provide our forest products, to increase jobs with downstream productions and to protect our great wild forests.

This measure is part of a suite of measures coming through here which cuts the legs out from under that. It is so short‐sighted—whether you look at the environment, whether you look at the profitability, whether you look at the downstream products being available on the Australian market and for export or whether you look at jobs.

What an absurd situation for us to be fostering. What a crazy situation. We have such a glut of plantations at the moment. We have 24 million cubic metres of mature sawlogs, which is six times the annual native forest sawlog cut. The plantation sawlog supply will double over the next three years.

We are in a beautiful situation to fix this enormous controversy that has been going on for three decades in this country because the majority of Australians do not want our great wild forests destroyed and plundered by the woodchippers and the loggers when other resources are available. For the first time, it is unarguable that an alternative resource is there.

Do you know what this regulation is going to do? The regulation is going to divest the minister of any responsibility to give us that win‐win situation. It is going to have those plantations shipped out of the country and processed somewhere else. What an absurd and irresponsible situation. No wonder the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, is not here. There is no way he can answer the charge of irresponsibly handling our forest resource, our environment and our potential for job creation.

What is the Labor Party doing supporting this sort of regulation? What are they doing for job creation in the industry? What are they doing giving control over to the boffins of the big logging corporations? We know those corporations are irresponsible when it comes to the environment, and we know they are not interested in creating jobs.

Those corporations have shed 20,000 jobs in the last 25 years or so since the export woodchipping industry arrived in this country. That is 20,000 jobs lost, although native trees in this country are being cut down faster than ever before in history. What a scandalous situation it is. No wonder Robert Hill, the honourable minister, is not in this place to respond to this derelict set of regulations which is being brought before the Senate.

I appeal to the opposition to think again before they go over there and support the government in allowing these regulations through. I cannot think that any responsible look at the potential for job growth in rural areas and in downstream processing around this country can be treated in such a cavalier fashion—if you really do mean you want to create jobs in this industry, if you really do mean you want to get a win‐win situation and if you really do mean you want those people who would invest in downstream processing in this country to get some assistance to do so, rather than having the rug pulled out from under them by an export industry which does nothing for this country but turn our forest resource into a quarry and turn our forest resource into a bonanza for job creation and money making everywhere else in the world but in this country.

That is a challenge very often put to the Greens. I say keep those forests here. I say give assistance to this industry to downstream process here. I say take away the assistance to those people who want to simply export our forests out of this country. I say if you cannot do that you are hypocrites. I say this is a derelict and irresponsible policy as far as our forests are concerned. I say this is a watershed opportunity for the government and the opposition to get back on line as far as their joint responsibility to the environment and the workers in the forest industry in this country is concerned.

I know that in the wake of my speaking here members of past governments as well as the present one are going to come out with the claptrap fed to them by the industry and that emanates from these big logging corporations. That would be their only defence. But I ask you to tell me how you can give a tick to the export of millions of tons of our plantations in the coming years at the expense of our native forests, our downstream processing and our job creation.

I remind those senators who are interested in this debate or who will be voting on these regulations that the companies which grow plantations in this country include North, Wesfarmers, Boral, Amcor, Fletcher Challenge, News Corporation—which, of course, owns ANM—CSR and Auspine. I make a final appeal to those senators who may not know what the impact of these regulations will be to think again—because they are against the interests of this country.

No matter which side of the forest industry you are involved with, be it the workers or the environmentalists, there is a great complementarity of interests here. It is in the interests of both to see that we keep these plantations for forest processing in this country and that we move, because of the availability of these plantations, to protect our last great wild forests in Western Australia, Victoria, Tasmania, New South Wales and Queensland at the same time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government, I indicate that we shall not be supporting this motion of disallowance. It would be a ludicrous proposition to do so. In fact, it would break a bipartisan understanding of both the current opposition and the current government before the election as to how we could develop the forest industries of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I was listening to Senator Brown's contribution to the debate and wondering what he was going to bring before the Senate, he having waited 13 sitting days to bring this motion on. If Senator Brown thought this issue was so important, he could have brought it on at any time in the preceding 12 sitting days, but he waited until today. Senator Brown got himself so worked up that I thought he was going to take off like one of those birds he was referring to, but it would have been a flight of fancy.

The truth is that this debate is about the relaxation of export controls on unprocessed timber from plantations—not from the great wild forests that we have heard about for the last 20 minutes. That was one of the most irrelevant contributions I have heard. This is about plantation forests that were planted 20 years ago. It is about guaranteeing security of resources. It is also about ensuring that this country can actually get a sustainable timber industry by getting the best possible prices for plantation timber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't know the meaning of the word.

—I am glad you interjected, Senator Margetts, because about three or four years ago I was considering buying 200 acres of former forestry country in North Queensland, on the Atherton Tableland, which had been cleared and was being used for dairy and really should not have been because it was too hilly. I was going to buy 200 acres of that land and plant it to plantation. Honourable senators may want to know why I did not do so. I did not do so because there was no guarantee that, 20 years down the track, I was going to be able to get the timber off. This goes right to the heart of the issue. I did not have the confidence to put up my good money and to borrow money to invest it in the timber industry if, when the trees matured, somebody was going to hop up here and claim that this is all about some multi‐national company wanting to smash down the great wild forests. We are talking about plantation timber here, about giving an incentive to plant more plantation timber.

SPEECH.PARA: We always hear the Greens say that they want to have more plantation timber. I agree, but people are only going to plant plantation timber, as Senator Murphy would know, if they can get a price for it and make a profit out of the exercise. Of course, if you deny people access to the international market, if you deny Australian plantations access to the best prices, then nobody is going to have an incentive to plant here in the future. That is why the former government, to its credit, was willing to relax export controls on unprocessed logs from plantation stocks, not from ancient forests, not from areas that have never been felled before, not from rainforests, not from any of the things to which Senator Brown referred for most of his contribution.

BREAK.PARA: We are talking about unprocessed logs from plantations, areas which were deliberately planted so that they could be harvested. It is not unreasonable in the circumstances to say that, when they are harvested, given that people made the investment, given that these trees have grown and made a contribution to the environment and, when replanted, will do so again, they should have a right to a decent return for their investment.

There was the novel argument developed by Senator Brown that somehow we should not harvest this plantation timber and send it overseas, that instead we should use it as a substitute for native forest timbers. Of course, any honourable senator in this chamber who has any knowledge at all of the timber industry will know that most of the plantation timber in this country is softwood—it is not hardwood—and that most of the native timbers that are taken out are hardwood and not softwood. So softwood is not going to be a substitute for hardwood products.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is. In the majority of cases it is. That's where you're wrong.
—Haven't you ever built a house?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, you hear them squealing up the other end because they do not like a little bit of reason and rationality being injected into this debate. It is also obvious that the Greens refuse to extend to other people the courtesy that was just extended to them, that is, the courtesy of being heard in silence. Senator Brown's argument, of course, is that somehow we should just pretend that we can substitute the softwood plantations for hardwood resources and, moreover, that somehow it is going to grow the timber industry—and I see that is receiving some mirth on the other side of the chamber, as well it deserves to do.

BREAK.PARA: The fact is, we would lose some $2 billion of exports from the timber industry each year. Two billion is not a lot of money to the Greens because they never have to find it, but $2 billion is a major loss to export earnings in this country, as the former minister sitting opposite would know. That loss would be a direct consequence of the suggestions made by Senator Brown today.

If anybody believes that this country, with its high level of debt and its high balance of payments deficit, would want to lose $2 billion of exports, they must have holes in their head, but, quite clearly, that is the viewpoint of those on the other side. That would be $1.5 billion a month and that works out to about $50 million a day in lost export earnings. I want it on the record that that is the viewpoint of the Greens. They would like to lose $50 million a day of hard currency exports that this country so desperately needs. That would be the consequence of their policy and they should be condemned for it.

It would be utterly counterproductive to the development of a forest industry in this country were we now to challenge the very nature of the security which the plantation timber industry so desperately seeks. I speak as one who has been deterred from investing in plantation timber for just the sort of performance that we have seen today. Quite frankly, I am very glad to say that I understand that the opposition will be supporting us. We are basically applying a policy that the previous government in their wisdom brought forward. It received our support then and I understand that they are going to support us in supporting it now and I thank them for so doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown can in fact blame me for this. There is one thing that Senator Brown said that I want to comprehensively challenge. I wish it were true that Australia currently does have enough plantation resource to fully replace our need for forest products in Australia. Unfortunately, that is wildly inaccurate.
—It is true.
—It is wildly inaccurate, Senator Brown.
—Well, we have to disagree.
—On that and many other things.
—I get more disillusioned with you each day.
—I am not going to lose one second of sleep over that. Keep talking and you will talk me out of something I was going to support you on next week.

SPEECH.PARA: Having been through the forest debate, having observed the utter failure of the lobby that Senator Brown purports to represent in pursuing that debate, having seen the utter gullibility of the environment lobby in falling for the three card trick that they fell for prior to the election campaign, having seen senior representatives of that lobby group in my office on many occasions—and they always had a door open to them in my office as they will have to tell you if they are honest, Senator Brown; they got to see me every time they wanted to and I listened to what they had to say—

TALK.START.PARA: —And you sold out on the forests. And you sold out.

—I watched them sell out on the environment and embrace the coalition and appear on national television in the forests saying that the coalition were the greatest environmentalists in the world because they had the authorship—and Senator Brown knows it is true—of the coalition's environment policy. To watch them get absolutely duded after the election, as we knew perfectly well they would and as I tried to tell those individuals they would, Senator Brown, you have no credibility with me on this issue whatsoever. Come in spinner it was well and truly.

SPEECH.PARA: We now listen to Senator Brown weep crocodile tears for workers. That is always a convenient glib argument with people of Senator Brown's ilk. They never mean it. Those commitments absolutely drip with insincerity. Because the cold hard facts are that Senator Brown would be perfectly happy to see not a solitary person working in the forestry industry in Australia. That is his true agenda. To have the sanctimonious clothing of what Senator Brown really wants clothed with concern for the workers is a bit too much for me, I have to say. It is crocodile tears indeed. It is false. It is insincere. You do not actually believe a word of it. You would have every single worker in the forest industry in Australia out of a job tomorrow if you could achieve it.

BREAK.PARA: The facts are that we are still significantly short of plantation resource in Australia. We have demonstrably a massive annual deficit, which is in fact increasing not decreasing, in forest products into Australia. We need to expand our plantation resource.

One of the matters I pursued during discussions on forestry was why there was such a dramatic increase in plantation resource in New Zealand and there was not in a Australia. I questioned the companies that were involved in expanding the plantation resource in New Zealand why they were not putting similar investments into Australia.

I was interested to hear Senator O'Chee's personal involvement as a potential small investor in plantations. Senator O'Chee may be interested to know that one of the consistent causes of that lack of investment quoted was export controls over the resource. It is unlike wheat, oats, corn or any other agricultural product that would have come off that same land and was not subject to any controls at all. In other words, people were out in the marketplace getting a price for the product and that was all they had to cope with rather than the whim—and let me tell you it is a dreadful incentive for investors—and fate that their investment is in the hands of a parliament, irrespective of whatever government in power. It is a total unknown, particularly when—and let us be precise about this—it is in the hands of the Senate rather than the parliament. It is a huge disincentive for investment.

I am taking full responsibility for this. So I determined to persuade cabinet at the time to remove this disincentive to plantations in Australia to encourage further investment in plantations in Australia providing it was done with the best possible environmental codes of practice supervised, I might add, by CSIRO.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't trust them.

—I know. He does not trust anybody. The opposition will not be supporting Senator Brown's motion because if successful his motion would prevent this government putting in place an important part of the former government's wood and paper industry strategy and that is the removal of export controls on plantation grown timber, not native timber with the wedge‐tailed eagles in it, which I am as concerned about as you, Senator Brown. I am once again offended by the fact that you think you have an individual licence on concern for the environment that is possessed by no-one else. As someone who actually worked for the CSIRO division of wildlife research and worked for eight years as a wildlife researcher in what is now known as Kakadu National Park, I am constantly resentful of this mandate that Senator Brown thinks he personally possesses and which he thinks no-one else in Australia does about concern for the environment.

BREAK.PARA: The fact is that Senator Brown's argument fell down from the first piece of nonsense that he uttered in this debate—and nonsense it was. He said that Australia currently has a plantation resource as a result of investment over the last 20 years that is capable now of redressing our balance of payments deficit in respect of timber industry products. That is utter nonsense. We do need to continue to expand plantations to save the native forests that Senator Brown purportedly is so concerned about.

Under the regulations before the Senate, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy may lift these export controls only where state plantation codes of practice are found to satisfactorily protect environmental and heritage values in that state. Those codes have to be scientifically assessed by the CSIRO. I will declare my interest as a former employee of CSIRO. It is an organisation in which I do have a considerable amount of trust, an organisation which I think is very credible. That was our position in government, so we are certainly going to support that position in opposition.

In December 1995, the then government announced its wood and paper industry strategy backed by a four‐year funding package of $38 million. That strategy was complemented by funding for structural adjustment assistance. The key initiatives within that strategy included encouraging innovation, value adding and downstream processing; removing impediments to investment; improving international competitiveness; opening export opportunities and improving the skill base of the industry.

In January last year, the then government established a council to drive that strategy. It was our belief that its success would depend on the commitment of the industry, so we put the industry in charge. The council was provided with $3.5 million over four years so the council had the resources, the expertise, the time and the commitment to do that job. It was a high powered council by anyone's measure.

Its membership included senior executives from industry, senior union officials and state and local government representatives. It is worth just mentioning a few names in terms of what the government subsequently did to it: Kathryn Adams, the Executive Director of the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation; Ron Adams, a Director of Wesfarmers Bunnings; Christopher Brookes, the Chief Executive of Tasmania Development and Resources; Trevor Smith—
Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear the cackles and the laughter from the Democrats and the Greens, which just proves my case. Why are they laughing and cackling? Because I am actually mentioning senior industry figures. That is right, these are industry figures involved in investment in plantations, so obviously they must be the criminal. They must be the devil with two horns and a forked tail because they happen to be executives of companies that are investing in plantations. It is amazing, indeed, what turns the Greens on in these debates, and proof positive of the point I just made that the true agenda of the Greens has nothing whatsoever to do with jobs in Australia's timber industry—quite the reverse.

BREAK.PARA: The facts are that the people most relevant to advancing a plantation timber industry in Australia were on that council, despite, as I say, the derisory laughter from down at the other end of this chamber. So what did the new government do when they came to office? I will tell you what they did before they came to office. During the election campaign, they produced a primary industry policy, a document which in fact adopted our policy as their own. I do not mind that; in fact I applauded it at the time.

Almost the whole of the primary industry policy called Reviving the Heartland was simply a carbon copy of proposals which we had put into place in government. For those who may disbelieve me, let me quote directly from the coalition document. It says that a Liberal and National Party government will:
. . . implement the $38 million wood and paper industry strategy—
that is, ours—
and the $107 million forest industry structural adjustment package.

In other words, during the election campaign they committed themselves to adopt the same strategy that we had in government and the same funding. What did the government do when it came to office? You guessed it. It cut the funding and abolished the council—two things they had committed themselves in writing to keep when they were campaigning. In a letter to members of the council, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr Moore, advised:

The government has made a commitment to expedite the implementation of the national forestry policy statement. The government has also endorsed the four-year wood and paper industry strategy as an important part of its forest policy objectives. Consultative arrangements are . . . currently the subject of a comprehensive review and it is anticipated that the new arrangements will soon be finalised. As part of this review, the Wood and Paper Industry Council has been abolished.

That letter was dated September 1996. I have continued to monitor, and I will continue to monitor, the government's progress in this important area through the estimates hearings. After all, the industry does employ about 70,000 people, many of them in regional Australia. I have an interest in the jobs and the futures of those people, even if Senator Brown does not.

We have a serious trade deficit in timber that must be addressed, and we have an industry that is far too dependent on the housing sector and the economic cycles it follows for its livelihood. I asked some questions at the last estimates hearing only a couple of weeks ago and got some profoundly unsatisfactory, and indeed amazing, answers. I asked how the Wood and Paper Industry Council was going and whether there had been any change to its membership. The answer I got at estimates was:
Ministers are still considering a membership of that council and how it should be established.

It is almost a year to the day that the government—or, more precisely, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) and the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer)—announced they were going to fix this, but they have not even been able to settle the membership of a council to oversight the downstream processing that we are all so very concerned about. At the beginning September last year, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) said that the matter would be settled soon. This important process has in fact gone backwards and not forwards since March last year.

Whilst we are prepared to support the government in voting down this motion for disallowance, I will take this opportunity to remind those opposite that we do expect them to honour their commitment given in writing to the industry, the unions and the workers that are represented in that industry—70,000 of them—to implement the strategy in this key sector.

The coalition gave a written commitment to do so and breached it almost immediately after they got into office. We will continue to work with these groups and we will continue to monitor the progress of the government through Senate estimates and all of the other forums that are available to us to ensure that in this instance the government promise is declared to be a core one and is implemented in full.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I intended really to speak for only a few moments but I cannot let pass what Senator O'Chee had to say, which was an extraordinarily ill‐informed contribution, or indeed what we have heard from Senator Collins.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin with what Senator O'Chee had to say. Senator, if you had listened carefully to what Senator Brown was saying you would understand the link between what we are now doing, which is basically giving the okay to cheaply sell off our plantations, unprocessed, and the continued destruction of our native forests. So I will go through it step by step for you.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do the two go together?

—Thank you, Senator Collins. I am quite happy to explain it. If you look at the state by state breakdown of what people use—and housing is a good example—you will see that, where there is native timber available dirt cheap, that is what is used; whereas, in my home state of South Australia, where over 90 per cent of our timber comes out of the pine plantations, mostly down around Mount Gambier, people tend to go for the softwood timbers. And that is what the housing industry uses in bulk.

SPEECH.PARA: As someone who has built a house using native hardwood—because it was very cheap; it is built in the Croajingolong—and also a house in Adelaide that is of pine construction, a pole frame place, I can assure you which one I would prefer to hammer nails into. And it is obvious what the building industry would prefer if it were not for the fact that our hardwood timbers are virtually given away.

I have spent time with the industry, Senator. You seem to decry anyone who stands up in this place and says that they actually talk with industry. You seem to think that we have a problem with that. We do not. Indeed, I have consulted extensively with those in Mount Gambier, and they say to me that their prices are being kept down because the hardwood is being given away from our native forests. In other words, we are so undervaluing our native forests that the plantation industry does not get for its product what it really should.

We are not talking about a huge increase, but just go and have a look at what you can get in East Gippsland for finished timber. Slowly, plantations are finding their place but, Minister, it is obviously more expensive to go to the trouble of putting in a plantation—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm not a minister any more.

—Sorry, shadow minister. Well, I think we have heard in here today what was going on when you were a minister and I think that has been a very interesting insight into some of the processes—and I will be commenting on that later.
—Tell us the plantation resource is enough. Senator Brown did.

—Thank you, Senator. I will get to that in a moment. But let us just look at the industry and the situation it finds itself in. It believes that it cannot get legitimately what it is actually costing in some instances to produce because another product comes on the market from our native forests that is dirt cheap. So, yes, some are putting pressure on this government to let an unprocessed product straight out of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry has learnt the hard way. They are now trying to catch the chicken after it has escaped and trying to get some processing back. You are the one who drew our attention to other industries. Let us look at wheat, corn and oats and a whole range of other products where the industries are saying, `Gee, we are now trying to do some value‐adding. We are now trying to get the best possible price for our product and create jobs in this country.'

And if Senator Collins does not believe we are talking about the loss of jobs here today, we certainly are. We are talking about simply cutting down the trees, a few jobs to get them to the port—and that is it. What the Democrats would like to see happen is that the trees are cut down, sent to a mill, then processed and then exported.

So what we are basically seeing today is the green light being given for the south‐east forests in Mount Gambier, if they can manage to get them on a boat quickly enough and cheaply enough, to be exported at the expense of jobs in our state. And this has been fought for a long time, particularly by those who care about the jobs in South Australia, because virtually all of our timber—indeed, all of our commercial timber—is in plantations. And this is what matters—that they are processed here.

TALK.START.PARA: —What!

—And yes, I must say, Senator O'Chee, that it is the only timber industry that is running at a profit—and a substantial profit—and it has been well run for years. Through these sorts of decisions without very strict controls we are going to see jobs lost in my home state. And that is why I am on my feet today. I was not even going to talk about the environment because it is an issue that this government has put at the absolute bottom of its priorities. I was coming in here just to talk about jobs. And the estimate is that we are looking at 15,000 jobs if the wholesale export of unprocessed timber goes ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: To answer another question that you raised relating to the number of actual trees that we have available, what it does is provide us with sufficient timber for all our housing and cut timber needs. It does not go as far—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what Senator Brown said, Senator Lees.

—I am not arguing, Senator, with anything other than what you just asked me. You asked me about the replacement of timber in this country. We are talking in this debate about unprocessed timber from plantations. We have documents that can prove to you that we have sufficient plantation timber in this country now for all our—
—For housing?

—I rephrase that: our cut timber needs. That is beyond housing. That is all structural needs—housing, et cetera. What we do not have in plantations is the huge volumes that are being chipped. We do have some of the needs if we are going to keep up these extraordinarily high levels for chipping. Although we are heading down the road, we do not have as yet—although Tasmania, I understand, is working on it by felling their native forests and putting in hardwood plantations—enough chips to support our mills here. And I really would have thought that a government that comes in here and pretends to be worried about real jobs would have had some concerns about what this decision today is going to do. It is going to mean that instead of jobs here, there are going to be jobs in Asia or perhaps America or Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: That is really what we are debating—as well as the links with the environment. Envi ronmental arguments are lost on this government. But let us look at the potential in this country—

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you advise these companies as to where they invest their money?

—You can at least make sure these companies have a reasonable return on their plantations. I argue very strongly that this government needs to go back to the drawing board with its whole plan for creating real jobs. I suspect that, like so many other of the statements which it has not managed to sell either to us in here or to the media, this is going to have to be rephrased time and time again.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other comment I make concerns some of the extraordinary figures that have been thrown around in this place. If the $2 billion is right, I suspect that we are really looking at something closer to $6 billion if we process this timber. But some of the decisions that the previous government should have made about infrastructure—supporting companies out of our native forests and relocating some of the mills—obviously are not going to be made by this government either. Therefore, it is most disappointing to see that neither the government nor the opposition are going to support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been an interesting little debate thus far. But, while I would like to indicate—as I have indicated to Senator Brown—that we are unable to support his motion with regard to the disallowance, what I would also like to endeavour to do is to clarify what plantations are and some of the issues which relate to plantations. In the context of this debate, plantations should have been seen as both private and public. There are public plantations and there are private plantations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator O'Chee, in making his contribution, pointed out that one of the problems was that export regulations deny access to the free market. Senator Bob Collins pointed out that we do not have export controls on wool or wheat. That is very true. But, for a long time, the way in which our export controls have been applied has been wrong. Many of my colleagues know that on many occasions I have criticised—within the caucus of my own party—the approach we took to applications for and granting of woodchip licences. That was one of the most iniquitous processes you could ever have in front of you. But it has been continued by this current government.

I am going to watch with great interest how this government grants some of the woodchip licences, which are not three‐year licences, when they come up for renewal this year. Because, if you go to Senator O'Chee's point, you should have open slather with regard to all people in the private sector. In my view, all privately owned wood should have open access to the free market. That will not work, but that is what the case should be. Everybody should be treated equally; there should be no differentiation.

That brings me back to the point about the two types of plantations which I have a view about. In so far as the public forest resource of this country is concerned, I have a totally different view. As far as that resource is concerned, whether it be in the form of plantation or in the form of its current native forest status, there should be—and continue to be—export controls in place.

The unfortunate circumstance is that in this country there are so few players in our forest industry. By all accounts—and it is true—as a supplier of forest products we are but a very small player on the world scene. Senator Collins pointed out, very accurately, with regard to the importation of forest products, that we have a huge and growing trade deficit. Yet we do not see many steps being taken by the existing industry players—particularly the big industry players—to go to downstream processing and value adding in this country. That is what I want to address.

Senator Brown, you have an audience to play to and you have taken a course of action to appeal to them. I have been involved in the forest debate for a long time. I have been involved with nearly every major inquiry that has happened in the forest industry, and I have seen few changes. Even today nothing has really changed. I will read a couple of things from the National Forest Policy Statement, which the government committed itself to—as we did when in government; in fact, we were the creators of it. On page 16 of that statement in the clause on efficient use and value adding, it says:

In order to attract new investment and profitable value‐adding projects, the Governments must establish clear and consistent policies for resource development, providing secure access to resources and consistent environmental guidelines. Unnecessary impediments to market efficiency and access will be removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Senator Collins said yes, and I agree with that. The unfortunate thing, Senator, is that we failed a bit when we had the reins, and the government of today has continued not to address any of those questions. It was pointed out to the government that they have scrapped the industry development council. History has told us that the forest industry itself is not capable of coming to grips with how it might go on and develop. When I was the Secretary of the Australian Timber Workers Union, in negotiations with North Broken Hill when they sold the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills at Burnie they said that they were a resource based company and only had an interest in supplying resources to someone else to manufacture. Yet they continued to be granted the majority of export licences for woodchips out of this country. That in itself is a travesty.

SPEECH.PARA: If you look at the guidelines in the regulations that currently stand—albeit significantly weakened from the ones that we put in place—even those guidelines do have a little bit about value adding. But it is only a little bit because value adding is mentioned in just one sub point under part 8 `consideration of application for transitional licence'. Part 8 reads:
Before deciding whether to grant a transitional licence, the Minister may consider:—
and then (c):
the desirability of encouraging investment in value‐added production in forest industries and related industries . . .

If we are committed to employment generation in a resource based industry that probably has a greater capacity than most other resource based industries to create jobs in regio nal Australia, then we ought to be doing something about it.

As Senator Collins said, we are going to monitor this government; we are going to continue to review the course of action that you have taken. From my point of view, I put you on notice to this extent: at the end of the day we will do whatever we have to do to bring about a proper approach to industry development in this resource based industry, because if we do not do that we will end up with a position where we will see wholesale shipping out of the forest based resource.

I do not have any truck with that as far as private plantation wood is concerned. I think it is the right of the private forest owner and the private forest grower to have access to the marketplace, whether it be an international marketplace or a domestic marketplace. But I do believe, as I said earlier, that our crown forests belong to the country and they should be used as the basis for developing an industry within this country. There is a responsibility on all governments. All of the governments have signed up to—and eventually Tasmania did—the national forest policy statement, and the intentions and objectives of that statement gave a commitment to do that.

I want to refer to a paper put out by the Forests and Forest Industry Council of Tasmania entitled Secure Futures for Forests and People, which is a blueprint for the future of the Tasmanian forest industry. As a member of the executive of that council, I often go back and read the mission statement which says:
To responsibly and sensibly manage Tasmania's forests in a way that:
1. protects and conserves environmental values; and
2. provides long-term job security and additional job opportunities for employees.

Well, boy did we fail, because there has been nothing but a continued decline in the jobs in the forest industries in Tasmania. One of the primary reasons that has happened is that the state government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which runs the forests.

—Exactly right, Senator Collins, because at the end of the day it is state governments that have the principal responsibility for the management and operations of the forest industry. The Commonwealth has a capacity only in so far as export controls are concerned and, in many instances, we have overlooked the way in which those controls ought to have been used. This Tasmanian forest industry strategy document goes to the question of people issues. Principle 1 under the heading `people issues' reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The forests and forest industry strategy must produce an outcome which protects and seeks to enhance jobs of Tasmanians who currently work in the forest or who are dependent on the forest products industry for their livelihood.

Again, it is sad in that we have failed dismally. The course of action that this government has taken with regard to the scrapping of the industry council is just another example of the steps that have been taken by conservative governments to sell off the farm—to allow it to be chopped down and sold off at the earliest opportunity. You need to involve parties that represent workers in the industry to enhance job creation. At present you could go to any number of work sites around this country that are working in the forest based industry and ask them if they think that their industry is heading in the right direction in so far as job creation is concerned, and they will all tell you, `No, it is not.'

There have been many international reports produced on this industry over time which tell us that, within our own region of the world, there is a shortfall in terms of supply over demand of timber products. We know that for a fact. We know that, even if we cut down every tree and every plantation and indeed every native forest that is accessible, we still would not even be able to meet a small percentage of the requirement for timber products in our area of the world—that is, within the Asia-Pacific region. On the basis of our having that knowledge, if we cannot proceed to take steps to ensure that we get an industry that serves to better utilise the resource that is in the forests—whether it be plantation or not—then there is a major problem.

By way of example, I can remember—and Senator Collins will remember this very clearly as the principal minister responsible—when we used to deal with woodchip licences on an annual basis. We put in a requirement—I think it was in 1994-95—for a greater commitment to value adding. Even prior to that, we always placed some emphasis on a commitment to value adding. Of course, the companies used to trot up every year. They would have a feasibility study for an MDF plant or a pulp mill or a particle board mill. It was a feasibility study into a feasibility study but nothing ever happened. I have raised these issues before in this Senate.

When we debated another regulation that related to export woodchip licences, I noted that Senator Harradine said that he would also be watching how we proceeded, to ensure that jobs were created in this industry. I hope that he will take note of the circumstances that are occurring in this country's forest industries today.

I keep referring to Tasmania because I know the Tasmanian forest industry better than the industry in most other states. But I can give an example in Victoria where Harris‐Daishowa actually refused to take residue woodchips from Andrews Sawmill. Andrews Sawmill is a sawmill we initially helped set up. We ensured that the residue from their operation, which was cutting very low‐grade logs, would be sold at a fair price and exported as woodchips. This year, after the issuing of the licences, Harris‐Daishowa said that it would not take the residue from Andrews. It did so on the basis that they said that the residue was not saw log residue. Technically, they were right because the logs that Andrews were cutting were not classified as saw logs. They were a lower grade than any classification the Victorian forestry had for saw log classifications or specifications.

Let me refer to one proponent in Tasmania who was wanting to build a recovery sawmill and was seeking to purchase resource from the forestry for another sawmill on the north‐west coast. In my view the Forestry Commission of Tasmania, because of the pressures it had upon it from major industry players, refused—not directly, but indirectly; this was the net effect—to sell the wood to this person to run that operation, which would have created around 100 jobs. They stood up in a court case and said—which I find amazing—that they only had an obligation to find 300,000 cubic metres of saw logs. That was a statutory obligation. They did not have any obligation to go out and look for some additional saw logs to supply to other proponents. They did not have any obligation to set specifications for what they call category 8 saw logs—no obligation at all.

I say to the Forestry Commission of Tasmania: you do have an obligation. You have an obligation to ensure that we better this industry and that we create more jobs in it, because it can create many thousands more jobs. It has a huge potential. But it will have no potential if it is not guided in the right direction.

When we were in government, we did things with the car industry and the steel industry, because they needed that guidance. We need to do it with the forest industry. It is unfortunate that we had to come in here to debate a motion—and I say this with no disrespect to Senator Brown—put up by Senator Brown essentially for another purpose. I also agree with Senator Bob Collins in that I do not believe that Senator Brown necessarily has too much concern about how many people are working in the industry. I guess that is fine. That is a position he has taken. But I certainly do have a concern, as I said earlier.

I put the government on notice that, with my colleagues, I will pursue the government to ensure that you do put in place the industry council that you gave a commitment to and, when you have put that council in place, that it is representative of the people in the industry. That includes the workers of the industry. I have seen many councils called industry councils come and go. They have essentially failed. I will also, along with my colleagues, pursue the government to ensure that, whatever that industry council recommends in terms of industry strategy, it will be taken notice of. It will not be a straw man exercise. We will pursue the government and continue to review your position. As I said, we will take whatever course of action is necessary to bring about a change if that is what is required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting debate today; and it is a debate that needs to be had. I do find it disturbing that it seems that any sort of call for some sort of industry policy is greeted by both sides of the chamber as if it is a dirty word. An industry policy that looks at ecological sustainability and employment and outcomes should not be a dirty word. We seem to have changed so quickly in such a short time that the assumption is that whatever the larger and often internationally controlled corporations want is necessarily best for the industry, best for Australia and best for employment. I do not think the proof is there.

SPEECH.PARA: I personally have had a deep‐seated interest in the issues of employment and ecologically sustainable development. At the time I was elected, I was working on a research master's degree in economics on that very topic. That interest has continued. I was working on a cost‐benefit analysis in terms of real total outcomes with the community on resource development projects.

Also, I have had a very specific interest over time in relation to the sustainable timber industry in Western Australia and, in particular, the potential for agroforestry. A lot of the debate has been about plantation, but it is also about moving to a whole range of structures in the future which will allow a win‐win situation. I can back up this interest because under the internship program in 1996 we commissioned a student, Sophie Clayton, who produced a very good report—I will be tabling it at a later date and referring to it in some detail—which dealt with agroforestry as a component of the timber industry in Western Australia.

There have been a lot of issues and arguments thrown around today, but there are certainly differences of opinion about whether or not the current plantation and agroforestry resources in Australia are sufficient to cover the sawn timber needs of Australia. Judy Clark, in 1995, produced a report called `Australia's plantations: industry, employment and environment' for Environment Victoria in Melbourne. It is true to say there have been papers and criticism of Judy Clark's figures. Judy has got a lot of credibility on the issue, but it is true that the National Association of Forest Industries produced a report in 1995 refuting some of her statements. Judy, herself, has answered a lot of its criticisms in another report in 1996. What we can be sure of is that there is a debate about the current plantation resource.

There are those who believe they have the figures to show that the current plantation resources in Australia are sufficient to cover the sawn timber needs of Australia at the moment. Senator Lees mentioned the situation in the housing industry in South Australia. Across Australia the irony is that the vast majority of timber used in the housing industry is actually imported timber. Several speakers today have certainly mentioned that we have an annual trade deficit in forest products. It is true and it is around $2 billion a year. The total volume of timber in states like Western Australia is similar. But, in fact, the value adding and the difference in the costs means that we have a distinct deficit, and that is the same right around Australia. There is a total deficit of around $2 billion annually.

The Senate has heard from Senator Murphy in the past that he is concerned about the issue of value adding, and so am I. I really do think that in Western Australia some of the issues become very interesting in relation to this proposal to deregister regulations for the export of plantation wood, because Western Australia has been given a proposal for a mega pulp mill. This grew by 40 per cent even from the time it was drafted until the time it was presented to the Greens (WA), trying to get up to world scale. I hate to think what it is now.

I believe that pulp mills do not have to be at world scale, because the most important thing for any kind of value adding, such as paper manufacturing, is that you actually use your mill at full capacity. If you build a pulp mill at a scale at which you have no likelihood of continuing to be able to operate it at full capacity, you are not going to be operating efficiently, so I believe it is more effec tive to build your pulp mill at a scale that is realistic. Even boutique style pulp mills for different sorts of products might be useful at times, so long as you have your market organised, you have a little bit of flexibility and you can build in the options. I believe there is a potential to build in the options for farm forestry and agroforestry as well.

In the proposal in Western Australia, I think it was something like 250,000 cubic metres mooted originally. Now at that level in Western Australia we would have had enough, I believe, plantation timbers available to just meet that, providing they kept being replanted. But by the time the scale even reached 400,000 cubic metres, if my figures are correct, we were way beyond the point where they were even planning to meet the capacities of what existed in Western Australia. That meant that they were planning a pulp mill that would continue to be an old‐growth forest munching monster—there is no way around it.

When you add the fact of the removal of export controls on unprocessed wood—low value plantation wood—that means that if that proposal does happen in Western Australia, there is no way around it. Those people who will find a potential quick market for their plantation wood now will have that withdrawn from availability by the time the pulp mill comes into action, if it does come into action. I certainly hope the pulp mill that they are proposing does not. I would like to see appropriately scaled pulp mills that are, indeed, ecologically sustainable.

There have also been comments made today about the reasons why people are not investing in plantations, and I would like to give some other reasons as well. In Western Australia, Sophie Clayton went around to a large number of people. She talked to government representatives, farming representatives, pastoralists and graziers, foresters and forestry people. There are a couple of cultural impediments. They included the example that was given by the Department of Conservation and Land Management on this issue, which was not too special—their responsibility for education and extension on those issues—and also the lack of desire of many farmers to enter into an arrangement in Western Australia with CALM or Bunnings. So in Western Australia there are deep cultural issues which actually came up as more important to those people who were surveyed as things which currently hold them back from taking the step of getting into plantations or agroforestry.

There are economic barriers, and they include lack of finance due to the high cost of establishing trees. There was a situation where there is a market in Western Australia for blue gums, but not enough planning in terms of other forms of tree planting as well. But there were legal issues as well. One of those was the ownership of land and trees, which was cited as one of the those issues in terms of the investment patterns offered to farmers. That came out of the farm forestry task force of 1995. But, as was mentioned today, there were other things cited as legal impediments, and one is the ability to harvest produce. The only impediment that was mentioned today as the main impediment—and those people who mentioned it surely must have known others—was that people wanted access to exports. The work that has been done in Western Australia indicated that people wanted access to the ability to harvest, which does not necessarily equate to access to exports. If there was an industry policy, either state or federal, then the value adding and the ability to value add to these timbers would mean that the best price would be actually gained by value adding within Australia, providing those goods which we are currently importing at very large cost to our economy.

I think there are a lot of issues on employment that I have mentioned on many occasions but which people forget about, such as the fact that there are a lot more people employed in industries associated with live forests than there are with industries cutting them down. We risk a hell of a lot more jobs by cutting down old growth forests than we ever do from putting them through the chip mill. That is a fact; there are a lot more jobs at risk from losing the old growth forests to the chip mill than from the chipping industry or even at this stage from the sawn timber industry in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: We never tend to think of those, perhaps because there are a lot more women and younger people involved with those jobs in small industry—provisions, tourism and transport; you name it—all throughout the areas where people like to go to the forest. Those jobs are important and they should not be considered as if they are not existing. They do exist and they are at threat when you threaten that resource. I think it is important that we see this as a whole issue. I would like to point out that amongst members of the Greens and the green supporters there are farmers and farm foresters. These issues have been of great importance and I believe they have a lot to add to this debate.

The standard debate has been difficult today because there have been some statements made. I think Senator O'Chee probably started it off with some statements which tended to deliberately misread the statements made today. There must be an understanding of the connection between what we are doing on industry policy, with plantations or agroforestry, and our old growth forests. It is unfortunate that there did not seem to be a knowledge of the link between those two. I really hope the knowledge and understanding of that increases in the future. I would like to see us moving towards a truly ecological policy in relation to industry, a policy that does look at jobs in general, the total jobs available, that looks at sustainable policies in the future and at job creation within the industry. That is what I have been working on for a long time.

I look forward in the not too distant future to presenting and tabling in the Senate this report by Sophie Clayton and giving more details on the issues. In Western Australia it is a very important issue. I therefore indicate that I will be supporting Senator Brown's motion. I do believe we have to be looking at this issue as an industry policy and I do not think industry policy is something we in Australia should be ashamed of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts's focus on industry policy—and putting aside some of the failures acknowledged by Labor senators in the debate today—needs to be emphasised because it is an important and vital industry. It is an industry which needs to be promoted and provoked. In the last decades of decline, regional Australia has been depopulated and degraded, and it has lost many thousands of jobs, closed up communities, moved increasingly into agribusiness and experienced massive environmental degradation.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that the parties that have been in government in the Commonwealth and the states during those decades have been full of well‐meaning and committed Australians. Those are hardly outcomes that any one of them would like to have laid on their shoulders. But those decades have seen the National Party, the Liberal Party and the Labor Party capturing policies that have delivered those outcomes and at some time surely we have to question the value of their judgment in such matters.

This debate is about processing plantation timber in Australia—although Senator Margetts has properly made the link to old growth forests—and about raising the value of both the old growth and plantation timber industries. The careful, unradical—if that is a proper word—well‐researched and very capable Judy Clark, who is widely used, as senators would know, by the plantation companies as a consultant, has supported Senator Brown's disallowance motion in a letter that I received. I think that is quite an important point to make because it is one thing to point to Senator Brown and his constituency and his particular views; it is quite another when there is a wide ranging group which supports an alternative view on this matter.

I think this current government is going to be condemned by future generations for what may come to be described as environmental crimes. But ignore that emotive categorisation, because by their own standards there is an even worse possibility and that is that they are going to be condemned for their economic crimes. Judged by their own standards they are not fostering with this policy—as Senator Margetts, Senator Lees, Senator Brown and I think Senator Murphy have clearly indicated—the greatest return, long‐term industrial prospects or the creation of jobs. The current policies appear to us to be those of a grabbing, short‐term, commission taking sort of lawyers brief kind of government—let's have the brief, let's take the money and let's move on to the next issue.

Someone who I would describe as a laissez‐faire free marketer on the government side told me some time ago that he was absolutely dismayed by government policy in the timber industry. He believed that the timber industry, from whatever perspective—his perspective, the free market perspective, the economic perspective, the environmental perspective—is being ripped off because our trees, our industries and our resources are totally undervalued. Not only are we destroying an invaluable finite resource—and all of us on this side of the cross‐party benches believe those trees are worth far more standing up in the old‐growth forests than being cut down—but all of us believe that the plantation industry is not getting the returns it should. That person on the government side told me that he thought we were selling our assets for a pittance.

With regard to this export disallowance motion, we say that the Commonwealth is moving to deregulate all areas of the timber industry and to remove itself from any role in environmental protection and regulation in the timber industry without substituting a carefully crafted industry policy. The two Labor senators who spoke earlier made it clear that they are concerned at the big holes in the policy that has been spelt out. These government regulations are part of that overall process.

As a Western Australian senator, I must tell you that in our vast state we have approximately 87,000 hectares—I can never get my mind around cubic metres; I can get my mind around hectares—of pine or softwood plantations and approximately 60,000 hectares of blue gum hardwood plantations. We are indebted, in fact, to our conservative colleagues as the predecessors who established those plantation industries in the first place.

Most of the pine plantations in WA, the soft wood plantations, are publicly owned and managed by CALM, the Department of Conservation and Land Management—that well-known organisation which is both exploiter and conserver and is continually ridden by the conflict of interest that therefore results. Most of the blue gum hardwood plantations, in contrast, are privately owned—by many of the companies which Senator Brown outlined earlier.

Those stocks of logs—and no‐one in the Senate has disagreed—are an extremely valuable resource. Our view is that they are undervalued—and drastically so. They are undervalued in terms of the following things. As public assets, most of the pine plantation estate was established using taxpayer funds. The plantations are not valued in the national accounts. One of the things I like about the New Zealand national accounts is that at least they value their natural resources, and that appears in the national balance sheet. We would like to see the same thing happen in the state balance sheet and the Commonwealth balance sheet. What is the value of our national natural resource?

In terms of the economic value, if the logs were sold off onto the global commodity market, they would earn a fraction of the value they would earn if they were processed into timber products in WA. In terms of job creation, I had the enlightening experience of asking the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr McGauran) about manufacturing jobs and he gave a non-answer; I got no answer.

There is already major investment in downstream processing of plantation wood in WA and there is great scope, as my Western Australian colleague Senator Margetts has said, for increased processing and job creation. Once again, returning to the very level-headed economist Judy Clark, her landmark study shows that in WA alone there could be a doubling of the existing 1,500 plantation processing jobs if existing stocks of plantation wood were processed domestically. That is a doubling of jobs.

There is the potential to substitute resources to allow old‐growth forests to be protected. As you know, I have a strong interest in the tourism and small business industry and I believe old‐growth forests need to be protect ed not only for their intrinsic value as a natural resource but in terms of tourism, and small business relations with that.

Governments and industry, in contrast, in our part of the world appear keen to see this plantation resource liquidated—with that kind of short‐term, commission‐taking mentality of theirs—so that it cannot be used as an alternative to the destruction of our remaining old‐growth forests. When they hear that there is a bottomless market out there which we can hardly fill, they see an opportunity to chop the forests down. We must resist those people.

The push to deregulate the export of logs from the plantations is, in my view, a short‐sighted, short‐term, exploitative and asset stripping manoeuvre by state governments who are short of money and by business corporations who want money. CALM and our short‐term commission takers in WA would probably be delighted if they could liquidate their pine stock as a short‐term fundraising opportunity.

The Democrats have the view that, until such time as an industry policy is sketched out which preserves on a long-term sustainable basis the plantation processing industry and the old‐growth national park and tourism sector, we will not be satisfied with these kinds of regulations, which are simply based on an opportunity to exploit a finite resource.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all members for their contribution to the debate on the export disallowance motion. I would like to make some comments on some factors raised in the debate before this goes to a vote.

SPEECH.PARA: What has come out of the debate is the irrefutable connection between our plantation resource in Australia and our native forest resource. Senator Bob Collins, in his speech, asked: how do the two go together? The continual reference to the work of forest economist Judy Clark has answered that question.

One of the things that her studies—which were done in close conjunction with the plantation industry around this country—discovered was that there are 24 million cubic metres of plantation forests available for the wood products industry in this country. That is equivalent to six years of the sawlog supply currently coming out of our native forests. On top of that, the plantation sawlog supply in Australia will double over the next three years.

We cannot put our heads in the sand on that, Senator Collins. The reality is that this is factual material. It is time that the woodchip industry in particular, and some of the big players who are part of the National Association of Forest Industries—some of the CEOs that you listed in your contribution, Senator Collins—no longer get away with the myth that there is no alternative to our native forests for supplying the Australian domestic requirement.

It has been established that our plantation base can supply our domestic needs. What is required is the political will to achieve a win‐win situation by getting our domestic needs from that plantation availability at the same time as protecting our native forests from the big logging companies. The policies of successive governments are facilitating the wreaking of ongoing destruction by those companies.

Senator Murphy's words ring with a sad truth. He and I have been sparring partners in Tasmania in the past. Indeed, I can remember Senator Murphy, as a representative of the workers of the industry, blockading the Wilderness Society's head office at 130 Davies Street at the time of Farmhouse Creek, and the industry invasion of what is now a component of the world heritage forests of Tasmania. Senator Murphy was representing, as ever, the interests of the workers of the industry in Tasmania and targeting the environmentalists.
