He is a very honest man. Rarely does an honest man stand up in this Senate and say, `We failed'—that is, the Labor Party—`to protect the interests of the workers.' Here we are a decade down the line from that time when he was blockading the Wilderness Society and thousands of jobs had been shed out of the industry, not because of environmentalists but because of the big logging corporations. It is in their interests to foster their profit line by getting rid of workers. But it is not in the national interest—it is in nobody's interest—that we foster a policy of unrestricted export of whole logs which could be processed within the country and create jobs here.

I reiterate that the 440,000 cubic metres of whole logs already licensed to be exported out of Tasmania would create 44 jobs in getting those plantation trees stripped, trucked and shipped out. Were those trees to be processed here in Australia, it would create 1,800 jobs. When is the Labor Party going to listen to what Senator Murphy has to say? When is it going to make him the minister for resource development for forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's voting against your motion.

—I am coming to that. Do not sound so exasperated, Senator Collins. You are on the record today as saying that you want to lift all licence restrictions. You are on the record as saying that you take full responsibility for the Labor Party's debacle in office.
—I said nothing of the sort, Senator Brown. You specialise in misrepresentation. That's why you're such a dreadful hypocrite.
—We'll leave it to people who have listened to this debate and to Hansard .
—I said nothing of the sort.
—Well, let people read your record, Senator Collins.
—I said I proposed lifting export controls from plantation timber, Senator Brown.
—And that is what is proposed here.
—Correct.

—Let me say what is involved there because Senator Collins does not seem to understand. A majority of that plantation timber is on public land, not on private land, which is where Senator Murphy's concern is. It is on public land where once native forests stood. It is on land that the taxpayers of this country have a say on because it is their land. It is not the logging company's land; it is public land.

SPEECH.PARA: Those plantations are going to be knocked down and their timber exported elsewhere without us having the downstream benefit and opportunity for job creation in this country. That will be because of the regulation that the government is putting through here, which you, Senator Collins, are supporting. What is more, future native forests will be clobbered under this attitude of `Let the woodchip industry control the business' and `Let us divest the parliament of responsibility and export it.' Those lands will be turned into plantations where the industry deigns them to be. In the future there will be no licensing control of the export of those logs out of this country. That is how the whole process will go.

Let me remind you, Senator Collins, that when you were in government and the environment people, which you run down so readily, were lobbying as best as their hearts would let them on behalf of the majority of Australians to protect our native forests, the government was confronted with a blockade of this parliament—it was illegal; it would not have been allowed if they were environmentalists—basically at the behest of the CEOs on the list that you read out. They were the corporations facilitating that blockade.

When that blockade occurred, you sold out. Prime Minister Keating went weak at the knees. Let me give credit to former environment minister Senator John Faulkner, for he had come up with a list of forest areas in this country which were too precious to hand over to the woodchippers, limited as that list was. Prime Minister Keating brought you in and knocked the environment minister out of the way, and you presided over handing those forests to the woodchip industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—That's the record, and no wonder, in that extreme situation—
—Senator Brown, if you directed your comments through the chair you would not attract so many interjections from Senator Collins.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, it is your job to see that the interjections do not come.
—Don't you tell me about my job. You just get on with what you have to do. Direct your comments through me.
—I am doing that, because it is disorderly—
—You might as well be disorderly to everybody, I suppose.
—It is disorderly to have interjections like those coming from Senator Collins—
—I do not need your advice, Senator Brown.
—and it is not right to charge me with ignoring those when they are disorderly.
—Senator Brown, I am asking you to direct your comments through the chair.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think the honourable senator's comments were in contempt of the chair, and he should be asked to withdraw them.
—On the point of order, I did not take them as in contempt of the chair, but I remind Senator Brown to direct his comments through the chair and I ask Senator Collins to refrain from interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Of course they are not in contempt. We have it right now. Senator Collins has been asked to refrain from interjecting and I will, therefore, have no problem in not responding to his out of order interjections.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying, the logging corporations facilitated a blockade of this place. The Keating government went weak at the knees. They caved in. They sold out the forests. They sold out the interests of the Australian people. Part of the result of that has been a change of government, which is selling out even faster.

BREAK.PARA: The problem we have is that neither Labor nor Liberal has stood up for the public interest when it comes to the forests of Australia. Part of that awful failure to stand up for the national interests as far as our forests are concerned is re-emerging here today when Labor is going to support the Howard government in lifting any licence restrictions on the export of plantations out of this country as whole logs, and with them the export of jobs and the export of downstream processing.

Let me return to Senator Murphy, who, I think, made a very telling contribution to this debate from his position within the Labor Party benches. He said that the industry has huge potential but that it will do nothing if it is not guided in the right direction. That is what Senator Lees is saying. That is what Senator Margetts is saying. That is what this corner of the chamber—outgunned by Labor and Liberal—is saying as well. You do not overcome the problem by lifting what little restrictions there are on this industry, which is headed in the wrong direction.

I acknowledge that we are not going to have the numbers in the Senate, but I stand confident that we have the numbers on this matter when it comes to the Australian electorate. The opinion polls have repeatedly shown where the numbers stand as far as the logging industry—cutting into our native forests at a time when the plantation forests are available to meet our domestic supplies—is concerned.

Having listened to the debate, I feel more resolute than ever in moving this disallowance motion. I remind honourable senators that under the standing orders any senator shall declare any relevant interest as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the Senate on matters like this. I remind honourable senators that companies which grow plantations and in which they may have shares include North, Wesfarmers, Boral, Amcor, Fletcher Challenge, News Corporation, CSR, Auspine and a number of plantation investment trusts. I commend this disallowance motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare an interest in this matter, as I have done previously.
—I declare an interest but, at the same time, declare that I think it is a minimal interest.
—I declare the same interest which I have declared in the past and, as I have in the past, say that I do not believe it is a conflict of interest.
—I also declare an interest, as in the Senate register of shares, in CSR, Amcor and Boral.
—I declare the interest that I have declared in the past, Madam President.
—I similarly declare an interest, which is recorded in the register of interests.
—I declare an interest.
—I declare that I own two acres of pine plantation.
—I similarly declare an interest, which is in the register of interests.
—Following on from Senator Woodley, I also declare that I have five acres of pine plantation, although it is not being used for plantation.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—With respect to the vote on the previous motion, I declared my interest, as did others, but I question the materiality of the matter which was brought forward by Senator Brown. It is hard for any of us to know whether, in fact, there is any material interest by owning shares in companies involved in pine plantations because you really do not know whether or not they are exporting logs. Be that as it may, I bring to the attention of the Senate that it is recorded in the register of senators' interests, as reported on 3 October last year, that Senator Brown holds a share in the Tasmanian Greens Pty Ltd and is also a director of the Australian Bush Heritage Fund.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian Greens Pty Ltd is a proprietary company limited by shares and it lists its principal activity in the Australian Securities Commission database as political party administration. Information contained on the Internet in respect of the Tasmanian Greens party explains that the Tasmanian Greens Pty Ltd takes care of the financial concerns of the Tasmanian Greens and that its role is to keep track of budgets and cash flow, give approval for expenditure on behalf of the Tasmanian Greens and manage their wages fund.

The Australian Bush Heritage Fund is a company limited by guarantee whose principal activity is the raising of funds towards the purchase of private land of environmental significance. The fund raises money to both purchase private land and generally manage that land.

Given the role of the Tasmanian Greens Pty Ltd as fund raiser for the Tasmanian Greens and the fact that the political party's strident opposition to forest industries can be considered as a principal source from which it derives support, and further given that the Australian Bush Heritage Fund has both a direct and indirect benefit in land management issues in Australia, particularly the protection of various forms of forested areas, I wonder whether it is reasonable to conclude that Senator Brown by his shareholding and directorship has a potential conflict of interest in voting on matters relating to forest industries.

I note these matters without criticising either the Tasmanian Greens Pty Ltd or the Australian Bush Heritage Fund. Rather, I note that Senator Brown has participated in debates here in the Senate on several occasions and again today on motions related to woodchips or logging and there have been two occasions prior to today since 3 October on which this has happened. On neither of these occasions did he consider it necessary to follow the Senate's resolutions on the registration and declaration of senators' interest. In particular, he did not consider it necessary to satisfy the terms of section 5 of that resolution by declaring a relevant interest either at the beginning of the speech or as soon as practicable after the relevant division on the vote was called.

I further note that Senator Brown on 14 October last year reflected on the propriety of honourable senators in this place by calling on those senators who had shareholdings in the companies which potentially stood to obtain a financial benefit as a result of decisions in the Senate in that instance to stand aside from voting on the motion. Furthermore, on 6 February last Senator Brown drew the attention of the Senate, quite rightly, to the fact that several senators had failed to satisfy the terms of the standing orders by declaring their interests at the appropriate time.

As the Senate would be aware I, together with several others, had inadvertently failed to follow the correct procedure on that occasion but we made the appropriate declarations at the earliest possible opportunity; that is, once the matter had been drawn to our attention. Given Senator Brown's demonstrated concern for propriety in this chamber, I call upon him to declare his interests and explain why he has failed to declare those interests at the relevant times since the 3 October event.

At the same time, Madam President, I convey to you my concern that I believe the present operation of the standing orders in relation to declaration of interests in debate and at times of voting is quite ambiguous and leaves open to interpretation exactly what interests should be declared. I think the matter of materiality should be given consideration in those standing orders. They do nothing, in my opinion, to advance the disclosure of relevant interests to the Senate nor to the Australian people and therefore contribute nothing to the confidence of the Australian people in the parliament. I believe this matter needs to be looked into by a relevant committee of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The irritability of the honourable senator is understandable, but the interests register is there for the purposes of making sure that we as senators do not take inappropriate interest in self-serving matters which are going to help line our pockets. We have to be very careful about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very proud of the interests that the honourable senator has pointed out that I have in both the Greens and the Australian Bush Heritage Fund. They are not profit making ventures and they are not germane to the debate we have just had in any way.

I do understand your irritability, but the Senate has had long debate about this before. The rules are there. They are there to be acted upon. When you have such a clear interest in the matter of the logging industry that you have shares in the corporations making profits out of our private and public forests, you should declare that. It is as simple as that. If honourable senators opposite are obfuscated or feel aggrieved as far as the difficulty sometimes in putting your finger on what is a pecuniary interest or an interest in terms of this register is concerned, then that is a problem they will have to live with. I do not see any difficulty with the values that are incorporated in these rules for senators.

I intend, every time there is a vote like the one we have just had, to remind the Senate of the need to abide by these rules. They are sensible. They are there to help the public know that we are not lining our own pockets, that we are not going for a hidden pecuniary interest, that we are not fostering our own business connections or interests when we vote on matters in the Senate. I might add: it does not prevent us from voting. It simply says that we should make a declaration.

It is quite clear what the intention of the rules is. If you would like to seek a further ruling from the President in the matter, then I would be very happy to endorse that. I do not think it is necessary. I think the rules are quite explicit. I think the intention is quite explicit. As I say, I think it is a very healthy thing that senators who have a pecuniary interest or a self-interest of the sort that is meant by this register get up and declare it when they are voting on a matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will draw Senator Gibson's remarks to the attention of the Senators' Interests Committee.

DEBATE.TITLE:
TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1996 TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (TELECOMMUNICATIONS) BILL 1996
AUSTRALIAN COMMUNICATIONS AUTHORITY BILL 1996

TELECOMMUNICATIONS (NUMBERING CHARGES) BILL 1996

RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSMITTER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1996 RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1996
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1996

TELECOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1996
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Telecommunications Bill as a whole and Greens (WA) amendments 1 to 3, moved by Senator Margetts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I was part way through my discussion on network boundary. As I said, the Green and Democrat amendments are identical in intent. I went on to say that there was no indication in the legislation that consumers would receive a compensatory reduction in their installation costs or line rental charges reflecting the fact that carriers are no longer liable for wiring between the building entry point and the first socket. These were the concerns raised by the Communications, Electrical and Plumbing Union and by consumer organisations such as the CTN.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, these amendments also remove the right of the government to redetermine the network boundary through regulations. The Democrats sought to remove this because the definition of the network boundary has a major impact on consumers and we believe it should be spelled out in legislation.

The key problem with regulations as compared with legislation is that they offer significantly less opportunity for scrutiny. There is also the possibility that they will go by unnoticed by consumers or their representative organisations, particularly if the govern ment chooses not to make any announcements to the effect that they are seeking to redefine those network boundaries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposed to this proposition. The network boundary is an important factor in establishing the boundary between carrier equipment and cabling, and customer equipment and cabling. Its location is particularly crucial for competition. If I could just address some of the concerns that Senator Allison expressed, the location of the network boundary at the building entry point is not a conspiracy to save carriers money. It is in fact about providing an opportunity for the customers to have a choice. By definition, at least one carrier will suffer a disadvantage because it will remove a barrier to the introduction of competitive services.

SPEECH.PARA: The current location of the network boundary at the first socket or, in multi‐occupier buildings, at the main distribution frame works to the disadvantage of consumers by limiting the scope of competition for the installation of in‐building cabling, so customers have to pay the costs that their carriers decide to charge for cabling to the network boundary. It also makes it more expensive for customers to change carriers, because the carrier cannot connect at the network boundary and make use of existing in‐building cabling; it must install new cabling. This makes the introduction of competitive services more expensive than necessary and requires more cabling to be installed in houses while existing cabling is left unused.

The opposition went through this some years ago. Clearly, the closer the network boundary is to the actual handset, the less opportunity there is for competition and, therefore, choice and reduced prices. If you simply have a single carrier providing all of that service, then it is a monopoly service. If you allow competition, but nonetheless have that network boundary point very close to the handset, then the opportunities for in‐building competition or, in practical terms, to make your own arrangements for maintenance are dramatically reduced because there is hardly any length of cabling that could be put in on a competitive basis.

It is a very important element of competition to ensure that customers are able to choose that carriers will presumably continue to offer maintenance options. There ought to be the maximum scope for the carriers to do that, rather than having it minimised back to the closest point to the handset. For those reasons, we would oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you are not wrong to say that the Labor Party in government grappled with this argument about where the boundary of the network is. I suspect that as long as we have a telecommunications system with some national interests around, that argument will continue. My question about the structure of the present government legislation refers to page 31 of the Telecommunications Bill where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) If no regulations are in force for the purposes of subsection (1), then, for the purposes of sections 20 and 21, the boundary of a telecommunications network is:—

It then outlines what that is in (a), (b) and (c) and, over the page, it outlines what a building entry point is. It then outlines what a building is, which includes `a structure, a caravan and a mobile home'. I am not quite sure that, in a building industry definition, you would be able to say that a building is a caravan or a mobile home, but I understand why you have had to do that in terms of the Telecommunications Act.

Minister, do you have any plans that, when this is put through, that there will be generic regulations? Or will regulations only be brought in specifically for some special areas about the network boundary? You outline a description in (a), (b) and (c) that seems to me to be a pretty standard description. I just want to know whether it will be the exception to have regulations or a general rule to have regulations about what the boundary network is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that Austel has advised that it is not considered necessary at this stage to have regulations or guidelines but they would reserve the right to do that if problems emerged. But the starting point is to assume that there will be sufficient competition and the carriers and customers will be able to reach agreement which will not cause difficulties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that. In this definition about going to the entry point, particularly for a strata title building with many residents et cetera, the concern I have is really on the consumer side. It is about the simplicity of inquiring, if there is a malfunction or a fault. If the wire from the outside of the building in through to the actual flat or unit in the building is not part of the network boundary, that means that if the consumer has a problem they have to make a different phone call. How do they know who they ring to get that cable line fixed?

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing is that they ring Telstra or Optus, who are maybe the two in the local loop at the moment with more to come. If they are a subscriber to Telstra, how do they know that the cable from the outside of the building to the socket inside their unit is actually a Telstra responsibility? Where do they go and find who should fix it? If the building owner has done a different deal on wiring and so on and has got a different contract, maybe with a small independent electrical contractor, then I can see that some consumers are going to start arguing, or are going to find it difficult to get it fixed in an expeditious way.

I understand the competition argument but, in considering this, I want to try to balance that with the convenience of consumers getting quick access to how it is going to be fixed without being frustrated that you are going to have to make several phone calls to find out who is actually responsible for that last bit of cabling. The first thing that will happen is that Telstra will say, `It is not in our line, check your own internal line.' If you go to them further, they will say that it is probably Telstra's, back at the exchange. As we all know, that is the first device any bureaucracy, public or private, usually uses, to the frustration of customers. So that is an issue I wanted to raise: how the customer knows who to ring for a fault if they can try and find the fault in that part of the cable that is no longer part of the network.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that, in most instances, you would expect the carriers to offer a maintenance option. In other words, it will be business as usual for a great number of customers. It will only be for those who choose not to have the carrier accept responsibility for the in‐house cabling or maintenance where the alternative would arise.

SPEECH.PARA: Where you have got buildings that have a number of tenants in them, you could expect as a matter of practicality that there would be one person responsible for that for all tenants. It is most unlikely that you would be having a series of different arrangements. That is because in practice telephone systems do not break down all that often, and the need for that would not arise very frequently. It would therefore make sense to have one carrier or alternative tradesman responsible for those circumstances.

There may be a bit more I can add to that. It is that, in all cases, the carrier will test the line and determine whether the fault is on the carrier's or the customer's side of the network boundary. So in the first instance it would be business as usual, you would call your carrier.

If the fault is in the network, the carrier must fix this free of charge. If the fault is in the customer's cabling and if the customer has a cabling maintenance agreement with that carrier—which is what I was saying before—then the carrier will fix the problem. The carrier would be expected to do that on a contractual basis. If the customer has another arrangement, obviously the customer would call in that other person. So, in practice, it would only be those people who were proactively seeking to move away from the carriers who would have that alternative. Therefore, you would be aware of the fact that you had made other arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —In a competitive market, what happens with a building with several strata title households? The cabling is done when the building is put up. I am talking about in the future, so this is a new building. The landlord makes his or her own arrangement to put the cabling through and gets some separate contractor to do it to guarantee that the first socket is provided to everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: When that is done and you have a competitive market, people will start having different carriers. What happens if you get a lot of different tenants—a multitude of tenants, to use your phrase I overheard—using different carriers? Who is responsible for the various wirings? The switching box might actually be inside the building so some of it is going to be common cabling for the various households, but the households could have different carriers. What I am asking—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you overhear that answer?
—I just heard your question but I did not hear the answer. The advisers are very discreet. Perhaps you could repeat the answer for the rest of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —We were just saying that you would expect the body corporate to be responsible for those arrangements. Where you have a number of tenants, there would normally be a central organisation—a body corporate—responsible for a whole range of maintenance facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: It strikes me intuitively as being like an opt out situation. In other words, people would be connected to their carrier of choice. That carrier would charge them a maintenance fee, and that is who they would go to as a first and last port of call. It is only if they were consciously wanting their maintenance done by someone other than their own carrier that they would go to that other person, and they would know who that person was because they had made that conscious choice.

So, in practice, the vast majority of people will either rely on the body corporate or rely on the carrier because they will have built the maintenance fee into their rental charge. It is only those people in the population who actually see the competitive benefit from getting an alternative to their own carrier who would go elsewhere, and those people, by definition, would know where to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Just on this point, I think what we are talking about now is the actual demarcation point of the local loop. The minute you identify a body corporate as being the responsible party for cabling at the point of entry to a large block of flats—perhaps with a whole range of interconnected buildings—the distinction is drawn about the point of entry. How would you subsequently define that point of entry in a physical sense?

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned greatly about the notion that a body corporate would be responsible for the cabling at the point of entry to the building as opposed to the socket. That really does beg a physical definition of what constitutes a building, a structure and so forth. I ask the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) to think of this debate in those terms. How can we define anything other than the socket as being where the boundary of a network exists? It really opens up a can of worms that probably is not warranted at this stage because it can be dealt with quite succinctly with the amendment that we are debating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are opening a can of worms that is already well and truly open and thriving because the main distribution frame is the point at which responsibility for maintaining the cables inside those premises ceases. That does not cause any difficulties in housing estates or other areas where there are a large number of tenants.

SPEECH.PARA: But you still get back to the proposition that, if you take out a telephone line, if you rent a service, you will do it with a carrier of your choice and you will decide whether you want that carrier to continue to be responsible for maintenance. In most instances, I would expect that that would be the choice you would make. If you choose not to, then by definition you are aware that you have chosen not to use that carrier but you are prepared to make other maintenance arrangements. These are, in most instances, almost hypothetical because the need will not arise. But you will be aware that you have made that choice. If you have forgotten, the carrier will remind you.

It seems to me that all that is doing is providing you with an opportunity of choice which is not there at the moment. If you are simply required to have the carrier provide the service right up to a point close to the handset, then there is very little opportunity to do anything other than take what is a monopoly service from that carrier. That is obviously more expensive. You are better as a customer from having the choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The consumer can choose which carrier to have, as far as providing the service is concerned, irrespective of where the point is?
—Yes, that is right.

—They are not being restricted in having access to choosing any of the carriers who come along. If, for example, the cable at the moment goes to the socket and stays that way—and that is a Telstra installation, for historical reasons—and the consumer gets a better telephone deal on calls, packages et cetera from Optus and switches as a subscriber to Optus, Telstra does not go and pull the cable out, or Optus does not go and pull the cable out and re‐lay cable. They switch over and the infrastructure stays the same, because you do not rewire a building or your home just because you have changed subscribers.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what I understand all the arrangements for the interconnect are about, so that if you change the carrier, the cable is still the same. You might change the phone that plugs into the socket, because that is part of the deal, but you go back to the exchange, therefore that is an arrangement where there is an interconnect. It is Telstra's infrastructure which is being used and therefore they will charge Optus—if it is the new carrier for that subscriber—the appropriate interconnect fee that takes account of how they interconnect.

The real nightmare, in my view, might occur when you start having second and third carriers rolling around putting second and third cable ducts into buildings, like off the Optus cable outside which you can now see— and we have had arguments about that earlier today. If this means that second and third cables are going to be rethreaded into buildings so that that is the way the carrier comes in, I think the public are going to start saying, `This is getting out of hand. We don't need three water pipes or three gas pipes or three electricity wires coming in. Why don't we just have one wire? We can change between our carriers using the same infrastructure and the appropriate interconnect fee is there.'

If that happens, then I believe the maintenance issue handles itself: Telstra does the maintenance and puts that into their interconnect fee, and the customer knows who they ring up to get it fixed. Minister, if you go back to the kerb or the outside of the building, where the network ends, why not take it right back to the exchange? We had some evidence put before us at the Senate inquiry that, if you really want competition, let the consumer own the pair right back to the exchange and, at the exchange level, they will then have an ability to argue, `I do not want to be with any of you. You adapt the equipment at the exchange.'

This created considerable gulping of fresh air by Telstra, in particular, and Optus that the network would be so defined. Although we did not discuss this network issue at great length in the Senate committee, I may suggest after we had have this discussion that we should let this sit for a while, see how the new regulatory regime works in real practical terms and maybe revisit it in a couple of years. I cannot get clear the real advantage to the consumer in having the network shifted to the outside of the building from the socket.

I can understand it if it is simply a freestanding home because, in a sense, I do not think it is that complicated. But where you have a strata title building, which has a landlord and a strata title company involved, and people in the same building choosing to swap between carriers, they are not going to pull the lines out and redo them. The same line will be used. Therefore, if that is the Telstra line that is there at the moment, I believe people would expect them to be responsible for the maintenance and Telstra would then put that charge into its intercon nect fee if someone wants to go to Optus or Vodafone. It seems to me that this may not be a necessary issue for pure competition issues. There are practical consumer reasons for this to be left to work, and for us to see how it goes in the new regulatory regime and maybe in two years revisit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I find there are some fairly major issues in terms of consumer uncertainty here for many people. They do not have any idea about their cabling maintenance agreement. They put a phone on and they answer the phone. When the phone does not work, they try to find out why it does not work and try desperately to find out who is to fix it.
—They ring Telstra.

—They ring Telstra. People generally know that if the phone is within the house they are responsible for any problems, and that if it is outside that plug it is Telstra's problems. Even if they have not changed the system, if the rules change, then people who were used to having problems dealt with by the carrier, will suddenly find that their phone calls will lead to frustration and there will be a great deal of anger.

SPEECH.PARA: What you have done is roll back an existing provision and you have cost shifted on to the consumer. There is going to be a huge outroar, I believe, about the impact of this, and there will be frustration. We are not talking about people who have voluntarily negotiated a contract, we are talking about people who are living in a situation now who will find that the responsibility has shifted, overnight, without their doing anything. You talk about business certainty but this is consumer uncertainty. I think you will get angry consumers and you will deserve to get angry consumers if you go ahead with this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would also like to know a little more about these so‐called maintenance options. Would this mean that overnight all Telstra's current customers would be obliged to sign up for some maintenance agreement with Telstra? Is this an opportunity for revenue raising? What sort of fee would be involved in such an arrangement? Presumably the minister, or his department, has had discussions with the carriers. What is the indication of what a maintenance option might be? Is it an option not to have a maintenance agreement? How would all the customers of Telstra be informed about the options available to them? Would it go on their bill? Can you explain a little more how that system might work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Currently, Telstra charges $30 a month for a telephone handset rental and that includes maintenance. The vice of that is that it is a non‐transparent arrangement, it is bundled, and you do not know the true cost of the maintenance. It is no great secret that Telstra has made a lot of money over the years by building in a maintenance component and very rarely having to deliver. It is like insurance that never gets called up.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, with regard to the premises that you talked about—say a housing commission building involving a lot of different people—the main distribution frame is the building entry point, so beyond that everyone makes their own arrangements. As I understand it, Telstra have not been responsible for maintenance inside those premises for years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying in those places the socket entry—is it the main frame?
—Yes, it is not inside the flat.
—It is back downstairs in the basement.
—Yes, exactly. That is the main distribution frame and that has been the building entry point. That is the network boundary.
—You are saying that that is the network boundary.

—That is the network boundary and that has been the case for many years. What happens is that you ring the carriers, the body corporate, the housing trust or whoever is responsible if you have a problem. The reality is that people very rarely have a problem so it does not cause difficulties. But what would be able to happen under this arrangement is that if you make the boundary the telephone socket, that would mean that every competing carrier would need to provide in‐building cabling rather than connecting to a convenient point where the cable enters the building.

SPEECH.PARA: Your taking it right back to the exchange example is not simply an extension of the same principle at all, because once you get beyond the property perimeter you are getting into a whole area where faults can happen through no fault of anyone and where you would expect the carrier to be responsible. There might be an accident or there might be all sorts of breakdowns that it would not in any shape or form be realistic to expect an individual customer to solve. By that point individual lines have merged into a trunk line and individuals could not be responsible for all sending their own maintenance people in to fix the problem.

So once you get beyond the building line, or the property perimeter at the most, it seems to me you are talking about common property. But when you are on the premises, the issue really is whether you should be wanting to have some competition or as little as possible. If you make it the socket then you will have as little as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the maintenance competition will not be between the carriers. It will be between‐

—Yes, that is right. It will be between the people who actually do the work. So in theory you could say, `I don't want the carrier to do it. I want to save whatever it might be—$3 a month—because I know the chances of me needing that are infinitesimal.' On the other hand, I might have an agreement with a local tradesman who will insure me on an annual basis for half the price that Telstra will charge. Alternatively, I will simply buy in his services if I ever do need them, knowing that his rate is whatever it is—$20 an hour or something.
—Minister, can you explain that if the—
—There are other senators seeking the call, so I have to give them the call.
—I wonder, Minister, whether it is your expec tation that the connection fees would be reduced as a result of this different point of responsibility?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the inevitable consequences of competition—which is what we are talking about here—is that there are competing offers that would be available and you then have the choice. At the moment you do not have any choice and, therefore, you can be charged a monopoly price. Indeed, if it is built into your monthly rental fee you have no idea what you are paying. But if it is separated out and you then have the choice of continuing to pay, say, $3 a month to Telstra or maybe $1 a month to a tradesman who is prepared to give you insurance for it or simply pay as needed, you are in a position where you can make those sorts of decisions. The mere fact that you allow competition into the system means that monopoly rents cannot be charged and you are giving everyone a fair opportunity. At worst, you would end up with the status quo presumedly, where everyone would continue to use the same monopoly service and, I would have thought, run the very substantial risk of continuing to be overcharged.

—Minister, you did not respond earlier to Senator Schacht's question about why it was that the government has chosen this entry point and not the exchange. There were witnesses to the inquiry who made that suggestion and I have had subsequent correspondence from those people. Can you articulate a bit more clearly why it is that this is the right point and not the exchange or the socket? I do not know that we are altogether clear on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you really wanted to understand this chapter and verse you could look at a 1993 Austel report. I thought I had just been involved in an exchange with Senator Schacht where I was explaining how I thought it would create very serious difficulties if one tried to go back to the exchange as the point and then make people responsible for their own lines between the home and the exchange. Quite clearly, there are a number of breakdowns that could occur there where it would be quite unreasonable to expect individual consumers to address them.

—That would give true competition to the service providers. You want to get competition for maintenance. It is not in the provision of a range of services that can be provided. If you get back to the exchange, you really get competition on the services provided, not just on the maintenance.

—But the difficulty as I see it—and this is just an off‐the‐cuff assessment—is that, once your line gets out into the street and then is joined into a duct that contains a number of others, it becomes a much more difficult task to separate that out, particularly if there is a significant breakdown in the system. And the people who are the experts in that ought to be the ones that deal with it. The average tradesman who is looking after maintenance of telephone handsets inside the home probably has a different range of skills altogether and would not regard himself as being a network specialist.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are talking about here is whether you regard the point of competition as being the handset, in which case any competing carriers would have to build their own lines right up to that network point—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it only competition on maintenance you are offering?

—No, it is not, it is on installation and maintenance. That is why I say new lines. If a second carrier comes in, if they have to cater for the network boundary point being the wall socket, then they will have to install a new cable to the wall socket. I would not have thought that makes a great deal of sense. It is not in the consumer's interest. What the consumer wants is a convenient connection point outside the home and, from then on, you have one line coming in.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has the call.

—I suppose I was inviting Senator Schacht to respond. Perhaps I will just finish by saying that it is both installation and maintenance. On the maintenance front, if you have it at the wall socket, there is virtually no opportunity for choice because what can go wrong between that point and the handset is negligible. The further back it goes, the more opportunity there is for competition in maintenance of that system. As I say, you should not contemplate going beyond the house or the household perimeter but, if you go back to the building entry point, you are providing an opportunity to get competing quotes and lower prices as a result.

—I am not convinced that what we are going to end up with here is going to be cheaper for people. I am certainly not convinced that it is going to be easier or simpler; I think it is going to be extremely complex. I just wonder whether or not the potential for access codes for lines entering the building has been considered, instead of what you are talking about here.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —If by `access' you mean interconnection arrangements, they are quite separately dealt with. In many respects that is why you would not need to go back to the exchange, because you are guaranteed access. If you are talking about guidelines that govern how the maintenance arrangements ought to be engaged in, then you are simply trying to tell tradesmen how to do their job, I would have thought.

—No. To clarify the situation, Mr Chairman, I was not talking about that—or, at least, I did not think I was. I was actually talking about the potential to avoid all the duplication by the carrier, so that each time you chose a new carrier you would not have to put a new line in to the house. Basically, I was suggesting that there should not be all this duplication. We always talk about not wanting to duplicate. Could there not be a situation where, by means of access codes, existing lines that go to the socket could be utilised by whichever carrier gets the job? Is that impossible? Why are we actually entering into a situation where people have to change the lines if they change carrier, if that is not necessary?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that, if you want to change carriers and you are already connected to Telstra and you have got a single line into the home or a twisted copper pair, you simply cannot effectively appropriate the Telstra line. The alternative carrier has to provide a competing line to the network termination point. It is convenient to do that if it is at the building entry point on the outside of the building. But it is highly inconvenient, and obviously much more expensive, if the network boundary point is the wall socket, because that means that the second line has to be brought right inside the house up to that connection point. That is what happens. If you want to allow competition into the system, you ought to allow it to take place at a point where it is not inconvenient to the householder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, that is a very good clarifying point you made, and it is to the advantage of the Senate to consider it. If the boundary point is at the socket inside the house, or particularly a multiple‐residence block of flats of strata title, you are saying that, because it is owned by Telstra and the person swaps to another carrier, that new carrier—presumably Optus, in most cases, to start off with—would not only have to provide a new cable coming in to the outside of the house or the building, but also have to thread a new cable up to the wall socket inside the subscriber's home. All the existing wiring that is owned by Telstra is going to become redundant and is going to lie there until they choose to switch back: is that the case?

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that, whether people understand the purity of competition policy or not, I suspect they are going to be a little perplexed that, when they change carrier, the carrier has to thread a new wire and leave the other wire there, in case they switch back in another two years time when Telstra makes a better offer. That means that in all the existing buildings of Australia—and not just in multiple buildings but in normal homes—the wire is Telstra's property. I will wait for the minister to confer, Mr Chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy, did you wish to make any comment to the minister? If you want to comment to the minister, I do not know that he would be able to follow.

—I would like to further clarify this point. The minister has articulated the fact that the alternative hardware—the alternative line—goes to that external point. Yet the possession and maintenance or ownership and control of that point inside the home is—as I understand from what the minister is saying—very much in the hands of the resident. So, in fact, there is an inherent transfer or relinquishment of that hardware from the point of entry in the building, by virtue of the fact of the introduction of competition policy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can add another clarification. There are two ways in which you can change carriers. One is on an existing telephone service, where you simply want to go across and opt for Optus. You can do that by preselection and, in that case, there is no need to change the existing infrastructure.
—And they pay you the difference.

—That is right. If, however, you want to subscribe to a raft of new services—Optus, new telephony, broadband or pay TV—it is necessary for them to install their own line, because the Telstra line could not physically accommodate that raft of services. In order to do that, they have to run the cable in to the network boundary or the network termination point. It then becomes an issue of where that is located. If it is located right at the wall socket, then they have to run it into the house and to the wall socket. If it is located at the boundary of the house, that is where they run it to.
—But then, under your definition, to get it from the boundary on the perimeter of the building and up into the building—if it is a multistorey flat—are they going to use the existing Telstra cable?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is right.

—By legislation we are saying that what is Telstra's to the socket is not going to be owned by Telstra any more. Who is going to own it? You are saying to Telstra that, over the past 40 to 50 years, they have wired up goodness knows how many multiple buildings around Australia and yet suddenly, by legislative decision, that investment by the Australian people is going to be wiped out by a flick of the fingers and another carrier is going to get for nothing that wiring between the entry of the building and the socket. I have to say that that is appropriation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I clarify that? It is not appropriation; it is a matter of Telstra continuing to own that line but being prepared to lease it to Optus. Optus will then have built in to its service fee the cost of leasing that line—which, in most instances, would be a lot cheaper for it than actually building a second line. It is where you have got the raft of new services that it makes more sense for Optus to install its own second line.

—If in fact you do opt for a more specialised service and greater bandwidth, and that comes to that point of entry on the outside of the building, what if the bandwidth in the existing line that goes from that point to the socket is not of substantial enough magnitude to deliver that additional service?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It keeps going. Optus will install it right through to the socket.

—Minister, you are indicating that Optus would keep going. In that case, again, you have an extension of redundant wiring within that particular resi dence. It is not utilised. That is what you are saying, by making that comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. If you choose to have Optus as the provider of all your services—telephony, pay and broadband services—the Telstra cable would be redundant. It would not necessarily be causing any difficulties for the resident. It would not be worth Telstra's while to remove it, but I suppose that, if Telstra wanted to do so, it could. I would have thought that it would probably live in hope and, no doubt, make some phone calls to get you back onto its network.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 March, on motion by Senator Herron:
That this bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Brown had moved by way of amendment:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:

"the bill be withdrawn until such time as a referendum has been held on the issue of whether the Australian people support the option of voluntary euthanasia as provided by the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I will preface my remarks on the Euthanasia Laws Bill first of all by thanking all those individuals, groups and churches who have taken the time and trouble to provide me with opinions and advice. It is clear from the letters and submissions I have received that their authors were motivated by deeply held personal or professional beliefs. Those who called and wrote were not motivated by anything other than their own deeply held convictions, and sought only what they truly believed was in the best interests for Australia and for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I found much in the submissions, the letters and the calls that moved me. There are few words in the English language that evoke a universally intense emotional response, but `euthanasia' is one such word. `Love', `life' and `death' are other words that have a universal intellectual and emotional effect on us. That all four words are deeply linked does not come as a surprise, for these are words that reflect on our human existence and confront our humanity as individuals and as a society.

Although the word `euthanasia' evokes such a powerful response, few people would have difficulty with its actual meaning. `Euthanasia' literally means `a quiet and easy death'. I would suggest that the majority of people would endorse the hope expressed in the meaning of the word. I feel sure that a quiet and easy death is a private and heartfelt desire of everyone. Who here today would not wish for such a death—not only for themselves but for all their loved ones? It is my belief that we would all seek a quiet and easy death, if the choice were ours alone.

If the literal meaning of the word is not a problem, then what is the matter of contention? Opposition to euthanasia is not opposition to the idea of a good death, for who would argue that death should be painful, protracted or degrading? Rather then, opposition to euthanasia is something else. What then are we debating here today if euthanasia per se is not the issue?

We are, in fact, debating the right of parliament to make laws that have an effect on private morality. We are seeking an answer to the questions, `Do the terminally ill have the right to make a decision regarding the manner in which they will die?' and `Can the terminally ill person take responsibility for that decision?'

We are also debating the past, present and future ethical behaviour of the medical profession. In essence, we are debating the following questions: firstly, do we as individuals have the right to advance death by actively participating in our own death; secondly, should we have the right to decide the time, place and manner of our own death; and, thirdly, is the current medical practice of pain relief, which inevitably causes death, acceptable in our society and should it be allowed to continue? I believe that to the first two questions the answer is yes, and to the last question the answer is no. Based on these answers, I speak today in opposition to the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, the so‐called Andrews bill, and in support of the Northern Territory's groundbreaking legislation.

Very rarely do those of us who are elected to parliament get to debate issues of private and public morality—and perhaps that is as it should be. An individual's moral code should not be the subject of public debate and/or scrutiny, unless through public behaviour it impinges directly on the moral codes and ethical behaviours of significant others.

Our private moral codes are the very core values by which we test our belief systems and against which we moderate our private and public behaviours. For those of us who believe that we are all essentially moral beings, our individual system of ethics dictates our actions and governs our decisions and, as such, are private. It is when the private moral beliefs become desires and these desires fall within the view of others—that is, public actions—that, as legislators, we are faced with the dilemma of private versus public morality, private behaviour versus public behaviour.

I do not seek to argue with those who support the bill as a matter of faith alone. However, I do take issue with those honourable senators who would seek to impose their private faith on others with the force of law. I also take issue with those honourable senators and others who seek to oppose the bill for other reasons. In particular, I take issue with those senators who use the so‐called thin end of the wedge or the slippery slope argument as sufficient reason to support the bill. Their argument is fallacious. I would suggest that the Northern Territory's act will not open the floodgates. Rather, it will in fact reduce the number of assisted deaths by providing strict guidelines for medical staff to adhere to.

The current situation almost requires doctors to play God. Current practice provides no safeguards for either the medical or nursing professions. The practice of passive non‐voluntary euthanasia—that is, either the withdrawal of treatment or allowing to die—is widespread in Australia today. That the practice of passive non‐voluntary euthanasia is widespread will not come as a surprise to most people in this chamber—after all, we have all known about such things for years. What is so sad is that the current practices have been allowed to develop to the present state where almost one‐third of deaths can either be attributed to acts of omission or commission.

I have no doubt in my mind that, as I speak, an Australian will be having their treatment stopped or withdrawn—that is, a life will be shortened or ended following a decision by someone else, a decision to which that person will have had little or no input and for which no consent was sought or given. In survey after survey, both the medical and nursing professions admit to taking active steps to help their patients die. Sometimes nurses act on the instruction or request of a medical practitioner; in some cases, they act alone.

In a 1992 survey of Victorian nurses, one in 10 respondents admitted to acceding to patients' requests without a doctor's instructions, while a quarter of respondents admitted to being asked to help patients die by the patients' treating doctors. The figures for the medical profession are even more telling. In a survey completed in 1994, one in eight New South Wales doctors said that they had taken active steps to help patients die. The New South Wales figures are very much in line with those from previous studies carried out in South Australia and Victoria.

Those early figures represent the tip of the iceberg. The latest study reveals that 30 per cent of all Australian deaths came after a decision to end the patient's life. These deaths came as a consequence of treatment being withdrawn or withheld or where lethal drugs were administered. These deaths were almost all, without question, carried out as acts of compassion and love. Many would have been carried out at the request of the patient and some at the request of loving relatives. Yet how many were carried out with the full knowledge and consent of the patient? How many were carried out as a matter of hospital economic expediency? What safeguards were in place for the patient, his or her relatives or, for that matter, the professional who acceded to the request? In almost every case, the answer must be none—for each act was an illegal act and could have led to the nurse or doctor being charged with murder.

The Andrews bill, if passed, will not end the current practices of the caring professions; it will entrench them and drive them ever further into the shadows. Doctors and nurses should not have to play God. Patients should have a means by which they can seek an end to suffering that is open and subject to scrutiny. Under these conditions, the number of cases of euthanasia may well fall. This is the exact opposite effect of the much propounded slippery slope argument to which I now turn.

According to the slippery slope argument, the current Northern Territory law opens the door to some future government endorsing, and then practising, non‐voluntary euthanasia—that is, compulsory euthanasia. The slippery slope argument is emotive and frequently seeks to conjure up some of the worst images of this century. At its worst, the slippery slope argument attempts to link the Australian euthanasia program with the Nazi death camps; at a lesser level, it is claimed that somehow it will lead to a secular society that devalues moral values and must inevitably lead to attempts to widen the terms of reference by which an individual may seek to end their own life.

That anyone should attempt to link the Northern Territory act and voluntary euthanasia with the horrors of six million dead in the European death camps is odious. Any attempt to link the compassion of the Northern Territory's voluntary euthanasia act to the holocaust is to the discredit of the person who would advance such an argument. The slippery slope argument exists only to scare the vulnerable; it has no merit, it is preposterous and it is false.

Having said that the slippery slope argument at its most emotive is abhorrent, it is also necessary to refute the lesser argument, and that is that the practice of voluntary euthanasia must lead to more and more deaths. I agree that the proposed practice requires a very strict test and safeguards; it also requires an equally strict evaluation procedure. Much has been written and spoken about medically induced death as it has been practised in Holland. Much of what has been written and said is highly emotive. I note that the Tasmanian journal of the AMA asserts that patients in Holland request `not for euthanasia' signs over their beds yet this journal offers no proof of its assertion.

Paul J van der Maas et al writing in the New England Journal of Medicine of November 1996 found `no signs of an unacceptable increase in the number of decisions or of less careful decision making'. While the findings of the Dutch may not impress the proponents of this bill, in my view it is up to them to prove the slippery slope argument.

I am sure that like most of us much of my correspondence has concerned the provision and excellence of palliative care. The argument most frequently advanced in these letters is that somehow the provision of voluntary euthanasia negates or undermines the provision of good palliative care. As I see it, the right to voluntary euthanasia can only enhance the last days, weeks, or hours for those who choose that course. Voluntary euthanasia is not the negation of palliative care. Good palliative care has provided and will continue to provide quality end of life care for far more people than will ever choose voluntary euthanasia. I know of no proponent of voluntary euthanasia who sees it as being in conflict with or in any way replacing quality end of life care, be that in the home or in a hospice. Rather it is seen as an integral part or an extension of it.

I now turn to address those senators who would seek to preserve the present medical position; that is, the medical status quo with individual medical professionals deciding a person's fate as an acceptable alternative to voluntary euthanasia. I believe that the current widely held medical practices involved with death are no longer tenable, and at their worst are hypocritical. The medical status quo is variable, unregulated; it is the luck of the draw. A person who wants to die may be lucky that they have a doctor who will help them, equally they may not have a doctor who is prepared to help them. They may have a doctor who shares their views and moral position, or they may not.

I draw the Senate's attention to the use of the ethical doctrine of double effect to pro vide a shield for current medical practice. The doctrine of double effect provides an ethical smokescreen to cover medical practitioners from both legal and moral sanctions. The doctrine of double effect differentiates between a predictable or foreseen outcome of a voluntary action and an unintended outcome. Therefore, when the stated outcome of an action is the relief of pain and suffering, even when such treatment leads to pharmacological oblivion and death, it is ethical even though, as a consequence of the action or actions, human life is shortened or ended.

I acknowledge the fact that most often medical and nursing behaviours are both caring and compassionate. However, whenever the doctrine of double effect is used to justify behaviour that leads to death, therein lies a terrible double standard. At its worst the doctrine of double effect can be used to justify what is in reality an act of extreme medical paternalism. The doctrine of double effect allows doctors to decide what is best for their patients just so long as the doctor acts with only one intent, that is the relief of pain. Such treatment can be given without any requirement for specific consent from either the patient or family.

In arguing for consent I believe that consent should also be sought and given for all treatments, and that includes the current medical practice of withdrawing treatment. The withdrawal of treatment requires a decision and an action and should therefore require the consent of the patient, or where this is not possible the next of kin. The present medical practice of allowing a person to die has been described by the Tasmanian president of the AMA as `good medical practice'. I would agree with him if the patient has consented, and I would disagree with him if the decision was that of a doctor alone.

In conclusion, I am voting against the Andrews bill because it seeks to impose that member's personal morality on the vast majority of Australians who do not share it. I vote against the bill because I do not believe that a citizen's liberty should be restricted on no better grounds than that others disapprove of that citizen's personal choice. I vote for those Australians who will have their lives enriched by the knowledge that they will have their personal liberty extended by being given a choice that they do not now enjoy and that this choice will be protected in law. I will vote against the bill because I believe in choice. The majority of Australians want to be able to chose. They want to be in control of their death just as they want to be in control of their life.

The polls show that the majority of Australians do not want an anonymous professional, however well motivated and caring, choosing the time, place and manner of their death. The majority of Australians want to make their own final decision, which may be to continue living or it may be to die. Whatever the decision, it requires individual consent and then it requires that the individual take responsibility for their final decisions. I believe that rather than weakening the structure and fabric of Australian society the Northern Territory's act is a sign of our society's maturity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is certainly a very difficult issue, which I am sure everyone in this place has spent a considerable amount of time thinking and reading about, and indeed reading about from the many who have written to us. It is far from simple and it is far from straightforward. It is a difficult emotional issue and it is one on which I alone have received nearly 1,000 letters, so I can imagine how many letters have been written to all of us in this place on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: On both sides of the argument about voluntary euthanasia there are clearly some very determined and dedicated campaigners—some of them I suspect have been doing work on this issue for a long time. Between those two extremes is the bulk of the Australian community. The vast majority of those people are in favour of the right to choose the time to end their own life if it becomes intolerable and if there is no hope for recovery and they are in distress, severe pain and suffering.

I am a practising Christian and I have heard arguments about the sanctity of life from other Christians in this place who oppose voluntary euthanasia. So I want to spend a bit of time talking about this sanctity of life issue. I will begin by looking at some of the decisions that parliaments make that have an impact on the sanctity of life, but which never generate the same sort of public response or media interest as this decision that the Northern Territory has made about euthanasia has done.

Many of those speaking in support of Mr Andrews's bill argue that parliament should never make a decision that may mean a life is ended before its allotted time—that is, that there should be no intervention that may mean a life is deliberately or intentionally shortened. But where were some of those same people just a few years ago when this parliament made a decision to involve this country in the Gulf War? I did not hear those people stand up then and talk about this being a sanctity of life issue. Surely any parliament that sends its troops away has an understanding that there is a risk and that some of their lives may be shortened by those actions. Indeed, it was not just this parliament but other parliaments in this country who sent people away to the Vietnam War, the First World War and the Second World War. Surely the people making those decisions realised the risk was there. Surely they knew that those troops were possibly being sent away to die prematurely.

There are those in this place who happily accept that Australia year after year is putting less and less money into programs that would give people in the Third World a better quality of life and who argue that we cannot afford to put money into aid projects that will in many instances ensure these people live longer, healthier and more comfortable lives. To me that is a very real and urgent sanctity of life issue.

This government very recently, indeed very belatedly—it would have been nice if the previous government had done it—made the decision to work for an international ban on land mines, but for year after year there were people in this place who were quite comfortable in the knowledge that these appalling weapons were out there and they were causing hideous injuries and death to innocent women and children in other parts of the world. Surely that is an issue about the sanctity of life.

Many people condone, merely on economic grounds, the selling of weapons of war to other nations knowing that those weapons are going to be used to kill and maim people. I would go so far as to argue that many of those people who actively promote the mining and milling of uranium know that the product produced and exported is not always being used for peaceful purposes. While things may have improved now, that certainly was not the case a short time ago.

To me, all these issues are sanctity of life issues—issues which involve not just the lives and well-being of individuals here and now but those of future generations. These are issues where people condone or tolerate actions which prematurely end the lives of others. Yet where is the same level of angst, the same level of concern, and, indeed, the same level of parliamentary time set aside to debate these issues.

It seems to me that people basically reserve their concern—and certainly considerable angst—when the issue of sanctity of life involves the actual ending of someone's life when they choose. All this angst is missing when we are talking about issues over which the person has no control—in other words, when someone else's decision will end their life or create for them a life of misery. I have great difficulty when listening to some of these arguments because what we are really talking about is a person's right to choose—a person's right to say to their family or to their doctor, `I have had enough. It is intolerable.'

Another issue nearer to home that has caused me a great deal of angst is what we are doing to our young people. We are putting our young people under more and more stress as support for them to study is reduced. With the new changes we now see that the support for them to get accommodation has been reduced. Their access to social security is becoming more difficult. Looking at the number of breaches, you find that it is basically young people who simply do not understand the system who breach the system.

BREAK.PARA: Instead of government looking to invest in jobs which are becoming rare, young people are now being told that they are going to have to work for the dole. They cannot be left to look for jobs on their own. We are constantly increasing the pressures on young people. Yet we say on the other hand that we have to do something about youth suicide. We are not investing in the sorts of things that would turn young people away from despair and hopelessness.

I put very high on the list employment, free education, access to good health care, access to mental health and promises from politicians that really mean something in terms of training and opportunities. I would argue that many of the decisions in this place have very much had an impact on that critical sanctity of life issue. I would argue that the energies and efforts put into this debate would surely have been better directed towards reducing the number of young people and young adults who take their lives rather than taking an option away from people who are in such distress and such pain and suffering.

So I cannot accept the argument that the debate on this particular bill is somehow more about the sanctity of life than all those other debates that we have had. I think it is a great pity that some of those letters that have been written to me from so many people put so much emphasis on what really is a matter of choice. It would have been nice to have so many letters on Aboriginal health, on foreign aid and on youth suicide. The difference with this issue is that we are not imposing on other people; we are simply giving individuals the right to choose, the right to choose the time and the circumstances of their death, and that would generally be a death in the company of their family and loved ones.

Such a decision is an incredibly personal one, and one that I believe should be left to individuals and their families and, of course, where needed, the doctor, if he or she is willing. As we see from the Northern Territory legislation, the safeguards are there for a number of doctors to be involved, and that is why I totally reject this slippery slope theory that seems to have crept into some of the speeches.

There are many different religious and philosophical views in the world and in this country. To a great many Australians, voluntary euthanasia is an acceptable way of terminating their life because it is part, and often a central part, of their religious beliefs and their philosophies. Those Australians tend to place the notion of quality of life ahead of the sanctity of life. Their views should be respected and this parliament should not seek to impose on them a different set of beliefs.

So I will be voting against Mr Andrews's bill. Yes, I realise the Northern Territory senators and particularly those from the ACT are very interested because it is a state and territory issue, but it is not for that reason. It is obviously a territory issue but, more importantly, it is an individual issue. We will be reducing the likelihood of prosecution for the families and friends and perhaps medical people involved in helping someone to end their life through their own choice.

My only reservations involve the concerns of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. I note the Northern and Central Land Council's submission to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee which made the point that the council did not seek to make any statement on euthanasia as such but was concerned about the process and context of the Northern Territory legislation.

It is little wonder that Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory have so little confidence in the capacity of their government to protect their interests. I believe their concerns, at heart, relate to that lack of confidence and that is the result of the neglect, abuse, misunderstanding and lack of resources and compassion that they continue to endure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to this debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill will focus on only three significant issues since my colleagues in this chamber and in the other place have already traversed every medical, philosophical, legal and religious nook and cranny of this issue over recent days and months.
