SPEECH.PARA: The very special opportunity given to me to take part in the Senate's inquiry by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee enabled me to question key witnesses and, more importantly, to listen to a wide range of views from both highly qualified witnesses and those whose options and opinions represent a large number of ordinary men and women in the community. For me, it was a particularly valuable experience which I shall never forget, and the views expressed ranged from stories of terrible suffering and sadness to those who spoke of the great benefit provided by palliative care teams in both home and hospice. I approached this very difficult issue with an open mind and I am grateful to the wide range of people who offered me wise counsel on many points of the argument.

Questions about the Northern Territory legislation which arise in my mind cover three particular areas. Firstly, how does a law permitting voluntary euthanasia impact on various vulnerable and disadvantaged groups? Many of my early concerns on behalf of these people were reinforced and strengthened during the committee's public hearings and in the letters I received. There is also no doubt that some of the older members of our community, experiencing for perhaps the first time some of the more serious medical difficulties of ageing, believe that they may be approaching the age where they should helpfully remove themselves as a potential burden to their families using the means the Northern Territory legislation currently offers.

A second question concerns that other significant group clearly feeling seriously threatened and, in some cases, likely to be deterred from seeking medical treatment as a result of the rights of the terminally ill legislation. These people are the 40,000 Aboriginal residents of the Northern Territory. My early concern about this group was that they comprise almost a quarter of the territory's population and yet were not formally consulted prior to the introduction of the legislation.

Mr Chips Mackinolty, who was engaged by the Northern Territory government to devise an Aboriginal education campaign after the bill had been passed, gave valuable confirmation of this lack of consultation. Mr Mackinolty's work with Aboriginal communities in remote areas showed very clearly that the legislation had the potential to damage the hard won reputation of the territory health service among indigenous families, and none of us needs to be reminded of the critical need to improve the health of our Aboriginal communities.

If the existence of the territory legislation deters communities or individuals from seeking medical advice, surely the appropriateness of this legislation must be seriously questioned. The view among some that a fear campaign had been deliberately spread through these remote indigenous communities was dismissed by Reverend Gondarra who told the committee:
We are not frightening people. We are telling them the truth about this legislation.

Notwithstanding the assurances of these respected spokespeople, there is no doubt in my mind that many Aborigines consider the Northern Territory legislation to be `sorcerer's law' and it may well affect their individual health care decisions.

My final focus in this offering arose not as a result of evidence presented to the committee but from the comments of a group of very special people in my home state of South Australia who form the palliative care team at the Mary Potter Hospice in Adelaide and with whom I spent some very valuable time last week. I visited the hospice, for the first time actually, to resolve in my mind questions relating to the medical options available to the terminally ill.

Under the highly professional and compassionate leadership of the medical director, Dr Mary Brooksbank, the staff provide a range of specialised services and compassionate care in the final days and weeks of terminal illness. Their service offers the active and total care of patients at a time when their illness or disease is no longer responsive to curative treatment and when control of pain, or other symptoms, and of psychological, social and spiritual problems, is paramount.

Using a range of sophisticated medical technologies, mixed with a liberal dose of human kindness, this highly trained group offers a support system to help their patients live as actively as possible as their lives come to a close. Numbers of patients enter Mary Potter anxious to bring their lives to a rapid conclusion—increasing medical discomfort having made their lives unbearable—with early death appearing the only option.

Dr Brooksbank and in fact other palliative care specialists who addressed the committee assert that pain can be managed, that the `hard death' referred to by some other groups and witnesses that addressed the committee is not a necessary by‐product of unmanaged or unmanageable pain.

This hospice wing in Adelaide has only 16 beds and yet it is able to offer dignity at the end of life to 400 patients a year and bereavement counselling to hundreds of other families. Another 200 or so patients are treated in their homes through an outreach service because there are simply not enough hospice beds. Surely, this is where a priority must lie, where valuable health funds must be spent, where our end of life decisions can take place—supported by the best medical technology available.

I have deliberately chosen not to refer tonight to the end of life decisions made by members of my own family and friends. Suffice to say that they reflect the views and experiences expressed by many in this chamber. Nobody wants to see a loved one suffer and as we contemplate the end of our lives each one of us optimistically contemplates a peaceful passing, with as much choice as possible at that time. I left the Mary Potter Hospice confident that my apprehension about the medical ability to manage terminal pain had been resolved.

In conclusion, I would like to address one of the cornerstones of the pro voluntary euthanasia arguments, whose proponents argue that it is currently not legal in Australian states to intentionally request that a life be prematurely ended. These people say that only when the Northern Territory legislation was enacted could such a choice be legally fulfilled. Curiously, however, it seems to me that the Northern Territory legislation, in codifying and legalising the means by which it is possible to choose a premature death, an early death, may have in fact set down what is an indisputable and therefore far less flexible nine‐day pathway to death.

BREAK.PARA: Nine days—no ifs, no buts, no short cuts. Is that really an enhanced choice? Or has it, in establishing such an inflexible pathway, in fact reduced the means by which other terminally ill people around Australia right now are quietly making individual medical decisions and choices with their families and their doctors which will effectively shorten their lives by hours, days or weeks? Is this quite lengthy process in the Northern Territory really extending the life choices available to Australians?

Baume and Kuhse in their recently published work, which they claimed demonstrated support for a change in the law, in fact showed that one in three deaths in Australia at present occurs prematurely as a result of a medical intervention. Surely, this is clear evidence that the laws as they stand have enabled thousands of individuals to make their own flexible end of life decisions right now, without a journey to the Northern Territory, a computer keyboard or a willing medical practitioner.

The power of the Commonwealth to overturn the Northern Territory's legislation has been well argued in this place by others, and I do not propose to canvass it again tonight. But it is interesting, isn't it, that this piece of legislation is available without any residential qualification at all to any Australian, regardless of their home address, if they are willing and able to travel to Darwin? And that is a point well understood by Mr Marshall Perron. It is therefore effectively national legislation available only in the Northern Territory.

I have valued very much the opportunity to take part in this debate and also in the Senate inquiry, where a wide range of compelling evidence supporting the Andrews bill was presented and ultimately accepted by me. I now indicate my support for the Euthanasia Laws Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some debates that occur in this place that we as members of parliament and elected representatives look forward to participating in and there are others that we seek to avoid. This is one that I certainly would have sought to avoid, but I think it is incumbent upon me as a representa tive of my state of Western Australia to clearly put on the record some of the views that I have on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I address the issues contained in the Euthanasia Laws Bill, there are a couple of things I want to mention in acknowledgment. I acknowledge Senator Tambling and the badge that he distributed to all of us yesterday in this place—a badge that depicted the flag of the Northern Territory—and he asked each of us to wear it as a mark that we respected the rights of the citizens firstly of the Northern Territory but also, I understand, of the other territories that are impacted and infringed by the content of this bill.

I make a deliberate point of mentioning that because I have a notice of motion on the Notice Paper, which I understand has upset some people in the Northern Territory because of its content, but I think the people understand where I am coming from. I wear Senator Tambling's badge on the collar of my shirt, which is the custom in the Northern Territory because I understand they do not wear jackets in that chamber there.

Secondly, before I get into the body of the bill, I want to acknowledge the work of the secretariat of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee who are acknowledged in the report of the committee which was brought to this place the week before last. Neil Bessell and his team of people did a magnificent job—a job that they will probably never get the full recognition for. To cope with the numbers of submissions on their own was just a fantastic effort, but to do that and to do it with good grace at the same time was just stupendous.

That was not the only work the secretariat of that committee were engaged in. They were involved in numerous other works, both the references committee and the legislation committee. As a matter of fact, when the legislation committee held its public hearing in Darwin on the Euthanasia Laws Bill, we coincided that with a public hearing to take evidence on the legal aid inquiry. So I do publicly recognise the work of Neil and his team, commend him for that work and, on behalf of the Senate, thank him for that work.

BREAK.PARA: I was one of the people who entered into this debate and the debate of the committee with an open mind. I did not have the benefit, like some of my colleagues in this place obviously have, of knowing where we are going on the bill and how we would do it before I listened to the evidence that was given in the public inquiry and through the submissions. I listened carefully to the arguments that were put and, as a member of the committee, took the opportunity to ask questions of those who came before the committee.

I think the record will show that the stream of my questioning was not along one particular line or pushing one particular barrow—be it in favour or in opposition to the content of the bill and the effect of the bill. I tried to do it as objectively as I could. I formed the view during the committee work that some of my colleagues were blessed in other directions and that they were the fount of all knowledge on the impact of this bill. That being the case for them, good luck to them, but it certainly was not the case for me.

There are expectations in the community that, because of my birthright and the religion that I was brought into, I would automatically follow a particular line. I do not think as a member of this place that I am obliged to do that on each and every occasion. Certainly, when it is a matter of conscience vote, I do have to be aware of what my constituents are after. I, like every other member of the Senate and indeed probably every member of the Commonwealth parliament, have been inundated with letters, with telephone calls and with faxes and have been met in the street and encouraged to follow particular lines. The numbers of submissions that the committee has received is on the public record.

From my point of view, when the debate occurred in this place about the reference of the bill to the legal and constitutional committee, I made the point then of the numbers of letters I had received from constituents in my state about the bill at that time. I have—and I say this with some degree of confidence although I have not signed each and every letter—replied to every letter that was written to me from within my constituency of West ern Australia. The replies took the form of form letters and I apologise to the individuals for doing that, but many of the letters that I received were also form letters. I will give an example of a letter—and I am not going to give the name of this individual—which was typical of many that I received during the course of the inquiry:

I am writing to you to ask you to vote for the Andrews Bill. I am very opposed to euthanasia as it is using killing to solve a social problem. If doctors are allowed to kill patients eventually, despite any safeguards, it will be easier, cheaper and quicker to kill than to care for the sick, elderly and vulnerable in our community.
God gave us life and God will take it in His time.

That was typical of the letters that I received. Some of the people who wrote to me actually put their telephone numbers on them or I took the initiative myself to ring them after searching through the phone books. Many of the people did not know what was contained in the Andrews bill. They did not know the impact of it but they were scared about it. I did not seek to talk them out of their position. Clearly, there were a number of very frightened people in our community. For those that perpetrated that fear, they will have to answer in their own time. I think what some people have done on this is unforgivable; I really do. Why would somebody not support the Andrews bill? The committee's report states:
The Bill removes the power under the Self-Government Acts of the three Territories to enact laws:
which permit or have the effect of permitting (whether subject to conditions or not) the form of intentional killing of another called euthanasia.

Why would I stand in this place and not support a bill that contains those words? I should. Indeed, that was part of my dilemma before the committee debated the bill. I do not support the intentional killing of another human being. I do not support capital punishment and I certainly will oppose, in my state of Western Australia, any moves by the current government to reintroduce capital punishment there.

So why would I not support Mr Andrews's bill? When it comes to the vote, I will not support the bill. The simple reason I will not support the bill is that I do not believe the act of parliament that is in operation in the Northern Territory does give an individual the right to intentionally kill another human being. I do not believe that is the case.

I do not believe that Bob Dent was killed by another human being. I do not believe that Janet Mills was killed by another human being, intentionally or non‐intentionally. I accept the fact that they made their own decisions. How do I know that? I never met Bob Dent. I never met Janet Mills. I have not met any of their family members, to the best of my knowledge. I have not met the two other individuals who have also taken advantage of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act to end their lives.

But I have had the opportunity to read the last words of Bob Dent and Janet Mills. The additional comment that I and Senator Bolkus attached to the committee report included the words of Bob Dent and Janet Mills. They are worth repeating here yet again tonight. I will only repeat them in part. After describing in detail the suffering that Bob Dent had endured in the latter years of his life, he composed a letter that he was unable to write himself. He dictated it to his wife. One can imagine the trauma that both of them were going through at the time that this last letter of Bob Dent was being written. He said:

My own pain and suffering is made worse by watching my wife suffering as she cares for me: bathing and drying me, cleaning up after my "accidents" in the middle of the night and watching my body fade away. If I were to keep a pet animal in the same condition I am in, I would be prosecuted.
I have always been an active, outgoing person, and being unable to live a normal life causes much mental and psychological pain, which can never be relieved by medication.

Mr Dent also made a plea about palliative care, which we quote in the report, saying he did not want any more. He also made the comment that he could not be hugged by his wife. Any of us who are in a relationship like that will know how important that is. He could not—in his last hours, days and weeks—allow his wife to get that close to him because his bones might have broken. So he took advantage of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

Mrs Dent came along to the public forum that Senator Tambling and Senator Collins arranged on the night before our public hearings in Darwin. On behalf of Mrs Mills's husband, she read to the audience a letter from Mrs Mills. I will quote a part of that as well. It says:

I believe that euthanasia is the greatest thing for people who are sick with no chance of getting better. It's a wonderful idea and it stops people from suffering when they don't need to. Nobody wants to die if they don't have to, but I know I have had no hesitation in asking for this. No one should have to suffer . . .

They are her words, not mine. The letter was dated 1 January 1997, just a few weeks before the committee took the evidence in Darwin. They were moving words and they certainly had an impact on me, as did the words which I have quoted previously from Bob Dent. Those two individuals, despite the pain and the suffering they went through, were very lucky human beings because they were able at the end of their lives to have some say in how they left this world.
I want to return to the bill itself and deal with some of the terminology included in it. I quoted from part of it before:
. . . the form of intentional killing of another called euthanasia (which includes mercy killing) or the assisting of a person to terminate his or her life.

If one looks around for the definition of `euthanasia', one does not find a definition that says `intentionally killing another human being'. There are a number of definitions and the committee looked at these as we progressed. On page xi in our report, we come up with these terms:

Literally, "euthanasia" refers to a good death or a gentle and easy death. However, euthanasia and related terms have come to mean different things to different people. This was reflected in the variety of ways the terms were used in submissions.
. . . the Parliamentary Research Service in a series of papers on euthanasia considers that "euthanasia" can be divided into four categories.

It enumerated them and I will not read all the details. They are `active voluntary euthanasia', `passive voluntary euthanasia', `passive in/non‐voluntary euthanasia' and `active in/non‐voluntary euthanasia'.

Isn't it strange, when you have words like these around, that Mr Andrews did not seek to use them in his bill? Why would Mr Andrews put the term `intentionally killing' into a bill when there were much calmer, more soothing words available to him? I do not know. I have suspicions, but I am not going to cast aspersions on a member of another place.

I have got a number of other letters, as we all have, on this matter. There is one other that I want to refer to. It is similar in style to the one I read earlier. Again, I will not name the individual. It says:
I am writing to you to ask you to vote for the Andrews Bill. I am opposed to Euthanasia, as it is using killing to solve a social problem. What is needed instead is a good palliative care program.

Palliative care and the delivery of palliative care services was not a reference of the committee. It was not one on which we sought to gather and gain information but, nonetheless, it came through in a steady stream of the submissions how important palliative care was. A deal of criticism was given about the lack of adequate palliative care services in the Northern Territory and other parts of Australia. International organisations of palliative care came to the committee in Canberra and gave evidence to us. Doctor Michael Smith, the President of the Australian Association of Hospice and Palliative Care told the committee:

As has been recognised in the soon to be released report of the palliative care program review 1996, the development of palliative care services across Australia is now at a critical stage, as it is still incomplete. For palliative care services to mature and be funded as a mainstream health service, a number of milestones are yet to be achieved. In this difficult time, the Commonwealth has reduced its funding of palliative care for 1996‐97 by 10 per cent, in the name of administrative efficiency. In the absence of agreed administrative arrangements between the Commonwealth and the states, this cut has simply meant less Commonwealth money for patient care.
The future of the specific Commonwealth palliative care funding program, PCP, is uncertain, as it is due for completion in July 1997, with no evidence of Commonwealth commitment to its continuance.

It would be worthwhile for senators to perhaps stay their vote on this bill until we know what is going to be delivered in the Commonwealth budget on 13 May. Are there going to be further cuts to palliative care?
One final matter I want to mention is evidence we received in the Northern Territory from Mr Marshall Perron, as stated to the committee:
. . . we have never died so slowly and, for a very few, we have never died so agonisingly.

Mr Perron provided the committee with a list that came from the Australian Bureau of Statistics of suicides by Australians 75 years and older in the five‐year period between 1990 and 1994. It detailed the deaths of 672 people. Others have talked about youth suicide but we perhaps ought to have a special debate and forum in the parliament to look at the horrific means by which many—a darned sight more than four—of the elder citizens and residents of this country are leaving this world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —By the time we finally vote on the Euthanasia Laws Bill the arguments for and against voluntary euthanasia will have been thoroughly canvassed. This bill has little to do with euthanasia and is much more about the federal parliament seeking to override the sovereign jurisdictions of the Northern Territory, the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island—relegating the residents of these territories to the status of second‐class citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than revisit the various arguments for and against euthanasia, I intend addressing five fundamental issues I feel will better inform the Senate about the gravity of the bill currently before us and its consequences. Firstly, what did Marshall Perron, the architect of the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act of 1995, set out to achieve? The Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act totals fifteen pages. It is compulsory and essential reading for any senator intending to vote on the Andrews bill. It is this act, already passed by a democrati cally elected parliament, that the Senate is essentially in the process of scrutinising.

I remind the Senate that the original rights of the terminally ill legislation passed through the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly 15 votes to 10 at the all important third reading. In his speech introducing the original bill in the Northern Territory parliament, Marshall Perron said:

This is not a political issue, it is a human rights issue. I began preparing this bill following searching thought about the rights of those who face a distressing, undignified and possibly painful death and the dilemma confronting them and their medical advisers on the question of whether or not to actively terminate life.

Quite obviously, Marshall Perron set out to provide the option of voluntary euthanasia for a very small number of people who have a terminal illness and who meet the strict requirements and safeguards of a particular piece of legislation. This intention is also reflected in the first paragraph of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, which reads:

An act to confirm the right of a terminally ill person to request assistance from a medically qualified person to voluntarily terminate his or her life in a humane manner; to allow for such assistance to be given in certain circumstances without legal impediment to the person rendering the assistance; to provide procedural protection against the possibility of abuse of the rights recognised by this act; and for related purposes.

The Northern Territory act is based on the principle of personal choice—debunking the myth that the terms of the legislation will somehow be accessed on an involuntary basis. Surely in today's sophisticated society we can confidently face the responsibility of end of life decisions in extenuating circumstances with our families, medical advisers and spiritual friends.

Supporters of the Andrews bill will have us believe that the Northern Territory legislation is too loose and too open to abuse. You be the judge of that. In my opinion, this is a well crafted piece of legislation, having been very properly shaped by the Northern Territory's own select committee—which honestly gave a much more comprehensive study than our own, which was a very good report as well—and the subsequent parliamentary debate and amendment. The territory legislation has also survived a number of attempts at repeal and a Supreme Court challenge.

The Northern Territory act contains a defined series of important safeguards and established bona fides which were recently bolstered by the successful passage of an amendment bill. As the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report rightly acknowledged in discussing the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, the question of finetuning the act is a matter for the Northern Territory parliament alone. The committee recognised the very important role constitutional convention plays in the administration of the federal system of government.

Unfortunately, the committee did not acknowledge the next logical step—and most pertinent to this debate—that any repeal or termination of this legislation rests solely within the jurisdiction of the Northern Territory parliament. Why would the committee very properly acknowledge that the federal parliament has no place amending Northern Territory legislation and yet propose to ride roughshod over the Northern Territory parliament and remove a whole range of legislative powers?

We need to remember that Marshall Perron, whilst pioneering voluntary euthanasia for Australia, was not the first to do so internationally. The practices in Switzerland, the Netherlands and the United States of America also contribute to the timeliness and acceptability of the debate. Marshall Perron and his territory colleagues picked up the concepts and contemporary relevance and were not afraid to face the expectations so transparent in the community. Too many supporters in the House of Representatives and in the Senate face the debate with fear, with pessimism or with a dogged reliance on the intellectual bribes of vested interest groups. Marshal Perron's examples and actions highlight for us the fact that we live today in a secular, multicultural society and not a church state.

Secondly, what has the member for Menzies, Kevin Andrews, done? A provision exists in the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act of 1978 which allows the federal government to disallow legislation generated by the Northern Territory parliament within six months of the date the Northern Territory legislation receives the Administrator's assent. This action was not proposed or initiated in federal parliament. Therefore, the opportunity for the member for Menzies, Kevin Andrews, and like‐minded federal parliamentarians to effectively interfere with the Northern Territory parliamentary process has lapsed. In fact, the idea was squashed by the then Keating Labor government on principle. It is this issue that certainly now rankles Territorians with so many Liberal and National friends adopting what can only be seen as a hypocritical and pious attitude on this matter.

Now, nearly two years after the Northern Territory parliament very properly enacted the rights of the terminally ill legislation, we are presented with a torpedo style private member's bill. The Andrews bill is short-sighted, paternalistic and patronising in the extreme. The Commonwealth Attorney-General's office agrees, conceding that the impact of the bill on existing legislation such as the Northern Territory's Natural Death Act and Criminal Code is unknown and will require a series of test court cases to be heard before the precise impact of the Andrews bill is known.

Many of the arguments in the House of Representatives and the Senate have relied on extremely personal and theological positions of those arguing along with Mr Andrews on issues of legalising morality and spirituality. A number of church leaders presented similar views to the Senate committee. As a Christian myself, I find this argument disrespectful in recognising the diversity of the cultural interests of the community in which we live. I have certainly searched my own soul throughout the past two years on this issue and I cannot find any scriptural condemnation of anyone who chooses to take their own life. In fact, the respect for the dignity of the individual is supported in all of my studies, and I believe too many of my fellow Christians rely on their own judgments rather than those of the Bible and Jesus.

Thirdly, is there a constitutional principle at stake? There surely is. All state premiers supported the territory's view that the Commonwealth should not legislate on this issue at their leaders forum on 27 September 1996. I remind the Senate that the Northern Territory parliament presented a unanimous remonstrance to this parliament on 27 October 1996. This was not done lightly. The Senate's own Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills observed of the Andrews bill:

The Commonwealth parliament, while undoubtedly having the power to pass the bill, would, by so doing, create a situation where some Australians are treated in a way different from other citizens because it curtails their present right to self-government in circumstances where, were they live to in the states, it could not do so.
The committee concluded:

This bill, if passed, would override the decision of the democratically elected government of the Northern Territory when it appears that there would be no head of power or international convention by which it could override the same or similar legislation enacted by the states.

I do not have a problem with this parliament investigating, debating and legislating on the issue of voluntary euthanasia, as long as it is on a national basis and it is consistent with the existing federal convention of division of responsibility between the tiers of government. I believe addressing such issues as euthanasia is a sign of a mature community able to confidently and competently broach relevant issues of the day. My objection is to this federal parliament legislating in a jurisdiction where clearly we have no place and on social issues properly the prerogative of the states and self-governing territories.

As my colleague in the House of Representatives, Nick Dondas, pointed out in his speech in the second reading debate on this bill, the dispatch boxes and the mace in the Northern Territory parliament were originally a gift from the federal parliament to the Northern Territory when self-government was attained. Why now would some self-righteous federal parliamentarians attempt to bastardise the Westminster system and overturn centuries of constitutional convention? As Mr Dondas noted, the presentation of the mace in particular signified the personal approval by Her Majesty the Queen for the Northern Territory parliament to make laws within its constitu tional power and according to the collective conscience of the parliament for the wellbeing of the people of the Northern Territory.

I am certainly attracted to the motions of Mr Sinclair in the House of Representatives and my fellow Northern Territory senator, Senator Bob Collins, seeking to refer the matter raised by the Andrews bill to the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice for legislation to be drafted which will apply on a national basis. Surely, legislation applying to the whole of Australia would serve the interests of Mr Andrews and his supporters a great deal better than legislation pragmatically targeted at three territories for the sole purpose of convenience.

Federal parliamentarians have underestimated the strength of conviction of Northern Territory residents on the issue of the federal parliament overriding the democratically elected Northern Territory parliament. I am sure senators present at the January public forum in Darwin of over 450 people will recall a number of Northern Territory residents expressing their disdain for this parliament's intention to undermine the Northern Territory parliament. A constitutional principle is at stake. The Andrews bill does not recognise the significance of Northern Territory self‐government, which established a self-governing body politic on the traditional democratic Westminster model.

The Northern Territory is treated as a state for all funding, administrative and federal relations purposes. The record of Northern Territory economic, social and political development since 1978 is unparalleled anywhere else in Australia. Therefore, it is not surprising to learn that, in the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department, any retraction of the grant of self‐government is unthinkable, except in the instance of civil breakdown. I endorse that view. In my lifelong experience as a territorian, I cannot recall any circumstances that required draconian federal intervention such as that now proposed—and we certainly do not have civil breakdown in the territory.

Fourthly, can we acknowledge areas for further action? Yes, we can. The debate on voluntary euthanasia naturally attracts atten tion to 101 other associated issues. Many of them have an essential health focus. Many of them impinge on the issues of family responsibility and caring. Importantly, we cannot ignore palliative care. Under no circumstances do I want to deny the priority of these issues in our daily lives or their relevance to government policy and public administration. By scratching the surface of problems and challenges in health, family and aged care, we will reveal problems galore, but let us not get drawn by distractions from the real issue in this debate—how we handle dignified dying for the terminally ill.

Far too often, we are aware that the rich and connected can access euthanasia by deals and arrangements with their doctors. Not only is this immoral and illegal, but it also highlights the tragic fact that equity does not exist for terminally ill people who are not rich and connected. I acknowledge that palliative care is inadequate. Thankfully, this two‐year debate and my family experiences have focused me on accepting an involvement I had not previously accepted. We all can and should do more.

Living in northern Australia, with its unique lifestyle and proximity to Asia, has made all territorians aware that our neighbouring Asian countries provide us with intimate examples of close‐knit family networks whose members accept responsibility for the care of the aged and ill. Again, I say we all can and should do more.

A close assessment of the impact of voluntary euthanasia on the Aboriginal community is essential. Submissions came to the Senate committee from far and wide and, in my opinion, were both good and bad. There were genuine concerns expressed about health care practices and availability, raising the need for attention by community leaders and health care providers. At the same time, it is all too easy to be drawn into a fanciful world of sorcery and supernatural poppycock by people with strange agendas who, for political reasons, would return many Aboriginal people to feudal times. In trying to do so, they damn far too many Aboriginal people to awful public health standards and shocking life expectancies.

BREAK.PARA: Only through delivering 20th century health care, technology and advanced education will the issues in Aboriginal communities be properly addressed. We certainly have a responsibility to fully explain voluntary euthanasia and palliative care and to not get caught up in patronising Aboriginal communities by coddling them in cultural protectionism rather than dealing with the fundamental issue of dying and the need to involve through education.

The Northern Territory government should be complimented on the innovative approach it has taken to Aboriginal health care. High expenditure commitments have been developed for effective living with alcohol programs, remedial attention to the incidence of sexually transmitted diseases and improving ghastly public hygiene—all with outstanding results. It is mischievous to imply that voluntary euthanasia will set back these necessary advances.

Fifthly, and finally, what is a true `conscience' vote? I am aware that all senators have wrestled with this legislation, and it is apparent from their comments that many senators are torn between their personal emotions and opinions, the constitutional and legal controversy over just who has the legislative prerogative, and the clear views of a majority of ordinary Australians in their electorates who obviously support voluntary euthanasia.

At the end of the day, the second reading vote will test us all, without any party or special disciplines. This is clearly an unprecedented debate where senators cross party lines and make many strange alliances. In the House of Representatives, manipulative forces played a large role in determining many votes in marginal seats. Thankfully, the Senate can stand aside and exercise what is truly a conscience vote. I go one step further and suggest to those of my colleagues who cannot reconcile their personal values with competing public interests that it is just as appropriate for a senator to abstain, after having stated those views, as it is to exercise a deliberative vote.

In drawing my comments to a close, I challenge the Senate to return to the funda mental principle of why voluntary euthanasia is considered by a majority of Australians to be an appropriate option. Carol Atkinson, the last of 51 speakers at the public forum in Darwin in January, hosted by Senator Bob Collins and me, gave us all an outstanding summary. She said:

I have been in a position of being a registered nurse in an oncology and haematology unit where many people have died. Of those people, what I learnt was that some would have chosen to exercise their choice through this bill; others would not have. That did not mean that not all of them suffered. They all did. With the decisions in their death, the way they faced up to it, all of those people were very active in their death. However, those who would have been able to choose to take this opportunity and use this bill are being incredibly active; they are not running away from their decisions about their death. They would have made that choice in what was at that stage a very high quality palliative care situation. I don't know what decision I would make in their situation; what I would like to see is that I would have that choice.

These sentiments and the totally unconstitutional, undemocratic and discriminatory thrust of the Euthanasia Laws Bill make it imperative that we in the Senate recognise reason, commonsense, humaneness and constitutional support for the Northern Territory's legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —This euthanasia legislation has obviously attracted a great deal of interest not only in the Northern Territory but throughout Australia. I have had literally thousands of letters from people who believe very strongly and very strenuously and very passionately in both sides of this debate. It has been very interesting to listen to the debate so far in the Senate because we have found people, perhaps whom we would not have expected to, believing very passionately, strongly and strenuously in both sides of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: But, when it comes down to how I intend to vote on this, it will be according to two basic principles. The first of those is the basic human right to your own life. You have a basic right; it is given to you for your own life. The military junta cannot roll up to your door and take you away and kill you. Nobody can take you away and kill you in Australia. But you have the right—and you ought to have the right to your own life—to make decisions about your own life and when it will end.

The second principle is the right of the Northern Territory government to enact its own legislation. We have just heard a very passionate speech from Senator Tambling—and I must agree with him—that it is a really outrageous step for this parliament to take to override a piece of Northern Territory legislation. The Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Act is not about suicide. It is about the right of a person who has a terminal illness—the illness has to be terminal and they have to be going to die from it—and who is experiencing pain, suffering and distress to an unacceptable level deciding when they wish to end that extreme pain and suffering while maintaining their own dignity.

I am a great supporter of palliative care. We have some excellent hospices and palliative care units in Australia and I think we should be funding them to a far greater extent than we are. We should be encouraging them in their excellent work. I visited a hospice myself a few years ago when a friend of mine was dying of AIDS. That visit was a very difficult thing to do, mostly because the friend was dying of AIDS in the hospice. But the hospice was a very warm, friendly and, to the extent that it could be, delightful place. He really enjoyed being there. It was far better than having been in an ordinary hospital or anywhere else.

He did not choose, and I do not think he would have chosen, to end his life before his life ended itself. But I believed then, and I believe now, that he should have had the right to make that decision if had wished to. He should have had the right when that pain and suffering became too great—and the pain and suffering does become very, very great—to decide for himself, `Okay, that is it.' We have to acknowledge that there may come a time, even with the best palliative care, when a person may decide they just cannot take any more. When that time comes, I believe that person should have the right to decide to let go and to end their own pain and their suffering with grace and with dignity.

BREAK.PARA: We have heard a great deal about how doctors already assist such patients to die at the right time. The thing I find offensive about that is the assumption that a doctor will know better than the patient when the pain and suffering and distress of the patient have become too much for them. The idea that the doctor has a natural right to know when a patient should end their life but the patient does not is something I cannot agree with. It is already happening, but it is happening at the will of the doctor and not of the patient.

The second principle that I mention, and I am very conscious of it in this debate, is the autonomy of the Northern Territory parliament and its right to enact laws which have effect in the Northern Territory. We have heard about the angst and the soul‐searching that the Northern Territory parliament went through before it finally passed this act. We have heard about all the studies that they went through, about how much they deliberated and how much they had to go through before this happened. Now we are considering, in Canberra, whether we will allow them to keep that act. What will be the next act of the Northern Territory parliament to be challenged? What about ACT legislation? Should we let them? Are they old enough and big enough to make their own legislation?

I found yesterday's debate on this bill to be far more interesting than I had expected. I thought Senator Vanstone made a particularly interesting point that this was not an election issue, that this had not come up during the election and that the people of Australia had not voted in their representatives on any basis of how they would vote on a bill to override an act of the Northern Territory. That act of the Northern Territory was in before the election, and the people of Australia should have had the opportunity to comment if anyone was going to bring this bill up and was going to try to push it through.

Another interesting point, of course, is that this bill is a private member's bill. I have raised several private member's bills myself. I think they are just as important as this and I think they are just as vital to the health of the nation as this. There is no way on the face of this earth that they will get the same imprimatur from the government as this bill has done. That is a very important and very interesting point.

The point that Senator Vanstone made was a very important and interesting one. In all the studies where we have asked the people of Australia about how they feel about this, whether they believe that euthanasia should be legal under these circumstances—these incredibly strict circumstances in this bill—about 75 per cent of them said yes. So I wonder who is representing their constituencies here, In fact, most of us do not really know if we are on this, I suspect.

Yesterday, allusions were made which were quite unnecessary and thoroughly offensive. I wish to goodness that all of us in this parliament would stop alluding to Nazi Germany. I find it offensive whenever it is used. It is always over the top. It is not something we should ever do.

So many people who lived through the Nazi period in Germany are still alive in Australia and find it incredibly offensive when somebody mentions Nazi Germany and then says that somebody in Australia reminds them of that. Invariably, the person whom they say reminds them of it bears absolutely no resemblance whatsoever to the appalling things that happened at that time. We all should take that one right out of our lexicons and never use it again.

Finally, let me say that the way I intend to vote on this legislation is the way that I hope others would vote. I strongly believe, and always have throughout my life, that you do unto others as you would have them do unto you. What I would have others do unto me, if I were in the situation described in the bill, is to allow me the right, when I felt that I could not go on, to decide that with dignity and grace it is time to stop. I would like that right for myself, for others and for anyone I love. I intend to vote, first, to enable others to have that right and, second, to make sure that we do not override an act of a popularly, democratically elected parliament of one of the territories of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Andrews bill. I do so on the basis of moral, social and ethical values. I declare at the outset, as I have in the media, that I am a Christian and I hold Christian values. I will also declare, so people who are listening to this broadcast will know, that I am one of the 13 senators who signed the advice to the Senate in support of the Andrews bill, from pages 115 to 130. So my position in that respect is clearly well known.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I would like to thank all those people who wrote letters to me or sent me faxes from both sides of the argument. While one might presume that I have a predisposition, I did read the arguments that were put forward with interest, and let me say that my views are my personal views; I am not influenced by anyone or any outside sources.

I am not going to canvass all the issues that have been raised in this debate so far, but there are a number I want to concentrate on and a number that I want to answer in a very simple way without demeaning the force of argument behind them, so that I can get on to the main thrust of what I wish to talk about.

I speak first on the issue of the rights of the Northern Territory to legislate and the issue of states rights generally. In my view, it stopped being a territory issue when people crossed the border to take up the offer of euthanasia. That is when it stopped being something that was isolated to or insulated in the Northern Territory. In that case, I see it affecting other states and other people within the confines of Australia.

The constitutionality issue is covered very well in the report, so I am not going to canvass that at length, suffice to say that I believe the Andrews bill is properly before the Senate. I, as a member of this Senate, believe that I have a legitimate right to express an opinion on this bill and to vote on it.

I have also heard canvassed the idea that we should have had a referendum on the issue. I want to address that very briefly. Whilst this is nice in theory, I believe that we do have a bill properly before this parliament and we do have a parliament that is elected by the people. Whether that parliament was elected by the people to consider this particular issue is not at stake as far as I am concerned. The parliament is elected to govern and must confront all issues that come before it. The idea of a proletariat democracy is, to me, a nonsense.

Even if there were to be a debate, because euthanasia means to different people a wide range of things, one would have a great deal of trouble conducting an informed referendum on the issue. I believe it would be an impossibility.

On the issue of polls, I want to make this very brief comment: tell me the result that you want and I will frame the question. I have been involved in numerous things over the years where people have conjured up the result that they want and have then written the question to suit the result. I am not saying that some people have done that on this occasion, but that is always the danger with polls.

I move to some of the more substantive things. I believe that every life has a value. I also believe that life is an experience. We experience joy, we experience sadness, we experience warmth and chill, we experience success, we experience failure, we experience pain and we experience relief. Life is not perfect, and the experience of life shapes us as individuals. It makes us what we are. It shapes those around us as well. So to me, life is an ongoing process that has effect not only internally but also externally. I concede that death itself is not an easy process but I believe it is a part of life. I believe that truncating the process of dying is denying an experience of life for both the person dying and those surrounding them.

I have been through the death of my parents. I have suffered and experienced their pain, their anguish. Both of my parents died of cancer. In one case it was not a lengthy period, in the other case it was a matter of some weeks. Yes, I am human. Yes, I do feel. Yes, I did feel it was a difficult time for me, my sister and my wife.

Certainly, I did feel. I am not an inhuman sort of person but in no way did I not get value from that experience. Whilst I experienced sadness, I also experienced how to cope with life. I think that is important to everyone in the dying process. People who do not experience the dying process because they are remote from their loved one who dies miss out on something. I feel that is very important in this whole debate.

Also, I must say that I am against capital punishment. I believe that just as capital punishment is wrong because it is the state exercising its authority to take away someone's life so too is euthanasia. That is my view. Euthanasia has the problem compounded by divesting the authority or the power to a third party, namely, the doctors. Like everyone, doctors are fallible. The euthanasia argument puts for them a position of power that no other individual or group in our community has conferred upon them. There are no safeguards or supervision where euthanasia is involved, other than the three doctors being in agreement. The twist in all of this is that no‐one is certain when death will ensue anyway. How does one really know that someone has a week, two weeks, three weeks, a month, 10 months or whatever it might be to live? No‐one can tell me when life is going to end. The unfortunate part—and this is not meant to be facetious—is that death cannot be undone. It is final. That is why—whether it be capital punishment or euthanasia—I am fundamentally opposed.

The practical problem for me—and those who know me know I am a practical person—is the slippery slope. Whilst that has stood some criticism in this debate, I cannot be convinced that we will not go from voluntary euthanasia to involuntary euthanasia because no‐one—and it does not matter who they are—can give me a guarantee that this will not happen. No doubt there are supremacists or purists in our society who like to see everything in a perfect or pristine state. In the longer term, they will use the ongoing existence of a euthanasia act to turn their attention to the disabled, the suicidal, those in prolonged pain, those who have had enough of life and those who may feel worthless; in other words, people who are vulnerable.

I believe every individual has worth. That worth cannot be dismissed by those in positions of power or privilege. As I have said, no‐one can give me an ironclad guarantee that voluntary euthanasia will not ultimately become involuntary as we become inured, hardened by the fact that people are able to have their lives terminated, albeit at their own request.

I believe that life is the cornerstone of civilisation and tampering with it is unacceptable. Basically, I cannot see any justification for why we would head down this path of euthanasia. One of the arguments which has come out in this debate has been the argument about pain, the suffering of people. That has moved me a great deal. I know someone who suffers great pain and the rigours of huge amounts of medication on a daily basis. That person, Lyn Doring, happens to be a cousin of my wife. Lyn is about my age. I will not give any secrets away, but I am nearer to 50 than anything else. Lyn suffered a tragic car accident back in 1967. Her qualifications are Bachelor of Physiotherapy in 1971, getting first class honours in 1975, Bachelor of Medical Science in 1978 and she was heading down the path to becoming a doctor. However, the tragedy of her accident stopped her and prevented her from going any further.

From her experience of suffering pain over a long period, Lyn has put together a number of papers on pain and the ability to cope with pain. I have two of her papers which I am going to quote from in the time I have left because her words say it much better than I could ever say. In the first paper entitled Go Forth with Joy she says:
My main problem is pain. Sensory and motor deficits were comparatively easy to manage.
This was in the early 1980s. She goes on in the same paper:
Since 1979 I have been totally disabled by pain. My condition has proved to be progressive and degenerative. We investigated every avenue, all to no avail.

This led her down the path of looking at the power play involved in pain. This is the thing that concerns me, that there is a power play by those who are in a position of power as opposed to the patient who is generally in a position where they are powerless or feel powerless. I will quote selectively, but if anyone wants to read the full articles, I will supply both of them so that they can test their veracity. As I go through, I will read the quotes and make brief comments. She talks about power play and goes on:
Paradigms are special cases of the way in which people may choose to operate to make sense of a chaotic and complicated world.
She goes on:

The totality of each person's paradigms may be termed the assumptive world (Frank 1974). This is a highly structured, complex, interacting set of values, expectations and images of self and others. These guide and in turn are guided by perceptions and behaviours that are closely related to emotional state and feelings of wellbeing.
Differences between the assumptive worlds of individuals are inevitable.
She is talking about the assumptive state. She continues:

Within an individual's assumptive world, physical and psychological aspects are meshed. Loss of control of the physical body has a profound psychological effect and is associated with a loss of self‐esteem and a sense of being powerless to control events.
This is my worry in the euthanasia debate—that people find themselves so placed. Reading on, she says:
. . . Their assumptive world includes loss of status and the loss of a place in the scheme of things.
Through these mechanisms, a sense of powerlessness enters the assumptive world of those who, for whatever reason, are severely disabled.

Pain is isolating, as is any disability. When courage diminishes, patients might appear to withdraw. Within the patient's assumptive world it may be an indrawing, a self‐encapsulation, in order to contend with external difficulties with apparent poise. In this situation, if a carer is perceived to have disproportionate power, the dynamics of the relationship are affected.
This is from a person who suffered for a substantial part of her life. I believe she has a great understanding. She goes on:
Seemingly inappropriate responses may be elicited from a patient by a carer who is unaware of the patient's assumptive world.

It is often assumed that people can do anything if they really try, but this is not always so. Disabled persons may be thwarted in their efforts to promote self recovery simply through determination and this can lead to guilt and puzzlement when they find that, despite widely held beliefs, sheer determination makes no difference. The next move for many is to call upon survival tactics. In the midst of the fray, patients may become fugitives from their own bodies—refugees from suffering who have nowhere to go. Their assumptive worlds have not hitherto needed to deal with this extremity.
That is the problem that people are faced with when they are faced with pain. She goes on to say:
Many people with long‐standing debilitation live lives in which they exercise little if any power, possess low self‐esteem, possess low social status and possibly even experience social disapproval.
Last but not least, she says:
. . . There are no masks, no pretences, and there can be great honesty, great vulnerability and humility on the part of those who are chronically or terminally ill.
This is from someone who experiences; someone who knows pain.

My fear is that people like Lyn Doring will be, in the longer term, the advocates of euthanasia. Whilst those supporting voluntary euthanasia might very genuinely and sincerely say this is not their intention today, they cannot give an ironclad guarantee that today's legislation will not lead to more dire interpretations later on. So whilst there is not a slippery slope for some people today, no-one can give me a guarantee that there will not be a slippery slope further down the track.
I want to end with a few brief quotes from Lyn Doring, a person who suffers pain daily. This is her attitude to life in Go Forth With Joy. She says:

. . . Even disabled, I can pursue excellence. There is no impediment to my pursuit of beauty, truth, goodness and loving kindness. That might sound like goody two shoes, but I make no apology for that. Goodness is just wonderful and there is not enough of it. There is a cult of the ugly currently. I simply do not comprehend its appeal.
Then she goes on to say:
. . . Friends who genuinely could not handle what had happened and who could not find words stayed away.
This is referring to her illness. She continues:
I do not blame them, but that does not solve the wounds of loss and grief.

This is one of the things that I think is fundamental in the debate that is going on here about euthanasia. As I said, life is an experience. It is a difficult experience. Not everything is perfect, and we have to face up to the good and the bad. In facing up to that, courage is, on many occasions, required.

In concluding, I would like to briefly remark that I believe there is a greater need for more palliative care. It will make the process of dying easier, and it should not remove the emotional side for the patient or the loved ones. I am concerned about the Aboriginals and what was in the report. Last but not least, I am not convinced that, when people have an understanding of the full range of issues involved in the euthanasia debate, there is any justification for supporting euthanasia. I support the Andrews bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout this debate I have deliberated on the many issues put before me on euthanasia. I have taken account of the position of those who are suffering painful terminal illness and disease. I have read hundreds of letters from ordinary concerned citizens, as well as individuals from the legal and medical professions, hospices, hospitals, various denominations of the clergy, the Aboriginal community and a range of community organisations seeking my support for their particular view. Over this time I have come to understand both sides of the debate, and I have taken into account the considerations provided by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in its recent report on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: In considering this question, I looked towards a definition of euthanasia. I know that, historically, `euthanasia', in the original Greek sense of the word, was defined from the word `euthanatos'—`eu' meaning good and `thanatos' meaning death. Hence, the earliest usage of the word was meant to convey a gentle, good or easy death. This may, to some, seem an absurd concept, but, in the context of human life, most would hope for a good death—one that deals with the effects of the physical illness and suffering of dying, one which addresses the sadness, fear and anger which may be experienced and one which nurtures and gives comfort and support.

BREAK.PARA: In no way did this term mean to include committing an act to directly effect or to cause the direct death of a person. But today the term `euthanasia' has become a controversial topic. Not even the definition of the term can be agreed upon, with arguments on classification and category types being devised to differentiate between the types and deaths which could be incurred.

The four main categories which seem to have been accepted into this debate have included active voluntary euthanasia, passive voluntary euthanasia, active involuntary euthanasia and passive non‐voluntary euthanasia. However, all these classifications seem to stem from a precept of allowing human intervention which would end a patient's life. They all seem to involve the concept of intentional killing with or without the patient's consent. As such, I could never sanction any form of euthanasia.

Let me be clear in my belief of what euthanasia is not. It is not the withdrawal or the withholding of medical treatment which is futile, unwanted or burdensome. Nor is it euthanasia to provide sufficient pain relief to a patient, even if that treatment may hasten death by a short time. However, euthanasia is and involves the intentional causing of death to a person.

Furthermore, it has become quite evident throughout this debate that those who argue to legalise euthanasia would also seek to muddy the waters on the definition of what constitutes euthanasia on the basis of what is intended and what is foreseeable. They have tried to infer that the legitimate withdrawal of futile medical treatment or the provision of pain medication, which may as a consequence shorten a person's life, is somehow a party to concepts of euthanasia, which it is not.

In the terms of the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, euthanasia is described as the deliberate intervention by the medical profession to assist a terminally ill person who meets a range of predefined criteria to end their life. This act also seeks to regulate the law, as we have seen it applied in criminal law, and to intervene in the application of the coroners act by limiting the jurisdiction of the coroner in the investigation of a death occurring within the provision of the act.

In point of fact, the act serves to support assisted suicide—assisting to bring about the deliberate death of another human being. In the terms of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act there can be no doubt that euthanasia is the wilful death, albeit killing, of a human being. It lies somewhere between homicide and suicide, where the actual death is carried out by the patient with the sanction and support of secondary parties.

I would have to concur with the views put forward in the House of the Commons debate on euthanasia in 1970 by Mr Norman St John Stevas where he reasoned that a doctor, no matter what his views, had a duty to preserve life. He argued that this duty was the basis of the patient‐doctor relationship. Though he said this did not mean that life was to be prolonged at any cost, he reasoned that there was clearly a moral distinction between giving a pain killing drug knowing it may or will shorten life and giving a drug with the direct intention to kill.

I have also noticed that a dichotomy of values, beliefs and ideas has been running through this debate. But this split which has occurred on many levels and aspects of the debate—that is, in terms of state‐territory rights versus Commonwealth rights, the definition of euthanasia and even what constitutes a conscience vote—is not the heart of the matter. The crux lies in the long‐term implications of this law and the value we place on human life. I emphasise life because it is life, and our ability to protect and maintain human life, which underpins our very existence. All our efforts this century in particular and throughout history have been driven by our ability to protect and sustain life. Our very humanity is based on this precept.

To devise methods of killing and then cloak them in the veil of law works against all that humankind has worked and suffered for. Has life become so mechanical, so routine, so easily replicated—especially now that science has demonstrated the ability to clone—that we now place less value on life that exists? Have we come so far that we are now ready to establish sterile clinical dormitories, death rooms, which will be fully equipped to take away the lives of our people, the very people who are in need of support, by using a law of government sanctioning their death? Have we come so far that we are willing to agree which lives are expendable? What morals, what values, what philosophy do we lean upon to make this decision? How do we show our children that human life is a mystery in itself when we put in place laws that clearly show that life is expendable and replaceable?

How will we manage to stop youth suicide in this nation if we give our youth dual messages about the value of life and the struggle to go on when it seems all hope has gone? Does not the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act sanction death—that is, all you need is a reason which can demonstrate futility—or is a perception of futility when support no longer exists? No. Just as we clearly know that we must support our youth through their despair, pain and sense of hopelessness, we must also provide support for our chronically ill, terminally ill and fellow human beings who are suffering long‐term chronic pain and disability.

I believe that a cry for euthanasia is a cry for help, but who has heard the real cry? Instead, we debate the merits of medically assisted induced death. Rather than meet this cry with a death warrant, we must ensure that effective palliative care programs are put in place. We will truly be a compassionate nation when we turn our minds and medical science focus towards mechanisms which offer real and effective pain management and holistic care in death.

I am particularly concerned that with the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act we have government sanctioned suicide with limited coronial review and it will become, in time, less and less clear or provable that a death has occurred without possible provocation, collusion or insidious manipulation of the patient's physical, emotional and psychological condition.

At present, the Northern Territory act relates to individuals suffering a terminal illness. But in our Aboriginal communities it has been made clear that there are illnesses and diseases which, for this population, are terminal but for the wider community have been eliminated as a serious threat of death. By adopting the act do we justify the possibility that many indigenous Australians may become eligible for euthanasia by default of meeting a criteria that many other Australians do not meet? If we adopt euthanasia will our efforts to eliminate these diseases and illnesses in these communities be affected?

I have many concerns with the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, but in particular with the assessment of mental competence. The act specifies that a qualified psychiatrist must certify that the patient is mentally competent to elect euthanasia. Under the act, as it stands, it would seem that for a psychiatrist to not sign the consent form there would need to be a speedy and genuine diagnosis of mental incompetence directly arising from the medical condition with which the person was diagnosed as terminally ill. This would mean that the psychiatrist would need to undergo a thorough examination and be familiar with the personality of the patient so as to determine the person's true mental health state.

My concerns are grave for people subject to this act. For example, take a patient who projects, or seems to demonstrate, outward understanding of the full implication of a request to terminate their life. Has the request been guided by reason and rational calm or has some other factor or factors played a part in the decision making process? What safeguards are in place to ensure this decision is really desired and fully understood? Is there really sufficient opportunity for a person to change their mind, have a change of heart or regain hope? Once the decision is made, as Senator Hogg said, it is final.

Is there really sufficient time in the assessment phase for a clear evaluation of the patient? Have all the influences been examined such as family attitudes and support; financial position; provision of adequate, effective and appropriate palliative care; pre-existing personality factors; factors directly related to managing pain and the terminal illness; factors arising from treatment processes and/or the quality of care; moral, ethical and social factors pertinent to the patient; accumulative stress from the illness or other illness existing; and previous medical history? Do other medical conditions contribute to the psychological state? Has, for example, there been a recent bereavement?

Many questions with regard to how rigorous the psychiatric assessment really is could be posed. However, it would seem that one psychiatric evaluation is hardly sufficient, especially since our courts are filled daily with cases argued and defended on conflicting evaluations and opinions contained in psychiatric reports. Opinions given by psychiatrists and psychologists can be open to interpretation.

I have noticed that the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act places great emphasis on the fact that the patient is making his or her own decision, but how rational are most people during critical incidents or when faced with life threatening or stressful situations such as severe illness, enduring bereavements or during tragedy? Once we have agreed that the terminally ill should be allowed to seek out death, how long would it be before there were `reasons' for the diseased, the long-term ill, the disabled, the aged and all those who find life intolerable and painful either emotionally, psychologically or physically, to also seek death?

As we are aware, Australia is part of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1966, coming into effect in 1976 and ratified by Australia in 1980. Article 6 of the covenant states:
Every Human being has the inherent right to life. This right shall be protected by law. No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his life.

While there are no specific international laws which cover euthanasia, there have been numerous inquiries into it. In fact, there have been a number of in‐depth inquiries into the validity and legal implications of legislating for euthanasia. Of all the bills supporting euthanasia in the United Kingdom over the past 60 years, not one has been successful. Furthermore, the fact that a law or statement at an international, United Nations, level does not exist, only serves to demonstrate that this course of action is not one to pursue. I further believe that the reason euthanasia is not supported at any United Nations level is that the right to life is sanctioned by all United Nations bodies, to which Australia is a party.

One thing I do find amazing is the fact that the argument of those who support euthanasia and oppose Commonwealth intervention, either under section 122 of the constitution or on a states rights basis, has been steeped in concepts of self-government. It is ironic that some of the very people who welcomed Commonwealth intervention in the past—on the Franklin Dam issue and on homosexual human rights issues—now hope there is no international treaty or covenant to stop Commonwealth intervention on a protection of human life issue.

As we can see, there has been a dichotomy of views, beliefs and ideas running through this entire debate. I firmly believe that the laws of this land must be drafted so as not to cause disadvantage or vulnerability and to ensure that the elderly, the sick and the distressed do not experience pressure, whether real or imagined, to have their life put to an end.

It is well documented that, when a person expresses a desire to die, it is often out of weariness or depression resulting from a prolonged period of pain or intensive treatment. Sometimes it is because the person feels a burden on the people who care for them or on the family which has given support to them. Sometimes it is because the person no longer feels of value and/or is being told that death would be the best solution. A report on `Clinical issues in euthanasia' in the Medical Journal of Australia, 3 February 1997, recently highlighted that the:

. . . importance of families in personal decision‐making should not be underestimated. Families can, either consciously or unconsciously, influence patients so that they may begin to feel that their life is not worth living.

As such, it is well understood that any change in support for a patient, no matter how subtle, can be a dominant influence in the patient's ability to cope with the illness as well as the pain associated with their condition and their mental wellbeing, including decision making. It has been reported that the incidence of depression in family support members can be highly correlated with depression occurring in terminally ill patients. Depression, uncontrolled pain and the lack, or failing, of family support can often lead to requests for death.

But what are the rights of the individual? It has often been cited in this debate that the rights of the individual should be paramount in the consideration of euthanasia, and yet the effects of such a law have implications on each and every person who lives under the flag of this nation. The euthanasia debate cannot be filed into a folder of purely medical or individual concerns. Its implications are ethical, social and legal.

In society, as a whole, we have not only rights but also responsibilities to others—a duty to our neighbour. As such, euthanasia is not a question which lies with the individual alone. This view is supported in findings by the House of Lords Select Committee on Medical Ethics in 1994, which stated:
We believe that the issue of euthanasia is one which the interests of the individual cannot be separated from the interests of society as a whole.

With regard to the role of medical practitioners, I have received numerous letters and submissions which have clearly identified ethical, professional and moral concerns in the participation of the medical profession in the deliberate taking of life, especially since their primary task is to preserve and support human life.

The AMA has written to me expressing the view that, `Doctors should not be involved in interventions that have, as their primary goal, the ending of a person's life.' The AMA has also said that while it understands that this view is not necessarily held by all in the medical profession it believes that this divergence can be attributed to many `complex factors, including lack of experience in palliative medicine.'
I have taken note of the position of the medical profession on euthanasia throughout the world, which is summarised in a policy by the World Medical Assembly both in 1987 and 1992. I quote:

Euthanasia, that is, the act of deliberately ending the life of a patient, even at the patient's own request or at the request of close relatives, is unethical. This does not prevent the physician from respecting the desire of the patient to allow the natural processes of death to follow its course in the terminal phase of illness.

However, this debate is not just about euthanasia but the management of pain in ensuring that there are services available which encompass a range of needs for those who are terminally ill, afflicted with devastating illness and disease or who are suffering intolerably from life‐enduring or life-ending medical conditions.
