I note with concern and some sadness the comments made by Dr Michael Smith, President of the Australian Association of Hospice and Palliative Care, who has indicted that the public fear aroused by this debate has caused uncertainty and concern by patients receiving palliative care—so much so that patients are now fearful of receiving injected medication. I think that that is a very sad thing that has come out of this debate.

I would also like to quote something that was referred to by Senator Hogg. It was what he called the slippery slope. I could not help but notice the remarks by Frank Devine in the Australian. He said:
The experience in The Netherlands demonstrates that the practice of euthanasia is corrupting and ultimately uncontrollable.

I would not like to think that as we have become more adept in saving and preserving life we have lost sight of the awe and mystery of life. As a father and husband, and servant of the people in this nation, I have given this matter much consideration and I have asked myself: what value do we place on human life, if it is easier to die than to live? What kind of nation will we be known as if we create laws which act to aid death rather than preserve life? What real compassion can we be seen to have if we do not act to ease pain and suffering, if we do not act to nurture people? What kind of nation will be become? What kind of people will we be? What values, ethics and morals are we teaching our children?

As I consider the issues and the implications that euthanasia may cause, I am led to the comments of Justice Angel when he characterised Wake v. Northern Territory in 1996 as unique and `as one that institutionalised intentional killing which would otherwise be murder; and as one that institutionalised aiding suicide which would otherwise be a crime'. I can find no reason, no matter how emotionally charged, to support any legislation to terminate human life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 dealing with the issue of euthanasia is one of conscience. In other words, there has been no party room decision on the issue which senators have been requested to support. One is free to make one's own decision to support or oppose the legislation, based on the principles one uses to make personal judgments on issues combined with an analysis of the facts relating to the particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of euthanasia has caused divisions in Australia probably not seen since the emotional issue of the abortion debate in the 1970s and 1980s, which similarly polarised many in the community. It therefore goes to the fundamentals of our democratic process and the appropriate role of freedom of speech and freedom of decision by parliamentarians in acting according to their conscience.

A number of those who have written to me opposing this legislation have argued that my own conscientious view on the issue should not determine how I vote. One argument put is that I should simply support what they claim is the majority view in the community as revealed in public opinion polls. I reject that approach. It means we could dispense with parliament altogether and simply take polls on all decisions required of governments.

Another argument is that, irrespective of my own views and indeed of those of others in the community—even perhaps if those views are in a majority—they should not be foisted on those who do not share them. I also reject that approach. There are many areas where it is determined to be in the overall interests of the whole community to legislate about a particular issue which in some way impinges on the freedom of some who may disagree with the restriction involved.

BREAK.PARA: Related to this has been the suggestion that my particular values should not be a determining factor in my attitude to this legislation. I also reject that view. I am sure my values and attitudes were a factor in people choosing to elect me to serve in this place and they would expect my values and attitudes to inform my decisions on issues.

Value‐free legislation would have the same detrimental consequences on this nation as has so-called value‐free education. My Christian conviction demands my support for the sanctity of life and does not allow me to accept that a person or people can hasten the end of that life through artificial means.

It has been argued that euthanasia is already being practised in many states and jurisdictions, albeit with subterfuge. Euthanasia rights supporter, Professor Peter Baume, estimated that 7,000 Australian medical practitioners have been party to at least one act of euthanasia. However, this is not a justification for legalisation of the process. In Australia today, no-one is forced to accept or endure unwanted medical intervention.

Doctors providing palliative care already administer large doses of pain killing drugs which, while the intent is to relieve pain and bring comfort, may also hasten death. There are those who tell me that it is wrong to prolong the suffering of the terminally ill and dying. This is where palliative care is so important—ensuring that the person in question is kept as comfortable as possible without either artificially prolonging or intentionally extinguishing life.

Just as we should not by medical intervention hasten death, neither should we by medical intervention prolong life just for the sake of proving that we are medically superior or because we might learn something or because a miracle cure might be just around the corner.

It was with sorrow that I learned of the first medically assisted case of euthanasia in late September. It was with sorrow that I read of the extraordinary tribulations being endured by Rob Dent prior to his decision to end his life, and it was with concern that I learned about the parlous state of available palliative care in the Northern Territory. Since that time at least three other people—one a South Australian woman, Janet Mills, and another unidentified man—have also availed themselves of the Northern Territory legislation. No‐one could not have been moved when looking at the ravaged face of Janet Mills and hearing her impassioned plea for a third doctor to sign a piece of paper to put an end to her suffering.

I have received many hundreds of letters from people across Australia in relation to this debate and they are still coming in. More than 80 per cent give overwhelming support to this legislation, the so‐called Andrews Bill. We do not have a right to fiddle with the natural process of death and dying, except, as I have said, to ensure the patient is as comfortable as possible until nature takes its proper course. It is possible that Rob Dent would not have taken his final course of action if he had had access to properly funded and staffed palliative care. With regard to Dr Nitschke, the builder of the Northern Territory's death machine, by his own admission he believes he will be referred to as Dr Death, hardly an accolade of honour.

The suggestion has also been put that the Commonwealth parliament should not intervene in matters before the Northern Territory parliament and that the member for Menzies' bill on voluntary euthanasia is repugnant because it targets and isolates the territory from the rest of Australia. This creates two separate issues—that of euthanasia and that of the autonomy of democratically elected governments in states and territories.

The Prime Minister has committed the federal government to facilitating statehood for the Northern Territory but has not yet specified a date. Until such time as that date is set and full statehood is bestowed on the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth government retains responsibility to oversee Northern Territory legislation. Furthermore, this particular piece of Northern Territory legislation does have ramifications for the whole of Australia. Neither Mr Dent nor Mrs Mills were from the Northern Territory. Within days of the legislation taking effect, a terminally ill Broken Hill man travelled to Darwin. His attempt to hasten death was thwarted when he could not get the necessary medical assessments. He has since died.

The aim of this bill is to repeal that part of the Northern Territory legislation which allows people to deliberately and actively help to cause the death of another. There is the moral and ethical dilemma for medical practitioners, who have pledged under oath not to administer lethal medications. The World Medical Association Declaration on Euthanasia states that the act of deliberately ending the life of a patient, even at the patient's request, is unethical. This declaration was adopted by the 39th World Medical Assembly in Spain in 1987 and reiterated in the World Medical Association Statement on Physician Assisted Suicide from the 44th World Medical Assembly in 1992. The Australian Medical Association continues to support both the declaration and the statement, which encourages doctors to respect a patient's autonomy regarding their medical condition and the right to withdraw from treatment.

People have the right to refuse burdensome and futile medical treatment, such as refusing chemotherapy or asking that a ventilator be turned off when any chance of recovery is nil. However, I believe that no‐one has the right to assist a person to bring about an early death. We have a rapidly ageing population and I have a very real fear that people could be the targets of involuntary euthanasia simply because they have passed their `use-by' date. They are simply old and with old age often comes an increased reliance on hospitals and other medical care.

The Netherlands adopted the practice of euthanasia in 1984. According to a 1990 Dutch government report, upwards of 20 per cent of Holland's annual death statistics are the result of euthanasia, and an average of 14,000 cases of involuntary euthanasia are recorded each year—that is, deaths that have been asked for by the patient's family and not by the patient themselves.

The member for Menzies argues that euthanasia is `not about helping the dying, it is about disposing of them'. I agree with this assessment. Euthanasia is not the same as withdrawing medical support. It is about consciously administering drugs, usually by injection, which kill the recipient. We live in a disposable age—disposable razors, disposable plates and disposable nappies—but surely we are not at the stage where we believe in disposable people.

Legalisation of euthanasia creates a very real possibility of selective culling of Australians. The wide‐reaching effects are very frightening. It is not just about administering lethal injection to the ill and dying. Indeed, it was suggested to me by a pro‐euthanasia campaigner, no doubt jocularly, that those who voted for the Andrews bill would be the first euthanased if euthanasia legislation subsequently succeeded. However, what might be a joke today could well become the reality of tomorrow.

Let us remember the joy on the faces of the recently returned and very triumphant paralympians, many with birth handicaps we would consider insurmountable. Should they have been disposed of at birth because they were not perfect or because somebody else made a judgment on their quality of life? Do we allow the young man who has just lost his legs in a car accident to request that he be euthanased, or do we encourage him to believe that there is a future, albeit different from the one he had mapped out for himself prior to his accident? The Netherlands experience highlights the difficulty in ensuring that there are safeguards that ensure the request for euthanasia is a genuinely voluntary one. Are we so naive that we do not believe that some people will act to further their own best interests?

There is the argument that people have the right to die with dignity. Everyone of us also has the right to live with dignity. Again, the issue is the availability and quality of palliative care across Australia, not euthanasia. Frail and elderly people, those dying of terminal illnesses and those with handicaps deserve the protection of legislation. They have the same rights as any other member of the community to live with dignity.

I conclude by saying that it has been suggested to me that euthanasia should be allowed because no person has the right to play God with another person's life. To that I say, no person has the right to play God with anyone's life, including their own. Only God has that right. This legislation should be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try not to take too much of the Senate's time this evening. I would first like to say that I accept that the views of senators and, earlier in the House of Representatives, of members are genuinely held in relation to this matter and, like them, I hold my views and I intend to be true to them. I wanted to start with a quote, which is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Edmund Burke once described a good parliamentarian as one who is responsive to his electorate and able to employ his judgment and his skills for the benefit of his constituents.

There are a few facts that I would like to recite following that. It is a fact that the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Bill was introduced into the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in February 1995; it is also a fact that in July 1995, having been passed by the Northern Territory parliament, the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act was given assent and passed into law; it is also a fact that in February 1996 there was, as we all know, a federal election campaign culminating in a poll on 2 March; and it is also a fact that Mr Kevin Andrews ran as an endorsed Liberal candidate for the seat of Menzies and was elected by a very large proportion of the electors of that electorate.

I have made contact with those from my party who were campaigning at the same time, and I believe I am reliably informed that Mr Andrews made no mention at any time in any material or in any statements in that election campaign that he had concerns or would take action such as the action which he has taken in relation to the introduction of the bill that is before the Senate tonight. Mr Andrews introduced the Euthanasia Laws Bill in September 1996 and said in his first reading speech:
Last year, the Northern Territory became the only place in the world to legalise what proponents describe as voluntary euthanasia . . .

He knew what had occurred in 1995 and I believe he knew what he intended to do in 1995. The quote that I referred to at the beginning of my speech was a quote from the first speech of Mr Kevin Andrews, the member for Menzies, on 5 September 1991, when he said:
Edmund Burke once described a good parliamentarian as one who is responsive to his electorate and able to employ his judgment and his skills for the benefit of his constituents.

But in this matter Mr Andrews was not prepared to take to his constituents in the 1996 election campaign an intention to pursue the question of a private member's bill to overturn the Northern Territory legislation, which at that time had been law for over six months. I believe Mr Andrews had a duty to tell the electors of Menzies of his intention at the election and, as I said, he did not. I believe he was clearly opposed to the Northern Territory legislation at that time.

We have recently received some evidence that the overwhelming majority of the constituents of his electorate—Menzies—oppose this bill. We have also received some information by polling that an overwhelming majority of his constituents disapprove of his action in pursuing this bill. If that survey is correct, and in the context of what I have described as the circumstances, the chronology of events, then I think I and others are entitled to have serious concern.

Mr Andrews was elected to represent the electorate of Menzies. If indeed, as I believe he did, he concealed his intentions at the election, it does not bring any credit on his actions in pursuing this bill. We are all voting according to our conscience on this matter, as I understand it, but Mr Andrews's conscience on this matter cannot be clear. If he did not bring this bill to the parliament, having first taken his intention to do so to his constituents when he clearly had the opportunity, then he is not bringing a bill to this parliament with a clear conscience. And in that regard, I believe it was improper of Mr Andrews to pursue this bill in these circumstances.

In my view, he owes the electors of Menzies an apology for what I would describe as a betrayal of their trust, and I would condemn Mr Andrews in this regard. Neither he nor his supporters can afford to question the morality of others in these circumstances. I do not believe that the electors of Menzies will easily forgive Mr Menzies for his chicanery.

Having said that, the bill is here and I, like other senators, must address it and—if I choose to—vote upon it. I intend to vote upon it, and I intend to vote against the Andrews bill. I will do so substantially for the following reasons. Firstly, the Northern Territory legislation is clearly about voluntary termination of the life of a terminally ill person.

I reject the view that particularly was put by Senator Coonan last night that it is more appropriate for this issue to be judicially rather than legislatively managed. It seems to me that the opponents of the Northern Territory legislation have relied upon the circumstances in the Netherlands as pointing to the reasons why we should oppose the Northern Territory legislation, when in fact the Netherlands situation is based on a judicial administration of the system and not a legislative administration of the system.

What has occurred has occurred because the legislature has not led on the issue. I have heard many in this chamber and in the House of Representatives talk about and question the role of courts and the way that they may seek to interpret or make law. In this case, the Northern Territory parliament has led on an issue, has not left it for others, and is being criticised for it.

The opponents of the Northern Territory laws have referred to the Netherlands situation, where apparently voluntary and involuntary euthanasia occurs in significant numbers. In this case, we are talking about a bill about which there is little real doubt that it is about voluntary termination of the life of a terminally ill person.

It seems to me that, on the one hand, you cannot condemn the Netherlands situation but, on the other hand, support the method by which the situation has been reached as the preferred option for this country. In essence, if this bill is carried, that is what we will be doing. We will say that this legislature is telling the Northern Territory legislature, `You have no role in this matter. Leave it to the courts.' That is what we will be doing.

BREAK.PARA: Let there be no doubt that, at the moment around Australia, doctors end patients' lives with and without their consent. We can argue about how many times it occurs, but it does happen. We have also seen circumstances recently where family members who end the lives of sick loved ones are dealt with by the judiciary and by juries with great leniency when clearly they have ended the loved one's life with the intent to end their suffering. That is the trend in terms of the community and judicial treatment of this issue.

There was a case recently in my state of Tasmania where a young man shot his elderly father. He was not imprisoned, although convicted. That was the view of the judiciary on that matter. It was arguable that there was some consent by the father, but certainly not the sort of consent that the Northern Territory legislation requires. Are we really saying that is what we want, because that is where we will end up?

I believe that a clear statutory direction on this issue is better than a situation where there is a gradual but uncontrolled opening up of access to euthanasia, however disguised. I believe we are not going to change community attitudes on this issue by voting for this bill. The community, it seems, overwhelmingly opposes this bill. I stress again that I support voluntary euthanasia only.

There is also a debate about this issue of voluntary euthanasia—assisted death—versus the question of allowing death by the withdrawal of treatment, and the third issue of the so‐called double‐effect treatment. It is arguable that often a cruel and painful death occurs on the withdrawal of medical treatment. Yet some who support this bill prefer that option to a lethal injection voluntarily sought and obtained. I find it hard to accept that it is better for someone to die in extreme pain or by starvation or asphyxiation than by a lethal injection sought freely.

We are also looking at the issue of the double‐effect treatment—that is, where a doctor gives medication which has the effect of ending the life, although it is arguable that the intended effect was to end pain. On this matter, last night Senator Coonan said:
This may well be an area of the law which is unenforced and, for all practical purposes, unenforceable.

Are we saying we are prepared to close our eyes and accept that this happens and say that that is better than the legislature prescribing a situation? Is that really better? I think not. We have to be honest with ourselves and with the Australian people on this issue.

I support the palliative care option and think we can do a lot more in relation to palliative care. Indeed, many of the supporters of the bill have talked about palliative care as the solution for a lot of people as a viable alternative to seeking euthanasia. I support that. We really have to put that in perspective.

It has already been said in this debate that the government recently cut funding of palliative care programs. I think it was in the last budget. Did we hear any of the supporters of this bill openly opposing that and moving amendments to the appropriate legislation? We did not. If we are genuinely saying that that is where we want to go with this issue, people have to demonstrate that, not just say it.

We have also seen hundreds of Australians over the age of 75 take their own lives in the last year. Most took their lives violently. We can never really know exactly why. But it is reasonable to speculate that some did so as their way of ending their own lives rather than undergoing a painful and prolonged death. Is that better? Is that really a better alternative than access to voluntary euthanasia, with the controls laid down in the Northern Territory legislation?

In terms of my conscience on this matter, I chose to ask myself a number of questions in relation to the exercise of my vote. I had to ask myself whether, if someone I loved was suffering a terminal illness and wanted to be helped to end their suffering by being helped to die, I could refuse their request for help. Would it be wrong for me to help them with their choice? Should such action be illegal? Should I or anyone be compelled to give such assistance? I must say I answered no to each question.

The Northern Territory law does not offend me. I believe it is, in many respects, a piece of enlightened legislation and I hope that it is not overturned. It provides a compassionate, ordered process for a terminally ill person to follow and I hope that it becomes a benchmark for the rest of Australia. I, like many here, have had personal experience with loved ones and their departure from this earth. I choose not to discuss that in this debate.

In terms of some other matters I just wanted to touch on, I do not believe that this is an issue of whether or not the Commonwealth parliament can or should interfere with the decision of a territory. I believe this issue ought to be determined on its merits. With respect to some other comments that were made, I would wish to associate myself with the comments Senator Newman made last night. I have a great deal of admiration for the comments that were made.

With respect to the question of a comparison of support for euthanasia and support for capital punishment, I reject that there is any comparison. On the one hand we are talking about a decision of a person freely reached to end their own life and on the other we are talking about a decision by society to end the life of another person against their wishes. I believe there is no comparison.

In conclusion I would say this: whether this bill passes or does not means little in terms of the continuation of this debate. It will not conclude the debate either way. It is my belief now, having reached this point in the process, that the pro‐ and anti‐euthanasia forces, having been mobilised, will fight their campaigns for the foreseeable future. I believe that candidates at the next federal election will be canvassed as to their support for or opposition to the principle of euthanasia. Public opinion on this issue may have an effect on the outcome of the election in particular seats as a result of those campaigns. I am not able to predict in which way it will turn, but I think we have embarked upon a debate which will continue in this country for some time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Heffernan, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —It is undisputed that the Commonwealth parliament has the power instilled in it by section 122 of the constitution to enact the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. It could be argued that some of those who seek to hide behind the comfort blanket of states' rights are in fact shrouded by unconscionable political convenience. What is, of course, disputed is the desirability to enact the provision, the constitutional implications for the territories of the enactment of these provisions, the impact of the enactment of the provisions on the Northern Territory criminal code and the impact on, and attitude of, the Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.PARA: I am grateful for the opportunity to have been a participating member of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee which was given the important task of inquiry. I was able to listen to and inquire from those interested parties who came before the committee and also read the unprecedented number of written submissions together with letters from members of the committee who took the time to write to me personally.

I have listened to all sides of the debate and now stand before the parliament to support the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. The Rights of the Terminally Ill Act is far from an act to provide terminally ill patients the right to die. What it does is legalise doctors to kill. The universal adoption of this legislation would provide for a new generation of doctors graduating into our health system with the normality in medical practice of a licence to kill, causing a paradigm shift in the medical ethic.

This convoluted legislation, despite all its safeguards, if allowed to stand irreversibly changes the medical ethic built up over the last 2,000 years when Hippocrates sought members of the medical profession to pledge an oath to observe the highest standards of moral and ethical conduct. Doctor Nitschke has indicated on ABC radio his enjoyment of the travel and publicity associated with his new career as a rights of the terminally ill facilitator. I asked Dr Nitschke:
. . . would it be fair to say that you have neglected the life saving of drug users to participate more full time in the application of death to other patients?'
The doctor's answer was:
It is a true statement.

In other words, a doctor in Australia is turning his back on his six years of university education, turning his back on his pledged code of ethics and turning his back on his years of practical experience of caring for the sick and vulnerable in our society, and is now pulling from his medical bag this new instrument: a licence to kill. Does this mean killing clinics? Dr Nitschke's actions are evidence of a dangerous change in the medical ethic.

In 1987 the World Medical Association declared euthanasia to be unethical. The Australian Medical Association supports this position that euthanasia; that is, the act of deliberately ending the life of a patient, even at the patient's own request or at the request of close relatives, is unethical. Proponents of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act argue that the act empowers the individual to decide the end of their existence and that the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 threatens what in our democratic and liberal society is held so dear, the freedom of the individual.

This would be true if the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act related to suicide, where the individual is the sole determinant of the outcome. John Stuart Mill, the often quoted authority on the rights of the individual, wrote in Three Essays: On Liberty, Representative Government, The Subjection of Women:
The only part of conduct of anyone, for which he is amenable to society, is that which concerns others. In that part which merely concerns himself, his independence is of right absolute.

The Rights of the Terminally Ill Act is a piece of legislation that directly affects at least three others: two medical practitioners independent of the other, one with specialist qualifications in the patient's terminal illness and a qualified psychiatrist; and, less directly, the family, friends, the dependent, the vulnerable and the disabled.

Mr Max Bell was denied the use of this legislation because he could not find a specialist who would assist him. Mr Bell is proof that the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act is not autonomous. He was a mentally competent, terminally ill patient who wanted to die, but a doctor would not consent to it. The Rights of the Terminally Ill Act creates a new executioner. Capital punishment has been rejected in the past partly because of the unintentional innocent victims. Euthanasia will also have its innocent victims, perhaps more so than the number of so-called beneficiaries of the legislation.

During the inquiry, many things came to light. Perhaps the most shocking was the admission by Marshall Perron, the former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and sponsor of the private member's bill, that he was unfamiliar with the term palliative care and what it really meant. In fact, on further questioning by me, he admitted it was only after he decided to introduce the legislation that he discovered palliative care.

In the 1993-94 budget, the federal government announced a palliative care program costing $55 million over four years. The program was designed to maximise the quality of life of people suffering terminal illness, to avoid inappropriate hospital admissions and to provide support to families and carers. The Northern Territory government, with Marshall Perron as Chief Minister, did not take up the funding in the first year, denying the people of the Northern Territory comfort during terminal illness. What they got in its place was euthanasia legislation and perhaps gross political negligence at the expense of the territory's terminally ill—hardly what you would call a fair substitute. Perron told the inquiry:

I certainly agree that palliative care in the Northern Territory, prior to the introduction of this legislation, was deficient. I accept responsibility for that, having been Chief Minister for a number of years up until that time . . .
However, if there is something good to come out of it all, it is that we all—all the politicians and all the community—know what palliative care means now. There is a deal of focus on it of course.
He went on to say:
. . . because of our sheer population we will be unlikely to have the sorts of facilities that are available in much bigger, better resourced states.

Had Marshall Perron known what palliative care was, the Northern Territory would have been much better off with the Commonwealth funding. The state governments are endlessly complaining about their health funding, and here is an example of where they did not even take up the offer. The Northern Territory AMA, in its submission to the committee, said:

BREAK.PARA: Given the experience of the Netherlands where euthanasia is not even legal, it is not unreasonable to assume that given time and distance, the cheaper option of Euthanasia over Palliative Care will become very attractive to this government as it struggles with the limited funding resources for its public health system versus escalating need and health care costs.
Professor Ravenscroft, President of the Australian and New Zealand Society for Palliative Medicine, went further. He told the committee:

I do not have any doubt. The option is $30 for an injection or $10,000 to keep an AIDS patient going for a year and perhaps $20,000 to keep an ordinary palliative care patient going for a year. It is simple. You go for your $30 option and save a lot of money.
Majority support for the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 will ensure that the $30 option is not available and medical treatment decisions will be made on a needs and not an economic basis.

Perhaps nowhere else are Aboriginal health problems more acute than in the Northern Territory. Making up 23 per cent of the population, many Aboriginals from both city and regional and remote areas have a distrust of Western medicine. Professor Ian Ring, who published research in 1996 on the health of our indigenous people in the Cape, found no improvement in any major health indicators since 1976. Despite government efforts, language, culture and remoteness keep Aboriginal people from seeking medical help until it is often too late.

While we cannot group all Aboriginals into the one community, as the inquiry's terms of reference might suggest, we cannot ignore the unanimous response from Aboriginal individuals and groups to the committee on the effect of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. Similar evidence was heard by the Northern Territory select committee in 1995. Djiniyini Gondarra of the Northern Regional Council of Uniting Aboriginal and Islander Christian Congress expressed the view:

Aboriginal people are being driven further from the health services they are so desperately in need of because of the fear and suspicion generated by the existence of the new Northern Territory legislation.

We in this place and that other place know too well that perception is reality. For Aboriginal communities, the perception under the Northern Territory legislation is that, if you go to hospital, a doctor is allowed to kill you. We as a government have a responsibility to all Australians to provide the best health care and feeling of security within the health system. The Commonwealth will be meeting that responsibility with the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

The Northern Territory, in its arguments, takes comfort in polling as the overwhelming support for euthanasia. However, one must question the accuracy of their polling when a significant proportion of the Aboriginal communities are in remote areas without access to telephones and where English is often a second, third or even a fourth language.
`What is all the fuss about?' inquired Fred Finch, former Northern Territory health minister on ABC radio. He said:
Most Aboriginal people would not utilise the legislation and, therefore, it should not really matter if they were not told about it.

This kind of reasoning is really absurd. It is like saying that, because only one Aboriginal student graduated from an Alice Springs high school in 1996, most Aboriginal people would not utilise the education system, so why consult the Aboriginal community on curriculum? Same logic.

The Northern Territory government stated that consultation with Aboriginal leaders and communities was a consistent feature of the development of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. But did the government listen? The Senate committee heard much about the safeguards in the legislation. These safeguards, we are told, restrict those able to use the legislation to mentally competent terminally ill patients. However, what I find myself asking is: where will this end, once society condones doctors killing instead of saving lives? I agree with Archbishop Hickey's comment during the inquiry. He said:

While that act remains in force, it impairs the intricate system of relations which sustain our civilisation and our laws. A new disturbing element is introduced into the relationship between the doctor, nurse and patient; the family and its member facing death; the citizen and the state. The promoters of euthanasia say that those who are to die and those who are to kill under the legislation will always do so freely and willingly. These assurances are unconvincing enough in society as we now know it. What value would such assurances have in a society altered over time by legislation like the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act?

Marshall Perron thinks that there are too many safeguards and that there is a case to expand the legislation to other categories. The first group that comes to his mind is non‐terminally ill competent adult quadriplegics. Ms Wright, speaking on behalf of the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties, went further and said:
. . . there should be no objection to a person . . . for whatever reason, if they find their life unbearable for quality of life reasons . . . availing themselves of it.

I find the strength of the human spirit a formidable thing, but pressure can eventually come to bear and break it down. The mere existence of the euthanasia legislation is itself a pressure on the elderly, the sick and the vulnerable. If we allow the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act to stand, if we allow `safeguards' to be dropped and if we allow the legislation to expand to other categories, we are saying to the elderly, the sick and the vulnerable that death is a cure.

Mentally competent elderly or incurably ill persons who are clinging to life consciously and with great determination will begin to feel the pinch of the legislation. So too will their family members and primary carers. Just over three months ago, I made a commitment to this parliament to reward the individual, unburden the dependent and protect the vulnerable. I honour that commitment today by supporting the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been pointed out by many of the senators in this debate, this is an issue which has profound implications for all within our community. I agree with Senator Cooney's comments in his additional remarks to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report on this matter. He said:

BREAK.PARA: The Rights of the Terminally Act affects the nation as a whole. It influences the ethos, the culture, the attitude of people who live in various parts of this country. It is likely to affect those of many who live throughout the world.

I do not think we should hide from these potential implications. The importance of this debate has prompted me to make some additional comments that I had not originally planned. If I take a little more than the 10 minutes I estimated, I apologise to those following me, including Senator Tierney.

This is an issue and debate which, I am sorry to say, has been characterised by simplistic and emotional reporting and an enthusiastic promotion of euthanasia advocates by much of the mainstream media. This media reporting has, in my view, denied many within our community an opportunity to hear an appropriate and reasoned debate on the issue. Views such as those of Dr Colleen McCullough have not been given the prominence which I feel they deserve and so I would like to open my remarks by quoting a letter that Dr Colleen McCullough wrote to me. She says:

Prior to becoming a full‐time novelist, I worked as a neuro‐physiologist. My experience with the terminally ill extended over 20 years. At first glance, euthanasia seems a welcome solution for those who do genuinely desire an easier, swifter and far less painful end to suffering. In an ideal world it would already be accepted practice.

But alas, our world is far from ideal, far from perfect. Therefore, I have grave misgivings about legalising euthanasia for persons afflicted with terminal or incurably incapacitating diseases. My reasons are grounded in human nature and chiefly concerned with the human propensity to think of events in terms of money or gain of one kind or another.

Is it moral or ethical for a government to contemplate legislative action which inevitably incorporates an element of saving large amounts of taxpayers' money, when it simultaneously deprives other taxpayers of life?

It is important to state at the outset that I intend to support the Euthanasia Laws Bill. I do so from a reasoned examination of the facts, of existing community evidence and evidence presented to the Senate's inquiry into the bill and also of the recommendations arising from the House of Lords inquiry, the New York State task force and the Canadian Senate inquiry, all of which concluded that euthanasia cannot be safely legalised and that euthanasia laws pose profound risks to many individuals who are ill and vulnerable. Are we to disregard these recommendations and this evidence? My professional background also leads me to acknowledge my moral and ethical views, as a person raised as a Catholic. They also lead me to acknowledge the social and political framework from which I come and my own personal life experience.
I found it ironic, for instance, that Lindsay Tanner, in the other place, was somewhat lonely amongst the group often characterised as the socialist left when he commented:
There are many areas in our society where we inhibit individual freedom—
unlike many of his colleagues who are focused more on the importance of freedom of choice.

I also find it somewhat ironic that last night Senator Coonan perhaps explained best the framework that I apply when she pointed out in her comments the importance of the balance between individual rights and the public interest. I would like to refer to the comments made by Senator Coonan last night because they are quite instructive. She said:

Assuming once again for the purposes of argument that sufficient safeguards could operate to protect the vulnerable and that consent were fully informed and freely given, the question is whether society should yield to that expression of individual choice or whether we as a society are justified in denying to a few fellow citizens assistance for the form of relief they seek. Are there risks to society collectively that outweigh individual freedom of choice to end a life in this manner? I have come to the view that extending end of life options to include a formal regime for voluntary euthanasia or physician assisted suicide does pose appreciable risks to the way our society is presently ordered and is not in the public interest.

Hear, hear! It has been obvious that many within our community have similar apprehensions regarding the Northern Territory euthanasia act. This apprehension has been exemplified by the number of letters I have received and by the majority of the more than 12,500 submissions to the Senate inquiry into the bill.

Despite Senator McKiernan's comments tonight, in an attempt to discredit some of those submissions, the counterargument could be put that submissions running the argument on the other side have also been questionable. Certainly, I can say from my experience that some of the methods have been questionable as well. But I do not think it does the debate service to go into that sort of argument.

It has been stated that the responses from the general public to the Senate committee do not reflect mainstream community opinion on euthanasia and that public opinion polls demonstrate clear community support for the right to die. I would like to deal with that issue. They are correct on one aspect: the community does seem to support a person's choosing the right to die in what appear to be very limited and selective circumstances. They appear to support a person who is frail and ravaged by cancer choosing to die but do not support a teenage boy or girl suffering intense distress choosing to end their life. It is on that point that I would like to go back, not in too much detail, to my personal life experience.

Senator Newman last night, in what I understand was a very moving contribution, and I respect her position in terms of her own life experience, unfortunately implied that the general public view might more reflect people not involved with groups or the like who have had life experiences associated with those people who are terminally ill. My own life experience from dealing with people with chronic illnesses and who have made suicide attempts actually leads me to support the Andrews bill rather than away from it.

My life experience from dealing and working with people with disabilities leads me to support the Andrews bill and leads to my considerable concern about the way disability has been used within this debate. It leads me to considerable concern about the people who fight or strive for a continued dignified existence in ways which some people might characterise as undignified.
Senator Newman also made a comment in her speech which I think is implausible as a rationale for a choice in social policy. She said:
. . . I wish to have the right to knowingly choose the time of my death and the circumstances in which I die.
We all might have that wish, but I do not think it is a strong basis for social policy. It seems more like a dream.

I wonder, though, whether the public supports the right of a person to be killed on request. Does the community support legalising what is currently illegal in states and territories other than the Northern Territory? Do they support an act which has the potential to fundamentally alter the doctor‐patient relationship if not the very culture of our society? Do they support doctors being granted the right to terminate the lives of those who are suicidal and terminally ill? Do they support the right of a doctor to intentionally kill by lethal injection another human being? These were questions asked by the pollsters for the mainstream when the polling was conducted.

It is important for me to also state that I have the deepest sympathy for those in severe pain and distress, who are terminally ill and are seeking relief from their suffering and pain. Many in our community have understandable compassion and a desire to help those who are suffering and who are wishing to experience relief from their suffering. But I believe that euthanasia is not the way to achieve this.

It is interesting that the legislation was passed by a single vote even though the personal views of the majority of the members of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly opposed euthanasia in principle. I believe, because of the national significance and the potential effects of the right to die act, that the Commonwealth has an obligation to override it. It is apparent that the Commonwealth has the power conferred on it by the constitution to take this course of action. I also think that it would be inconsistent, as a Labor senator, to argue the territory or states rights issue. I feel it is incumbent upon those who oppose the Andrews bill to demonstrate why it should be feasible to codify in statute form circumstances in which life can be legally extinguished by another human being.

In articulating my position on this, I think it is instructive to refer to the comments by the Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr, which were also referred to in the Senate committee's report. He asked:

Is it possible to reduce to black and white law on the pages of a statute book the circumstances, and the safeguards in which we would allow the taking of a life? I have spoken to many experts, people engaged on both sides of this argument, and what has shaped my bottom line conclusion is the view that it is not possible to codify in law the safeguards, the circumstances, in which the extinguishing of a human life would be possible.

I would like to examine arguments put forward by proponents of euthanasia and respond to them. A primary argument put forward by euthanasia advocates is that society should legalise what is already occurring within the medical profession. It is apparent that a minority of doctors are facilitating a patient's death when terminally ill. But is that sufficient justification to change the law?

An appropriate and perhaps current analogy would be to change gun laws because individuals could still obtain possession of illegal weapons. Should we change existing laws because this minority does not wish to adhere to the law?

Additionally, if doctors are at present breaking the law when it is illegal, what realistic constraints are there in a law where euthanasia is legalised? A recent survey in New South Wales indicated that up to 14 per cent of doctors replied yes when asked whether they had ever assisted a patient to die. I have grave concerns about the lack of protection for those seeking a lethal injection or assisted suicide—I think that is compassion also. How is abuse going to be prevented when the primary witness to the abuse is dead? Under the provision of the Northern Territory right to die act, provided the paperwork is in order after death, no questions will be asked.

Another argument is that doctors, as part of palliative care practice, are presently killing patients by administering pain relievers in doses that are lethal. We have heard more about this tonight. Whilst this undoubtedly occurs, palliative care experts claim that it is the intention to relieve patient pain, not to kill them—the intention that is critical. To put it into this framework, if you provide a pain‐killer which risks hastening death and the person is still alive, then you do not provide further doses unless they are required for more pain, but if a doctor is administering a lethal injection and it does not kill the patient, then the doctor would be required to administer a higher dose immediately and continue to do so until that person is dead. The objective is the determining factor. The lack of decent accessible palliative care is an issue that needs to be addressed, regardless of what happens with this bill.

Another argument put forward, which I alluded to earlier, was that argued by Chris Gallus in the article which appeared in the Canberra Times yesterday—perhaps focused at some of her Liberal colleagues—where she opened the article by saying:
Central to the concept of Liberalism is individual responsibility and the rights of the individual.

The argument propounded by Ms Gallus is that the right to die is a matter of individual rights, that it is an individual choice and a matter personal dignity—that word again. To me, that is quite clearly not the case.

What the individual wishing to die is asking is to be killed by another party. What is being requested is for the doctor to determine whether a patient will have a worthwhile life. Adding to the comments made earlier by Senator McKiernan, if you do not couch it in those terms, then the terms have to be whether we, as a society, should endorse some people suiciding and others not. But what protection does a person in pain and severe distress, who may ardently believe at the time that they make the request that they wish to die, have? How is the administration of a lethal does by a third party a matter of individual rights and liberalism?

Under the provisions of the right to die act, a patient has to wait for a cooling off period of 48 hours before they are able to receive a lethal injection. What protection is that, when you get 10 days for an encyclopaedia?

The concept of the slippery slope is familiar and has been addressed again many times tonight. To me, it still remains a powerful argument against legalising euthanasia. Even with the existing Northern Territory act, there is some confusion as to who might qualify for euthanasia. Under the Northern Territory act, euthanasia is defined as applying to people who have a terminal illness. Terminal illness applies to anyone, regardless of prognosis, who is in such a state of health that, if treatment were discontinued, they would die. A legal opinion has been provided by a group of QCs from around the country that this definition could logically include those who are not normally regarded as having a terminal illness but who require treatment to continue living. This includes people with diabetes who are dependent on insulin and people with asthma who are dependent on ventolin. In find this interpretation disturbing. I do not think it is just fear‐mongering. It is indicative of the scope that an interpretation of this act might come to rather than its original purpose.

A disturbing trend has been established, for instance, in the Netherlands, where euthanasia is not legalised but is widely practised and tolerated by the government. The official guidelines claim that euthanasia is limited to those who have a serious physical illness and make a voluntary request for euthanasia. In a recent decision in the Dutch courts, a woman with no physical illness, but with a history of psychiatric illness, requested a lethal dose from her doctor. She had experienced recent domestic difficulties with her husband, who had walked out on her, and her two sons that had died, one through suicide. Her doctor provided her with a lethal dose. Despite the guidelines, the Dutch court held that she was an appropriate person for euthanasia.

The court held that all suffering is ultimately mental and it is both non‐compassionate and illogical to allow euthanasia for those suffering from physical causes but deny it to those suffering from non‐physical causes. The important lesson from this decision is that the courts will follow the principle to the very limits of its logic. It will not necessarily come back here.

It is also interesting to note that the majority of members of the medical profession who are at the coalface do not support legalisation of euthanasia. Organisations such as the AMA, disability groups, senior citizens groups, palliative care doctors organisations and other doctors have all expressed concerns. Who are we as parliamentarians to disregard the concerns of those facing these issues at the coalface?

Overall, there are compelling arguments to override the Northern Territory right to die act. It is our responsibility as politicians to accept responsibility for the vulnerable and the disadvantaged and offer protection to them beyond a superficial freedom of choice. I conclude by quoting from Dr Brian Pollard in his book The Challenge of Euthanasia where he talks about rights, a term I usually like to avoid. He says:

When a right to die is claimed in support of euthanasia, what is meant is something different. The same words are now used to mean a right to be killed on request and the right of another person to kill when asked.

It can be seen that this is a misuse of language and a mistaken concept of rights, since there is no right to be killed by another person, nor any right to kill on request. Such claimed rights have never appeared in any code of ethics or law and no argument is ever produced to justify them. It is therefore unreasonable to expect the law to be changed to protect rights that do not exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to make my contribution to the debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. Some members of my family will be surprised by my vote because of my family's experience with death and dying from cancer. An aunt and an uncle of mine both had families with a predisposition to cancer. Their family formation created a genetic time bomb which prematurely took the life of my uncle, in his early 50s, and the lives of my two cousins, who both died of stomach cancer when they reached their early 40s. Three out of four members of that family were taken by cancer within 10 years. My mother, who had nursed her own mother before she had also succumbed to cancer, said many years after—an expression that reflected her rural upbringing—`If I ever get like that, just knock me on the head.' Therefore, I understand the feelings and the compassion which drive those who support euthanasia.

SPEECH.PARA: Surveys show that a majority of Australians support euthanasia and, indeed, personal experience like this colours the opinion that is often expressed to opinion pollsters. But how accurate are these opinion polls? The touted 70 per cent support that is said to exist in the community for euthanasia must, I believe, be treated with some caution. As a former researcher who has designed questionnaires, I am well aware of the importance of the way in which a question is framed. If you ask a leading pejorative question, you can bias the results. For example, `Do you agree that the law ought to be changed to allow a doctor to give a lethal injection to a person suffering a terminal illness?' With such a pejorative question, you might doubt the sanity of the 30 per cent who fail to answer, `Yes.' Australians perhaps fear and do not comprehend death, so when this painless alternative is put it is seen as an easy way out.

Like a lot of my other Senate colleagues, I have received hundreds—it seems like almost thousands—of letters on this issue urging me to either vote for the bill or vote against it. These letters present some very compelling personal stories to influence one's final vote on the decision. In truth, we have all had to canvass our consciences on a broad range of issues to arrive at our final vote on euthanasia. These include the constitutional position of this parliament and the powers of the Northern Territory parliament; the morality of euthanasia; personal life experiences and anecdotal evidence; religious beliefs and commitment to those teachings; belief in a fundamental set of human rights, including life and liberty; the impact of medical ethics for doctors, nurses and carers; and the practicality of codifying euthanasia in statute law.

I want now to examine some key criticisms levelled against the Andrews bill—firstly, that the Andrews bill singles out the Northern Territory and impinges on territory rights. This is not true. The bill enacts a law to the extent of the Commonwealth's parliamentary powers. The Northern Territory legislation has rejected the national approach which prosecutes intentional killing and assisted suicide. Secondly, it is said that the Andrews bill invalidates the Northern Territory natural death act. Again, this is not correct. The bill is solely about euthanasia and no other matter. This bill has no retrospective effect.

The bill under consideration tonight, the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, or the Andrews bill, restates two clear principles—firstly, that legislative assemblies of the territories should have no power to legislate the intentional killing of another. Secondly, this bill confirms that the legislative assemblies do have power to make law about the withdrawal or withholding of medical or surgical treatments to a terminally ill patient.

A number of other principles have guided my decision on this legislation. Euthanasia raises enormous medical ethics issues for doctors. Hippocrates, in ancient Greece, said: `I will never give a deadly drug to anybody if asked for it, nor will I make a suggestion to that effect.' The AMA, the nursing profession and the overwhelming majority of the caring professions are opposed to euthanasia. The doctor, not the disease, kills the patient if voluntary euthanasia is practised. There is a danger that legislation will put undue pressure on medical practitioners.

Accurate diagnosis is also sometimes difficult. Doctors only give an opinion. Irrespective of the eminence of the doctor, it is well recognised in world practice that they can only give an opinion. Other speakers have given examples tonight and at other times in this debate, and in the other chamber, where diagnosis has been wrong and people have, following such a wrong diagnosis, resumed their lives.

Overseas experience in Holland suggests legislated euthanasia can lead to more control over the lives and the rights of people. A Dutch finding reported that upward of 20 per cent of people given a lethal injection had neither expressed consent nor had any knowledge of their impending death through injection. The advancement of incremental steps down the slippery slope—as so many have mentioned—as euthanasia law is expanded is a considerable concern. The first incremental step is voluntary euthanasia, which is followed by involuntary euthanasia. The third step is euthanasia for prescribed classes of persons: the aged and babies with deformities under one month or so. This could become a reality in future times once we start down this slippery slope.

Unscrupulous relatives could also use euthanasia as a cloak to hide their greed. In 1997, care of the aged in our society does not have the priority it should. Euthanasia could become one of the convenient legal vehicles to cover quasi‐criminal activity. An elderly relative in a weakened mental and physical state could have their life ended prematurely for the financial gain of another person.

Laws that legalise euthanasia also send very bad signals to the youth of Australia. Such law legitimises the concept of ending life early. Youth suicide in Australia is already one of the worst when compared with the Western world with 3,000 cases per annum. It is a greater killer in our society than road trauma. Millions of dollars are now spent by government and non‐government agencies to try to turn this tragedy around. The Northern Territory law and continuous publicity condone intentional killing and assisted suicide and, therefore, send the wrong message to our youth, many of whom see no future for themselves and are depressed and often suicidal.

The law is a very blunt instrument and not appropriate to regulate life and death in this way. The law does not have the finesse and flexibility to deal with all the issues associated with euthanasia. Statute law cannot cover every possible event or circumstance in life and death issues. It is too codified and inflexible. The Northern Territory act has shown this flaw already. There is a problem issuing death certificates for the first persons using the Northern Territory law as it stands.

Not all things in life should and can be regulated by law. What we should be doing is legislating for higher standards and quality in palliative care and enact modern refusal of treatment legislation. Neither of these options has been used in the Northern Territory.

I have, therefore, on the basis of what I have said so far, in conscience decided to vote against the Northern Territory legislation which allows voluntary euthanasia. I will be casting my vote in the Senate for the Andrews bill—the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a historic debate. In fact, in my 10 years in this place, this is the first time on which I have had the opportunity to participate in an issue where a free vote has been allowed. As a Tasmanian who has crossed the floor to defend states rights, I have to ask myself what I should do. I acknowledge the strong and moving arguments put by my colleagues Senator Grant Tambling, Senator Bob Collins and the Hon. Nick Dondas protecting the rights of states and territories. They ask: why should a federal government override the decisions of states and territories? My answer to them, and to others who offer a similar view, is that, in this case, it is not a government which is attempting to override subordinate legislation; it is in fact a majority of individual people representing all parties and political persuasions in the Senate and the House of Representatives who will decide this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: As individuals, we represent a broad cross‐section of the Australian community. We are elected by our constituents to make decisions on their behalf. In this unique case, I believe a majority of the people's representatives will say that the Commonwealth must override this particular territory law to protect the lives, in the future, of many other Australians.

Like my colleagues, I have received hundreds of representations on this bill and, understandably, they represent a broad cross‐section of community views. There is not an individual in our community who has not been touched at some time or other by the death of a family member or loved one when the particular circumstances of that passing have no doubt had a profound effect on all involved.

We should not neglect the fact that of the 12,500 representations received by the Senate Legal and Constitution Legislation Committee, which was the most representations ever received in the history of the Senate, around 93 per cent opposed euthanasia. This was mirrored by the correspondence which has been directed to my own office. That correspondence has brought to my attention that the euthanasia legislation runs contrary to all major religions in the world, including Juda ism, Islam, Christianity and Eastern religions. Similarly, it runs contrary to all health care protocols and is opposed by all reputable doctors' associations.

In their submission to the Senate committee, the national forum of the National Council of Churches, which is recognised as the most representative body of our Christian churches in this country, rejected euthanasia on the grounds that it was `contrary to God's law and the values of civilised society'. No higher a religious authority than His Holiness Pope John Paul II has said `the direct and voluntary killing of an innocent human being is always gravely immoral'. I believe that the views expressed by our churches represent the views of many in our community, but I also appreciate that there is a strong argument being put forward by opponents of this bill that we have a responsibility as a community to end the suffering of those with an incurable or terminal disease.

This is an emotional argument and, as one who has witnessed the suffering of a number of relatives, I can appreciate how this view arises. I feel for these people and acknowledge their genuine compassion. However, I would like to draw to the Senate's attention an article written in the Tasmanian newsletter of the Australian Medical Association by Professor Ray Lowenthal. Apart from being president of the Tasmanian branch of the Australian Medical Association, Professor Lowenthal is a medical oncologist, palliative care physician, the current chairman of the Cancer Council of Tasmania and has had 30 years experience in the treatment of cancer. He was explaining the reason for the attitude of members of the AMA. He said in part:

Our attitude has nothing to do with a shift in the power balance between patients and doctors, as claimed by Dr Phillip Nietschke, a prominent proponent, in an interview published in the Paris‐based International Herald Tribune, and certainly not from any lack of compassion. The vulnerability of the frail and infirm impels us. `Can't something be done . . . ' is a question put from time to time by distressed relatives but almost never by dying patients themselves. But the family's attitude causes anguish. Should one life be shortened because of another's distress? . . . For the dependent and the powerless, the pressure may overwhelm. Yet people value life differently when they are well and when they are facing death: then, every day is precious. As long as the symptoms are tolerable, every extra moment with family and friends is a bonus.

It is no coincidence that, when we look at this question of suffering and dying, the type of experience detailed by Professor Lowenthal is also reflected in a submission I received from Mr Pat Flanagan, the manager of Mary's Grange Home at Taroona in my own state of Tasmania. Mr Flanagan wrote:
After observing many deaths in this home, there are three observations I would like the make—

(a) Sometimes it is the relatives who cannot cope with the concept of someone dying. The actual person can be quite accepting of the situation. In this case, euthanasia is a solution for the relatives, but what of the person?

(b) The aged, facing a limited future (with often vastly reduced facilities), frequently express the wish not to be a nuisance, not to be a burden. This reflects their diminished self‐esteem and, possibly, Australian society's view of the aged. As such, these people can be highly susceptible to certain ideas put to them i.e. you should go into a home. In some tragic cases, families exploit these feelings.
Finally, Mr Flanagan makes what I believe is the most pertinent observation in relation to the whole euthanasia debate when he writes:
Although it is not uncommon for residents of a home to say they wish to die, when death approaches, they often fight it with tenacity and dogged determination.

There are many people here who have put their own slants on this debate. Like many other people, I have my own feelings on this matter. Just two years ago my father died. I worked with my father from the age of 15. We lived and worked together on a farm until I was married. Even after that I worked in partnership with my father until he retired. Unfortunately, in later years he suffered from the often quoted and increasingly occurring Alzheimer's disease. The family eventually had no alternative but to put my father in care. It got to the stage where for him to live with my mother was quite unfortunate and it was too traumatic for him to stay there.

As his health deteriorated, it crossed my mind on more than one occasion, because I had worked with him on the farm and we had had the experience of putting down sick animals, whether if he had all his faculties he would have said, `Put me down.' He was a person who loved his family and needed them. Of course we needed him. In my opinion, it was out of the question that that sort of thing should happen.

There is no doubt that in the last few weeks there was great pressure on us all, and as his health worsened we had in the back of our minds a hope that he would pass on. As it happened, we had a family meeting and we decided to bring our father home for whatever time it took because he was in a terminal state. I suppose, through his life, in death my father united the family in a way that he never had in his lifetime. We were all good friends and worked together, but in those last few weeks he united the family in a way that I will never forget and I think the rest of the family will never forget. We nursed him over those last two or three weeks. My sister and I were with him when he died. In finality we all know that God's way was the only way.

There are many arguments which have been put already by my colleagues in the Senate as to why we should protect human life. There have been some very moving speeches made on both sides of the argument. I think issues such as the sanctity of life and the impact on our society if we devalue the life of one individual are most important. The religious beliefs which I mentioned earlier, the slippery slope which has been quoted on many occasions, the erosion of medical ethics and the deterioration of doctor‐patient relations are most important in this debate.

Fundamental also is the issue of palliative care. There are significant advances being made in this particular area of medical treatment and I know that there are concerns that the growing use of euthanasia would impact upon the resources which are being made available there. It is possible for one to face death with dignity and it is possible that the time spent with a loved one can be quality time, although not in the traditional sense of what we may consider quality time when we are fit and healthy.

It is acknowledged that palliative care and the treatment of the elderly is not cheap, but it is a responsibility which we in society must bear in the same manner in which traditional families consider it their responsibility to take care of their elderly relatives. We should not as a society use euthanasia as a means of saving money in the care of the elderly.

There is one last issue I wish to raise and that is the possibility that euthanasia could be misused. The previous speaker mentioned this. I note in a very good paper on the inquiry into euthanasia that was conducted by the British House of Lords that euthanasia advocates in Holland were forced to admit that it was impossible to devise safeguards against the abuse of euthanasia practices. Investigations into the practice of euthanasia in Holland in 1990 found that 20 per cent of deaths each year were by euthanasia and only 10 per cent of those who died had actually given a formal request. I am sure these figures are of concern to everyone in the Senate and everyone participating in this debate. I would hate to see these types of figures ever become relevant in the care of our elderly in Australia.
To conclude, I would like to draw upon the findings of the British House of Lords select committee which in paragraph 237 of its final recommendations concluded:
Society's prohibition of intentional killing . . . is the cornerstone of law and social relationships. It protects each of us impartially, embodying the belief that all are equal.

I am proud to be a member of our Australian community and I value the laws and beliefs which we all hold dear. I cannot support the use of euthanasia as I believe it is contrary to the belief on which our nation has grown and prospered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak briefly on the Euthanasia Laws Bill. As senators and many members of the public would know already, I oppose this legislation, and the reasons for my opposition to it have been canvassed in the additional comments that Senator McKiernan and I made to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue, regardless of whichever way we vote in this legislation, is one that we have all lived with and, regardless of what happens, one that we will continue to live with in our personal lives outside of politics. Like many others who spoke in this debate, I have also suffered the experience of friends and relatives who have suffered slow, painful deaths—some as recently as the last 12 months or so.

I have always wondered, as I have been with them, what I would like to happen. Of course, that is something that has been canvassed by many senators in this place. I have always wondered whether quicker would be better and—as I think all of us have—have often been relieved at the end of the suffering. So often I have always wanted that suffering to end and to end early. Just as often, I have walked away knowing that a decision was probably taken and that quite often honest, caring people have been made to feel guilty by their actions and by the lack of protection of the law. It is these sorts of issues that have confronted everyone in a very direct and personal sense as they have experienced the suffering and the passing away of close friends and relatives. Overwhelmingly, this debate has been conducted on that plane in this particular place.

I have to comment on some elements of the debate. The analogy, for instance, with nazism is one which is totally inappropriate and totally offensive both to many victims of Hitler's Germany and their families, some of whom are living in Australia, the victims of the genocide and also to the well meaning in our society who are concerned about and are supportive of a proposal like euthanasia. It does no-one any good at all—especially, I must say, the clerics—to draw the analogy with Hitler's Germany and nazism.

It is an issue where, no matter what our position, we can find many reasons, many arguments, many quotations, many reports from across the world to support one position or another. I do not want to recanvass the detailed reasons that Senator McKiernan and I have given for our report. I want to restate the fundamental basis of the view reached by Senator McKiernan and me: individually, neither of us wish to deny others the right to use the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. Nor, for that matter, do we want to deprive other Australian citizens, in particular—due to the provisions of this bill— the people of the ACT, of the right to choose how they end their lives.

Rather, I wish to focus on the issue that I believe is central to this debate, and that is the issue of conscience. I do not think there can be any doubt that this bill raises significant issues of conscience. We all have different views as to what `life' means to us, and this bill and the subject of euthanasia go to the heart of what each of us understands that meaning to be. The strength of the views that have been displayed on each side of this debate and the deep emotion this debate has stirred in this community are both testaments to that.

When matters as fundamental as this come before the parliament, it is not surprising that the first reaction of members and senators is to defiantly stand by their own views as to what is right and what is wrong. However, that is a judgment I do not want to make tonight. I accept that there is genuine and heartfelt division within our community as to what to do on this subject. There are genuine divisions of conscience as to whether euthanasia is right or wrong. I also note that, rather than debate these issues within our party fora, many on both sides of the debate have argued that it should be left to the individual consciences of members and senators to determine what they feel is right and what is wrong. I think that has been the right position to pursue.

This issue, it has been argued, should be left to each of us to determine for ourselves in accordance with our own individual views and morality within our own sense of the meaning and value of life. Having listened to much of this debate, I must say that I am a bit disappointed by the response of many who have taken the privilege that has been vested in us and decided that they can and must impose their conscience on that of others. Many of those who have fought vociferously to throw off the shackles of the party view—and, as I said earlier, rightly so—and who stood up for the right to exercise their own personal consciences are now willing to apply their own shackles to the consciences of many individuals across Australia.

BREAK.PARA: All of those who have accepted that this is a vote of conscience have, I submit, a duty, an obligation and a responsibility not to abuse that privilege by denying the consciences of others. If we can accept that this is an issue upon which we as party members—as members and senators—can be legitimately divided, then surely it is an issue that we as a community can be genuinely divided on as well.

As we have demanded that we be allowed to exercise our conscience to choose, I submit we should not seek to prevent others from exercising their right to choose. We should not disregard the rights and consciences of our fellow Australians and we should not assert that, on matters of conscience, we have superior rights to others.

That I fear and believe is precisely what this insidious bill seeks to do. It seeks to prevent the people of the Northern Territory and the ACT, through their elected representatives, from exercising their consciences and from making their own judgments about the meaning and value of life. More particularly, it seeks to deny all Australians as individuals the right to make that judgment for themselves.
