Just as repugnantly, this bill seeks to apply its moral righteousness not to the people of Australia as a whole but rather to the people of the Northern Territory and the ACT. It singles them out as being somehow unworthy of the right to exercise their own consciences. It treats the hundreds of thousands of Australians who live in the territories as if they were second‐class citizens, as has been argued very strongly by Senator Tambling and Senator Bob Collins.

So, if individual members and senators or members of the public disagree with euthanasia, they have a legitimate right to choose otherwise and to not exercise their rights under any legislation. But I ask all of you, and I ask them, not to force that choice on others, thereby denying our fellow citizens of a right citizens cherish very highly.

So any conscience vote in this parliament should, as a matter of fundamental obligation, respect the consciences of others. Many of us, for instance, have indicated that we personally would choose life. That, I think, includes me, but it is a very hard decision and one, as I say, as I have lived through the experience of others, I have found very hard to address and come to a conclusion on. I think as things stand I would choose life, but I, like many others, are willing nonetheless to respect the choices made by others. For this and the other reasons mentioned in the additional comments in the report of Senator McKiernan and me, I urge all senators to oppose this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief contribution to this debate to indicate my reasons for voting the way I intend. First of all, I want to thank all of those very sincere and committed people on both sides of the argument who believe passionately in their approach for the time taken and the effort they have made to make me aware of their beliefs and the matters they believe I should take into account. I also want to pay tribute to my colleagues on the Senate committee for their difficult and time‐consuming task in attempting to guide the Senate in its deliberations.

SPEECH.PARA: I should mention that in forming my view I have as well taken into account, in what I emphasise is only a very secondary way, the views of certain people and organisations for whom I have the highest regard. These include: the Liberal Party of Australia, speaking through its Federal Council; the Young Liberal Movement—of which I am a life member and a former federal patron; my parliamentary colleagues from the Northern Territory; the Law Council of Australia, which represents the legal profession in Australia and of which I continue to be a member, speaking unanimously through its constituent bodies—the bars and law councils of each state; various church people and groups.

I note that the response to the Senate committee is at odds with public opinion polls and the impression I get from public meetings I have attended and from my own discussions with constituents. But this is not, in my view, of great consequence in the decision I have to make. I do believe that in a democracy citizens speak through their elected representatives in parliament.

My opinion is, I believe, no better formed than the views of a democratically elected parliamentarian of the Northern Territory—a parliamentarian who was required over a much longer period of time than I to determine how the laws of that state like territory should apply. I am not one of those who believe that because I am in the federal parliament my opinions are that much superior to those of representatives of the people of the Northern Territory.

The bill before us is not one of general application but is one intended to override the wishes of a parliament of one part of our country. But I am required to vote according to my conscience. I regret the allegations that some have made that by voting in favour of the Northern Territory legislation I will be killing someone or that one person will be able to determine the death of another human being. I do not believe that fallacious argument has been at all helpful to the debate. Any proposed legislation that ever suggested that this could be done legally in Australia would be vehemently opposed by me.

Perhaps the most telling argument put to me for voting against the Northern Territory legislation was the suggestion that some elderly terminally ill people may feel pressured to shorten their lives because they were a burden on their family and loved ones. In the end, I came to the conclusion that this is related more to the elderly generally who would not in any case be able to take advantage of the Northern Territory legislation.

The Northern Territory legislation, as I understand it, applies only to the terminally ill who are mentally able and so certified to be able to make the decision to shorten their lives. The feelings of the frail aged that they are a burden on their family will not be strengthened or weakened by this bill. Only greater family love and understanding and the assistance of the churches and other people of compassion can help to overcome the trauma and sometimes sadness of the frail aged. The Northern Territory legislation is not about those people; it is about the terminally ill.

The other argument I want to briefly deal with is the one that is summarised by the allegation that the Northern Territory legislation is the thin edge of the wedge. I am dealing with the law as passed by the Northern Territory parliament, not some hypothetical legislative possibility of the future. Any extension that gives one person the right to make decisions about another person's life will also be vehemently opposed by me.

My decision finally comes down to one of individual choice and freedom, provided that there are watertight safeguards in place to ensure the ability to make an informed and rational decision. I have seen a brave Christian committed family lady make the decision that the inevitable should be brought forward but, as with most things in her life, it was only her absolute determination that allowed her to die happily knowing that she had overcome. Her decision took many months to consummate because of even her frail body and also because of the inability of the law to help her—even this law. But in the end, after a long uncomfortable and torturous battle, I suspect that at the very end she was assisted in any case.

I cannot accept that those who are terminally ill should not have the right themselves of their own free will to shorten their suffering. To do otherwise is, I believe, unchristian and uncharitable and lacking in compassion. I intend to oppose the bill before the Senate for these reasons. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Macdonald) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from Dr Andrew J. Hapel of the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the Australian National University. I have shown it to the opposition, the government and Senator Brown, and I have sent it to Senator Kernot.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The letter read as follows—
THE JOHN CURTIN SCHOOL OF MEDICAL RESEARCH
THE AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY
Andrew J. Hapel,
Head
Experimental Haematology Group
CANBERRA CITY ACT 2600
To whom it may concern

I note the statement made today in the Senate by the Leader of the Democrats, and her attempt to table "parts" of a letter from Professor Funder. I believe that the letter in question is already part of the Hansard record from 1992.
The Senator states that "The report shows that Dr. Hapel is `a bit loose with his facts'". I have no choice but to respond.

Certainly Prof. Funder made the award to me of an NH&MRC fellowship subject to my undergoing appropriate medical evaluation so that myself, and the JCSMR could be assured that my continuing to work at the bench "is not only possible but does not endanger himself or those around him".

However, it is not a condition of award of an NH&MRC fellowship that one undergo any sort of medical assessment. So on principle I would not undergo such an examination to satisfy Prof. Funder or the NH&MRC. Thus Prof. Funder's judgement was in effect that I should not be awarded a fellowship by the NH&MRC. There is no escape from that.

Nor is there any escape from the other questions raised by my letter of 28 Jan 1997, as tabled by Senator Harradine. Let me be clear here that the complaint goes back to 1992 and was investigated by the Privacy Commissioner. It is not a recent issue as implied by the Senator.

None of the NH&MRC fellows that I know has been asked to provide a medical opinion that `clears them from being a danger to themselves or their fellow workers.' Surely such a request is a discriminatory condition of award of a fellowship by the NH&MRC.

I attach a copy of Prof. Funder's letter of invitation from ANU to help them with the problem of implementing the recommendations of the Stephen Committee report in the JCSMR. Nowhere in it do I see a request to weed out possible defectives with poor eyesight. This letter of appointment was not sufficient to convince the Privacy Commission that Prof. Funder could be held accountable for his recommendations since he appeared not to be earning a wage for his work on behalf of the ANU chancellery. Since he technically was not employed by a federal agency Prof. Funder was apparently immune from investigation by the Privacy Commission.

So we return to the main points of this debate. Why was I not formally interviewed? Where did the information about my allegedly poor eyesight come from? Why was this information used by Prof. Funder in his report? And why single me out for such treatment

Was it just hearsay? Who knows. As Senator Harradine has stated in the Senate I have maintained a good level of performance despite alleged problems with my eyesight. I would not like to think that my career was in any way harmed by the advice of Prof. Funder

I see the Funder recommendations of 1991/2 pertaining to JCSMR as a disgrace. Many others do too. I sincerely hope that the Leader of the Democrats shares this view. To appoint the author of these recommendations to chairmanship of the peak health authority in this country would have been, based on the evidence, unfortunate.
(signed)
Andrew J. Hapel

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 June 1992, Captain Bill Bone, Captain Bill Craig, Captain Peter Ivanoff and Captain Love, as complainants, sought relief from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission against Australian Airlines who, as respondent to the proceedings, strongly resisted their claims. By consent of the parties, the commission dealt with all four cases together.

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 August 1996, the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Chris Sidoti, delivered the report of his inquiry into the four cases to the Attorney-General, the Hon. Daryl Williams AM, QC, MP. The second paragraph on page 19 of that report neatly sums up the issues in the inquiry. It reads:

The complainants had all worked under contract as pilots on domestic B727 or A300 aircraft operated by Australian Airlines, now part of Qantas Airlines Limited, (the respondent). Mr Bone commenced his contract on 10 January 1990, Mr Craig on 24 March 1990, Mr Ivanoff on 27 October 1989 and Mr Love on 24 November 1989. Each of the complainants had extensive prior service with Australian Airlines. Between August 1990 and May 1992 the respondent terminated the employment of the complainants upon their reaching 60 years of age pursuant to a compulsory age-based retirement policy. The contracts under which they were employed did not include a specific clause to provide for compulsory retirement at that or any other age. Each of the complainants held a First Class Airline Transport Pilot Licence and a valid Class 1 medical certificate at the time of termination. These basic facts of the complaints are agreed by all the parties.

It is essential to a proper understanding of this matter to know that, immediately after Australian Airlines sent Peter Ivanoff into retirement, he was engaged by another airline company as a B727 captain and continues to work as a contract B737 simulator instructor.

On 30 March 1994, the federal parliament amended the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to make it unlawful to terminate a person's employment on the grounds of his or her age. The Workplace Relations Act 1996 has preserved the provision. This is in keeping with International Labour Organisation convention No. 111. Following the amendment to the Industrial Relations Act, Captain Allman, a pilot then employed by Australian Airlines, reached 60 years of age. He lost his job as a consequence and, because of that, took proceedings for relief in the Industrial Relations Court relying on the amended act. On 18 May 1995, Chief Justice Wilcox found in his favour ordering that Qantas—who in the meantime had taken over Australian Airlines—re‐employ him. It did so. Subsequent to this decision, Qantas ceased to impose a retirement age on its domestic pilots. Neither it nor Ansett now do.

On 14 August 1995, roughly 17 months after the amendment to the Industrial Relations Act and almost three months on from the decision of Chief Justice Wilcox, Mr Chris Sidoti was appointed as Human Rights Commissioner. He undertook the resolution of the cases of Captains Bone, Craig, Ivanoff and Love. On page 20 of his report to the Attorney-General, he writes:

As a result of inquiries and investigation into the compulsory age‐based retirement of the complainants it appeared to the former Human Rights Commissioner that the practice constituted discrimination. Upon appointment as Human Rights Commissioner on 14 August 1995 I reviewed this finding and formed the same opinion.

Accordingly, pursuant to sections 33 and 27(a) of the Act, I invited the respondent to make submis sions either orally, in writing or both in relation to the practice of compulsory age-based retirement. The respondent elected to make oral submissions in addition to its written submissions made during earlier stages of the inquiry and after the preliminary finding.

On 9 November 1995 I convened the inquiry in Melbourne to take oral and written submissions from the respondent. As a matter of procedural fairness, the complainants were also invited to participate in the process. The complainants and respondent were legally represented at the submissions hearing.
On page 26 of his report, Mr Sidoti states:

Neither party submitted any evidence significantly different from that put to Wilcox CJ on the medical and safety issues. The respondent maintained its view that pilots over the age of 60 represent a health and safety risk. However, it did not appeal from the decision of Wilcox CJ and now has 6 pilots over the age of 60 flying its aircraft on a regular basis. I am sure that, if it seriously considered this a risk to airline and passenger safety, it would have taken and exhausted every possible avenue of appeal from the Chief Justice's decision. The fact that it did not do so speaks for itself.

On 12 April 1996, the commissioner found `that the acts and practices complained of by the complainants, namely their compulsory retirement upon reaching 60 years of age, constituted discrimination in employment based on age'. Mr Sidoti made three recommendations to the respondent. The two relevant here were:
. that the respondent should pay to Mr Bone, Mr Craig, Mr Ivanoff and Mr Love compensation for loss of earnings suffered by reason of the discriminatory conduct of the respondent;

. that the respondent should make the necessary arrangements for Mr Ivanoff to undertake "over 60" medical tests and, if these and other requirements of the Civil Aviation Authority are satisfied, re-employ Mr Ivanoff and where necessary retrain him as a pilot to fly aircraft as near to equivalent is as possible to those he was flying prior to his compulsory retirement.
Qantas refused to accept these recommendations. It told the commissioner, amongst other things, that:

Qantas has considered the recommendations made in respect of the compensation for the individual complaints and the re-employment of Mr Ivanoff at a senior level within the company. It has given the recommendations serious consideration recognising your statutory discretion to make such recommendations where you think appropriate. Qantas has decided, however, that it is not appropriate to accept the recommendations in this case.

When it was legally obliged to re-employ Captain Allman, Qantas gave way to compulsion. When it was morally obliged to re-employ Captain Ivanoff, it defied propriety. It showed itself a poor corporate citizen.

Does its conduct towards these pilots reflect its true character? Is Qantas a company which will do the right thing only when compelled by law to do so? The various outcomes for the men named in my adjournment speech tonight indicate that it is. Advise Qantas of the right course to follow and defiance is the result; command it to act properly or legal consequences will follow and it fears to do otherwise. Spare the rod and spoil the airline—it is a sorry profile for what is supposedly a great Australian icon to present.

I believe that corporate life is best when informed by a moral sense rather than inhibited by prescriptive laws. But where a moral sense is blunted, the cut of regulations must be sharpened. That is cause for dismay for right‐thinking companies though apparently not for Qantas.

Community life is at its best where its members act towards each other on the basis of mutual respect, of courtesy, of a sense of honour, of a consciousness of the dignity of others. Where its citizens deal with each other as if the letter of the law is the only thing that matters, its quality is sadly prejudiced. Qantas loves the law but not its ethos.

Chris Sidoti has rendered a vital service to the community in producing the Report of inquiry into complaints of discrimination in employment and occupation—compulsory age retirement. Its presentation in parliament has enabled that institution to see how four decent men, dedicated to flying aircraft with great skill and experience for their employer, have been treated by Qantas. They put their cases before a commissioner who made a decision about them in accordance with the legislature's intent. Qantas has defied that intent. Parliament should not allow that recalcitrance to go unnoticed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about the serious state of our science and technology sector. Honourable senators may be aware of a forum that was held today at the National Press Club entitled `Putting the talent to work'. It was organised by the Federation of Australian and Technological Societies and the National Tertiary Education Union. Today's forum highlighted the lack of career opportunities and career structures for younger scientists engaged in research and sought constructive solutions to make the very best use of their talents.

SPEECH.PARA: You may have seen at the Press Club luncheon today Professor Ian Lowe who was the keynote speaker at this function. I believe his comments, and certainly his address, were right on target. There is an Australian malaise in science and the government, unfortunately, has failed to recognise the value of science.

The significant challenges of the future are within our lifetime and will require a response and serious action. They include environmental issues such as global warming, pollution, starvation, emergent diseases, environmental degradation, population pressures and a whole range of other global and local happenings. Science and technology will most likely provide us with some of the solutions to these problems and will most certainly identify relevant considerations and workable solutions.

I thought the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Peter McGauran, was perhaps following a perilous path when he suggested today that the concern about the prospects for young scientists was a false crisis. Many offices, not only my own, have received many letters, faxes and e‐mails complaining about the future prospects for young scientists—not only those people who are currently involved in science studies but also those students in secondary schools who are considering science based courses at university and science based careers.

I hope this is not perhaps another Austudy actual means test case where the warning signs are coming through very early but, unfortunately, the government is not necessa rily taking notice. Something the government has done which is contributing to this crisis in science is the increase in the HECS fees for students in tertiary institutions. Charges for science per annum are now $4,700. That puts science and technology courses in the second highest band, making them the second most expensive courses. Adding to this factor is the erosion of academic salaries, conditions and opportunities. Science is not a particularly attractive career option for many young people as a result. The enrolment figures this year illustrate that young people are choosing courses other than science. This is because young people understandably are increasingly employment focused and thinking about their futures. Science, unfortunately, does not offer a secure future at this time.

The forum today provided a number of examples of young people who have excelled at science and undertaken considerable education and training to make themselves eligible for science and technology jobs. These talented people are at the stage of their careers where they seek some permanency and an opportunity to develop continuity and make the choice whether to give up or continue. The talented people are deciding not to continue and their loss should be of grave concern to the decision makers in this country and the federal government. Without the brightest and best, we are not taking advantage of our best assets in this country and the people best able to provide the answers to the challenges I mentioned for our future.

On that note, I recall Senator Harradine's question today to the chamber on patenting and—something I certainly have great concerns—patenting of genes and gene sequences. Another issue that both Senator Harradine and I have raised in this place is the whole ethical and legislative dilemma of cloning: how we approach that as decision makers and how scientists are involved in that ethical debate and the pursuit of further scientific advances. All of these issues demonstrate politically and academically that we must be focusing more on the area of science.

The Minister for Science and Technology has acknowledged quite openly in budget documents and in recent press releases that science and technology are Australia's No. 1 wealth generator and the key to improving all of our lives. If this is true—and it is certainly something the Australian Democrats and I agree with—then we must provide our young scientists with the possibility to set down their ideas and visions by creating jobs opportunities and real futures for them. This reiterates Professor Lowe's comments today that Australia will lose out on the growth industries of the future. This is important. It is a serious matter and it should not be compromised.

The art of creativity and nurturing upon which science and engineering rely does not always march to the beat of an economic drum and certainly not to short‐term economic timetables. The market drive to reduce funding and to seek accountability must be balanced with the pursuit of excellence and the quest for knowledge. Focusing on reducing funding alone, whether it is through a general budget deficit reduction strategy or within our tertiary institutions, will stunt the discoveries and the inventions on which our future depends.

We need a serious commitment from this government and state governments to support and fund innovative science programs in schools and create a vital research community with real career opportunities. I do acknowledge that $12 million has been set aside by the minister for a program designed to promote science in schools and to encourage young students in schools to pursue science based courses. I must say that $12 million over a three‐year period is just a drop in the bucket but a good start.

The government has a role in encouraging private sector research and development and the private sector forms an integral part of the research and development future of Australia. I believe the government must recognises the value of science teaching and research and the long‐term benefits that follow from healthy and vibrant research.

Today's `Putting the talent to work' forum at the Press Club‐ and I congratulate the organisers, FATS and the NTEU—highlighted the so‐called Australian malaise for young scientists and the fact that we do need action before these talented people give up and do something else. I do not want us to risk creating a science and technology deficit in this country as a result of our zealous pursuit of budget deficit reduction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make brief reference to the Australian Defence Force's environment effort at Shoalwater Bay and I want to make these comments tonight, as close as possible to the time I visited the area at the time of the major joint American‐Australian defence exercises last Monday. I was particularly impressed with the way the Australian defence forces and their environmental unit looked after the Shoalwater Bay area generally throughout the year and particularly at the time of this major exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: I visited the site, along with many other parliamentarians. There were a number of other parliamentarians invited who had indicated that they were coming but who withdrew at the last moment, which is a pity because there were some people who had concerns and they had the opportunity during this exercise to have a closer look at those concerns and whether they were being addressed. Unfortunately, they did not avail themselves of the opportunity.

My visit started with a briefing generally on the exercise and particularly on the environmental aspects. I was very impressed with the fact that material had been prepared for each one of the more than 20,000 combined American and Australian troops who were taking part in the exercise and the pamphlets that were given to them were very detailed and got across a good and proper message on how the training area should be used, taking very high regard of the environmental significance of the area. As well as these pamphlets there was a newspaper specifically prepared. That provided interesting reading and had a message.

We left Rockhampton and then journeyed to the forward headquarters base at Sam Hill. We lunched, if you could call it that, on American ration packs with a one star and a three star general. It was interesting talking to those people. They were particularly impressed with Shoalwater Bay as a training area. They say it is one of the few areas in the world which give such a diversity of experiences for an army exercise. They also could not speak highly enough of the Australian defence forces. I should mention that and I would like to even repeat it because they were genuinely complimentary of the standard and professionalism of the Australian forces. It does make me proud to hear that and it does Australians good to know that we are defended by a very professional and well‐trained group.

I had the advantage of flying over the Shoalwater Bay area by helicopter. It is an absolutely huge area and you really cannot appreciate the large area without seeing it from the air. It is very well maintained. They tell me there is not a lot of native fauna there, which I found unusual, but our environmental experts and caretakers—although they are not called caretakers anymore—did indicate that the fauna is just not naturally there.

There has been some work done in getting rid of feral animals from the mainland and some of the islands. The area seems to me to be very well maintained. There was a program to look for and identify dugong, although at the time I was there, which was fairly late, my escorts did not then have any evidence of dugong sightings.

As I said, there were over 20,000 troops in this area but it was very difficult to find out where they were and where they had been except at the main base, on roads leading to and from, and at exercise areas. I suppose that was part of the exercise. We did stop at Freshwater Beach, which is a magnificent beach in the Shoalwater Bay area. There had been a cyclone around for the previous week or so and there had been some severe erosion caused by the cyclone to the beach, which was already repairing itself.

We arrived at Freshwater Beach on Monday, which was the day after a great number of American troops had landed on the beach with all of their equipment. On our visit the next day it was very difficult to see where they had been. Interestingly, although the exercises were very real and lifelike, most of the way along the dunes behind the beach had been taped off by our environmental people so the attacking marines were able to go further inland, but only along a specially selected path that had been identified by our environmental experts.

Whilst I certainly claim no technical expertise I was very impressed with the technical expertise of the people in the Australian Army. They are not actually army officers, they are civilians, but they work as a unit with the Australian defence forces and monitor, plan and enhance the environment of the area. I was very impressed with the work they were doing and I was very impressed with the work the Australian defences forces generally are doing in that area in preserving a fairly significant training area in the world but, as well, in preserving a very significant environmental site.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 12 December 1996

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many people were penalised in the 1995‐96 financial year for social security breaches which resulted in the partial reduction or complete withdrawal of income support payments.

(2)(a) What was the total cost of identifying and administering these breaches and penalties; and (b) what was the total saving resulting from the consequent withdrawal of income support payments in the 1995‐96 financial year.

(3) What categories of social security breaches result in withdrawal of income support payments (broken into specific types of non‐compliance, for example, failure to declare income not just administrative and activity test breaches) and, in relation to each of these categories in the 1995‐96 financial year: (a) how many people were penalised by complete withdrawal of income support; (b) for what average length of time; (c) generating what costs saving; (d) how many people were penalised by partial withdrawal of income support; (e) for what average length of time; and (f) generating what cost saving.
(4)(a) How is the data supplied in answer to (1), (2) and (3) obtained; and (b) how reliable is the data.

(5) What savings were estimated for the 1996‐97 budget from new arrangements relating to breaches where the penalty is the withdrawal of income support, and what proportion of these savings are attributable to: (a) increased administrative efficiency; (b) tighter scrutiny of recipients; (c) changes in penalties; (d) changing the classification of some administrative breaches to activity test breaches; and (e) other factors (please specify).

(6) When people have income support payments reduced or withdrawn for long periods such as a penalty for breaches, what options do they have to obtain: (a) shelter; (b) food; (c) clothes; (d) health care; and (e) and other necessities.

(7) Is data collected on the number of people seeking help from non‐government welfare agencies as a result of the withdrawal of income support payments for social security breaches; if so, can this data be provided for each State for each of the past 5 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Information to permit a comprehensive answer to the honourable Senator's question is not readily available. To collect and assemble it would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in assembling such information. However, after investigating the matters raised I can provide the following response which may be of use:
(1) Partial reduction of benefit as a form of applying a breach penalty was not applicable during the 1995‐96 financial year.

The number of social security breaches which resulted in complete withdrawal of income support payments for the 1995‐1996 financial year was 109,842. Of this number a proportion of customers appealed against the decision to impose a breach and were successful in having their payment granted or restored and the breach set aside. It is estimated that some 15,000 customers had their breach set aside during 1995‐96.

(2)(a) An estimate, of the salary cost only, to administer breaches for 1995‐96 is $1.818 million. It is difficult to determine the cost of identifying and administering breaches and penalties as many elements of the Department are involved and cannot be separately identified for costing purposes.

(b) Currently available information does not allow an accurate savings figure to be provided. An estimate for savings from breaches for 1995‐96 is $39.891 million assuming an average breach length of 3.7 weeks for activity test breaches and 2.3 weeks for administrative breaches.
(3) The information sought is detailed and all of it is not readily available.

(3)(a) The gross number of breaches coded was 109,842. Of the 109,842 breach instances coded, Activity Test breaches accounted for 54,634 and Administrative breaches for 55,208. Failures to notify changes in circumstances, for example failure to declare income, were Administrative Breaches in 1995‐96.

Activity Test breaches comprise:

Administrative breaches comprise:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) The estimated average length of breach was 3.7 weeks for activity test breaches and 2.3 weeks for administrative breaches.
(c) Refer to answer 2(b).
(d)‐(f) All breach penalties during 1995‐1996 imposed a non‐payment penalty, there were therefore no partial reduction penalties during the 1995‐96 financial year.
(4)(a) From Departmental computer records.
(b) The data is a count of actual events and codes.

(6)(a)‐(e) Customers are presumed to rely on their own, their family's or community resources.

However, it must be noted that current procedures require that an interview with the customer must be undertaken before any Activity Test breach can be imposed. An interview is conducted to fully determine the circumstances surrounding the possible breach. This allows for any mitigating circumstances to be considered and ensures that those customers who provide an adequate reason for non compliance will not be penalised.

In circumstances where a customer appeals against a decision which imposes a breach penalty, payment may be continued (after consideration of financial hardship, compliance history and disability) until the result of the appeal is known. This pro vision is not available to customers who have become voluntarily unemployed or are unemployed due to misconduct.

If, notwithstanding the above safeguards, people choose to take action which results in a reduced or non‐payment penalty, it will be their responsibility to support themselves during the penalty period.

The Government has maintained the formula for determining emergency relief funds. This financial year the Government has added a further $7 million which represents a 25% increase above the formula. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Was a letter dated 28 January 1997 advising recipients of the Newstart Allowance of a change in the allowance [sample letter provided to the department] part of a mailout to a large number of people; if so: (a) to how many people was it sent; (b) what was the purpose of the letter; (c) what was the total cost of sending these letters out; (d) who was responsible for the wording of the letter; (e) will this letter be, or has it already been, followed up by any subsequent letters; and (f) what was the change that apparently occurred to the allowance on 10 January 1997.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Energy, Energy Research and Development Corporation Program: Budget Reductions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 27 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the department's portfolio budget for the 1996-97 financial year for sub-program 2.4 (Energy, Energy research and Development Corporation) $6.55 million.
(2) Was this a reduction in the budget allocation of $5.288 million from the allocation of the 1995-96 financial year.
(3) In the 1996-97 Budget statement, what is meant by the words `to return held cash balances to budget'.
(4) How has this reduction in funding from the 1995-96 to 1996-97 financial years been implemented.
(5) Have any projects that were undertaken in the 1995-96 financial year been abandoned, or have ceased, as a result of the reduction in the budget allocation.
(6) What impact will the 1996-97 budget allocation have on the fuel ethanol projects supported by the Energy Research and Development Corporation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) ERDC had accumulated unspent funds to a level that the Government considered was in excess of its immediate financial needs. As such, in a one-off saving, which contributed to the Government's fiscal target, the 1996-97 appropriation was reduced.
(4) The 1996-97 appropriation was reduced.
(6) The 1996-97 Budget allocation will have no impact on the fuel ethanol projects which are being supported by the Energy Research and Development Corporation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Senator Colston: Use of Parliamentary Library

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President, on notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Senator Colston demanded in 1991 that the Parliamentary Library produce a background paper which appeared to meet the course requirements of a subject for an Arts Degree at Queensland University.
(2) Did Senator Colston request that the paper be fully footnoted and contain an extensive bibliography.
(3) Did the library refuse this request.
(4) Did Senator Colston complain to the Chief Librarian on this matter.
(5) Did Senator Colston say he would take the matter to the President.

(6) How many research papers, in the period 1990-91, did Senator Colston request the Parliamentary Library to prepare which could have been useful in the completion of an Arts Degree at Queensland University.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There is a long-standing convention, by which I feel bound, that research requests made by senators to the Parliamentary Library are confidential to the individual senators. On consideration, however, I believe that the purpose of the convention is to protect the confidentiality of the subject matters of requests rather than the fact that particular senators have made requests, and therefore I can provide some answer to the question without breaking the convention.

Occasionally research requests by senators are declined by the Library because it is not appropriate for the Library to accede to the requests. I am advised that in recent years one request by Senator Colston was declined.
